column5: The possession of civic virtue: Movement narratives of race and class in the Knights of Labor. [References].
column11: Gerteis, Joseph: Dept of Sociology, U Minnesota, 267 19th Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN, US, 55455, gerte004@umn.edu
column12: Gerteis, Joseph: U Minnesota, Dept of Sociology, Minneapolis, MN, US
column13: American Journal of Sociology. Vol.108(3), Nov 2002, pp. 580-615.
column19: Explores how race is understood within an explicitly class-based movement, the Knights of Labor. It is argued that the movement presents an empirical puzzle: it simultaneously pursued racial openness and racial closure, and it justified both in the name of class interest. The article examines movement-level narratives of race and class to show how underlying conceptions of class become implicated in the construction of interests regarding race. Communications drawn from the movement's official journal provide comprehensive data for identifying and interpreting the movement narratives of race and class. There were 3 separate Knights of Labor narratives. They were Interracial Organizing and Black Workers; Competition, Democratic Citizenship and New Immigrants; and Slavery and the Social Position of Free Labor. Although each connected race and class in a different way, all were driven by the movement's understanding of class and to "civic virtue" as a particularly important resource. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Psychodynamic Practice: Individuals, Groups and Organisations. Vol.8(1), Feb 2002, pp. 55-73.
column19: Draws on feminist and post-colonial theory to situate an account of a 6-mo therapy between a Black, Asian woman therapist and a woman patient of mixed Pakistani-White parentage. While referred for depression and a pattern of abusive relationships, therapy progressed when the patient revealed that she felt like a 'black sheep'. The authors draw on this analysis to further the debates between psychotherapeutics and social theory, challenging each in 3 ways. First, in relation to the literature on culture, class, gender and sexuality in psychotherapy, the authors indicate how these enter into the therapeutic relation in distinct and intersecting ways, which, second, challenge the separation between inner and outer worlds frequently maintained within psychotherapy circles. Third, in terms of the correlative challenge psychotherapeutic perspectives pose for social theorists and activists, the authors highlight how the therapist's constructive and explicit use of her power and socio-cultural position was central to the progress of this client's therapy. Finally, the authors reflect on the broader questions around the theorizing of culture and gender within psychotherapy, including the available positions and representations of Black therapists as well as Black patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: School counselor's perceptions of biracial children: A pilot study. [References].
column12: Harris, Henry L.: U North Texas, Counseling, Development, & Higher Education, Denton, TX, US
column13: Professional School Counseling. Vol.6(2), Dec 2002, pp. 120-129.
column19: Examines school counselors' personal perceptions of biracial individuals. 900 school counselors competed a 25-item survey covering a broad range of issues regarding biracial children. The results indicated school level, years of counseling experience, and gender influenced certain perceptions. School counselors' perceptions were also affected by the presence of actively promoted cultural diversity and awareness programs. When cultural diversity and awareness programs are actively promoted in schools, they create an environment in which a variety of cultures are celebrated and genuinely valued. The Personal Perceptions of Biracial Individuals Questionnaire is appended. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A qualitative exploration of ethnic identities in Chinese husband-White wife couples.
column12: Lam, Paul Chi Sung: Alliant International U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(5-B), Nov 2002, pp. 2653.
column19: Interracial marriages pose a unique opportunity to study the influence of ethnic differences on the marital relationship. This study used a qualitative approach to explore ways in which Chinese husband White wife couples bridged their ethnic differences and how their individual ethnic identities were influenced by their marriage. Individual interviews were conducted with both partners of four couples. The husbands were foreign-born Chinese and immigrated to the U.S. between the ages of 17 and 27. The wives were U.S.-born and of European descent. Interview data were transcribed verbatim, categorized based on topic and compared and contrasted for the husbands and wives separately. Each topic was analyzed to identify common themes and findings, which were presented as results. Negative reactions toward the decision to get married came only from the wives' families. All couples seemed to have experienced either blatant or covert forms of racism. The husbands reported their ethnic identities were not influenced by their marriage, and three of the four husbands identified strongly with being Chinese. The wives reported increased ethnic awareness and appreciation. Ethnic differences that seemed to affect the marital relationships were: differences between the couples' role expectations of husband, wife and extended families, the husbands' emphasis on their children's education, and differences in parenting styles. Differences in communication styles were also identified, but did not seem to be solely related to ethnicity. The author concluded that despite strong identification with being Chinese, the husbands' ethnic identities changed partly due to being in an interracial marriage and partly due to acculturation. Their identities seemed to be unaffected by racial discrimination or the seemingly prejudicial objections by their wives' families to their marriages. Regarding ethnic issues, the wives seemed to do most of the accommodating within the marriages. Their willingness to do so perhaps indicated a reported diffuse identification as an American, or perhaps was gender related. Cultural influences seemed predominant in the husbands' emphasis on their children's education, exerting parental authority, hierarchical marital roles, and expectations of in-law involvement. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: African American children's racial attitudes and global self-worth.
column12: Crabtree, Valerie Mclaughlin: U Southern Mississippi, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(4-B), Oct 2002, pp. 2052.
column19: The primary purpose of this study was to determine the relationship between racial attitudes and global self-worth in African American children, particularly as a function of the race of examiner. Forty African American children, ages 8 through 14, were recruited from after-school and summer programs in Louisville, Kentucky. A female African American examiner interviewed twenty of the children, while a same-age female Caucasian examiner interviewed the other half of the children. The children's interracial attitudes were assessed with an adapted version of the Preschool Racial Attitudes Measure-II (PRAM II; Williams, Best, Boswell, Mattson, & Graves, 1975) and the Racial Identity Questionnaire (RIQ; Crabtree, Wagner, & Leach, 1998). Within-group racial attitudes were measured with the Porter Skin Tone Connotation Scale (Porter, 1985), and global self-worth was assessed by the Self-Perception Profile for Children (Harter, 1985). No relationship was found between children's in-group or out-group racial attitudes and their global self-worth. Furthermore, there was no significant impact of the race of the examiner on children's responses to measures of racial attitudes. There was a trend, however, toward children interviewed by the African American examiner expressing more counterstereotyped attitudes, defined as positive attitudes toward African Americans and negative attitudes toward Caucasians, than those interviewed by the Caucasian examiner. A subset of children had their responses to the RIQ qualitatively analyzed, and several children reported a belief that teachers exhibit racial bias in the classroom as a function of both the students' and teachers' race. Furthermore, a pattern emerged in which children who expressed stereotyped attitudes on the PRAM II exhibited a preference for future spouses and children with Caucasian features (e.g., lighter hair, skin, and/or eye color), while those who expressed more nonstereotyped attitudes on the PRAM II reported a wish to have future spouses and children with African American features. The implications of these findings for psychological practice are discussed, including the importance of children's resilience in the face of racism and the fact that no significant race of examiner effect on children's openness was found in this study. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Underlying dimensions of White racial attitudes.
column12: Neuger, Debra Ann: Columbia U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(3-B), Sep 2002, pp. 1610.
column19: The purpose of this investigation was to explore the structure of the White Racial Identity Attitude Scale (WRIAS, Helms & Carter, 1990). In addition, items that addressed components of the theory of White Racial Identity (Helms, 1990) that were not measured in the existing instrument were developed. These new scales developed from the WRIAS and new items were compared to measures of racism in social psychology to assess convergent and discriminant validity. They were also used to predict a criterion variable, the Reactions to Interracial Situations at Work Questionnaire (Block, Roberson & Neuger, 1995). Their ability to predict the criterion was compared to the predictive ability of the Modern Racism Scale (McConahay, 1986). The WRIAS was developed to measure five statuses of white racial identity: contact, disintegration, reintegration, pseudo independent, and autonomy. There have been numerous studies on the psychometric problems of the scale, with a one factor, two factor, three factor, and five factor model suggested. The current findings support a five factor model. However, the scale structure differs from the scales developed by Helms (1990). The five factors that emerged through this research were discomfort with and avoidance of blacks, curiosity about blacks, bitterness toward blacks, surface understanding of blacks, and unawareness of racial issues. Forty-seven items were developed to address dimensions postulated in the theory of white racial identity that are not included in the WRIAS. Six experimental scales were developed from a factor analysis of these items: discomfort with being white, pride in being white, belief in white superiority, belief in white responsibility for eliminating racism, awareness of white benefits, and impartial to race. The findings indicate that a multidimensional conceptualization of white racial attitudes fits the data best. The scales developed from the new items complement the scales developed from the WRIAS items, providing information on whites' attitudes toward race that more completely reflects Helms' theory. In addition, the racial attitude scales developed here provided a better prediction of the criterion variable than the Modern Racism Scale alone. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The own-race bias in children's eyewitness memory.
column12: Dore, Heather S.: The Florida State U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(3-B), Sep 2002, pp. 1608.
column19: The own-race bias (ORB) refers to the research finding that adults are more accurate at recognizing individuals of their own race than those of another race. The primary purpose of the present study was to determine whether children exhibit an ORB, and to identify the relationship of the ORB to experience with other races in an eyewitness paradigm. There were forty Black and forty White participants at each of 4 combined grade levels (i.e., grades 1-2, 5-6, 9-10, and undergraduates), with the exception of 1-2-graders. There were only 33 Black and 40 White children in this group. Participants saw a brief videotape of a Black or White man committing a theft, then answered a series of questions and attempted to identify him from a 6-person target-present or target-absent lineup. There were no age effects for target-present lineups, as was expected, and age interacted with race of participant in unexpected ways in target-absent lineups. Surprisingly, only minimal evidence of an ORB was found. Since the ORB was small amongst adults, a group that had previously shown the effect, no definitive conclusions about the existence of the ORB in children can be drawn. Analyses of objective questions indicated that the youngest children were less accurate than were older children and adults. Concerning confidence, a significant three-way interaction between race of target, race of participant, and lineup type indicated that Black participants were significantly more confident in own-race identifications in target-present than in target-absent conditions, and White participants were marginally more confident in other-race identifications in target-absent than in target-present conditions. There was a small positive correlation between identification accuracy and confidence. Other-race identification accuracy was not related to the extent of other-race experience for children or adults. Finally, other-race identification accuracy was strongly related to other-race attitude scores for Black undergraduates, and other-race attitudes were strongly related amount of interracial contact for White undergraduates. Explanations for the findings and directions for future research were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Exploring variables associated with interracial and intraracial couples' relationship satisfaction.
column12: Asidao, Christine Snyder: U Illinois At Urbana-Champaign, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(2-B), Aug 2002, pp. 1085.
column19: This study looked at interracial and intraracial dating couples' relationship satisfaction. The goals of this study included: (a) identifying the similarities and differences between groups and couples dating interracially and intraracially; (b) investigating whether specific love styles, conflict tactics, relationship length, family, friendship, and general public influence/approval, and ethnic identity significantly predicted relationship satisfaction; and (c) examining whether couple status (i.e., interracial or intraracial) moderated the relationship between family, friendship, and general public influence/approval and relationship satisfaction. Participants included 35 interracial and 58 intraracial heterosexual dating couples. The majority of the intraracially dating couples were White and the majority of the interracially dating couples were Asian/White pairings. Analyses included a repeated measures MANOVA, several paired post-hoc t-tests and a series of multiple regressions. The results of the present analyses indicated that there were no significant differences between couples dating interracially and intraracially on relationship satisfaction, love styles, conflict tactics, relationship length, ethnic identity, family, friendship, or general public influence/approval. Results also indicated that there were significant sex differences within each dyad. Furthermore, relationship satisfaction for the overall sample was predicted by greater family influence/approval, less friendship influence/approval, less psychological aggression towards one's partner, more passion and less game-playing love. Relationship satisfaction for the men in the sample was predicted by less friendship influence/approval, less game-playing and more passionate love styles. Relationship satisfaction for women in the sample was predicted by more passion and less psychological aggression towards their partner. None of the moderating relationships were supported. This study provides new information within the realm of interracial and intraracial dating and also expands the knowledge base in the area of dating relationships by exploring important dyadic differences which take into account sex and couple status. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: What about the children? The psychosocial well-being of multiracial individuals.
column12: Wrathall, Mark William: Azusa Pacific U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(1-B), Jul 2002, pp. 556.
column19: This dissertation reviews and critiques the literature on multiracial identity formation, adjustment, and the clinical implications suggested by these findings. Empirical support for the biracial models proposed by Kich (1992), Jacobs (1992), Poston (1990), Collins (2000), and Root (1990) is also presented. The literature provides support for the theory that biracial identity is multiply determined depending on such factors as family, family history, community environment, geographical location, and historical time period. Findings suggest that racial identity is fluid over time and, often, situation; and it may not always be the most salient identity at any given time. Multiracial individuals appear to function as well socially and psychologically as monoracial individuals under similar conditions. Empirical research on this topic is limited and weakened by the use of small sample sizes, by the use of clinical populations as normative, and, in some cases, do not account for racism as a negative social influence. Future research implications are suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Multiracial women in psychology doctoral programs: A phenomenological investigation of their identities in graduate school.
column12: Marks, Julia Beth: Alliant International U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.63(1-B), Jul 2002, pp. 537.
column19: This study explored the graduate school experiences of thirteen multiracial women currently enrolled in clinical psychology doctoral programs. The participants were interviewed using an interview protocol created for the purpose of describing their experiences of identity construction in their doctoral programs. The interview covered the following domains: (1) background and family information, (2) experiences in classes, (3) the peer community, (4) mentorship relationships, and (5) clinical placements. The study was conducted from a phenomenological perspective and its data analyzed according to a method of thematic analysis adapted from Georgi (1985). Results were presented on three levels: situated summaries for each participant of her graduate experiences, general themes frequently endorsed by at least two participants throughout the interview, and themes depicting participants' experiences in each of the interview domains of classes, peer community, mentorship, and clinical experience. Findings indicate that all of the participants expressed feelings of racial difference in their graduate programs. Participants described this sense of difference in both negative and positive terms: often they felt like outsiders in groups of monoracial people of color and like multiracial representatives in classes; they also felt that they could negotiate their way in multiple racial groups and form connections with others who felt marginalized. Participants prioritized their ethnic minority identities over their White identities: they focused on exploring and identifying with their ethnic minority backgrounds whereas they associated their White backgrounds with the privileges of the dominant culture. The study also found that although participants had multicultural courses, the large majority of participants did not have any courses which included material on multiracial peoples. Most courses presented the races as separate entities, causing participants to feel "invisible" or pressured to choose one race in their multiracial background with which to identify. Participants presented several recommendations for graduate programs, one being that courses include the psychologies of multiracial groups when discussing people of color. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The impact of interracial interactions on cardiovascular reactivity and behavior.
column12: Sayoc-Parial, Maria Celina: Miami U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(11-B), May 2002, pp. 5390.
column19: The main objective of this study was to examine the relationship between perceptions of racism and cardiovascular health. The sample consisted of African American, Asian American, and Caucasian participants. The behaviors and cardiovascular reactivity (blood pressure and heart rate) of 123 dyads (126 females, 120 males) were assessed as they participated in same-sex interracial interactions. Participants also completed questionnaires that assessed their feelings during the interactions as well as their experiences with perceived racism. The results revealed that African Americans have the most experience with racism. Correlational analysis showed that perceptions of racism were significantly related to various symptoms of psychological distress, including depression and paranoia. Hierarchical regression analysis indicated that among minority participants, perceived racism was significantly and positively related to a composite measure of resting systolic blood pressure. Multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) revealed significant race effects, particularly in those dyads involving African Americans and Caucasians. Among the various dyads, Whites with Black partners felt the least comfortable during the interactions and had more reactive blood pressures than their Black partners. The results of analyses involving Asian American-Caucasian dyads and Caucasian-Caucasian dyads were less clear and suggest further study is needed. The analyses also revealed significant gender erects. Women were more behaviorally engaged and more comfortable than the men during the interactions. However, men had more reactive cardiovascular measures during the interactions and felt less friendly than did the women. The findings highlight the potentially significant role of perceived racism in the cardiovascular health of ethnic minority members. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Integrated lives, isolated living: The Black suburban experience, teen peer relationships, and the role of Jack and Jill, Incorporated.
column12: Nicholson, Melba Jenine: U Illinois At Urbana-Champaign, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(8-A), Feb 2002, pp. 2894.
column19: Qualitative and survey data facilitate an understanding of parent and teen experiences of their community, teen friendships, and an organization for middle-class African American youth. Participant observation, group and individual interviews with parents and teens, and archives from the local, regional and national level of the organization reveal participants' lived experiences. In their own words, local mothers, fathers, and teens describe the integration and isolation that characterize their experiences as Black families in predominantly White suburban communities. Specifically, during their daily lives they are integrated with their White neighbors as extreme minorities (less than 1%) at school and in their neighborhood. However, geographic location and a lack of daily interactions with a larger Black community create a sense of isolation from their Black counterparts. Regional survey results reveal suburban teens' low levels of connectedness to their neighborhood, high levels of comfort around their White counterparts, and a great desire for more daily experiences with Blacks. Teens and parents articulate strategies for negotiating this marginalized existence. Moreover, African American adolescence is characterized by ethnic identity and same-race friendship development. As a result of residing in predominantly White suburban communities the ability to cultivate these friendships is limited. Although local teens report having strong relationships with their White friends, their parents report a "birthday party effect," or change in the quality of these relationships overtime, but particularly at the onset of dating. Teen regional survey data and individual interviews describe Black friendships as more intimate and less conflictual than their White friendships. Same-race friendships are associated with adolescent physical self-concept, whereas cross-race friendships were not. Additionally, teens and parents discuss the need for same-race dating experiences, and the barriers to interracial dating, which include gender, religion, and race. Participating families join Jack and Jill of America, Incorporated to facilitate the development of same-race peer relationships for their youth. Data suggest that Jack and Jill has a history of elitism that sometimes overshadows its broader purpose and goals. Nevertheless, current and former members relate that by providing a socializing context for African American youth with similar daily and cultural experiences, Jack and Jill of America, Incorporated addresses the developmental dilemmas created by the intersection of the Black suburban experience and adolescents' need for same-race relationships. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The influence of perceptual learning in memory for faces: A process-tracing approach to investigating the own-race bias.
column12: Meissner, Christian August: The Florida State U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(7-B), Jan 2002, pp. 3397.
column19: Own-race faces are better recognized when compared with memory for faces of another, less familiar race. This phenomenon, termed the "own-race bias," has been demonstrated across a large number of studies and a variety of ethnic groups; however, the social-cognitive mechanisms governing the effect are poorly understood (Meissner & Brigham, 2001). The current investigation posits a perceptual learning framework from which to evaluate the underlying processes. In the first experiment, an encoding manipulation is undertaken in which participants are asked to sort faces of their own- and other-race into related groupings, and subsequently to recognize previously viewed faces and recreate the structure generated at encoding. In the second experiment, participants' eye-movements are recorded as they study and attempt to recognize own- and other-race faces. Results across experiments find support for two tenets of the perceptual learning framework, namely (a) characteristics of a skilled representational system, including greater complexity, number of taxonomic features, and reliability of retrieval, and (b) greater cognitive efficiency in the processes operating at encoding and recognition of own-race faces. In addition, prior interracial contact was found to mediate both of these factors. Differential recruitment of taxonomic features, the third tenet of the perceptual learning framework, found minimal support in the current investigation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effect of racial threat on interracial and intraracial crimes. [References].
column9:
D'Alessio, Stewart J

Stolzenberg, Lisa

Eitle, David
column11: D'Alessio, Stewart J.: School of Policy & Management, Florida International U, University Park Campus, ECS 437, Miami, FL, US, 33199, dalessi@fiu.edu
column12:
D'Alessio, Stewart J.: Florida International U, School of Policy & Management, Miami, FL, US

column13: Social Science Research. Vol.31(3), Sep 2002, pp. 392-408.
column19: This study extends extant research on interracial violence research by using county-level data, drawn from South Carolina's National Incident-Based Reporting System, race-specific voting data, and demographic data to investigate the relationship between racial threat and interracial and intraracial violent crimes. White-on-black, black-on-white, white-on-white, and black-on-black crime rates are the 4 dependent variables analyzed in the study. Political threat is measured as the ratio of black-to-white voting in the South Carolina general elections. Economic threat, another independent variable, is measured as the ratio of black-to-white unemployment. Results from a pooled cross-sectional time-series analysis time-series analysis show that 1 dimension of racial threat, economic competition, has a modest substantive effect on interracial crimes involving white perpetrators and black victims--as economic competition increases between whites and blacks, whites commit more violent crimes against blacks. Political threat has no statistically discernable effect on the white-on-black crime rate. Further, neither measure of racial threat--economic competition nor political threat--is associated with the black-on-white, the white-on-white, or the black-on-black crime rate. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Wedding as text: Communicating cultural identities through ritual. [References].
column12: Leeds-Hurwitz, Wendy: U Wisconsin-Parkside, Parkside, WI, US
column13: (2002). Wedding as text: Communicating cultural identities through ritual. xvi, 308 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column19: (from the cover) A wedding serves as the beginning marker of a marriage; if a couple is to manage cultural differences throughout their relationship, they must first pass the hurdle of designing a wedding ceremony that accommodates those differences. This book documents the weddings of 112 couples from across the US, studied over a 10-yr period. The author focuses on intercultural weddings--interracial, interethnic, interfaith, international, and interclass--looking at how the couples cope with cultural differences in their lives. The case studies explore how couples display different identities simultaneously. The concepts of community, ritual, identity, and meaning are given extensive consideration. Because material cultural plays a particularly important role in weddings, food, clothing, and objects are given special attention. This book is a distinctive study of those who have accepted cultural differences into their daily lives and how they have managed to do so successfully. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Compared verbal IQ, number of sexual partners, and birth weight among African-American, White-American, and Black/White mixed race US adolescents. 4,271 African-American, 10,315 White-American, and 116 Black/White mixed race US adolescents (mean age 16 yrs) completed questionnaires and tests concerning verbal IQ, number of sexual partners, birth weight, parental education, and family income. Results show that African-American subjects(Ss) reported lower birth weight, lower verbal IQ, and higher number of sexual partners than did White Ss. For each characteristic, the mean of mixed-race Ss fell between the means of the 2 other populations. Birth weights were heavier as social class increased. In African-American Ss, the number of sexual partners was not associated with social class; those associations were weak in White Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (create) This reprinted article originally appeared in Counselling Psychology Quarterly, 1998, 11(2), 181-188. (The following abstract of the original article appeared in record 1998-04866-004.) Intercultural couples may present many dilemmas for therapists. It is suggested that ideas from postmodern narrative therapy such as adopting a collaborative, curious stance, generating alternative understanding, encouraging a both/and stance, and searching for liberating tradition within each culture may be helpful with therapists working with intercultural couples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Therapists experience added strain attempting to form a treatment relationship with students of different races and cultures than they. Therapist feelings of estrangement and anxiety, typical in this work, can contribute to countertransferential pitfalls, but race and ethnicity can also facilitate powerful transferentiai reactions that provide a useful way to access a client's difficulties and advance the treatment process. The author addresses common countertransference reactions and reviews some major psychoanalytic research on cross-cultural and interracial psychotherapy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Unions between blacks and whites: England and the US compared. [References].
column12:

column13: Ethnic and Racial Studies. Vol.25(5), Sep 2002, pp. 728-754.
column19: In this article, US and UK census data are used to compare the propensity for matches between blacks and native born whites in England and the US. Blacks are disaggregated into three ethnic groups: Black Caribbeans, Residual Blacks and, in the US, African Americans. The first group receives the most theoretical attention. Both raw percentages and parameters that control for several covariates--such as age, education and city of residence--are examined. The results indicate that, with or without controls and irrespective of ethnicity, blacks in Britain are significantly more likely to have a native born white partner than their US counterparts. These findings accord with assimilation theory, but the article's conclusion suggests that, in both countries, the assimilation of people of African descent operates differently from the assimilation of whites. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Leisure Research. Vol.34(2), 2002, pp. 135-156.
column19: There has been a significant amount of research that has indicated divergent patterns of leisure participation among African Americans and European Americans; however, there has been a paucity of research that addresses the leisure patterns of interracial couples and families. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to investigate the leisure patterns of interracial couples and families, specifically African American and European American couples. A qualitative design was employed to gather in-depth interview data from 6 couples (Ss aged 21-44 yrs). The findings indicated that the interracial couples felt socially isolated in various aspects of daily life, including work, family, and leisure. The primary cause of their social isolation was due to race and racism. The couples experienced low levels of comfort when participating in leisure within public spaces. There was not a distinct pattern of leisure activity among the couples; however, there was a distinct process the couples went through in selecting activities prior to participation in order to avoid negative social reactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interrogating the hyphen-nation: Canadian multicultural policy and 'mixed-race' identities. [References].
column11: Mahtani, Minelle, Mahtani@geog.ubc.ca
column12: Mahtani, Minelle: U of British Columbia, Sing Tao School of Journalism, Dept of Geography, Vancouver, BC, Canada
column13: Social Identities: Journal for the Study of Race, Nation and Culture. Vol.8(1), Mar 2002, pp. 67-90.
column19: This paper examines the ways 'mixed race' women in Canada contemplate their relationship to national identity. Through qualitative, open-ended interviews with 24 women identified as 'mixed race' (aged 20-55 yrs), the research demonstrates how some women of 'mixed race' contest ideas of the nation as constituted through the policy of multiculturalism in Canada. To challenge the tropes of the national narrative, some women of 'mixed race' develop nuanced models of cultural citizenship, illustrating that national identities are formed and transformed in relation to representation. Refusing to be positioned outside the nation, they effectively produce their own meanings of identity by working through their own personally identified 'mixed race' bodies to the national body politic, where some of them see their own bodies as intrinsically 'multicultural'. The paper ends by addressing the paradoxes of multiculturalism, emphasising through narratives that the policy produces hierarchical spaces against which some 'mixed race' women imaginatively negotiate, contest and challenge perceptions of their racialised and gendered selves. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The psychological adjustment of transracial adoptees: An application of the Cultural-Racial Identity Model. [References].
column11: Baden, Amanda L.: St John's U, Dept of Human Services & Counseling, 306 Marillac Hall, 8000 Utopia Parkway, Jamaica, NY, US, 11439, badena@stjohns.edu

column19: In response to the need for increased understanding of the identity process of transracial adoptees, the Cultural-Racial Identity Model (A. L. Baden & R. J. Steward, 1995) was developed and tested. The model results in 16 proposed identities based on the degrees to which individuals (1) have knowledge of, awareness of, competence within, and comfort with their own racial group's culture, their parents' racial group's culture, and multiple cultures, and (2) are comfortable with their racial group membership and with those belonging to their own racial group, their parents' racial group, and multiple racial groups. Four dimensions of the model were determined: the Adoptee Culture Dimension, the Parental Culture Dimension, the Adoptee Race Dimension, and the Parental Race Dimension. The Cultural-Racial Identity of 51 19-36 yr old transracial adoptees completed a modified version of the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (MEIM; J. S. Phinney, 1992). Psychological adjustment was assessed by the Brief Symptom Inventory. Findings show that the MEIM successfully yielded variation in the potential Cultural-Racial Identities that the Ss reported. Findings did not support differences in psychological adjustment among transracial adoptees having different Cultural-Racial Identities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Discovering how urban poverty and violence affect health: Development and validation of a neighborhood stress index. [References].

column19: Health problems of the urban poor have been attributed to psychosocial effects of environmental stress. Testing such models requires an ability to measure neighborhood characteristics that make life stressful. The City Stress Inventory (CSI) uses self-report to assess perceived neighborhood disorder and exposure to violence. Data from an interracial sample of urban adolescents show the CSI to be internally consistent, stable, and correlated with census indices of social disadvantage. Validity for stress research is indicated by correlations with trait depression, anger, hostility, self-esteem, and mood changes during a debate with an unfamiliar peer. The CSI can be completed by persons with an 8th-grade education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column11: Benet-Martinez, Veronica, veronica@umich.edu

column13: Journal of Research in Personality. Vol.36(6), Dec 2002, pp. 598-606.
column19: This paper presents recent work examining the meaning and impact of individual variations in the way bicultural individuals organize their two cultural identities, a construct the authors call Bicultural Identity Integration (BII). While biculturals high on BII describe their two cultural identities as 'compatible' (fluid and complementary), biculturals low on BII experience them as largely 'oppositional' (i.e., conflicting and disparate). The authors first report experimental evidence for how variations in BII moderate biculturals' socio-cognitive behavior, specifically, the way in which bicultural individuals process cultural knowledge and use it to interpret social behavior. The authors then report structural equation modeling findings that elucidate some important personality, contextual, and performance predictors of BII. Finally, the authors conclude with a brief discussion of how the study of bicultural identities provides an ideal ground for the integration of cultural and personality psychology. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Different methods of measuring inter-racial contacts produce large differences in the level of the same. Experiments conducted on the 1998 General Social Survey indicate that estimates of how many people have inter-racial friends are much higher when a direct question is asked, intermediate when a three-step procedure is used, and the least when a name-generator, network approach is used. Cognitive and social desirability reasons for these effects are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column19: Examined the significance of ancestry on racial identity and its influence on healthcare. 20 individuals of mixed African-American-White and Asian-American-White ancestries (aged 45-94 yrs) completed interviews concerning self-identity. Results show that racial identity included the 5 dimensions of cultural identity, ascribed racial identity, racial identification to others, racial self-identification, and situational racialization of feeling. Mixed African-Americans described greater consistency in ascribed racial identity and a consistency between ascribed racial identity and racial identification to others. Mixed Asian-American subjects appeared to be less restricted by racial definitions. Findings suggest that the assessment of health care needs should not be based on narrow definitions of race. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Factors affecting ethnic identity and other group orientation were assessed in 115 college students from 5 ethnic groups. Ethnic group self-identification, negative and positive interracial experiences, perceptions of racial bias, social support, just-world beliefs, and psychological distress were each associated with various components of ethnic identity and are discussed within a counseling perspective. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column15: Child Welfare League of America; US
column19: Examined 10 Black child welfare workers' perceptions of transracial adoption (TRA) and foster care placement (FCP). Informants were asked to discuss their attitudes toward the placement of Black children with White families, as well as their perception of the Multiethnic Placement Act of 1994 and the supplemental Interethnic Adoption Provision of 1996. This study expands existing research regarding the viability of TRA and FCP by incorporating the previously ignored perceptions of social service professionals who are charged with the responsibility of providing child and family services. Findings illuminate the significant role that prioritization of client need plays in the perceptions of workers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Howard Journal of Communications. Vol.13(3), Jul-Sep 2002, pp. 237-249.
column19: This work examines the relationship strategies employed by Black/White interracial couples and considers their unique challenge in managing a relationship that commands so much public scrutiny. The field of communication has highlighted many differences in racial styles. This work attempts to explore how intimate communication across racial lines can and does work effectively. The authors consider four stages of relationship development (racial awareness, coping, identity emergence, and maintenance) to explore the communication requirements at various stages of the couple's life together. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Race and interracial relationships in children's television commercials. [References].

column19: This study is one of a few to examine empirically the portrayal of race and interracial relationships available in television commercials in children's television programming. The study attempts to describe not only the proportions of racial portrayals, but also the settings, activities, interactions, and products advertised in commercials in which White children and AHANA (African American, Hispanic, Asian and Native American) children were portrayed together compared to when White children were alone. There appear to be positive portrayals in many areas, including the presence of racial diversity and the portrayal of White and AHANA children interacting and communicating together in positive, constructive ways. However, while commercials featuring only White children were plentiful, commercials featuring only AHANA children were rare. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: American Sociological Review. Vol.67(4), Aug 2002, pp. 614-627.
column19: Patterns of racial classification in the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health are examined. The survey's large sample size and multiple indicators of race permit generalizable claims about patterns and processes of social construction in the racial categorization of adolescents. In examining racial fluidity, the authors (1) contrast counts of multiracial youth obtained from common schemes of racial classification, (2) describe individual-level patterns of consistency in racial reporting, and (3) examine how youth who self-identify as multiracial answer questions that insist upon single-race responses. About 12% of youth provide inconsistent responses to nearly identical questions about race. The authors conclude that context affects one's choice of a single-race identity, and nearly all patterns and processes of racial classification depend on which racial groups are involved. The implications of the findings are discussed for users of data on race in general, and for the new census data in particular. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Social Science Quarterly. Vol.83(3), Sep 2002, pp. 745-761.
column19: Addressed methodological limitations in tests of contact theory which the authors extend its theoretical focus to behaviors. Linking insights from social and cognitive psychology with contact theory, the authors hypothesize that prior racial contact will have significant effects on the racial diversity of contemporary social ties. Using the 1999-2000 Lilly Survey of Attitudes and Social Networks, a national sample of 2,561 Americans (mean age 44 yrs), a univariate and multivariate analyses was conducted to test the hypotheses. Those who had experienced prior interracial contact in schools and neighborhoods were more likely, as adults, to have more racially diverse general social groups and friendship circles. They were more likely to attend multiracial as opposed to a uniracial religious congregations, and to be interracially married. In general, these findings applied not only to all Americans, but to Whites, African Americans, and Hispanics separately. They did not apply to Asians. Contact theory can and should be extended, rendering it more fruitful for studying race relations. Except when groups are an extremely small percentage of the population, even limited prior contact in multiracial settings appears to have important effects on contemporary social ties. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Goodwin, Robin [Ed]; Cramer, Duncan [Ed]. (2002). Inappropriate relationships: The unconventional, the disapproved, and the forbidden.  (pp. 247-263). xvi, 281 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column19: (from the chapter) Discusses how the definition of "inappropriate relationship" is likely to be highly dependent on the cultural and subcultural setting in which it occurs, and that any comprehensive account of inappropriate relationships needs to explain historical and cultural differences. Recent survey data has enabled some monitoring of attitudes toward interracial and extramarital relationships, as well as an understanding of the categorizations of relationship behaviors across cultures. Questions remain about why individuals persist in or pursue inappropriate relationships when the costs are so high, and when these relationships may lead to social retribution, loss of employment, prosecution, or worse. Several possible explanations are presented, including personality factors, sociobiology, social exchange theory, and cognitive consistency approaches. The authors conclude that the study of inappropriate relationships provokes us to challenge further our assumptions in the relationships field and to better appreciate the emotional and conflictual nature of relationship thoughts and actions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) Considers the historical and contemporary circumstances that have allowed "old-fashioned" and "modern" racists alike to deem interracial dating and marital relationships--especially Black-White dating and marital relationships--as "inappropriate". Specifically, the authors examine the processes by which stigmatization (i.e., the marking of individuals as inferior by virtue of their membership in socially devalued groups) simultaneously affect nonstigmatized and stigmatized individuals alike. Focus is primarily on the US, partly because virtually all of the published research on interethnic marriages is based on US samples, and partly because Black-White intermarriage rates in the US are among the lowest for all Western nations. Furthermore, focus is primary on Black-White romantic relationships, partly because the Black-White dichotomy underlies most of the race-based empirical studies on stigmatization, and partly because most of the published research on interethnic marriages has dealt with Black-White marriages. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Inappropriate relationships: The unconventional, the disapproved, and the forbidden.
column11: Goodwin, Robin, Robin.Goodwin@brunel.ac.uk
column12:
Goodwin, Robin: Brunel U, Dept of Human Sciences, Uxbridge, England
Cramer, Duncan: Loughborough U, Dept of Social Sciences, Loughborough, England
column13: (2002). Inappropriate relationships: The unconventional, the disapproved, and the forbidden. xvi, 281 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column19: (from the cover) Contributors to the chapters in this book discuss the personal boundaries and taboos of modern relationships. Together they examine the power struggles that can occur when individuals are involved in "inappropriate" relationships, and the ways individuals in such relationships may attempt to buffer themselves against sanctions--or even embrace this relationship as an agent of social change. Representing work from a range of disciplines, this collection will be valuable to those researching relationship issues in areas across the social sciences, including those working in the fields of social psychology, family studies, social anthropology, cultural studies, and communication. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Biracial sensitive practice: Expanding social services to an invisible population. [References].
column11: Hall, Ronald E.: Michigan State U, Coll of Human Medicine, B421 West Fee Hall, East Lansing, MI, US, 48823, hallr@pilot.msu.edu
column12: Hall, Ronald E.: Michigan State U, Coll of Human Medicine, East Lansing, MI, US
column13: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment. Vol.5(2), 2002, pp. 29-44.
column19: Discusses provision of social services to biracial individuals. A biracial individual may assume a multiplicity of identities, including African-, Asian-, Latino-, and Native-American when negotiating with large institutions, including those providing social services. As an alternative to traditional, static views of race, the identity-across-the-lifespan model provides a more comprehensive paradigm for biracial clients. In the aftermath clients will be rendered visible by such an identity model, which prevails less on the basis of race and more on the basis of lifetime experience. It is concluded that biracial clients require the option, at least, to identify themselves rather than be identified by superficial racial characteristics. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology. Vol.8(2), May 2002, pp. 88-102.
column19: The authors review a series of studies that illustrate how one form of contemporary racial bias of Whites, aversive racism, can shape different perspectives of Blacks and Whites in ways that can undermine race relations. This research demonstrates that contemporary racism among Whites is subtle, often unintentional, and unconscious but that its effects are systematically damaging to race relations by fostering miscommunication and distrust. In particular, the authors examine the effects of aversive racism on outcomes for Blacks (e.g., in selection decisions), on the ways that Whites behave in interracial interactions, in the impressions that Whites and Blacks form of each other in these interactions, and on the task efficiency of interracial dyads. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Studying hate crime with the Internet: What makes racists advocate racial violence? [References].
column9:
Glaser, Jack

Dixit, Jay

Green, Donald P
column11: Glaser, Jack: U of California, Goldman School of Public Policy, 2607 Hearst Ave., Berkeley, CA, US, 94720-7320, glaserj@socrates.berkeley.edu
column12:
Glaser, Jack: U of California, Goldman School of Public Policy, Berkeley, CA, US
Green, Donald P.: Yale U, New Haven, CT, US
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.58(1), Spr 2002, pp. 177-193.
column19: The authors conducted semistructured interviews with 38 participants in White racist Internet chat rooms, examining the extent to which people would, in this unique environment, advocate interracial violence in response to purported economic and cultural threats. Capitalizing on the anonymity and candor of chat room interactions, this study provides an unusual perspective on extremist attitudes. The authors experimentally manipulated the nature and proximity of the threats. Qualitative and quantitative analyses indicate that the respondents were most threatened by interracial marriage and, to a lesser extent, Blacks moving into White neighborhoods. In contrast, job competition posed by Blacks evoked very little advocacy of violence. The study affords an assessment of the advantages and limitations of Internet-based research with clandestine populations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: (2002). Principles and practice of child and adolescent forensic psychiatry. xiii, 385 pp. Arlington, VA, US: American Psychiatric Publishing, Inc.; US.
column19: (from the preface) This book replaces the authors' previous book, Clinical Handbook of Child Psychiatry and the Law, which is now out of print and outdated. This volume covers the same basic issues addressed in their previous book, with expanded and updated material and increased emphasis on issues related to adoption, youth violence, and juvenile offenders. The authors introduce new topics, including vicarious traumatization of the clinician, parenting assessments, transracial adoptions, sexual harassment, child pornography, sexually aggressive youth, and the neurodevelopmental impact of violence in childhood, and telepsychiatry. More background material on law and more research in important areas such as the suggestibility of child witnesses and the effect of violence on children are included. This book is intended for a wide audience, including but not limited to, practicing clinicians, forensic examiners, attorneys, and judges who may wish to use it as a reference book and trainees in child and adolescent psychiatry or psychology who may use it as a basic text. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Howard Journal of Communications. Vol.13(2), Apr-Jun 2002, pp. 113-128.
column19: Examined the relationships between specific communication behaviors and overall perceptions of Black and White communicators and sought to replicate the findings of R. Leonard and D. Locke. 18 communication behaviors were identified in the literature representing "Black" and "White" communication. 105 Black and 159 White Ss (aged 18-62 yrs) recalled a past interaction with a racial "other" and completed a 2-part questionnaire regarding these behaviors and overall impressions of the other. Pearson correlations were used to answer 7 hypotheses regarding these behaviors and impressions. Individual communication behaviors were associated with several negative race-type impressions, suggesting that macrolevel interpretations between interracial speakers may be problematic. Results also suggest that the exact order of stereotypes/perceptions might change from place to place, depending on how the instrument is used, and may be influenced by interpersonal interaction. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) Used questionnaire responses from 1st yr collegiate athletes to explore potential relationships among athletic identity, racial identity, interracial contact, and interpersonal aggression. The authors found that a significant number of college students are influenced through their direct participation in intercollegiate athletics. Whether by forging self-identities as athletes; interacting with and working toward manual goals with teammates of different racial or ethnic backgrounds; or competing against opponents, the athletic arena is one in which participating students come to develop normative attitudes, beliefs, and behavior in a wide range of social areas. This chapter examines empirically how the backgrounds are prior experience of 1st-yr Black and White, male and female, scholarship athletes are related to the nature of their athletic and racial identities, their interracial attitudes and contacts, their perceived interpersonal aggression both on the field, and the nature of beliefs about their interpersonal relationships. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Stereotypes about Black sexuality fostered hypotheses that racial factors and racism influence rape victim blaming. 332 predominantly White and Asian college students (mean age 20 yrs) completed the Modern Racism Scale and evaluated a rape vignette varying victim race, perpetrator race, and rape type. As predicted, racial factors determined victim blaming. Compared to intraracial rapes, interracial rapes were less uniformly judged as "definitely rape" and were judged as having more culpable and less credible victims, and less culpable perpetrators. For men, racism scores positively predicted victim blaming in all rapes. For women, racism scores moderated victim blaming in interracial acquaintance rapes. In conclusion, the durability of racial stereotypes about rape and their influence on discriminatory adjudication outcomes is emphasized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: (2002). Adoption, race & identity: From infancy to young adulthood (2nd ed.). xii, 231 pp. Piscataway, NJ, US: Transaction Publishers; US.
column19: (from the cover) This book is a long-range study of the impact of interracial; adoption on those adopted and their families. Initiated in 1972, it was continued in 1979, 1984, and 1991. These 4 phases trace the Ss from early childhood into young adulthood. The authors provide a broad perspective of the impact of transracial adoption and include profiles of the families involved in the study. They identify and compare the experiences of both the parents and the children. The authors also identify families whose adoption experiences were problematic and those whose experiences were positive. Finally, the study looks at the insights the experience of transracial adoption brought to the adoptive parents and what advice they would pass on to future parents adopting children and different racial backgrounds. They include the reflections of those adopted included in the 1972 1st phase who are now adults themselves. This 2nd edition includes a new concluding chapter that updates the 4th and last phase of the study. This work may be of interest to social workers, policy makers, and professionals and families involved on all sides of interracial adoption. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Dovidio, John F.: Colgate U, Dept of Psychology, Hamilton, NY, US, 13346, jdovidio@mail.colgate.edu
column12: Dovidio, John F.: Colgate U, Dept of Psychology, Hamilton, NY, US
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.82(1), Jan 2002, pp. 62-68.
column19: The present research examined how implicit racial associations and explicit racial attitudes of Whites relate to behaviors and impressions in interracial interactions. Specifically, the authors examined how response latency and self-report measures predicted bias and perceptions of bias in verbal and nonverbal behavior exhibited by Whites while they interacted with a Black partner. As predicted, Whites' self-reported racial attitudes significantly predicted bias in their verbal behavior to Black relative to White confederates. Furthermore, these explicit attitudes predicted how much friendlier Whites felt that they behaved toward White than Black partners. In contrast, the response latency measure significantly predicted Whites' nonverbal friendliness and the extent to which the confederates and observers perceived bias in the participants' friendliness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Beyond Black: Biracial identity in America. [References].
column9:
Rockquemore, Kerry Ann

Brunsma, David L
column12: Rockquemore, Kerry Ann: Boston Coll, Boston, MA, US
column13: (2002). Beyond Black: Biracial identity in America. xi, 179 pp. Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; US.
column19: (from the preface) In 1997, the Office of Management and Budget announced that a multiracial category would not be added to the 2000 census. This decision followed a protracted and heated debate. The primary reason why the authors undertook this project was to address the scarcity of empirical research that informed the 2000 census debate. The goal of this book is to provide analysis of a quantity of data that has heretofore been unavailable and to provide the quality of analysis that enables answers to important and enduring questions about racial identity. The addition of a multiracial category will most likely emerge once again as preparations are made for the 2010 census; therefore, the authors' hope for this project is twofold. First, they hope that this study will open a new path toward a more empirically based and less emotionally laden discourse on multiracialism. Second they hope that the findings reported in this book will open the debate about a multiracial category in the 2010 census to a more dynamic, multifaceted understanding of what biracial identity means to members of this population. The authors also hope that their work will be of interest ot parents of biracial children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Applied Social Psychology. Vol.31(7), Jul 2001, pp. 1350-1378.
column19: Self-evaluations after interracial and dyadic interactions were examined. 95 African American and White females interacted with either a same- or different-race partner in 1 of 3 role conditions: the high-status role of an interviewer, the low-status role of an applicant, or a peer of equal status. Following the interaction, responses to the Collective Self-Esteem scale assessed social self-evaluation, while the Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale and the State Self-Esteem scale assessed personal self-esteem. Combinations of racial composition and situational role had striking influences on self-evaluations. For instance, when situational roles signaled a reversal from societal status, participants reported lower collective self-esteem than when situational and societal status were consistent. Thus, roles can have compelling consequences for self-evaluation after intergroup interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Multiethnic identity development, psychological adjustment, and parental attachment in adolescence.
column12: Jones, Jennifer E.: Adelphi U, Inst Advanced Psychological Studies, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(10-B), Apr 2000, pp. 5227.
column19: Research has suggested that ethnic minorities differ in the development of an ethnic identity, and that these differences are associated with self-esteem. Ethnic identity development may be an especially complex challenge facing biethnic and multiethnic individuals, who are often forced to choose one ethnicity. As children of interracial relationships, biracial and multiracial youth have legitimate claims to multiple ethnic heritages, yet these heritages are often not recognized due to skin color, appearance or name. This study examined the differences in ethnic identity development among adolescents, particularly focusing on multiethnic individuals, exploring the relationships among ethnic identity and self-esteem, ethnic identity and psychological adjustment, and ethnic identity and parental attachment. Two hundred and fifty-one participants completed four pencil and paper measures; the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (Phinney, 1990), the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (Rosenberg, 1965), the Achenbach Youth Self-Report (1991) and the Inventory of Parent and Peer Attachment (Greensburg & Arsmden, 1987). A series of one-way analysis of variance revealed that multiethnic participants scored significantly lower on ethnic identity than both African-Americans and Latinos. As predicted, Multiethnics showed no difference in psychological adjustment and self-esteem, as compared to their monoethnic counterparts. In addition, it was found that the relationship to mother and father was significantly correlated to psychological adjustment, but not to self-esteem. It was revealed in a series of multiple regressions that the relationship to mother, father and ethnic identity achievement accounted for 38% of the variance in psychological adjustment. Lastly, a somewhat limited finding is that having an African-American friend conferred the most significant contribution, predicting 8% of the variance in ethnic identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of heritage combination on ethnic identity, self-esteem, and adjustment among American biethnic adults.
column12: Mukoyama, Tammy Hiroko-Josefa: California School of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(4-B), Oct 1998, pp. 1864.
column19: The past three decades have yielded an increased number of biethnic individuals in the United States due to changing social trends and removal of laws prohibiting unions between members of different ethnic groups. Empirical and theoretical literature concerning this population has been limited and often inconclusive. With continued growth of a multiethnic/multiracial movement issues concerning this population are becoming more salient. The current study investigated ethnic identity, self-esteem, and adjustment among Japanese-African Americans and Japanese-European Americans. The sample consisted of 86 biethnic adults (54 Japanese-European Americans, 32 Japanese-African Americans). Subjects were recruited at local college campuses, through multiethnic organizations, and through snowballing techniques. Subjects completed materials that were mailed to them. The study was correlation with a pre-experimental, cross-sectional design. Heritage Combination (majority/minority, minority/minority) was the primary predictor variable with Gender, Current Involvement in Multiethnic/Multiracial/Interracial/Biracial Organization, Ethnically Diverse Community Upbringing, and Perceived Parental Support of Biethnic Identity comprising additional predictor variables. Instrumentation included the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE) (Rosenberg, 1965), the Adjective Check List (ACL) (Gough & Heilbrun, 1965), and the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (MEIM) (Phinney, 1992). Results of the study provided a greater understanding of the heterogeneity within the biethnic community and the need to look further at process as well as outcome. Japanese-African Americans and Japanese-European Americans did not significantly differ in their decisions to identify monoethnically versus biethnically, though monoethnic identifiers were more likely to be male. In terms of ethnic identity as measured by the MEIM, Japanese-African Americans were more likely to assert higher ethnic affirmation and belonging than Japanese-European Americans when education and parental support were sufficient. On remaining aspects of ethnic identity, the predictor variables of Current Involvement in Multiethnic/Multiracial/Interracial/Biracial Organization, Ethnically Diverse Community Upbringing, and Perceived Parental Support of Biethnic Identity accounted for a significant amount of variance in ethnic identity. Relative to self-esteem as measured by the RSE, Heritage Combination was not predictive of self-esteem, though the predictor variables of Current Involvement in Multiethnic/Multiracial/Interracial/Biracial Organization, Ethnically Diverse Community Upbringing, and Perceived Parental Support of Biethnic Identity added significantly to the prediction of self-esteem. In general, irrespective of heritage combination, subjects appeared to have high levels of self-esteem. In terms of adjustment measured by the ACL - PADJ, neither Heritage Combination or any predictor variables contributed significantly to the prediction of adjustment. However, in general, the sample represented a well adjusted group of individuals as evidenced by an ability to effectively manage life's stressors and to maintain a positive outlook. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Attitudes toward weight, shape, and eating in African-American college women: A cultural analysis.
column12: Griffith, Jeana Renee: Miami U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(3-B), Sep 1998, pp. 1367.
column19: The purpose of the present study was to examine attitudes and behaviors related to eating from an ethno-cultural perspective. An index of eating disordered behavior, the Eating Attitudes Test (EAT) (Garfinkel & Garner, 1979), an index of Africentric Beliefs, the Belief Systems Analysis Scale (BSAS) (Fine & Myers, 1988), an index of self esteem, the Rosenberg Self Esteem scale (Rosenberg, 1965), and a demographic data questionnaire were administered to two non-clinical samples of African American college women (one from predominantly white institution and one from predominantly African American institution). This was the first attempt to examine disordered eating in African American college women while considering the following factors: Africentric world view, interracial contact, participation in African American interest groups/classes, self esteem, region, community size, parental racial socialization, African American group evaluation, and peer and parental ideal body type for participant. Multiple regression analyses, analyses of variance, and correlational analyses were used to test the hypotheses advanced. The results of this study lend support to the following protective factors against disordered eating behavior in African American women: having an Africentric World View, high self esteem, being born in a small city, and being socialized integrative/assertive. In addition, there was a relationship between involvement in African American interest groups and BSAS scores. There was also a trend for participants with a negative African American group evaluation to score lower than participants with a positive African American group evaluation on the BSAS and higher on the EAT. Further, both parental and peer ideal body type for participant were good predictors of participant ideal body type. No relationships were found between region and eating disorders scores or between racial setting and eating disorders scores. Limitations of the study and suggestions for further research are provided. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Biracial identity development: Psychosocial contributions to self-esteem and racial identity.
column12: Cooke, Trude Ilese: Arizona State U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(10-B), Apr 1998, pp. 5669.
column19: Demographers estimate that by the beginning of the 21st Century, more than one-third of the United States will be composed of people of color. Included in those numbers will be individuals who have two racial group heritages, though only one part of their racial background may be minority. Typically, these individuals will be considered, exclusively, as members of the minority community which negates the existence of their "other half". Existing research studies on the racial identity development of biracial individuals has been replete with studies on the identity development of offspring from Black/White or White/other unions, with little emphasis on the similarities and differences between these minority-majority biracials. This exploratory study serves the following purposes: (1) determine which factors may predict biracial identity choice for minority-majority biracials, (2) examine whether statistically significant differences exist between demographic factors and the psychological factors of biracial identity and self-esteem for minority-majority biracials, (3) explore the possibility of a relationship between racial identity and physical characteristics for minority-majority biracials. Fifty-six (56) minority-majority biracials--of Asian/Caucasian, Black/Caucasian, and Hispanic/Caucasian racial heritages--completed the Biracial Identity Attitude Scale, a revised version of the Multiethnic Identity Measure and the Rosenberg Self-esteem scale. Four of the participants took part in a phone interview to enhance the information collected by these instruments and add a more personalized perspective on the biracial identity process. Correlational analysis was used to study the relationship between racial identity, self-esteem, and various demographic factors (i.e., age, gender). Results suggest that minority-majority biracials tend to associate their experiences as biracials with their minority parent, although they may choose to embrace both of their racial heritages. Recommendations for parents, mental health professionals, teachers, and others who serve biracial populations are presented in order to promote a better understanding of the biracial identity process leading to more effective services. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The self-esteem of preschool age biracial children as predicted by their racial identity, their parents' racial identity, and their parents' self-esteem.
column12: Karasaki, Dana M. A.: Pepperdine U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.58(10-A), Apr 1998, pp. 4081.
column19: This study investigated whether a preschool age Biracial child's self-esteem can be significantly predicted by his/her racial identity and his/her parents' racial identity and self-esteem. The examiner looked at the impact of three subgroups of predictor variables: (a) child's racial identity, mother's self-esteem, and mother's racial identity; (b) child's racial identity, father's self-esteem, and father's racial identity; and (c) child's racial identity, difference between parents' self-esteem, and difference between parents' racial identity on six dimensions of the child's self-esteem. The following instruments were used: (a) the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (Rosenberg, 1965); (b) the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (Phinney, 1992); (c) Jacobs' doll-play instrument (Jacobs, 1977); and (d) the Pictorial Scale of Perceived Competence and Social Acceptance for Young Children (Harter & Pike, 1983). Multiple Regression Analyses were conducted for 30 sets of Biracial children and their parents, recruited in Los Angeles and Boston. No significance was found in any of the linear composites investigated. However, a methodological issue was discovered which may have great implications for further research in this area. Namely, the possibility that a sampling bias may be inherent in studies of this nature as participants tend to be self-selected. Generalizability of findings would be seriously compromised if, as suggested in this study, participants tend to be skewed in the direction of having higher self-esteem and racial commitment. Future researchers are cautioned to use care in using the self selection process with this population. It is further suggested that findings from quantitative studies be viewed cautiously if nonprobability sampling is used. Studies of this nature may need to focus on seeking out cultural meaning rather than attempting to generalize these findings to the population at large. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).
