column5: Racial identification and self-concept issues in biracial.
column12: Harrison, Patricia Maria: Columbia U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(4-B), Oct 1997, pp. 2123.
column19: This study investigated whether racial identification in biracial adolescent girls varied as a function of demographic, social/familial, and psychological factors. Fifty-three biracial girls aged 11-22 and their White mothers participated. Thirty-four subject-pairs were interviewed in person and nineteen responded by returning the research instruments by mail. Daughters completed the Adolescent Interview Form, created for the purpose of this study to obtain quantitative and qualitative data about the daughter, the Self-Perception Profile for Adolescents (Harter, 1988), the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (Rosenberg, 1979), a revised form of the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (Phinney, 1992), and the Brief Symptom Inventory (Derogatis, 1975, 1992). Mothers completed the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (Phinney, 1992), the Family Information Form, and the Parent Interview Form, developed to collect demographic and qualitative data about the target family. Demographic variabies considered were age, self-descriptions of skin color and physiognomy, and dominant racial composition of the neighborhood and school environment. Social/familial variables considered were perceived quality of relationships with extended family members, contact with other interracial families, amount of interaction between mothers and daughters on issues of race, and daughters' perceived pressures to identify with a particular racial group. Lastly, the relationship between patterns of psychological adjustment and racial identification was explored. The results of multivariate analyses indicated that the strongest predictors of racial identification were physiognomy and the amount of discussion of racial issues between mother and daughter. Girls who more frequently discussed race with their mothers and who perceived themselves to have more Negroid features were more likely to self-identify as Black or biracial, but feeling predominantly Black. Additional factors associated with such racial identification were a perceived good relationship with paternal grandparents, the age at which daughters first experienced pressure to identify racially, frequency of contact with other interracial families, and a high level of achieved ethnic identity. Self-reported symptomatic distress was within normed limits and did not differ significantly by racial identification. Self-esteem and self-concept were also not significantly related to racial identification. Findings are discussed in relation to contemporary theory of racial and ethnic identity development. Implications for future research are also addressed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Examining racial and ethnic differences in Asian adolescent drug use: The contributions of culture, background and lifestyle.
column9:
James, William H

Kim, Grace K

Moore, David D
column12: James, William H.: U Washington, Seattle, WA, US
column13: Drugs: Education, Prevention & Policy. Vol.4(1), Mar 1997, pp. 39-51.
column19: Examined a selected population of Asian and Pacific Islander adolescents' drug use and related cultural factors. 39 Asian- American adolescents from 8th-12th grades completed the Adolescent Substance Battery. Complete data were gathered on 21 students, and additional data were gathered from the chemical-dependency counsellor and database system 6-9 mo later. The 21 Ss consisted of 7 students from Southeast Asian backgrounds, 7 students from Filipino or Hawaiian backgrounds, and 7 students of biracial heritage. Five of the 7 Southeast Asian students, 3 of the 7 Filipino or Hawaiian background students, and 4 of the biracial students had high alienation scores on the psychological screening inventory. One Southeast Asian, 2 Filipino or Hawaiian, and 2 biracial students had high social nonconformity scores. Six of the 7 Southeast Asian students, 5 of the 7 Hawaii or Filipino students, and 5 of the 7 biracial students had high discomfort scores. 62% of the students referred for suspected drug use had used drugs, and nearly half had serious drug problems. It is suggested that the transition to Western culture disrupts the hierarchical family structure, interdependence, and self-identity of young Asian Americans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Structural and individual influences affecting racialized dating relationships.
column12: Fujino, Diane C.: U California, Santa Barbara, CA, US
column13: Chin, Jean Lau [Ed]. (2000). Relationships among Asian American women.  (pp. 181-209). x, 251 pp. Washington, DC, US: American Psychological Association; US.
column19: (from the chapter) Explored racialized patterns of heterosexual dating among Chinese American and Japanese American females and proposed and tested a model showing how structural and individual factors influence Asian American females' selection of intraracial and interracial partners. 163 college students completed a 50-min questionnaire concerning interracial dating, the Attitude toward Women Scale, and the Attributional Relationship Scale. The majority of the Ss have dated at least 1 Asian American male, however, interracial dating is on the increase, particularly, with White men. Factors affecting racialized dating included individual tastes and preferences and structural influences. Results indicate that controlling images have come to determine how males view Asian American females. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the book) In this chapter, the author addresses the limitations of feminist analyses of pornography to date. These analyses have ignored the extent to which pornography also serves racist agendas and seeks to degrade Women of Color because they are women and because they are minorities. Cowan also presents an empirical analysis of ethnicity in pornographic videos, with particular attention given to interracial pornography. She suggests that racism and misogyny cannot readily be disentangled in pornography or in the lives of Women of Color and that research and political action regarding pornography must begin to address racism. column5: Psychological models of race: What have they been and what should they be? [References].
column12: Jones, James M.: Minority Fellowship Program, University of Delaware, DE, US
column13: Goodchilds, Jacqueline D [Ed]. (1991). Psychological perspectives on human diversity in America.  (pp. 3-46). 192 pp. Washington, DC, US: American Psychological Association; US.
column19: (from the chapter) Race has been one of the recurring and critical themes of psychology from the beginnings of the science in 1892. The legacy of psychology with respect to race is a decidedly mixed one. It cannot be said that the concern of psychology with matters of race has produced the greatest accomplishments of our discipline, yet we have made some contributions that stand out. In the pages that follow, I will highlight some of the more interesting studies done over the past 90 years; draw out the implications of this work for our understanding of race relations; and point out some of the consequences of these studies for members of minority racial groups and members of the current majority population in this society. I will note some possible implications for psychological practice, assessment, and research in the decade ahead. In an attempt to follow some of the empirical and conceptual themes in psychology, I have chosen to focus largely but not exclusively on the results of research and arguments regarding Blacks and, for comparative purposes, Whites. Many, but certainly not all, of the conclusions we draw from such an analysis have relevance for the other racial groups. This chapter is organized into four sections. The first reviews some perspectives and lines of reasoning on race from early in this century. Definitions, basic conceptual orientations, and illustrative examples of research are presented. The second section addresses the question of the biological basis of race and the evidence for "a race difference," and why it is or is not important to pursue this line of enquiry. The third reviews the evidence for continuing bias of Whites against Blacks--understood as the analysis of prejudice, racism, and discrimination--and proposes how that might affect the social and psychological responses of Blacks to interracial interactions. In the fourth section, selected areas of theory and research are considered, and some of the psychotherapy implications for clinical practice are explored. This will include the studies designed to assess "racial differences" and to understand foundations of behavior among members of racial groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The power and collapse of paternalism: The Ford Motor Company and Black workers, 1937-1941.
column12: Brueggemann, John: Skidmore Coll, Dept of Sociology, Saratoga Springs, NY, US
column13: Social Problems. Vol.47(2), May 2000, pp. 220-240.
column19: Examined the significance of paternalism in two interracial labor organizing drives at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant during the Great Depression using a comparative historical analysis. The 1st drive resulted in ongoing interracial antagonism among Ford workers and the union's failure. The 2nd drive generated interracial labor solidarity and led to the union's recognition. One of the distinctive aspects of the setting was Henry Ford's paternalistic relations with the Black community of Detroit. Drawing from M. Jackman's (1994) research, the author examines the dimensions of paternalism and how it contributes to split labor market dynamics, in particular, and power relationships, in general. This analysis suggests that a split labor market based on paternalism can only be overcome by workers when another political actor intervenes in ways that challenge the stratification. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Social integration of low-income Black adults in middle-class White suburbs.
column9:
Rosenbaum, James E

Popkin, Susan J

Kaufman, Julie E

Rusin, Jennifer
column12: Rosenbaum, James E.: Northwestern U, Ctr for Urban Affairs & Policy Research, Evanston, IL, US
column13: Social Problems. Vol.38(4), Nov 1991, pp. 448-461.
column19: Examined whether racial and socioeconomic integration leads to social isolation by studying participants in the Gautreaux Program, which helps low-income Black families move into better housing in White middle-class suburbs and Black inner-city neighborhoods. 342 Gautreaux participants were surveyed, and 95 were interviewed. Little difference existed in the overall social integration of people moving to the suburban and city neighborhoods. Both groups reported making friends in their new communities and reported about the same level of interaction with and support from neighbors. Suburban movers experienced more incidents of harassment and racial discrimination, but these incidents decreased over time. Suburban movers were more likely than city movers to form interracial friendships. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Predictors of interracial homicide victimization for Asian Americans: A macrostructural opportunity perspective. [References].
column9:
Jang, Sung Joon

Messner, Steven F

South, Scott J
column11: Jang, Sung Joon: Department of Sociology, State University of New York, Albany, NY, US, 12222
column12:
Jang, Sung Joon: State University of New York, Albany, NY, US

South, Scott J.: State University of New York, Albany, NY, US
column13: Sociological Perspectives. Vol.34(1), Spr 1991, pp. 1-19.
column19: This paper uses Blau's macrostructural opportunity theory to explore patterns of interracial homicide victimization among Asian Americans. Data are drawn from the F.B.I.'s Supplementary Homicide Reports and aggregated for 131 SMSAs over the 1976-1984 period. Unlike previous research, two out-groups-white and black offenders-are considered to see if the same predictors behave similarly for the different out-groups. As expected, the descriptive data show that Asian Americans as a minority group have a greater conditional probability of being killed by out-group members than do whites and blacks. On the other hand, logistic regression analysis reveals that educational inequality and population size are significant predictors of the conditional probability of out-group victimization, while hypotheses concerning the effects of relative group size, income inequality, and residential segregation fail to be fully supported. We conclude with a discussion of possible reasons for the unexpected results and of important tasks for future research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: An examination of the effects of residential and church integration on racial attitudes of Whites.
column12: Yancey, George: U North Texas, Dept of Sociology, Denton, TX, US
column13: Sociological Perspectives. Vol.42(2), Sum 1999, pp. 279-304.
column19: The contact hypothesis, which suggests that interracial contact promotes harmonious racial relations, was tested in residential settings and religious institutions. Data were collected from the 1990 General Social Science Survey. Ss were 264 Whites who stated that African-Americans attended their church and 340 who stated that African-Americans did not attend their church. Residential integration did not appear to alter racial attitudes of Whites toward African-Americans. After basic demographic controls, however, Whites who attended interracial churches exhibited less social distance toward African-Americans and had a lower tendency to stereotype Blacks. Interracial religious groups may lessen development of racial myths and encourage more harmonious primary relationships between Whites and Blacks. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Trends in Asian American racial/ethnic intermarriage: A comparison of 1980 and 1990 census data.
column12: Lee, Sharon M.: Portland State U, Dept of Sociology, Portland, OR, US
column13: Sociological Perspectives. Vol.41(2), 1998, pp. 323-342.
column19: Uses data from the 1990 census to compare patterns of 18-64 yr old Asian American's intermarriage with those reported by S. M. Lee and K. Yamanaka (see record 1990-22338-001). Lee and Yamanaka used data from the 1980 census on Asian American racial and ethnic intermarriage, and found that one-quarter of married Asian Americans were outmarried; of these, 90% were married to non-Asians. Variations by gender and nativity were also observed. Women and the native born were more likely to be outmarried. The current authors expected to see a decline in Asian American intermarriage since 1980 because of high levels of immigration, growth of the Asian population, and increased social distance between Asian Americans and Whites. Main findings from the 1990 census data show that: (1) the overall outmarriage rate has declined, (2) Asian American inter-ethnic marriages (that is, marriages between 2 Asian Americans of different Asian ethnicities) have increased; and (3) social distance, measured by an Index of Intermarriage Distance, between Asian Americans and other racial and ethnic groups has widened. The authors conclude by discussing some implications of the findings for the role of racial and ethnic intermarriage as an indicator of intergroup relations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A structural approach to sexual attitudes: Interracial patterns of adolescents' judgments about sexual intimacy.
column12: Howard, Judith A.: U Washington, Seattle, US
column13: Sociological Perspectives. Vol.31(1), Jan 1988, pp. 88-121.
column19: Evaluates the utility of cultural and structural perspectives in accounting for interracial patterns in sexual values and attitudes. Data were from the responses to questionnaires and interviews with 932 White, Black, Hispanic and other ethnic male and female adolescents. There were no racial differences in attitudes toward rape or male-female relationships. Black Ss anticipated more negative reactions from the police and expressed greater distrust of other institutional agencies. Black women were more likely to anticipate turning to their parents or other family members for support. Results are interpreted as supportive of a structural perspective. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Investigated perceptions of family acceptance concerning interracial friendships and romantic relationships. The Assessment Scale of Interracial Relationships (ASIR) was constructed and administered to 68 men and 74 women college students. Results showed that both men and women held negative attitudes toward interracial relationships, although Black students held more favorable attitudes than did White students. Findings also showed that the women were less accepting of interracial friendships and romantic relationships than were the men. Both Black and White students indicated that family perception of these interracial relationships would be negative. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Traces the development of the writer's self-concept in relation to experiences in 3 regions of the world: the Caribbean, North America, and West Africa, relating specifically to racial and ethnic dynamics and concluding with a definition of internationalism. Two assertions emerge from the discourse: (1) Black people everywhere come to experience the world from an inferior position, sooner or later, and (2) there will always be deficiencies in communication and interaction. When people differ in color, expression of culture, or gender, among other things, these deficiencies heighten. J. E. Helms (1986) suggests that racial identity issues have implications in the counseling process and should be specifically addressed. The extent to which this may be relevant in the African context ought to be an interesting line of research. (French abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined interracial and intraracial differences in neuropsychiatric symptoms, sociodemography, and treatment among nursing home patients with dementia, using an adaptation of L. K. George's (1989) social antecedent model of psychopathology. The final sample consisted of 164 US-born African Americans (mean age 79.7 yrs), 54 African Caribbeans (mean age 79.5 yrs) and 68 Caucasians. Although there were appreciable interracial differences in sociodemographics, there were minimal clinical differences. This finding may reflect both racial differences in pathways to institutionalization and the homogenization of clinical characteristics created by new governmental standards for nursing homes. There were no substantial differences between African Americans and African Caribbeans. Use of medication to treat neuropsychiatric symptoms was low, and may have reflected difficulties in diagnosis and concerns about the abuse of medications. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the use of racial identity attitudes as predictors of racial mistrust, or perceived interpersonal racism, of African Americans and other racial contact variables among Asian Americans. A packet consisting of the Visible Racial/Ethnic Group Members Identity Attitudes Scale (J E. Helms and R. T. Carter, 1990), the Cultural Mistrust Inventory (F. Terrell and S. L. Terrell, 1981), a modified version of the Marlow-Crowne Social Desirability Scale (D. P. Crowne and D. Marlow, 1960), the Racial Contact Scale (E. L. Kohatsu et al, 1994), and a demographic data sheet that solicited information such as socioeconomic status, birthplace, generational status, ethnicity, and neighborhood composition was administered to 160 Ss (aged 17-60 yrs). Hierarchical regression analyses revealed that racial identity attitudes significantly predicted racial mistrust, overall group impression, four racial stereotypes, and two quality of racial contact variables in ways consistent with racial identity theory. Implications for the findings for Asian American psychology, and race relations research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Vietnamese Amerasians: Predictors of distress and self-destructive behavior.
column12: Bemak, Fred: Ohio State U, School of Physical Activity & Educational Services, Columbus, OH, US
column13: Journal of Counseling & Development. Vol.76(4), Fal 1998, pp. 452-458.
column19: There have been few empirical studies of Vietnamese Amerasians, children fathered by US servicemen and civilians during the Vietnam War. This study investigated pre- and postmigration variables that predict psychological distress and self-destructive behavior among this population. The sample (N = 169) was selected from 10 cities throughout the US. Multivariate regression analyses were used to determine the predictors of distress. Results revealed that observing traumatic events rather than actually experiencing trauma was a significant predictor of psychological distress. Participants with frequent cognitions about loss of significant people, places, or both were more likely to report psychological distress and self-destructive behavior. Implications for research and practice are discussed in relationship to cross-cultural counseling with at-risk populations, including individuals from inner cities and war-stricken environments. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:
Parker, Woodrow A

Moore, Margaret A

Neimeyer, Greg J
column12: Parker, Woodrow A.: U Florida, Dept of Counselor Education, Gainesville, FL, US

column19: Examined the impact of a 15-wk multicultural training program on the development of White racial identity and interracial comfort of 96 graduate students in counseling education. Ss were enrolled in either a course in multicultural counseling (intervention group) or in counseling skills (controls). All students were White and both teachers were Black. Ss completed both the White Racial Consciousness Development Scale (WRCDS) and the Interracial Comfort Index (ICI) pre- and post-training. Findings indicate that the integrative multicultural training program resulted in significant increases along 3 dimensions of White racial consciousness (contact, pseudo-independence, and autonomy) and enhanced expressed interracial comfort. This work extends related efforts to study White racial identity as an important parameter of multicultural training and counseling. In addition, psychometric data and factor structures are provided for the WRCDS and the ICI. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Black, with a White parent, a positive and achievable identity.
column12: Goldstein, Beverley Prevatt: U Durham, Ctr for Applied Social Studies, Durham, England
column13: British Journal of Social Work. Vol.29(2), Apr 1999, pp. 285-301.
column19: Uses historical, research and theoretical material deriving largely from anti-racist and psychological frameworks to synthesize and critically reappraise the existing research on Black children with a White parent, living with their original families, in Britain. The objective is to "normalize" these children by identifying and rejecting the forces that pathologize them. The racism, marginalization and alienation which are likely to impact on their world are highlighted, so that action may be taken to combat these. A lack of clarity as to the personal and political complexity of identity has hampered professional perspectives and intervention. The paper consequently explores, from a postmodernist Black perspective, the racial self-concepts that are available to this group, identifying their underlying agendas and their consequences. It concludes that the availability of the self-concept "Black, with a White parent", offered in the framework of change, multiplicity and individuality, is beneficial. However, any consideration of racial self-concept or identity is deemed productive only when combined with efforts to reduce racism, marginalization and alienation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: White mothers, mixed-parentage children and child welfare.
column12: Barn, Ravinder: U London, Royal Holloway, Dept of Social & Political Science, Egham, England
column13: British Journal of Social Work. Vol.29(2), Apr 1999, pp. 269-284.
column19: The majority of mixed-parentage children who enter the public care system in Britain have a white biological mother and a black African Caribbean father. This paper explores some of the underlying factors which increase the vulnerability of mixed-parentage children. The situation of white single mothers is examined in the context of race, class, gender and location in British society. Empirical findings from two recent research studies (R. Barn, 1993; R. Barn et al, 1997) provide a profile of white single mothers and their children in receipt of social work help and assistance. Some of the factors which necessitate the admission of mixed-parentage children to the public care system include "family relationship breakdown", "physical abuse and neglect", "mother's mental health", and "child beyond parental control". Moreover, financial and material hardship, the absence of the black father and of social support networks, families' experiences of racism, and the nature of social work intervention require serious attention. The multiplicity of risk factors paints a grim picture and presents important challenges in the work of the personal social services. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The polls-trends: Race relations and American youth, 1976-1995.
column9:
Tuch, Steven A

Sigelman, Lee

MacDonald, Jason A
column12: Tuch, Steven A.: George Washington U, Washington, DC, US
column13: Public Opinion Quarterly. Vol.63(1), Spr 1999, pp. 109-148.
column19: Examined American race relations by describing trends in the racial attitudes and interracial experience of Black and White Americans (aged 13-23 yrs old) from 1976-1995. A 2-decade -long series of nationally representative annual surveys of high school seniors was used. Trend data on the closeness and frequency of interracial contact among these groups are presented, along with Ss' evaluation of their own personal experiences with members of other races, endorsement of interracial ties, and degree of concern about racial issues and perceptions of relations between Blacks and Whites. Results show some convergence in the responses of Black and White youths, especially in the 1990s. The authors note that this result is not encouraging because it is the result of Blacks expressing less positive feelings about their interracial experiences and decreasing enthusiasm for interracial contact. Blacks' and Whites' reported behavior toward people of there races has become more similar as lower percentages Black youths form close interracial friendships at the same time that higher percentages of Whites do so. The degrees of concern expressed by Blacks and Whites about race relations as a problem confronting the nation became more similar. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Compared single morning serum testosterone samples from 75 violent, 102 nonviolent, and 17 sexual offenders (aged 15-17 yrs) admitted to a psychiatric assessment center. There were 40 Native Americans, 28 mixed-blood Native Americans, and 126 Caucasians in the group. Results show the violent group had the highest level of testosterone and differed significantly from the nonviolent and sexual offender groups, which were statistically equivalent. The Native American/mixed blood group had significantly higher testosterone than the Caucasian group. Higher testosterone in the combined Native American group may be because this group committed significantly more violent offenses than the Caucasian group. Genetic factors, such as the human leucocyte antigen system, may also be associated with higher testosterone in the combined Native American group. column5: Reflecting on race and family identity: Therapy with a multiracial adoptive family.
column12: Romney, Patricia: Hampshire Coll, Amherst, MA, US
column13: In Session: Psychotherapy in Practice. Vol.1(4), Win 1995, pp. 87-99.
column19: Illustrates the clinical use of a postmodern family therapy that makes race, racism and family identity central themes in therapeutic dialogues with transracial, adoptive families, specifically Black children adopted into White families. The author states that this approach honors ideas that have sprung from the work of postmodern family therapists which can be helpful in fostering the development of family cohesion, multicultural perspectives, and antiracist strategies. An illustration of this approach is presented through the case report of a White mother seeking a Black therapist to counsel and serve as a positive role model for her 15-yr-old adopted daughter who was Black. The client was described as falling in and out of latent hostility and closing herself off from the rest of the family (consisting of the mother, father, 17-yr-old son, and 8-yr-old daughter) all of whom were White. The client was also reported to be experiencing problems at school. This case illustrates that, for the Black adopted child, identity issues are extremely complex and both the identity and family-building process is contaminated by racial prejudice and discrimination. Guidelines are offered for therapists working with multiracial family issues. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Stams, Geert-Jan J. M.: Leiden U, Leiden, Netherlands
column13: Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry. Vol.41(8), Nov 2000, pp. 1025-1037.
column19: The present study (N = 159) provides evidence of an increased risk for behavior problems of infant-placed 7-yr-old internationally, transracially adopted children in the Netherlands. However, parents reported more behavior problems for adopted boys than for adopted girls. Results indicate that about 30% of the adopted children were classified as clinical on the Child Behavior Checklist. Also, results suggest that maternal sensitive responsiveness in adoptive families declines in the transition from early to middle childhood. In contrast to the home setting, the adopted children showed favorable behavioral and socioemotional adjustment at school, while their academic achievement and intelligence were in the normal range or above average. In particular Korean children had high IQs: 31% of these children obtained an intelligence score above 120. It was suggested that adoptive parents seem to offer their children sufficient or even more than average cognitive stimulation. Furthermore, adopted girls scored higher in optimal ego-control, social competence, and peer group popularity than nonadopted girls from the general population: 30% of the adopted girls were rated as popular by their classmates, which compares favorably to the 13% found in the general school population. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Child Psychology & Psychiatry & Allied Disciplines. Vol.38(8), Nov 1997, pp. 1039-1050.
column19: Results from adoption studies suggest that adoptive families may experience special impediments with respect to the developmental progress and outcome of their children. Based on attachment theory, 2 early intervention programs (IPs) were designed to support families in the Netherlands with an internationally adopted child. The IPs aimed at promoting maternal sensitive responsiveness, secure infant-mother attachment relationships, and infant exploratory competence. 90 families with an interracially adopted infant (71 from Sri Lanka and 19 from Korea) were assigned to either a control group or one of 2 IP groups. The 1st IP group (N = 30) received a personal book , which focused on sensitive parenting. The 2nd IP group (N = 30) was provided with the same book and 3 video-feedback sessions at their home. The control group (N = 30) received no IP. In the control group sensitive responsiveness and security of attachment were comparable to outcomes from normative samples. The personal book IP did not bring about change in mothers or infants. However, intervention effects were established upon maternal sensitive responsiveness, infant competence, and infant-mother attachment in the book and video IP group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Provides a critical account of all the available literature on the transracial family placement (TFP) of children. Data were collected from other bibliographies and 2 British databases (CAREDATA and BIDS). The authors provide a background history to TFP, examining placement in the US and the UK, discussing the concept of racial identity, and describing the context of TFP. The authors describe the arguments for or against TFP, which resolve themselves into 2 main stands: the psychological and the political. The authors examine both arguments and present psychological, political, and social questions regarding TFP, including developmental outcomes, survival strategies, and acceptance by minority communities. Unanswered questions, future research strategies, and implications for practice are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Using data for national samples of high school seniors between 1976 and 1992, we examined gender differences in racial attitudes in the US. We found an important effect of gender on "social distance" attitudes: Females expressed more favorable attitudes than males, and this gender difference was significantly greater among Whites than Blacks. The gender effect was not explained by gender differences in interracial friendship, religiosity, or political beliefs. We argue that females' greater concern for others and their focus on relationships foster more favorable racial attitudes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the social structural processes and arrangements related to racial group identification for 2,107 Black American adults, using data collected in 1979-1980 from the National Survey of Black Americans (J. S. Jackson and G. Gurin, 1987). It is argued that primary socialization experiences, particularly parental messages concerning the meaning of being Black, are important in shaping racial identity. Findings support this prediction and suggest that adult relations with family, friends, and community were important in fostering a sense of group identity. Also, integration into mainstream society, as reflected in interracial contact and adult socioeconomic attainment, was associated with less in-group attachment but more positive Black group evaluation. Adult socioeconomic status (SES) and interracial contact bolstered Black group evaluation. Findings support a multidimensional conceptualization of Black identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined differences among 180 Xhosa-speaking Black adolescents, 89 Afrikaans-speaking adolescents of mixed racial descent, 432 English-speaking White, and 117 Afrikaans-speaking White adolescents (aged 13-19 yrs) within a context of social change in South Africa. For comparison purposes, data were also collected from 263 White American adolescents. Ss completed a questionnaire that assessed aspects of these groups' perceptions of themselves (their identities), attitudes toward other racial groups (their prejudices), and beliefs about changes in the socio-political environment in South Africa. Overall, Ss demonstrated generally positive attitudes toward aspects of their own culture and slightly favorable attitudes toward interracial tolerance. They also demonstrated a moderate to positive sense of similarity to other members of their own race. Several statistically significant differences between all the groups were found. Comparative analyses on identity and attitude variables performed with White American adolescents were also statistically significant for all groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Used a sample of 303 White undergraduates in South Africa to cross-validate J. H. Duckitt's (see record 1993-03957-001) subtle racism (SR) scale. The validation of the SR scale was also extended by investigating its association with self-reports of actual interracial behavior. Findings show a high level of internal consistency on the SR scale and a strong correlation with an interracial behavioral intention scale. These findings as well as significant correlations with self-reported interracial behavior support the validity of the SR scale. Findings also indicate a very powerful relationship between anti-Black prejudice and authoritarianism and seem to confirm the SR scale as a more subtle and less direct measure of anti-Black racial prejudice in South Africa. column19: Issues such as the reactions of Black and White adolescents to scenes of violence and interracial conflict in local TV broadcasts were investigated in a research project amongst 97 adolescents from 52 areas in Johannesburg and Pretoria. The correspondence between initial levels of aggression and perceptions regarding fictional and non-fictional program contents, as well as the differences between the perceptions of the Whites and Blacks regarding the program contents, were investigated. It seems that regarding the non-fictional portrayal of violence in the South African media, White adolescents are more desensitized than Black adolescents who live within these conditions every day. Black adolescents may enjoy fictional programs with physical violence more than White adolescents, but they experience more anxiety during exposure to non-fictional portrayals of events similar to the realities in the townships. They therefore tend to rate the level of violence depicted in news broadcasts higher than White adolescents. (Afrikaans abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Compared 218 Black and 68 White nursing home patients with dementia for differences in the prevalence, recognition, and treatment of depression. There were no racial differences in depressive symptoms, but Whites were significantly more likely to receive a diagnosis of "possible depression" and there were few racial differences in clinical, social, or demographic factors associated with depression. Depression was often unrecognized and under-treated in both racial groups; several depression instruments developed for use in dementia had good reliability and validity among Blacks; and there were no significant differences in depressive symptoms or diagnosis between US-born and Caribbean-born Black patients. The absence of any appreciable interracial or intraracial differences in depression symptoms or diagnoses may reflect uniformity in nursing home selection criteria or lessening of mood differences that may have existed before admission. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Factor analyses of responses from 260 White and 81 Black college students in 2 neighboring universities were used to develop contemporary measures of racial attitudes and the degree of interracial contact experienced by Blacks and Whites. Two 20-item racial attitude scales were derived from the factor analyses. For Ss of each race, scores on the attitude measure showed a weak but significant relationship with a 16-item self-report scale of amount of interracial contact experienced, past and present. The relationship of these scales to earlier racial attitude measures was assessed. Second-order factor analyses suggested that Black Ss' racial attitudes were more heterogeneous than those of White Ss. In general, Black Ss tended to show more support for programs designed to increase opportunities for, and recognition of, Blacks. Black Ss also tended to endorse a greater degree of social distance between the races. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: 68 college students interacted with a White or a Black partner (confederate) on an achievement task. Consistent with this prediction, emotional reactions to success were more positive with a Black partner than with a White partner, whereas emotional reactions to failure were more negative with a Black partner than with a White partner. Under conditions of low public self-awareness, Black partners were given less credit for success and blamed more for failure than White partners. This prejudicial pattern of attributions disappeared under conditions of high public self-awareness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: This study explores the process by which interracial spouses construct narratives about their racial histories, identities, and experiences in their relationship together. Ten Black-White couples (aged 23-37 yrs) were interviewed individually and conjointly. The results reflected interracial spouses' experience of their life together their perception of others' perceptions of them, and their unique processes of negotiating racial, gender and class differences. Black spouses, compared with White spouses, demonstrated a greater awareness of and sensitivity to social resistance to interracial couples, and black spouses' familial and personal histories were sometimes relegated to silence in the couple relationship. The author discusses recommendations for marriage and family therapists working with interracial spouses. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column19: Compared functioning in biracial youth to white adolescents and other minority adolescents. Data was drawn from the core sample of the National Longitudinal Survey of Adolescent Health (Add Health). The Add Health public-use data set includes interviews of 6,504 adolescents and 4,600 parents. On the Add Health survey, adolescents were asked multiple questions to assess their racial/ethnic background. Results suggest that biracial/biethnic youth are a particularly vulnerable group in terms of self-reported delinquency, school problems, internalizing symptoms, and self-regard. As a group, they are also more likely to receive some form of psychological intervention. Given these findings and the shortcoming of clinical resources for work with this population, the authors provide a discussion of why biracial youth may be particularly vulnerable from a social constructionist framework and offer several strategies based on narrative family therapy for working with biracial youngsters and their families. The list of items used in making up variables in analyses is appended. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Compared the marriages of 72 couples (mean age 35.65 yrs) with 1 Mexican-American partner and 1 non-Hispanic White American partner, 75 Mexican-American couples (mean age 33.8 yrs), and 66 non-Hispanic White couples (mean age 40.45 yrs). Ss completed the Marital Satisfaction Inventory-Revised and the Acculturation Rating Scale for Mexican Americans. Overall, the interethnic couples were more similar to non-Hispanic White couples than they were to Mexican-American couples across multiple domains, with the latter group indicating modestly higher levels of relationship distress. Among interethnic couples, Mexican-American wives' level of acculturation related significantly to both their own marital- and parental-role orientation and to distress in their relationships with children, as well as to their husbands' marital distress regarding child rearing and the couple's interactions regarding finances. Implications for clinical interventions with Mexican- and White-American interethnic couples are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Ethnic identity development of internationally adopted children and adolescents: Implications for family therapists.
column12: Friedlander, Myrna L.: State U New York, Dept of Educational & Counseling Psychology, Albany, NY, US

column15: American Assn for Marriage & Family Therapy; US
column19: The life story of the internationally adopted child tends to be an emotional one. How the story is told and retold in the family can have lasting consequences for the child's adjustment and well-being. In telling the story, parents are faced with a unique challenge: To what extent is it desirable to encourage their children, who already struggle with identity issues related to adoption, to identify with their cultures of origin? Therapists working on these issues with multiethnic adoptive families can find little guidance in the family systems literature. To fill this gap, the present article reviews the literature on racial/ethnic identity development and the available research on ethnic identification, self-esteem, and the psychological adjustment of cross-ethnically adopted children and adolescents. Implications for practice include developmental considerations, identifying children and families at risk, and recommendations for those in need of intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column19: Examined how characteristics of students and of students' close friends affected the students' college aspirations and attendance, using T. Parsons's (1963) conceptualization of the influence process. An analysis of 20,036 friendship dyads from a national sample of high school students who participated in a longitudinal survey focused on whether differences in the ascribed and achieved characteristics (gender, race, other background characteristics, and track placement in high school) result in different peer-influence processes. Data generally supported the Parsonian framework in that solidarity tended to lead to greater peer influence. The influence of close friends on educational aspirations and outcomes varied with the racial and gender composition of the friendship, and interracial friendships were beneficial to the aspirations of both Black and White Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Discusses the complex organizational, racial, economic, and power issues associated with transracial adoptions in which Black children are placed in the homes of White families. The author discusses the historical and contemporary circumstances surrounding adoption, and analyzes adoption policies in the context of Y. Hasenfeld's (1983) model of human service organizations. Arguments for and against transracial adoption are given, with emphasis on the unique cultural needs of Black children and the desirability of within-race adoption. Agencies must undergo organizational change to better serve Black families willing to adopt children and Black children in need of permanent homes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Conflict Resolution. Vol.31(1), Mar 1987, pp. 192-199.
column19: Investigated factors that enhance the salience of group membership and consequent ingroup bias in 56 White female college students. S dyads were either competitive or interdependent with either White or Black confederate dyads. Ingroup bias was assessed as a function of attraction toward the outgroup (experimental confederates) relative to the ingroup (naive Ss). Data from questionnaires indicate that ingroup bias was greater when groups were competitive than when they were interdependent, and it was greater when the outgroup was Black than when the outgroup was White. Findings suggest an improved methodology for studying interracial conflict and validate the real-world phenomenon of racial bias in a laboratory setting. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The denial of racism: The role of humor, personal experience, and self-censorship. [References].

column13: Journal of Language and Social Psychology. Vol.20(3), Sep 2001, pp. 321-338.
column19: Informed by discursive psychology, this study aimed to identify and explicate those rhetorical maneuvers that function to introduce the issue of race into conversations in the presence of an interracial couple (the first two authors) in the "new South Africa" and to negotiate "race talk" in their presence while distancing the speaker from inferences of racism. Over a period of 2 months, conversations of people with whom the first two authors came into contact were tape-recorded in a variety of social settings without their knowledge. The study revealed that humor, personal experience, and self-censorship were rhetorical maneuvers drawn on extensively in conversations about race. Two possible reasons for this are suggested. First, the conversations involved the interracial, heterosexual couple and other persons of different races, rather than only White speakers, as in many previous studies. Second, unlike previous studies, conversations occurred in naturalistic settings and not in contrived settings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Conducted 2 separate studies to evaluate the items devised for the Attitudes Toward Multiracial Children Scale (AMCS) which measures the adult attitudes concerning the psychosocial development of multiracial children. In the 1st study, an initial version of the AMCS was administered to 250 college students (aged 17-51 yrs) from racially/ethnically diverse backgrounds. The results reveal that scores on the 43-item scale were internally consistent and that 4 factors (i.e., Multiracial Identity, Multiracial Heritage, General Adjustment, and Social Relationships) could be identified. In the 2nd study, the AMCS was revised and administered to a group of 187 Ss. Again, factor analysis yielded a 4-factor solution (i.e., Psychosocial Adjustment Self-Esteem, Multiracial Identity, and Multiracial Heritage). The internal consistency for scores on the resulting 23-item scale was good and 3-week test-retest reliability (n = 15) was .77. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: The Family Journal. Vol.9(1), Jan 2001, pp. 39-42.
column19: Discusses family therapy issues relevant to multiracial and multiethnic marriages and families. Though multiracial marriages are more common in the US than ever before, many multiracial children are faced with discrimination from all races, leaving them to feel like outsiders. It behooves interracial couples to recognize at an early stage in their relationship that offspring from their marriage will not only be racially mixed but also will be required to adjust to being identified as an "other." Interracial couples are confronted with finding ways to capture and maintain a sense of empowerment and cultural dignity. Counseling professionals have a responsibility to prepare individuals to live and work cross-culturally; counselors need to avoid the stereotyping that accompanies many intercultural marriages and families. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Three hypotheses about perceptions of interracial couples were tested. European American respondents read descriptions of interracial or interracial couples and rated the couple and the partners on a variety of dimensions. As predicted, interracial couples were perceived as less compatible than were interracial couples, but only when the other-race partner was African American, not when he or she was Asian American. Being in an interracial marriage had stronger effects on perceptions of men than women, and different effects on perceptions of minority group men than majority group men on dimensions of perceived racial identity and comfort with same-race others. However, contrary to predictions, there were no differences in perceptions of interracial couples. Implications for future research on the consequences of perceptions on actual characteristics of interracial couples are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Discursive constructions of racial boundaries and self-segregation on campus.
column12: Buttny, Richard: Syracuse U, Syracuse, NY, US
column13: Journal of Language and Social Psychology. Vol.18(3), Sep 1999, pp. 247-268.
column19: This discourse analysis examines North American college students' discursive constructions of racial boundaries, difference, and voluntary segregation on campus. Participants watched the documentary, Racism 101, at home with others and immediately afterwards tape-recorded their discussion about the video and related race matters. None of the participants disagreed with the existence of separateness on campus, they did, however, offer different accounts and positions. Some criticized such self-segregation while others justified it as understandable due to commonalities or differences. Still other individuals were ambivalent or avowed conflicting accounts, which seemed to reflect a dilemma, such as wanting more meaningful interracial contact but being unable to know how to achieve it. African Americans cited preserving group identity as a justification for boundaries. The findings fit with racial formation theory in that participants are partaking in different discourses so as to articulate, explore, or criticize different positions on interracial matters. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the extent to which romanticism (i.e., an orientation toward the welfare of one's romantic relationship dyad) is reflected in patterns of interpersonal resource exchange (i.e., the reciprocity of affection and respect as interpersonal commodities or resources) in a sample of 91 interracial couples. Results indicated that consistent with predictions, (1) men and women in interracial relationships as a whole exchanged affection as well as respect at significant levels; (2) a romantic model of interpersonal resource exchange provided a significantly better fit to data for an African American-Anglo and other interracial couples significantly better than did a core model of interpersonal resource exchange; and (3) means and correlations among romanticism and individuals' giving of interpersonal resources did not differ significantly across Black male-White female and White male-Black female couples. Implications for the study of personal relationship processes among interracial and intraracial couples are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Snowden, Lonnie R.: U California, Berkeley, CA, US
column13: Journal of Black Psychology. Vol.25(1), Feb 1999, pp. 36-47.
column19: Examined an acculturation scale designed for use in the African American population. Consisting of 10 items presented in Likert-scale format, the scale asked about: race-related cultural and media preferences (music, radio, television); racial balance in contexts of social interaction (friends, church congregation, parties, neighborhoods); race-related attitudes (relying on relatives for help, desirability of interracial marriage); and degree of comfort in interaction with Whites vs Blacks. Responses were gathered from a national probability sample of 923 African Americans (aged 18+ yrs). The data generally indicated an African American orientation within the sample but demonstrated notable variation on all items. The scale showed good reliability (internal consistency). Results from factor analysis pointed toward unidimensional structure. Evaluation of construct validity by examining sociodemographic correlates provided notable evidence of validity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial dating: Evidence from personal advertisements.
column12: Yancey, George: U Wisconsin, Whitewater, WI, US
column13: Journal of Family Issues. Vol.19(3), May 1998, pp. 334-348.
column19: Caste and exchange theories predict that Whites who enter into interracial relationships seek to trade their racial status for relational capital (i.e., physical attractiveness, financial security). Racial minorities, on the other hand, are likely to trade such assets for higher racial status. Whether race is a valued quality determines whether individuals will trade racial capital for other types of relational assets. However, previous research concerning interracial relationships has concentrated on couples who are already established; thus, the existing literature is of limited use in examining the initial decisions of individuals choosing to date interracially. In this article, content analysis of personal advertisements from magazines are reported. The mean age of male and female respondents was 38.62 and 40.8 respectively. It was found that race is insignificant as to whether the advertisers desired or sought physical attractiveness or financial security. Increased availability, not factors predicted by caste and exchange theories, is more explanatory as to why individuals enter into interracial relationships. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the asymmetrical relationship between attitudes toward interracial marriage and social dominance orientation across 4 ethnic groups in the US. Differences in these correlations were explained with the ideological asymmetry hypothesis, a specific feature of social dominance theory, which asserts that the relationship between attitudes regarding hierarchy-maintaining social practices and antiegalitarian social values will be more positive among members of high-status groups than among members of low-status groups. Ss were 618 Euro-Americans, 475 Hispanics, 282 Asian Americans, and 474 Blacks. Using opposition to interracial marriage and dating as a case of a hierarchy-maintaining social attitude, the data were found to support the ideological asymmetry hypothesis. With almost no exceptions, the correlations between social dominance orientation and antimiscegenation attitudes were significantly more positive within a high-status ethnic group vis-a-vis a given low-status ethnic group than they were within a low-status ethnic group vis-a-vis a given high-status ethnic group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: The Family Journal. Vol.5(1), Jan 1997, pp. 69-75.
column19: As the population of our society becomes increasingly diverse, there is a growing concern in our profession about the importance of culture in psychotherapy, counseling, and family therapy. Unfortunately, much of the literature treats cultural differences as a handicapping condition either for the therapist or for the clients. It is an unknown, something to adjust to, or something to overcome. The purpose of this article is to (a) briefly describe some aspects of culture as context in therapy; (b) state assumptions that undergird the development of techniques that can be developed to use cultural myths and traditions to bring about therapeutic change; and (c) describe some sample techniques developed by the author to illustrate how such techniques can be invented, adapted, and applied. Of course, the counselor first must gather some information about the cultural background of his or her clients. In these days of social acceptance of interethnic, interfaith, and interracial marriages, familie's cultural backgrounds can be more complex than in more homogenous societies. In these times of rapid change and the incredible mix of cultures in our society, cultures are themselves rapidly evolving in form and substance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: The Journal of Early Adolescence. Vol.17(1), Feb 1997, pp. 51-66.
column19: The Woodcock Youth Development Project (YDP) aims to reduce alcohol, tobacco, and drug (ATD) use among adolescents. The YDP targets risk factors that predispose youth to substance abuse and aims to improve problem-solving and coping skills, to raise awareness about dangers of substance abuse, and to improve self-perception by increasing academic achievement and fostering a sense of cultural pride. These outcome variables were assessed for 161 program participants and 292 controls (aged 6-14 yrs). Participation in the YDP was shown to reduce the incidence of drug use. Among 6-9 yr olds, participation in the YDP led to improved interracial relations and marginally boosted self-esteem and knowledge about ATD use. However, the program failed to produce improvements in these attitudinal risk factors among 10-14 yr old participants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Comments on R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' review (see record 1997-07307-001) on transracial adoption of African-American children. The policy issues and the methodological limitations of research on transracial adoption is appreciated. The review provides adequate evidence on personal self-esteem of adopted and non-adopted children. However, there is a lack of clarity in the nature of group identity among the 2 groups. Adoption research is inadequate with respect to the examination of group identity. Race per se has not been considered as an important aspect of Black children's lives in the review. Therefore, there is an ambiguity about the role of White parents in their adoptive children's lives. Transracial adoption is discussed in a broader child welfare context. Practical alternatives are provided to refine the concepts of self esteem and racial identity and their relationship to racial socialization efforts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Transracial adoption: Unanswered theoretical and conceptual issues.
column12: Goddard, Lawford L.: Inst for the Advanced Study of Black Family Life & Culture, Oakland, CA, US
column13: Journal of Black Psychology. Vol.22(2), May 1996, pp. 273-281.
column19: Comments on R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' review (see record 1997-07307-001) on transracial adoption of African-American children. Evidence presented about the known effects of transracial adoption is limited, contradictory, and imprecise. It is difficult to separate opinions and subjective feelings that are unsupported by empirical data from scientific facts that have been validated by empirical data. More subtle effects, such as individualism, cultural denigration, racial separation, and self-hate, are not examined. The weakness of transracial adoption literature is the notion of cultural homogeneity, and the nature of cross cultural research. The development and utilization of a Black developmental perspective, understanding of the influence of cultural features in adoption, and methodological consistency, are 3 general areas of concern. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Criticizes R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' review (see record 1997-07307-001) of transracial adoption of African-American children. The organization of the review into cross-sectional and longitudinal research is commendable. However, suggestions should have been offered for African American researchers to validate their claims and for transracial adoptive parents to help in the better adjustment of African-American children. Attitudes about research in the African-American community needs to be discussed. Their conclusion that the data support transracial adoption is erroneous, as the research is statistically flawed and racially biased. More information could also have been given on legal aspects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Comments on R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' review (see record 1997-07307-001) on transracial adoption (TAD) of African-American children, with regard to the societal context of the researcher, as well as experimenter and subject biases in such research. Most American researchers have a Eurocentric frame of reference so they do not expect to find problems with TAD. Similarly, in a post-integration society, families tend to deny racism or any problems related to the transracially adopted child. Based on the limited amount of empirical investigation, there is not enough evidence at present to support or counteract TAD, therefore, no conclusions can be drawn. A system should be implemented to protect the interests of African American children, to acculturate them, and monitor their development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Comments on R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' review (see record 1997-07307-001) on transracial adoption of African-American children. The failure of the African-American opponents of transracial adoption to provide adequate empirical support for their beliefs has resulted in judicial decisions favoring transracial adoption. African-American scholars often face challenges while conducting research on White families. Such considerations have implications for their ability to receive research grants to conduct the type of research relevant to their interest. African-American researchers have developed appropriate research tools to assess the culturally sensitive child outcomes. Issues on childhood experiences of the transracial adoptees need to be investigated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Argues that research on transracial adoption (TAD) of Black children by White families is biased and racist, in the light of R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' review (see record 1997-07307-001) on TAD of African-American children. No justifiable evidence against TAD has been found. Research studies have not followed standard research procedures for comparison or longitudinal studies. Research must be conducted on African-American and bi-racial adults who were transracially adopted by Whites because current research fails to address the psychological harm to the adoptees. Research by African-American researchers should address racial self-definitions, interactions with Black co-workers and neighbors, social distance with Blacks, racial identity of mates and social membership. Innovative family support programs should be initiated for the biological families. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Comments on R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' review (see record 1997-07307-001) on transracial adoption of African-American children. An appropriate process in dealing with major psychological issues is the deconstruction-reconstruction-construction approach (D. A. Azibo, 1988). The critical analysis began with the deconstruction of the transracial adoption literature but did not address the reconstruction and construction aspects of the process. As a result, the conclusions miss the essential and real issues of transracial adoption, which concern the reason that led to the creation of the transracial adoption concept and the priority of successfully socializing African children in the society. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Penn, Michael L.: Franklin & Marshall Coll, Dept of Psychology, Lancaster, PA, US
column13: Journal of Black Psychology. Vol.22(2), May 1996, pp. 240-245.
column19: Comments on R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' review (see record 1997-07307-001) on transracial adoption (TAD) of African American children. TAD is viewed through an international human rights perspective. The loss of cultural identity constitutes significant harm that should be of concern to state and national governments. TAD is proliferated because of the failure of the state to provide opportunities for African American parents to raise their children in safe and economically viable communities. Instead of comparing intra-racial and TADs, research should focus on TAD and orphaned nonadoptees. The psychological and behavioral functioning of the Whites should not provide the standard against which all other racial and ethnic groups can be judged. Efforts should be made to incorporate children's perceptions of the impact of TAD on the quality of life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Comments on R. Alexander and C. M. Curtis' (see record 1997-07307-001) review of empirical studies of transracial adoption of African American children. The conclusion that there are no harmful effects of such adoptions is premature, as certain crucial factors are still overlooked. Developmental status of the adoptee is an important determining factor for positive outcome of transracial adoption. Alexander and Curtis reflected inferred assumptions that are questionable. Lack of empirical evidence may not be indicative of no harm but may be due to the use of methodology that does not reflect the harm. An exploration of the contexts of families engaging in transracial adoption and the centrality of ethnic identity to self identity is essential. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Critically evaluates the empirical literature on transracial adoption of African American children, to understand the impact of parenting by White families upon these children's mental health. Studies show that although there were no differences in these children's level of self esteem, differences were found in the extent of racial identity. All children engaged in search behaviors. Transracial adoption was no more likely to be unstable than in-racial adoption. Longitudinal studies show that social environment played a crucial role in IQ development. Most studies reveal that African American children had adequate adjustment and were not psychologically harmed by these placements. Methodological issues like sampling methods, emphasis on statistical significance, and external validity of the studies are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the effects of vernacular Black English (BE) and code-switching (CDS) on interracial perceptions among 130 African-American college students (aged 17-27 yrs), including 63 male Ss and 67 female Ss. Ss were assigned to 1 of 3 groups: Group 1 heard a BE speaking person, Group 2 heard a CDS speaker, and Group 3 heard a Standard English (SE) speaking person. Ss completed an Interpersonal Evaluation Inventory for the respective speaker. Two additional items assessed how much the S would want to get to know the model and work with that model on a committee. The SE model was rated as more likable than the BE or CDS model. Male Ss rated models as more likable than did female Ss, regardless of vernacular. Ss expressed a greater desire to work with the SE model than with the BE or CDS model. Male Ss expressed a greater desire to get to know the speakers and to work with them on a committee. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Used the "matched-guise" technique to test the hypothesis that 37 Black and 37 White Ss would rate Blacks lower than they rated White accented speakers and would rate ghetto Black (GB) accents lower than they would rate middle-class Black (MB) or middle-class White (MW) accents on personality characteristics. Ss listened to a prerecorded reading representing the 3 accents and rated personality on 16 dimensions. Using a 3-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), results indicate a significant accent main effect and a significant population by accent interaction. GB accents were rated lower than MB or MW accents by White Ss, Black Ss rated GB accents no differently than they rated MB or MW accents, and White Ss did not rate MB accents significantly differently from MW accents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Cultural mistrust and mental health services for African Americans: A review and meta-analysis. [References].
column12: Whaley, Arthur L.: New York State Psychiatric Inst, Dept of Social Psychiatry, New York, NY, US
column13: The Counseling Psychologist. Vol.29(4), Jul 2001, pp. 513-531.
column19: The underutilization of mental health services by African Americans may be due, in part, to their cultural mistrust. The purpose of this article is twofold: (a) to conduct a meta-analysis of the correlations between cultural mistrust in 3,030 African Americans and their attitudes and behaviors related to mental health services use, comparing them to the correlations between cultural mistrust and measures relevant to other psychosocial domains, and (b) to test some methodological hypotheses about the Cultural Mistrust Inventory, the most popular measure of cultural mistrust. The meta-analysis suggests that the negative effects of Blacks' cultural mistrust in interracial situations are not unique to counseling and psychotherapy but represent a broader perspective. The meta-analysis also suggests that development of the Cultural Mistrust Inventory with a male-only college sample did not compromise its external validity. The implications of these results for the provision of mental health services to African Americans are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Convergence between racial and political identities: Boundary erasure or aversive racism?
column9:
Coover, Gail E

Godbold, Linda C
column12: Coover, Gail E.: U Wisconsin, Madison, WI, US
column13: Communication Research. Vol.25(6), Dec 1998, pp. 669-688.
column19: Examined the relationship between race group membership and political orientation with respect to the accommodation of White identity in media representations of Blacks. 182 White undergraduates watched a brief video featuring a pair of commentators-either a White liberal and a White conservative, a White liberal and a Black conservative, or a Black liberal and a White conservative. The portrayal of the relationship (agreement, disagreement) was also manipulated. Preferences for the racial outgroup were a function of the racial/political pairings. The dimension of race dominated the dimension of political orientation in participants' preferences for the outgroup and their judgments of similarity between interracial pairs of commentators. Results are consistent with aversive racism and previously untested assertions about White viewers' preferences for accommodating representations of Blacks. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined interracial similarity of the leadership dimensions Initiating Structure and Consideration, by performing a factor analysis on the responses of 224 Black and White male naval recruits to the Supervisory Behavior Description questionnaire. Coefficients of factorial congruence were computed between the factor structures of 2-factor solutions for Black and White Ss. As hypothesized, no differences were found. The leadership dimensions were stable with respect to race. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Contemporary measures of attitudes toward Blacks.
column12: Byrnes, Deborah A.: Utah State U, Logan, US
column13: Educational and Psychological Measurement. Vol.48(1), Spr 1988, pp. 107-118.
column19: Adapted E. S. Bogardus's (1933) Social Distance Scale and the Social Situation Scale by N. Kogan and J. F. Downey (1956), 2 measures of non-Black students' attitudes toward Blacks to measure racial attitudes in contemporary society. Ss were 286 college students. The resulting Social Scale contained factors involving intimate and nonintimate social relationships. The Social Scenarios Scale contained 3 dimensions involving pejorative remarks about Blacks, interracial intimate relations, and job/housing injustices. Ss indicated feeling less comfortable in intimate relations with Blacks and were least likely to respond in an antidiscriminatory fashion to racist remarks or intimacy scenarios regarding Blacks. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: A large number of adolescents of interracial ancestry (parents comprising various combinations of African-American, American Indian/Alaska Native, European-American, Chinese, Filipino, Hispanic, Japanese, Korean, Puerto Rican, Samoan, and Tongan ancestry) were contrasted with a monoracial European-American sample in the degree to which they reported symptoms of depression, anxiety, conduct disorder/aggression, and substance abuse. The adolescents of interracial ancestry were subdivided into three groups in terms of parental ancestry: both parents of interracial ancestry, one parent of interracial and the other of monoracial ancestry, and both parents of monoracial but different ancestries. The interracial ancestry groups did not differ significantly from one another or from the European American sample in terms of symptom scores. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Racial preference and biculturality in biracial preschoolers.
column12: Johnson, Deborah J.: U Wisconsin, Madison, US
column13: Merrill-Palmer Quarterly. Vol.38(2), Apr 1992, pp. 233-244.
column19: Racial preferences of 16 biracial children were compared with the preferences of 28 Black and 18 White children. Findings from the Preschool Racial Attitude Measure II (PRAM II) indicate that mean preferences of biracial Ss were not significantly different from either of their monoracial cohorts. However, mean preferences of Black and White Ss were significantly different, such that White Ss were more pro-White than Black Ss. PRAM II scores for biracial Ss were primarily based on the combination of positive affect toward White and negative affect toward Black. Although Black Ss made negative choices toward Black, their racial attitude score was dependent on the balance of positive choices for Black and White. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Cross-cultural racism in South Africa--dead or alive? [References].
column12: Slabbert, Andre: Cape Technikon, Faculty of Management, Cape Town, South Africa
column13: Social Behavior and Personality. Vol.29(2), 2001, pp. 125-132.
column15: Society for Personality Research; New Zealand
column19: Race, discrimination, prejudice and stereotypes remain emotive words in numerous societies around the globe. A non-racial world can exist only if theories and postulations regarding race are rendered irrelevant. Subsequent to the 1994 South African elections, it became imperative to do this. This artificially polarized society had the opportunity to develop racial unity and hegemony. To assess the relative status of racist paradigms in students, 265 students completed a questionnaire which attempted to measure ethnic group identification and particular interracial attitudes. Significant indications of racist stereotypes were found in all racial groups, with a strong bias towards Ss' own racial groups. The primary conclusion is that racist perceptions and stereotypes remain very prevalent and active in the South African society. The author proposes a number of recommendations to address the issue, e.g., school curricula should include particular components to develop greater understanding/sensitivity of other racial groups; social emphasis should be on cultural solidarity rather than on cultural diversity; national governments should contribute funding towards setting up an international forum to study/combat racism, etc. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
