column19: (from the chapter) Addresses the needs of multiracial children. The author defines and clarifies terms and explains racial identity classification of multiracial children. The history of interracial families in the US, the "one drop rule," and demographic trends are discussed. Prevailing myths are examined and advantages and disadvantages of a multiracial status are discussed. Literature on identity development of multiracial children and models of multiracial identity development are presented. Community imperatives to promote healthy identity development of multiracial children are delineated. Included are those by school counselors and other helping professionals, parents, and school (including activities and curriculum), and educational personnel. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race, school integration, and friendship segregation in America. [References].

column12: Moody, James: Ohio State U, Dept of Sociology, Columbus, OH, US
column13: American Journal of Sociology. Vol.107(3), Nov 2001, pp. 679-716.
column19: Integrated schools may still be substantively segregated if friendships fall within race. Drawing on contact theory, this study tests whether school organization affects friendship segregation in a national sample of adolescent friendship networks. 90,118 7-12th grade students completed interviews. The results support contact theory on two dimensions. First, the author found a strong and generally positive relation between heterogeneity and friendship segregation, though the relation is not linear. This finding suggests that simple exposure does not promote integration. Second, the author found that interracial mixing within settings that capture the positive elements of contact theory (status equality and interdependent action) promotes friendship integration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A test of the racial contact hypothesis from a natural experiment: Baseball's all-star voting as a case. [References].
column11: Hanssen, F. Andrew: Montana State U, Dept of Agricultural Economics & Economics, Bozeman, MT, US, 59717
column12: Hanssen, F. Andrew: Montana State U, Dept of Agricultural Economics & Economics, Bozeman, MT, US
column13: Social Science Quarterly. Vol.82(1), Mar 2001, pp. 51-66.
column19: The contact hypothesis is difficult to test because of selectivity bias: the direction of causation between contact and attitudes cannot be definitively determined. Selectivity bias can be avoided given a sample for which, for reasons unrelated to group member attitudes, whites divide into groups that differ systematically in the amount of contact they have with blacks. This paper uses a natural experiment that provides such a test: All-Star voting by baseball players versus fans. The average white player has more substantial and persistent contact with African Americans (as teammates) than does the average white fan, and the contact hypothesis would thus predict that players will discriminate less than fans, all else equal. Logistic, ordinary-least-squares (OLS), and tobit regressions are used to analyze the effect of candidate race on votes received, controlling for other factors. No evidence is found of a differential in discrimination related to the amount of contact, although discrimination by both groups is found to decline between 1970 and 1980. The contact hypothesis is not supported; exogenous variations in the amount of interracial contact are not associated with difference in levels of discrimination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Exploring racial variations in the spousal sex ratio of killing. [References].
column11: Regoeczi, Wendy C.: Cleveland State U, Dept of Sociology, 1860 East 22nd Street, Cleveland, OH, US, 44114-4435
column12: Regoeczi, Wendy C.: Cleveland State U, Cleveland, OH, US
column13: Violence and Victims. Vol.16(6), Dec 2001, pp. 591-606.
column19: Examines differences in the social situation of intimate partners as an explanation of racial differences in the female to male ratio of spousal homicides in Canada. An analysis of homicide data from 1961-1983 generated by the Canadian Centre for Justice Statistics revealed that the ratio of women killing their husbands to men killing their wives was highest for Aboriginals and lowest for Blacks, with the ratio for Whites falling in between. The possible sources of racial differences in this ratio included the proportion of couples (1) in common-law relationships, (2) who are co-residing as opposed to being separated, and (3) for whom there is a substantial age disparity between the partners. These factors were related to the spousal sex ratio of killing more generally. An exploration of interracial homicide patterns and racial variation in jealousy-motivated homicides was also undertaken. The findings revealed that controlling for the above factors substantially reduced the importance of race in predicting the gender of the homicide victim. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: The presence of intercultural marriages and intimacy is clear and expanding in societies throughout the globe. Cultural groups tend generally to have a more accepting attitude toward couples that have chosen mates outside their immediate ethnic or cultural identity. The focus of this paper addresses some of the issues, challenges, and opportunities that exist as individuals choose persons for intimacy or marriage beyond the continental divide. A pyramidal model is introduced to assist the reader in understanding the framework upon which this manuscript is based. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column19: Studied the personal ethnic identity of 13 18-33 yr old people of multi-cultural/ethnic/racial parentage living in Australia, and examined connections between their identity resolution and social relationships. Results of semi-structured interviews are discussed in terms of the search for an ethnic identity, sources of influence on ethnic identity, and orientation to the ethnicity of others. From the findings, hypotheses are formulated concerning the relationship between identity resolution and ease of bridging ethnic divides in social contexts. Implications of the findings for social work practice and the challenge of enhancing social cohesion are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the extent to which social work students desire a multicultural education, whether social work students have a distinctive multicultural stance, and factors that influence a student's multicultural predisposition. 437 undergraduate students (aged 17-51 yrs) completed surveys concerning: (1) degree of acceptance of multicultural goals; (2) social work status; (3) liberalism; (4) amount of interracial contact; (5) egalitarianism; (6) stereotyping; (7) racism denial; and (8) racial resentment. Results show that subjects (Ss) demonstrated partial support of multicultural goals. Most Ss agreed that multicultural information should be used in the university setting and that the university should hire more minority faculty and staff. However, this support was conditional for many Ss: a substantial number favored the availability of multicultural classes, but were reluctant to make these classes a graduation requirement. Only a quarter of Ss felt personally compelled to learn more about cultural diversity. Ss' perceptions were not static, becoming more positive toward a multicultural education after they initiated interracial exchanges and completed a social diversity class. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Diversity and the influence of friendship groups in college. [References].
column11: Antonio, Anthony Lising: Stanford U, School of Education, Stanford, CA, US, 94305-3084, aantonio@stanford.edu
column12: Antonio, Anthony Lising: Stanford U, Stanford Inst for Higher Education Research, Stanford, CA, US
column13: Review of Higher Education: Journal of the Association for the Study of Higher Education. Vol.25(1), Fal 2001, pp. 63-89.
column19: Examined the following questions: (1) To what extent did students perceive racial balkanization on a diverse campus, and to what extent did their closest friendships reflect balkanization? and (2) How influential were these friendship groups in student development of racial understanding, cultural awareness, and interracial interaction? 677 college students were surveyed about experiences within the friendship group, descriptions of the group's characteristics, and the group's racial composition. Multiple regression analysis was used to assess the relative influence of friendship group characteristics on engaging in interracial interaction outside the friendship group, students' commitment to racial understanding, and gains in cultural awareness. A discrepancy was found between perceptions of racial balkanization and the relatively high degree of interracial friendship among students. The results also demonstrated how diversity might influence student values and learning. Variables in the regression models are appended. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Identity development across the lifespan: A biracial model. [References].
column12: Hall, Ronald E.: Michigan State U, School of Social Work, David Walker Research Inst, East Lansing, MI, US
column13: The Social Science Journal. Vol.38(1), 2001, pp. 119-123.
column19: Traditional concepts of identity emphasize race to the exclusion of life span criteria. Race based models ignore the human behavior of biracial Americans in their social environment. Conversely, a substantial portion of the scholarly literature advocates social experience rather than physiological attributes as keystone to individual identity development. In the aftermath biracial Americans are conflicted. In an effort to insure their psychic health, scholars and practitioners must inculcate an identity development across the life span model to accommodate the nation's increasing level of ethnic and racial miscegenation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Race experts: How racial etiquette, sensitivity training, and new age therapy hijacked the civil rights revolution.
column12: Lasch-Quinn, Elisabeth: Syracuse U, Syracuse, NY, US
column13: (2001). Race experts: How racial etiquette, sensitivity training, and new age therapy hijacked the civil rights revolution. xviii, 267 pp. New York, NY, US: W W Norton & Co; US.
column19: (from the jacket) This book looks at how we capsized racial progress in the quest for self-esteem. It uncovers the hidden trajectory and terms of our thinking about race relations since the 1960s. Since segregation's dismantling, intense anxiety has surrounded interracial encounters, and a movement has arisen to engineer social relations through the specification of elaborate codes of conduct. Diversity training in business, multicultural education in schools, and cross-cultural psychotherapy have created a world of prescriptions. The author carefully analyzes the teachings of these self-appointed "experts" and offers a bold and searching analysis of the origins of their ideas in the human potential movement and the radical milieu of the 1960s. Casting race primarily as an issue of etiquette or therapy, rather than of justice or equality, has had dire consequences for American life, diverting attention from the deeper problems of poverty, violence, and continued inequality and discrimination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A qualitative study of adolescents' reactions to being biethnic Mexican American/Euro-American.
column12: Martinez, Laura: California School Of Professional Psychology - San Diego, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(5-B), Nov 2001, pp. 2492.
column19: A qualitative design was employed to explore and describe the reactions of 14-18 year-old adolescents to being biethnic Mexican American/Euro-American. A normal population was studied, and all of the participants were from intact homes where both biological parents were present. This study is important due to the lack of research specifically examining this unique biethnic subgroup. In-depth, semi-structured interviews were conducted with eight adolescent participants along with one or both of their biological parents. Twelve major categories and one minor category emerged from the data analysis based on the constant comparative method described by Maykut and Morehouse (1994). Major categories included: (1) Descriptions of others' perceptions of participants' ethnicity(ies); (2) Ethnic/racial category endorsement; (3) People/experiences impacting (bi)ethnic identity; (4) Positive feelings about biethnicity; (5) Others' questions about participants' ethnic heritage and participants' responses to inquiries; (6) (Bi)ethnic identity as contextual; (7) Perceived benefits of biethnicity; (8) Openness to having dating partners or life partners of any ethnicity; (9) Pressure from oneself or others to identify ethnically with one ethnic group; (10) Desire to become more proficient in the Spanish language; (11) Questioning one's 'Mexicanness'; and (12) Exposure to prejudiced comments against Mexican heritage individuals. The minor category consisted of feelings of social marginalization. The categories highlighted that the biethnic participants have been faced with unique challenges and experiences as adolescents with Mexican and European heritage. The categories were compared and contrasted to the existing literature on biethnicity. These data substantiate major points in the existing literature addressing biethnicity, and also add to it important factors that are potentially relevant for biethnic Mexican American/Euro-American adolescents. The results of this study indicate that the experiences affecting the (bi)ethnic identity of the Mexican American/Euro-American adolescent are complex, interactive, and ever-evolving. This dynamic process is influenced by multiple factors, including numerous personal, familial, and social variables that are interrelated. Clinical implications were also discussed and suggestions for future research were presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Body rocking as an indicator of disordered attachment in internationally adopted children.
column12: Martinez, Dana L.: U Hartford, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(4-B), Oct 2001, pp. 2067.
column19: This dissertation hypothesizes that body rocking in a particular population, i.e., adoptees from international orphanages, can indicate changes in children's mental representations of objects and relationships and, therefore, may be a measure of poor attachment abilities. The importance of early identification and treatment for these children should not be underestimated. With the growth of international adoptions and a decreasing number of children adopted as newborns, the likelihood of early deprivation is more present. As reported by Bowlby, as children grow older the effects of early maternal deprivation become more pronounced. Various research papers have been previously published on this subject with various hypotheses such as children's inability to make relationships, a history of institutionalization, or multiple foster care placements as being a cause or central feature leading to the development of childhood behavioral disturbances. Other researchers found that the attachment patterns formed in infancy tended to persist across time and had implications for later emotional and behavioral functioning. Given that important prosocial values, attitudes, and behaviors may be learned in the context of secure attachment relationships, empathy, caring, compassion, kindness, and morality, the implications for insecurely attached internationally adopted children are not only personal and familial, but societal as well. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The process of racial and ethnic identity development and search for self in adult Korean transracial adoptees.
column12: Lieberman, Kira: Massachusetts School Of Professional Psychology, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(4-B), Oct 2001, pp. 2066.
column19: This qualitative research project explored the way in which individuals adopted from Korea by Caucasian parents integrate their racial and ethnic identity with their sense of self and the changes in identity that occur as they move through the life stages of development. While quantitative and qualitative research has been conducted on the psychological effects of transracial adoption, little is known about the process of racial and ethnic identity development in transracial adoptees across the lifespan. Nine focused interviews were conducted with adult Korean adoptees ranging in age from twenty-one to forty-seven years. Seven prominent themes emerged from an analysis of the interview transcripts. The data indicated that some of the participants identify racially as Korean but are firmly rooted in the American culture. Others have developed a strong Korean ethnic identity as adults. Several factors played a role in precipitating an interest in learning about the Korean culture for some of the participants. These included personality, individual development, independence from one's adoptive family, age at time of adoption, and contact with Asian-Americans. The implications of Korean adoptees achieving a strong ethnic identity remain unclear. However, the results of this study support previous findings that racial and cultural identity is fluid, and that a reworking of one's identity may occur as one develops and encounters new experiences. Clinical applications and future research possibilities were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Two mothers and their child: A multimethod study of parenting bonds and division of labor within lesbian adoptive families.
column12: Bennett, Susanne: Smith Coll School For Social Work, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(4-A), Oct 2001, pp. 1582.
column19: This study examined the attachment process between lesbian co-parents and their internationally adopted children, focusing on the hierarchy of the mother-child attachment bonds. Variables affecting these relationships (e.g., division of labor, time spent with child, parental legal status) were examined. The sample consisted of 15 lesbian couples with 1 adopted child of pre-school age (14 transracial adoptions; 5 countries represented). Findings from 30 individual qualitative interviews were triangulated with statistical analysis of demographic data and a self-report questionnaire that compared division of labor between the partners. All children developed attachments to both mothers, but 80% had an initial primary bond to one mother, despite shared parenting and division of labor between the partners. "Quality" of maternal caretaking was a salient contributing factor, and no significant relationship existed between primary parenting and parental legal status. Complex ethical dilemmas existed in the adoption process, and racial-ethnic differences compounded the family's diversity challenges. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Relationships among racial identity, stress, values, and marital/relationship satisfaction of black-white interracial couples.
column12: Lovstuen, Brenda Catherine: U Missouri - Kansas City, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(3-A), Sep 2001, pp. 924.
column19: This study of interracial marriage was expanded to include members of interracial relationships who are living together but not married. This study was designed to examine the relationships among the marital or relationship satisfaction, stress, racial identity, and cultural values of Black-White interracial couples. Black-White interracial couples who were married and/or living together completed measures of racial identity development, stress, marital/relationship satisfaction, and cultural values, and responded to a demographic questionnaire. The main research questions that the study sought to answer concerned the relationship of marital/relationship satisfaction to stress, racial identity, and cultural values. Also of interest were whether stress acts to mediate the relationships between marital/relationship satisfaction and racial identity and between satisfaction and cultural values. Results indicated that stress and marital or relationship satisfaction were negatively related, as were stress and one subscale of cultural values. Stress did not mediate the relationship between satisfaction and racial identity or between satisfaction and values. Qualitative responses included experiencing negative reactions from others, as well as some benefits to being in an interracial relationship. Implications for counseling members of interracial relationships and future research directions are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Women's racial identity development: College student perceptions of an antiracism intervention.
column12: Turner, Bridget Denise: U Maryland Coll Park, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(3-A), Sep 2001, pp. 886.
column19: The purpose of this study was to describe the meaning students make of their racial identities and to determine if and how a long-term antiracism intervention influenced students' racial identity development. This research relied on qualitative case study design (Yin, 1984) and program evaluation methods (Guba & Lincoln, 1981; Weiss, 1998) to examine the influence of an antiracism intervention on the development of students' racial identities. The antiracism intervention was selected because it was a "critical case" (Yin, 1984) that specifically reflected the components identified in the literature as influential in students' racial identity development (college climate, antiracism curriculum, interracial dialogue, safe environment, and interracial contact). Data obtained from attitude scales, in-depth interviews, a focus group, and documents (e.g. writing assignments and journal entries) were analyzed to create themes about students' racial attitudes, students' racial interactions, and sources of changes in students' racial identity development upon conclusion of the antiracism intervention. Data suggested changes in students' attitudes, such as increased awareness and knowledge of racial issues, racial groups, and race relations. Changes in students' racial interactions involved increased comfort and confidence discussing race with people of various racial groups and increased desire to establish interracial friendships. Some unintended effects of the antiracism intervention included reinforcing students' stereotypes and encouraging students to limit their racial interactions. In addition, various non-intervention factors complemented the intervention's influence on students' racial identity development. Theoretical implications for this study relate to using an antiracism intervention to test what specific factors may influence students' racial identity development and how those factors may influence that development. Implications for research address the difficulty of measuring and securing rich data on racial identity development. Implications for practice relate to approaching the complex issue of racial identity development in a holistic manner. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The relationship of community attitudes toward battered wives to the race of the victim and the racial mix of the couple.
column12: Meade, Linda Lee: U Missouri - Saint Louis, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(2-B), Aug 2001, pp. 1091.
column19: Non-white battered women, and victims in mixed-race relationships, may encounter more negative attitudes than their white or same-race counterparts. Attitudes toward battered wives, as related to the race of the victim and the racial mix of the couple, were examined in the present study. It was predicted that participants (a) would view the black victim differently than the white victim, and (b) would view the victim in an interracial couple differently than the victim in a same race couple. In addition, it was predicted that (c) participants who had been victims of domestic violence would have more positive attitudes toward the victim, and (d) participants would have more negative attitudes toward victims of their own race. Two hundred and ninety-four participants read domestic violence scenarios and viewed obscured photographs in which the race of the victim and the racial mix of the couple were varied. After reading the scenario, each participant completed the Adjective Check List describing traits of the victim. Participants also completed the Revised Conflict Tactics Scale to provide information regarding domestic violence experience. The majority of participants had never been victims or perpetrators of domestic violence at any point in their lives. There were significant associations between lifetime and current domestic violence experience and participant race and education. The data failed to provide support for the hypotheses. Men saw victims significantly more negatively than women, and participants saw victims of their own race less negatively than victims of the other race. Results are discussed in relationship to previous studies examining attitudes toward victims, experience with domestic violence, and racial issues. Implications and recommendations for future research are presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The role of perceived similarity to parents in adopted children's adjustment.
column12: Brown, Lisa E.: Rutgers The State U New Jersey - New Brunswick, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.62(1-B), Jul 2001, pp. 538.
column19: The relationships among perception of similarity to parents, comfort with perceived similarity to parents, psychological and adoption adjustment were explored in two groups of adopted children-inracial and transracial adoptees-between the ages of 7 and 12. Perception of similarity and comfort with similarity to parents in intelligence, personality and physical appearance was assessed with a semi-structured interview developed for this research. The following measures of general psychological adjustment were obtained: the Self-Perception Profile for Children (Harter, 1985), the Relatedness Questionnaire (Wellborn & Connell, 1987), the Child Behavior Checklist (Achenbach & Edelbrock, 1983), and the Attachment Security Questionnaire, a measure developed by the author that is a modification of a widely used measure of attachment in young children (Waters & Deane, 1985). The following measures of adoption adjustment were obtained: the Emotional Reaction Scale (Smith & Brodzinsky, 1994), the Adoption Loss Scale (modification of scale used by Smith, 1994) and the Adoption Defensiveness Scale (Smith, 1994). Results indicate that perceptions of similarity were positively related to psychological and adoption adjustment for inracial adoptees, yet not for transracial adoptees. Comfort with the extent of perceived dissimilarity to parents was directly related to psychological and adoption adjustment for both groups of adoptees. These findings are discussed in the context of stress and coping theory of psychological (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984) and adoption (Brodzinsky, 1990) adjustment. Implications for clinical work and consultation are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A study of the experiences and psychosocial developmental outcomes of African American adult transracial adoptees.
column12: Brooks, M. Devon: U California, Berkeley, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.62(1-A), Jul 2001, pp. 327.
column19: The incidence of African American children who are adopted transracially will likely increase significantly as a result of recently passed federal legislation designed to achieve earlier and increased placements for children in need of permanency. Despite this likelihood, little is known about the long-term impact of transracial adoption on African American children. In response, this study investigates the experiences and psychosocial development of a sample of 109 adult, transracial and inracial adoptees. Data were obtained using self-administered questionnaires, as well as questionnaires completed by subjects' adoptive parents in three related studies that spanned more than 20 years. The Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (MEIM), modified versions of the Global Assessment Scale (GAS), the Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventory (SEI), and the Duke Health Profile (DUKE) were among the standardized instruments included in the questionnaires. Findings revealed that the long-term psychosocial development of adult, transracial adoptees was positive overall. Neither transracial placement nor racial identity was a predictor of adoptees' psychosocial development. Yet, transracially adopted subjects did experience numerous challenges related to the unique nature of their adoptions. In contrast with current law, data from this study call for child welfare professionals to routinely assess the racial needs of children who may be adopted transracially, as well as the ability of prospective adoptive families to raise a transracially adopted child. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Ethnic perspective-taking ability and ethnic attitudes in development of Korean-born adoptee youth.
column12: Lee, David Clinton: U Wisconsin - Madison, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(12-B), Jun 2001, pp. 6737.
column19: This study examined the social and personal significance of race for cross-racially adopted Korean children. This study addressee cross-racially adopted Korean children's development of understanding of ethnicity and its connection to children's chronological maturation, cultural exposure, ethnic knowledge, and self-esteem. Attitudinal components were also examined, including ethnic pride and ethnic preferences with age, cultural exposure and ethnic knowledge. Fifty cross-racially adopted children living in the U.S. (not born in the U.S.) aged 7-17 years old were interviewed to assess their understanding of the implications of their racial status for their social world, familial relationships, and personal identities, using the ethnic perspective-taking ability (EPTA) model developed by Quintana (1994, 1999). Specifically, ethnic perspective taking ability research involved examining the child's reasoning about ethnicity and observing maturational differences in their ability to understand the impact of their ethnic and racial status on their lives. In addition to EPTA, other components of the interview included questions about cultural exposure, ethnic attitudes, and adoption. An ethnic knowledge and self-esteem questionnaire were also administered. Results showed significant relationships between age and EPTA and cultural exposure and EPTA. Cultural exposure was also significantly related to ethnic pride and ethnic preference. There were no significant relationships found between self-esteem and EPTA, cultural exposure, ethnic knowledge, and ethnic pride. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Aggression and racism: Affective and inhibitory mechanisms.
column12: Beal, Daniel Judson: Tulane U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(12-B), Jun 2001, pp. 6757.
column19: This study examined the intricate ways in which modern racists aggress against African-Americans. Under most circumstances, blatant displays of interracial aggression are negatively viewed and socially condemned. However, if a covert mode of aggression is available, modern racists will utilize it in lieu of overt retaliation. This pattern of aggression may not hold, however, if modern racists are not motivated to control their prejudiced reactions. It was hypothesized that both overt and covert forms of aggression would be used in such situations. Furthermore, angry affect was expected to mediate the relation between Modern Racism and aggression when there was low motivation to control prejudice. Results indicated, however, that dispositional levels of internal and external motivation to respond without prejudice were better predictors of aggressive behavior. In particular, people with primarily external motivations were far more aggressive toward White competitors than other individuals. Also, they were affected by situational inhibitory factors more than other individuals. Participants were reluctant, however, to behave in either an overtly or covertly aggressive manner toward Black competitors, even when situational inhibitory motivations were low. Additionally, none of the various measures of angry affect mediated the relationships between prejudice and aggression. Discussion focuses on the multitude of inhibitory factors present in competitive interracial encounters, and the role of dispositional motivations to respond without prejudice in provoking situations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Biracial identity development individuals of African-American and European-American parentage.
column12: Coleman, Natasha Lynn: California School Of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/Alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(11-B), May 2001, pp. 6162.
column19: This qualitative study explored the process of biracial identity development in eight individuals of African-American and Caucasian parentage. Four male and four female individuals, between the ages of 23-28 years, participated in this study. These individuals were interviewed about the development of their racial identity over their life span, the salient factors contributing to their racial identity development, and the challenges they faced in overcoming and resolving conflicts related to their biracial heritage. Qualitative methods were used for data analysis. The primary method for data collection was the in-depth interview. Interviews were transcribed verbatim, coded, sorted, and integrated to uncover recurrent themes. Initially, each participant's responses were examined developmentally, from childhood to early adulthood. An examination of each case write-up, which consisted of summaries of salient information and relevant themes from each interview, was later conducted. Findings were that the factors influencing biracial identity development include: support of the nuclear family around biracial identity; openness to talking about issues of race in the home; living in a diverse community; exposure to a racially diverse and supportive educational environment; and having access to a biracial peer support group. Also identified were distinct shifts in attitudes, feelings, and experiences around biracial identity that occur over the course of an individual's life. Suggested areas for future studies included a study to explore the fluidity of the biracial individual's self-definition (as influenced by environmental circumstances) and its relation to the myth of the biracial person as confused in North American society. Another suggestion was to explore the similarities and differences in biracial identity development between biracial individuals who are perceived by society as Caucasian and those who are perceived as a member of a minority group. Based on the study findings, clinicians are advised: to familiarize themselves with local resources available to biracial individuals; to educate themselves around the developmental tasks faced by biracial individuals in order to support and guide their parents and the children themselves; and to consult, as necessary, with outside sources who have expertise on the topic of biracial identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Qualities that African American men desire in a mate and their willingness to date or marry non-African Americans: An exploratory examination.
column12: Greene, Nepthalim L.: U Memphis, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(11-B), May 2001, pp. 6186.
column19: A number of studies have examined the process by which people are attracted to and choose their romantic partners, however, little information about mate selection and willingness to date and marry interracially is available for African American males. This study examines a list of 23 characteristics that African American men desire in a potential mate. Dependable character ranked first while light skin complexion received the lowest ranking. The present study also explored factors that predict African American males' willingness to date or marry interracially. Two hundred eleven adult African American males from various backgrounds were included in the study. Demographic (age, education, income), homogamous (similar educational, religious, and political backgrounds), and racial identity (the Racial Identity Attitude Scale and the Centrality subscale of the Multidimensional Inventory of Black Identity) variables were entered into hierarchical regression equations to determine the participants' willingness to date or marry interracially. The results indicate that religious background and racial identity development are significant predictors of African American men's willingness to date or marry non-African Americans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Levis, Jennifer Ann: Pepperdine U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(11-B), May 2001, pp. 6140.
column19: This study was designed to investigate the possible relationship between self-esteem and racial identity within an interracial mentoring population. Subjects were solicited from Big Brothers of Greater Los Angeles and fell into three separate categories; (1) African American males, ages 12-17 years, who have not been matched with a Big Brother, (2) African American males, ages 12-17 years who have a mentor of the same race, and (3) African American males, ages 12-17 years, who have a Caucasian mentor. Self-Esteem was assessed by the Optimal Extended Self-Esteem Scale (Hamilton, 19). Racial identity was assessed by the Mutligroup Ethnic Identity Measure (Phinney, 1992). The mothers of the participants who also asked to fill out a Mentor Satisfaction Survey and a Personal History Questionnaire. One hundred and thirty subjects were actually sent the four-part survey. Due to the limited return response to this research a descriptive analysis was conducted rather than a qualitative analysis. Implications of findings are reviewed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A research synthesis of the social acceptance of relationships between Black and White individuals.
column12: Barr, Alicia: Arizona State U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(10-B), Apr 2001, pp. 5619.
column19: A meta-analytic review of the literature examining the social acceptance of marriages and dating relationships between black and white individuals was conducted. The goal was to determine the strength of the effect size representing the difference between blacks' acceptance of interracial relationships and whites' acceptance of interracial relationships. Additionally, potential moderators of this effect were examined. The moderators included the racial and sexual composition of the couple (white female/black male versus black female/white male), the reporter of acceptance (someone in an interracial relationship or a relationship outsider), the relationship between the couple and the person evaluating them (family versus stranger), and relationship intimacy of the couple (dating versus marriage). Results indicated that blacks are more accepting of intimate black/white relationships compared to whites. This difference between blacks' and whites' acceptance was greatest when the couple in question was a black male and white female, when the reporter of acceptance was a relationship outsider, and when the person judging the couple was a family member. Inferences regarding moderating variables and implications for future primary-level research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Correlates of social worker attitudes toward transracial adoption.
column12: Fenster, Judy: New York U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.61(9-A), Mar 2001, pp. 3772.
column19: An analysis of 363 questionnaires filled out by social workers in the United States assessing their attitudes on transracial adoption (TRA)-i.e., black children being adopted by white parents-found: (1) White social workers were more in favor of transracial adoption than were black social workers; (2) African American respondents who were members of the National Association of Black Social Workers (NABSW) had less favorable attitudes toward TRA than black social workers who were not NABSW members; (3) For all subjects, optimism about the future of race relations was the crucial variable associated with positive TRA attitudes; (4) For black respondents, TRA attitudes were also associated with: commitment to promulgation of the black experience, income level, and identification with one's own ethnic group; (5) For white respondents, altruism and Catholicism played a significant role in their attitude toward transracial adoption. Implications of the findings were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Gender differences in perceived love, empathy, relationship satisfaction, family influence, and importance of money and material things among individuals in current dating or marital interracial or intraracial relationships.
column12: Jansezian, Krikor: California School Of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(8-B), Feb 2001, pp. 4408.
column19: Interracial dating and marriages are on a rise, from 51,000 mixed marriages in 1960 to 330,000 black and white marriages in 1998. The focus of this research was to assess gender differences in perceived love, empathy, relationship satisfaction, family influence, and importance of money and material things among individuals in current dating or marital interracial or intraracial relationships. It was expected that there would be a significant relationship between gender and perceived family influence (support or nonsupport) of current dating or marital relationship. It was also expected that there would be a significant relationships between perceived family influence and levels of relationship satisfaction for males and females. Furthermore, it was expected that females act on love and empathy more than importance of money and material things while males would report higher levels of importance of money and material things than love and empathy. Lastly, males would report more importance of money and material things than love and empathy than females. Overall, the research findings did not show significant results. Several limitations emerged from the study. Subjects age range was from 18 to 32, which appeared to play a role in the limited amount of experience with interracial relationships among the subject pool. Furthermore, the income of the subject pool was markedly lower than older adults who are actively dating regardless of the type of relationships they are in. Recommendation for future research is offered as a way to enhance this study. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Risk factors for marital discord among interfaith and interracial couples.
column12: Kohn, Carolynn Susan: Allegheny U Health Sciences, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(8-B), Feb 2001, pp. 4410.
column19: The purpose of this investigation was twofold. The first objective was to examine clinical and theoretical explanations for intermarried couples' greater risk of divorce compared to homogeneous couples. It was hypothesized that compared to homogeneous couples, intermarried couples would report less family support, more severe problems with religion and family, more discrepant marital role beliefs, and greater discrepancies in acculturation. It was further hypothesized that intermarried couples' greater discrepancies in marital role beliefs would be associated with greater discrepancies in acculturation. The second objective was to examine for theoretical and clinical assumptions that intermarried couples with greater differences between the partners (i.e., interfaith/interracial couples) experience more distress and difficulties compared to intermarried couples with fewer differences between the partners (i.e., interfaith-only or interracial-only couples). Finally, exploratory analyses examined whether group status (intermarried versus homogeneous) would moderate the association between family support or communication/problem-solving skills and relationship satisfaction. Participants were 150 heterosexual couples (75 intermarried and 75 homogeneous couples), engaged or married less than 18 months, who completed a set of self-report measures. Results indicated that intermarried couples reported less family support, more severe problems with religion, and greater discrepancies in acculturation levels. Contrary to the hypothesis, no association was found between intermarried couples' acculturation and marital role belief discrepancies. In partial support of the hypothesis, results indicated that among intermarried couples, interfaith-only couples reported less distress and difficulties compared to interfaith/interracial couples. Contrary to the hypothesis, interfaith-only couples also reported less difficulties compared to interracial-only couples. Moreover, no differences were found between interracial-only and interfaith/interracial couples. Exploratory analyses revealed that group status moderated the association between communication/problem-solving skills and relationship satisfaction, such that communication/problem-solving skills were highly associated with relationship satisfaction among homogeneous couples only, and not among intermarried couples. These findings suggest that differences between couples at higher-risk versus lower risk for divorce, as well as the differential impact of culture and ethnicity on relationships, may have important implications for models of marital functioning and divorce prevention programs. Implications and limitations of these findings were discussed and recommendations for future research were made. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: More than words: A multimethod study of comfort and intergroup anxiety during interracial interactions.
column12: Littleford, Linh Nguyen: Miami U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(8-B), Feb 2001, pp. 4477.
column19: This study tested the validity of Stephan and Stephan's (1985) intergroup anxiety model and used Brunswick's lens model to understand the relationships among three methods of measuring comfort: observers' holistic ratings, participants' self-rated feelings, and participants' behaviors. Two hundred and five undergraduate students engaged in interracial and same-race dyadic interactions (44 African American-Caucasian dyads, 38 Asian American-Caucasian dyads, and 41 Caucasian dyads). Students also completed questionnaires that assessed their comfort toward their partners' racial/ethnic group and their feelings during the interactions. Multivariate analysis of variance and bi-variate correlations were used to analyze the data. The results showed strong support for the intergroup anxiety model. The race of partner comparison method revealed that involvement in interracial interactions did not cause Whites to automatically exaggerate their affect. The comfort comparison method confirmed that feeling uncomfortable did not automatically lead Whites to exaggerate their positive feelings. Rather, it was the combination of interacting with a minority partner and feeling discomfort that lead Whites to exaggerate the normative affect, increasing their positive affect and decreasing their negative feelings. Implications for improving interracial tension and for psychotherapist-client relationships were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The developmental status and expressive behavior of ex-institutionalized female Chinese infants: The early months.
column12: Nelson, Rebecca: Depaul U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(8-B), Feb 2001, pp. 4419.
column19: The present study empirically investigated the developmental and anthropometric status and expressive behavior of 54 newly adopted female Chinese infants (6 to 24 months) who spent varying durations of their infancy in institutional care in China. Infants were assessed 2 to 3 weeks upon arrival to the U.S. and approximately 6 months later to determine short-term follow-up status using the Bayley Scales of Infant Development-Second Edition. Infants also engaged in expressive behavior procedures to explore cultural and institutional effects on expressiveness. As a group, infants exhibited mild mental and significant motor delays at arrival. At follow-up infants showed significant developmental progress with normal mental performance and only mild motor delay. Developmental performance was scale specific and related to multiple background variables and anthropometric indices. As age at adoption and duration of institutionalization increased, mental performance declined. Neither variable was related to motor performance. Fostered infants performed more favorably than nonfostered infants on the BSID-2 at arrival and follow-up. Infants also showed significant anthropometric progress from time of arrival to follow-up, though their physical growth indices continued to be relatively depressed compared with American norms. Infants who were heavier, taller, and had larger head circumferences showed more favorable developmental performance. Risk factors for infants with significant developmental delays were identified. Expressive behavior age effects were shown with infants displaying significantly faster latencies to smile and longer durations of smiling during the peek-a-boo condition than at time of arrival. Age and culture effects were not shown in the gentle arm restraint condition. Findings from this study support the significance of institutional experience and subsequent adoption on the developing child. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The Acculturation Model of Black Racial Identity.
column12: Moody, Marcia Juette: U Wisconsin - Madison, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(8-B), Feb 2001, pp. 4418.
column19: The Acculturation Model (AM) of Black Racial Identity is a model of how people progress though racial identity states to form bicultural attitudes. The model is based on the premise that if African descendants have social relationships with European Americans when they are growing up, they are more likely to have adult relationships with European Americans. It is further presumed that those from higher socioeconomic status (SES) backgrounds are more likely to have interactions with Whites than those from lower SES backgrounds given the latter tend to function in racially homogeneous environments (Wilson, 1996). Moreover, the model specifies that contact with European Americans will lead to bicultural attitudes. Specifically, the AM has four exogenous variables: childhood interracial contact, adulthood contact, childhood SES, and adult SES. The endogenous variable is biculturalism. It is hypothesized that (a) there is a positive relationship between childhood and adulthood SES, (b) a positive relationship between childhood and adulthood contact, (c) a positive relationship between SES and contact in adulthood and childhood, and (d) a positive relationship between contact and biculturalism. Two studies were conducted to test the Acculturation Model. The first was a reanalysis of a study conducted by Demo and Hughes (1990) on the Black racial identity of 2,107 adults. The results of the reanalysis provided strong support for the interrelationships of social class, interracial contact, and Black racial identity as specified in the proposed Acculturation Model. Therefore, a second cross-sectional study consisting of a sample of 343 young, middle age, and older African descendants was conducted. Path analyses were performed to test the hypothesized model and alternative equivalent models. The primary analysis supported the underlying hypotheses of the AM. Additionally, a secondary analysis was conducted using one-way ANOVAS and t-tests to consider age cohort differences. There were significant differences between the older and young and middle age groups combined, providing further support for the significance of SES and interracial contact on biculturalism, the underlying premise of the AM. These studies were among the few to consider acculturation in the context of Black racial identity recognizing the multiple factors contributing toward identity development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Approach and avoidance regulatory concerns for interracial interactions.
column12: Plant, Elizabeth Ashby: U Wisconsin - Madison, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(8-B), Feb 2001, pp. 4479.
column19: The current work proposed a theoretical synthesis combining conceptual approaches from the general motivation literature with recent work on the assessment of internal and external motivation to respond without prejudice. The key assertion in the framework is that the source of people's motivation to respond without prejudice determines their specific regulatory concerns for intergroup interactions. Internal motivation to respond without prejudice was argued to result in a concern with approaching a desired end-state of egalitarianism and, thereby live up to personally important nonprejudiced beliefs. In contrast, external motivation was argued to result in a concern with avoiding an undesired end-state of social disapproval that would result if one were to express bias. These regulatory concerns were expected to influence a broad range of people's responses in the context of intergroup interactions, including their intended goals and strategies as well as their interest in pursuing a strategy to reduce their bias toward Black people. The first two studies examined people's intended goals and strategies for interracial interactions. Supporting the proposed framework, internal motivation resulted in approach-related goals and intended strategies, indicating a concern with approaching egalitarianism. External motivation resulted in avoidance-related goals and intended strategies, indicating a concern with avoiding social disapproval that would result from bias. In addition, to the extent that people expected to respond with bias in interracial interactions, internally motivated people pursued any strategy likely to eliminate bias and, thereby, approach egalitarianism. In contrast, people primarily externally motivated pursued a strategy only if it would reduce overt bias and, thereby, avoid social disapproval. These findings demonstrated that a full understanding how people regulate their prejudice for interracial interactions requires examining the reasons why people are motivated to respond without prejudice. In addition, the current work established the utility of identifying people's regulatory concerns for interracial interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The relationship ecology of intimate intercultural couples.
column12: Fulton, Linda Kay Welty: Southern Illinois U Carbondale, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.61(8-A), Feb 2001, pp. 3067.
column19: Social and behavioral sciences in general and the counseling profession in particular have failed to adequately investigate the relationship ecology of African- and European-American intercultural couples. The relationship ecologies of four such couples were investigated through a qualitative study designed to examine their perceptions of their such relationships. [Note: In this study all couples were married; consequently, the terms intimate and married are used interchangeably when referring to these couples.] The narrative information portraying the married couples' relational experiences was obtained through the Relationship Ecology Interview (REI), an interview protocol designed for the study. The REI protocol assessed the couples' appraisal of their management of socio- and psychocultural tasks and challenges within their relationship ecology (Fontaine, 1990). The narrative commentaries of the couples' interpretations of their relationship experiences are illustrated employing both Susan E. Chase's (1995) narrative analysis style and her theoretical propositions about the tension between individual achievement and inequalities in American society. Couples' narrative analyses revealed that as they communicated their relationship experiences, they simultaneously reflected on various cultural discourses about individual achievement (how they successfully managed their relationships) and inequality (how they experienced cultural, social, political barriers) within their relationship ecologies. Couples demonstrated confidence in their intercultural relationship qualifications accomplishing instrumental and affective relationship tasks. However, they acknowledge race discrimination and social, cultural, and political inequalities that determine their relationship experiences. Unlike the experiences of intracultural couples, Africanand European-American couples' discursive narratives reveal they must remain alert to the possibilities of racist treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Variations in selected parent variables in parents' perception of biracial (African American/White) children's early racial identification.
column12: Taborn, John Gregory: Howard U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(7-B), Jan 2001, pp. 3883.
column19: This study examined and described fifty-eight (N = 58) Black/White parent couples with biracial children (N = 116). The parents completed a survey using the Ideas About Parenting Scale (Revised), Black Racial Identity Scale, the White Racial Identity Scale and the Discussing Race With Your Child Questionnaire that assessed the relationships between their parenting styles, stage of racial identity development, race and gender, and variables reflecting their involvement in their biracial children's early racial socialization. Significant race differences were found between parents' reports of the initial racial label adopted by their child. More Black than White parents reported their children as having adopted a "Black" or "African American" label and as having adopted "no racial label." More White than Black parents reported their children as having adopted an "other" racial labels. Parents' levels of racial identity development assessed on a continuum of five developmental stages placed white subjects at the two advanced stages of "pseudo-independence" and "autonomy" and Black parents at the advanced stages of "emersion" and "internalization." Ancillary findings revealed significant relationships between parents' scores on each of the five stages of racial identity development and the extent of their involvement with their biracial child's early racial identity socialization. Advanced stages of racial identity development correlate with increased parent pro-activity in discussing race with their children. Factors contributing to these findings are discussed along with the need for more research to determine the psychological impact of which differences in parents racial socialization practices exert on biracial children's racial identity and healthy personality development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Black/white biracial identity development: A grounded theory study.
column12: Henriksen, Richard C.: Texas A&M U - Commerce, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.61(7-A), Jan 2001, pp. 2605.
column19: The study of Biracial individuals has received little attention in the literature. There currently is no clear theory of Black/White Biracial identity development available for use by professional counselors. The purpose of this study was to utilize the grounded theory approach to identify the process through which an individual develops a Biracial identity. Strauss and Corbin's (1998) techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory were utilized to develop a theory of Biracial identity development. Interviews were conducted with seven Biracial individuals from Hunt County, Texas. All participant interviews were audiotaped, transcribed, and analyzed. To ensure accuracy of data, all transcriptions were verified for accuracy. Strauss and Corbin's analysis recommendations were used to analyze data and included: (a) open coding, the process that leads to the identification of concepts and their properties; (b) axial coding, the process of relating categories to subcategories; and (c) selective coding, the process of integrating and refining the theory. Participants' responses suggested that Biracial individuals develop a Biracial Identity following the movement through several phases or periods of development. The Biracial Identity is a positive expression of pride in being Biracial. The model of Biracial Identity Development includes the following phases: (a) neutrality, that phase when the individual is not aware of race; (b) acceptance, that period when the individual accepts being racially different; (c) awareness, that period when individuals become aware that they have no racial group with which to identify; (d) experimentation, that period when the individual begins to seek a racial identity; (e) transition, that period during which the individual begins to develop his or her own racial identity; and (f) recognition, that period during which the individual recognizes his or her Biracial identity. Study participants demonstrated that they, like single race individuals, experience a developmental process leading to the recognition of a racial identity. Biracial individuals have been thought to exist without having a racial identity and were viewed as not being accepted by society. This study theorizes that not only do Biracial individuals have a racial identity, they are proud of being Biracial. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column21: Black White biracial identity development, racial identity

column5: White mothers of biracial, Black-White adolescents: Negotiating the borders of racial identity, culture and ethnicity.
column12: O'Donoghue, Margaret H.: New York U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.61(7-A), Jan 2001, pp. 2921.
column19: This qualitative research study explores how racial identity, culture and ethnicity informs the lives and parenting practices of White mothers of Biracial, Black-White adolescents. Eleven White mothers, married to African-American men and raising adolescent children were interviewed about their experiences. The majority of these women are socializing their children with a focus on African-American culture but not fostering a sense of ethnicity related to the mother's ethnic background. Through their parenting of their Biracial children, the mothers have come to a greater sense of their own racial identity recognizing White privilege and their own White identity. Their children identify as Biracial but with a public Black identity, their identity is neither linear nor progressive but varies between Black and Biracial depending on social situations. Adolescents has not been a stressful time. The mothers attempt to foster coping skills by choosing carefully where to live, promoting discussions on racial issues, reinforcing African-American culture, warning their children about societal hostility and joining peer support groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Domestic violence: The role of interracial/ethnic dyads in criminal court processing. [References].
column9:
Kingsnorth, Rodney F

MacIntosh, Randall C

Berdahl, Terceira

Blades, Carrie

Rossi, Steve
column12: Kingsnorth, Rodney F.: California State U, Sacramento, CA, US
column13: Journal of Contemporary Criminal Justice. Vol.17(2), May 2001, pp. 123-141.
column19: Examined the effects of using interracial-ethnic dyads during domestic violence case processing. 455 cases were assessed for the 5 outcome measures of decision to file charges, decision to file cases as felonies or misdemeanors, decision to fully prosecute or to dismiss, conviction on felony or misdemeanor charges, and the length of imposed sentence. Results show no effect of interracial-ethnic dyads on any examined decision points. Extralegal variables such as defendant substance abuse at time of offence attained or approached significance in all decisions, while victim substance abuse failed to even approach significance in all models. Marital status and cohabitation failed to play a role. Victim cooperation approached significance in filing charges and became highly significant in prosecution. Victim prior arrest and cooperation were not relevant to severity of charges filed nor conviction charge. Victim injury and severity of attack were not significant on decision to file charges. It is concluded that there is no significant effect of interracial violence on any of the five outcome measures examined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: An African American perspective on conversational improvement strategies. [References].
column9:
Martin, Judith N

Moore, Sherri

Hecht, Michael L

Larkey, Linda K
column12: Martin, Judith N.: Arizona State U, Hugh Downs School of Human Communication, Tempe, AZ, US
column13: Howard Journal of Communications. Vol.12(1), Jan-Mar 2001, pp. 1-27.
column19: Investigated conversational strategies used by African Americans to communicate with European Americans, based on a previously developed model of interethnic communication. This model assumes that interethnic and interracial communication is problematic and comprises 4 components: ethnic/racial identity, communication issues, conversational improvement strategies used to deal with the communication issues, and communication satisfaction. The research elaborated the conversational improvement strategies component. 133 22-75 yr old African Americans returned questionnaires in which they were asked to identify and describe conversational strategies used to deal with 7 specific communication issues: acceptance, understanding, negative stereotyping, goal attainment, powerlessness, expressiveness, and authenticity. Ss reported using 12 conversational strategies, ranging from accommodating (be friendly, treat as individual) to more divergent (assertiveness, avoidance, confrontation) strategies. Interviews conducted with 10 Ss concerning their interracial interaction in a specific context: an organizational setting. Both survey and interview results are seen to confirm the basic model and reveal interesting relationships among the communication issues and the conversational strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Love's revolution: Interracial marriage. [References].
column13: (2001). Love's revolution: Interracial marriage. viii, 230 pp. Philadelphia, PA, US: Temple University Press; US.
column19: (from the publicity materials) Breaking common stereotypes, and providing insight as to why people from different racial backgrounds choose to marry one another, this book presents the unique successes and failures that mixed marriages enjoy and endure. The author discusses parents' "grief" and how the prejudices of others can affect a couple. A range of topics, from raising children, to dealing with racism from strangers, are also addressed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: Marital happiness depends on many factors, and homogeneity of race and culture between the couple is surely among them. Over the past three decades, inter-racial marriages have increased rapidly, from 310,000 to more than 1.1 million, and their proportion among all marriages grew from 0.7% in 1970 to over 2.2% in the mid-1990s. In the meantime, the rate of divorce among all marriages in the cohorts of the 1980s and the 1990s reached between 50% and 67%. Intermarriage and divorce have been both extensively studied, but marital happiness among inter-married couples is seldom reported in the literature. In this article, the authors raise a research question whether marital stability and happiness are related to the racial and cultural background of married coup1es (aged 20-80 yrs), and examine self-reported marital happiness among a sample from a multi-ethnic community in Hawaii. The differential effect of race and culture on marital happiness will be given special emphasis in this study. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: White juror bias: An investigation of prejudice against Black defendants in the American courtroom. [References].
column9:
Sommers, Samuel R

Ellsworth, Phoebe C
column12: Sommers, Samuel R.: U Michigan, Dept of Psychology, Social Psychology, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Psychology, Public Policy, and Law. Vol.7(1), Mar 2001, pp. 201-229.
column19: Racial prejudice in the courtroom is examined through a historical sketch of racism in the legal system, a review of psychological research on White juror bias, and a study investigating White mock jurors' judgments of a fictional trial summary. The central hypothesis is that salient racial issues at trial activate the normative racial attitudes held by White jurors. In previous eras, these racial norms encouraged overtly anti-Black prejudice. But in modern America, many Whites embrace an egalitarian value system and try to behave in an appropriately nonprejudiced manner when race is salient. Therefore, contrary to the intuition of many scholars and researchers, contemporary White jurors are more likely to demonstrate racial bias against a Black defendant in interracial trials without blatantly racial issues. Empirical data suggest that this pattern of bias is not limited to one type of crime or one type of racial issue. Practical implications and future research directions are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Thirty years of investigating the own-race bias in memory for faces: A meta-analytic review. [References].
column9:
Meissner, Christian A

Brigham, John C
column12: Meissner, Christian A.: Florida State U, Dept of Psychology, Tallahassee, FL, US
column13: Psychology, Public Policy, and Law. Vol.7(1), Mar 2001, pp. 3-35.
column19: The current article reviews the own-race bias (ORB) phenomenon in memory for human faces, the finding that own-race faces are better remembered when compared with memory for faces of another, less familiar race. Data were analyzed from 39 research articles, involving 91 independent samples and nearly 5,000 participants. Measures of hit and false alarm rates, and aggregate measures of discrimination accuracy and response criterion were examined, including an analysis of 8 study moderators. Several theoretical relationships were also assessed (i.e., the influence of racial attitudes and interracial contact). Overall, results indicated a "mirror effect" pattern in which own-race faces yielded a higher proportion of hits and a lower proportion of false alarms compared with other-race faces. Consistent with this effect, a significant ORB was also found in aggregate measures of discrimination accuracy and response criterion. The influence of perceptual learning and differentiation processes in the ORB are discussed, in addition to the practical implications of this phenomenon. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column13: Group Processes & Intergroup Relations. Vol.4(4), Oct 2001, pp. 299-316.
column19: Two studies examined whether developing a common ingroup identity among Blacks and Whites can improve Whites' interracial evaluations. In Study 1, 53 White participants interacted with a Black or White confederate under conditions designed to produce cognitive representations as fellow group members or as separate individuals. Consistent with the Common Ingroup Identity Model, Whites evaluated Blacks more favorably when they interacted with them as members of the same group than as separate individuals. Study 2, was conducted using 183 fans entering a football stadium, Ss were asked to complete an interview regarding food preferences. Results revealed that Whites complied more frequently with a Black interviewer's request to interview them when they shared common university affiliation, relative to when the Black interviewer was affiliated with the opposing team. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) Addresses the issues that arise in therapy for intermarried couples, whose difficulties also include different culture-rooted beliefs and traditions. Common problems encountered by intermarried couples include: misguided expectations based on projected beliefs about other cultures; shift in implicit ethnic/racial hierarchy; difficulties in communication; differences in ways of coping; incompatibility between two cultures; different concepts in family boundaries and obligations and role division between spouses; different childrearing practices; and problems arising from the community's reaction toward intermarriage. Issues in therapy with intermarried couples include: being sensitive to cultural perceptions of therapy held by each partner; considering ethnic matching and therapeutic neutrality; emphasizing positive forces and common ground; promoting cultural knowledge, understanding, and skills; clarifying culture influences vs. personal factors; promoting flexibility and appreciation of differences; and avoiding too culturally-specific approaches. Several case vignettes are included to illustrate these issues. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the anticipated concerns and projected strategies in addressing the lack of birth information and identity development in adopted abandoned Chinese female infants. 10 parents (aged 37-66 yrs) residing in the US, who adopted Chinese females (aged 18-48 mo), completed interviews regarding their intended methods of developing their daughters' identities, and parents' projected plans to address lack of birth information. Results show that parents, who were of White or Japanese ethnicity, were concerned about their daughters' identity as adopted persons. Parents wanted to create a birth heritage, instill a sense of pride in Chinese identity, integrate adoptive parents' backgrounds, address the orphan identity, and cope with physical and medical special needs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Exploratory factor analysis was used to provide an organizational framework for data collected from an entering class of students at a large eastern university. Results from the factor analysis on responses of 1,912 students (mean age 17.6 yrs) indicated that items on surveys, based on various interests of administrators, can be grouped into dimensions that can be used to plan student services. Factors that emerged were Religion/Spirituality, Help Seeking, Interracial Relationships, Academic Self-Concept, Cultural Tolerance, Academic Preparedness, Shy/Lonely, and Cult Approval. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Gillem, Angela R.: Arcadia U, Glenside, PA, US
column13: Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology. Vol.7(2), May 2001, pp. 182-196.
column19: Two biracial college freshmen (17 and 19 yrs old), both of whom identify as Black, were chosen from a larger sample of participants in a qualitative study of biracial identity development to exemplify the differences in the paths that 2 biracial individuals could take to achieve racial identity resolution. Through the case study method, the authors describe the course and progression of racial identity development (RID) in these 2 individuals and discuss some key themes in their lives that have contributed to the development of their RID. The purposes are fourfold: to describe, nonclinical subjective experiences of being biracial in the US, to explore the differences in the paths that 2 biracial individuals can take to achieve what looks superficially like similar Black racial identity resolution, to demonstrate how identifying as Black can have different meanings and consequences for 2 biracial people, and to contribute to the differentiation of Black RID from biracial Black/White RID. The authors raise questions about the generalizability of monoracial Black and ethnic identity theories to biracial individuals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
