column5: An analysis of resistance to racial exogamy: The 1998 South Carolina Referendum. [References].
column12: Yancey, George A.: U Texas, TX, US
column13: Journal of Black Studies. Vol.31(5), May 2001, pp. 635-650.
column19: In order to find an effective way of balancing individual-level with macrolevel study of interracial marriage opposition as well as to circumvent social desirability biases, data from the 1998 South Carolina referendum on removing the prohibition of interracial marriage from the state constitution was examined. Data on demographics, political behavior, educational attainment, SES, religious affiliation, and economic/educational racial competition were assessed. It is noted that 38% of voters rejected the removal of South Carolina's antimiscegenation law. Macro-level analysis of the South Carolina elections suggest that a significant amount of animosity continues to exist toward interracial primary relationships. Findings also indicate that the effect of Black/White income inequality matters, indicating the importance of status differences between groups. This finding implies that decreases in Black/White income inequality can increase support for interracial marriage. Yet, it also means that because there is much income inequality between Blacks and Whites, the support and opportunity for interracial marriage is reduced. Implications for the role of education are also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Describes a parent training program currently in use at an adoption agency that places children transracially; describes a new instrument designed to measure parents' perception of the importance of racial awareness, multicultural planning, and survival skills; and describes the use of this instrument to evaluate the effectiveness of an agency-based training session with a small group of parents. 20 Ss from the 1st set and 22 of the trainees from the 2nd set completed the Adoption Questionnaire. Results suggest that training can have a positive effect on transracial adoptive parents' perceptions of the importance of cultural competence. Future research needs in this area are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (create) This chapter examines questions in cross-cultural literature, such as, where do mixed-race children and adults belong in the world of European Americans, African Americans, Asian Americans, Hispanic/Latino Americans, and Native Americans? and what ethnic categorization is assigned to those of a mixed-race origin? Topics discussed include the concept of identity, choice of ethnic identity, identity and social interaction, self-identification. A study surveying 72 high school students (mean age 15 yrs) to investigate how biracial children develop their racial identification and the communication that affects that process. The results indicate that from 3 courses of assimilation, the majority of the participants ascribe to the cultural pluralism model. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Feminist Family Therapy: An International Forum. Vol.13(1), 2001, pp. 1-31.
column19: This study explores how interracial couples experience their life together and negotiate race and gender in their relationships. 10 Black-White couples were interviewed individually and conjointly and the descriptive data were analyzed using the method of constant comparison. Results reflect the ways in which interracial couples struggle to employ, resist, and transform the discourse of homogamy in their relationship. Black spouses compared to White spouses demonstrated a greater awareness of and sensitivity to social resistance to the constitution of their relationship, and Black spouses' familial and personal histories were sometimes relegated to silence in the couple relationship. Implications for family therapists working with interracial couples are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: This article provides a clear conceptual definition of cultural competence for transracial-cultural adoptive (TRA) parents based on an extensive review of the literature and feedback from both experts and parents. Following the differentiation of cultural competence as defined in the social work literature and cultural competence as applied to TRA parents, a three-part definition of cultural competence for TRA parents is presented. The article expands on each of three constructs: racial awareness, multicultural planning, and survival skills, In addition, it describes the process of beginning to operationalize the constructs. Finally, implications for social work practice, education, and research are suaaested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) Emphasizes the cognitive, affective, and behavioral processes that are most likely to foster long-term satisfaction and stability in multicultural relationships. It is argued that (1) during the formation of multicultural relationships, satisfaction is promoted to the extent that partners genuinely appreciate, rather than simply tolerate, the differences in their respective personalities; (2) after multicultural relationships have been formed, satisfaction is maintained to the extent that partners jointly create and sustain relationship cultures that are uniquely theirs; and (3) throughout the development and maintenance of multicultural relationships, satisfaction is created and sustained to the extent that relationship partners are open to personal growth via their association with a partner who contributed to their growth, in part due to being from a different culture/ethnic group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Student reactions to the visual texts The Color of Fear and Rosewood in the interracial classroom. [References].
column12: Harris, Tina M.: U Georgia, Dept of Speech Communication, Athens, GA, US
column13: Howard Journal of Communications. Vol.12(2), Apr-Jun 2001, pp. 101-117.
column19: The current study involves a cluster analysis of student reactions to two films, The Color of Fear and Rosewood. One or the other film was shown in two interracial communication courses. As a course assignment, students wrote reaction papers to the film and its effectiveness as a pedagogical tool designed to educate them and others about racism and interracial communication. Using cluster analysis, there were several reactions to the films. Overall, students perceived the use of visual text as a powerful tool in educating people about racism and its impact on interracial communication. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Risk factors in international adoption: The family that makes "restitution". [Italian]. [References].
column13: Terapia Familiare: Rivista Interdisciplinare di Ricerca e Intervento Relazionale. Vol.64 Nov 2000, pp. 31-65.
column19: The article presents research with an exploratory character on the phenomenon of "restitution" in the area of the international adoption. It's an archive's research developed on 23 cases of restitution of foreign children. The authors, using the triangular structure as observation and analysis units, to whose vertexes they put the family's system (meaning with this term not just the adoptive couple, but also the wider three generational system), the child's system and the social operators's system, highlight a series of common factors concerning the examinated cases, that either alone or interacting among themselves, could have brought about the restitution of foreign children and that, generally, could most likely jeopardize an international adoption. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column13: American Educational Research Journal. Vol.37(1), Spr 2000, pp. 33-65.
column19: Examined the conversational styles employed by students attending a desegregated middle school while discussing race. Students discussed issues related to race in focus groups initially comprised solely of White, Black, or nondominant individuals. Subsequently, subjects (Ss) then convened in mixed-race groups, with conversation styles examined. Results show that Ss employed 2 distinct types of conversational styles. In the 1st type, which may be labeled "bridging talk", Ss used multiple strategies to build unity across differences. In the 2nd type, "conflict talk," Ss discursively created borders and conflict. Findings suggest promises and challenges for each type of discussion. A 3rd form for consideration, "democratic conversation," would invite perspectives while acknowledging the privileging and silencing that accompany them. It is concluded that educators should hold conversations that explicitly address the power dynamics inherent in such conversations and teach the conceptual tools and language to identify these dynamics. Although these conversations across racial lines are sometimes threatening and difficult, they are a critical component of democratic education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The adopting single mother: Four portraits of American women adopting from China. [References].
column13: Adoption Quarterly. Vol.4(2), 2000, pp. 29-55.
column19: In-depth qualitative interviews with 4 women, aged 39-47 yrs, who chose to become single mothers through international adoption were used to explore the influences, life experiences, and social factors that made their unconventional choice possible. Four themes emerging from the grounded theory analysis are addressed: (1) moral issues; (2) fear and prejudice; (3) agency; and (4) support. It is concluded that results give a new face and voice to the single mother, expanding our understanding of postmodern families and challenging currently available narratives of single mothers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: "Outcomes" of adoptions of children from India: A subjective versus normative view of "success". [References].
column9:
Goodman, Joan F

Kim, Stacy S
column12: Goodman, Joan F.: U Pennsylvania, Graduate School of Education, Philadelphia, PA, US
column13: Adoption Quarterly. Vol.4(2), 2000, pp. 3-27.
column19: Examined the differences in and relationships between normative and subjective outcomes for children born in India and adopted by US families. 110 families who had adopted 2 mo-11yr olds between 1973-1987 completed a questionnaire which supplied basic family information and identified children with disabilities. From this group, 76 parents with adopted children aged 15 yrs and older completed a questionnaire which gathered in-depth information on themselves and their children. 57 adoptees (mean age 22.6 yrs) completed questionairs assessing their schooling, work, relationships, and well-being. Results show that of the 146 adoptees, 67 were identified as having a significant disability. From a subjective orientation, the adoptees reported satisfaction with their lives & were optimistic about their futures. The presence or absence of a disability did not appear to interfere with their self appraisal. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined interracial dating behavior and attitudes toward romantic involvement in 4 ethnic groups of college students: Euro-American, Latino, Asian-American, and African American. Ss (196 men, 367 women, aged 18-58 yrs) were surveyed with regard to their willingness to be romantically involved interracially or interculturally along with their actual interracial dating experience. Analysis indicated a high willingness in all ethnic groups to be romantically involved as well as an absence of sex difference with regard to both attitude and experience. However, there were differences in both attitude and experience among ethnic groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Assimilation and masquerade: Self-constructions of Indo-Dutch women. [References].
column12: Pattynama, Pamela: U Amsterdam, Dept of General Literature, Amsterdam, Netherlands
column13: European Journal of Women's Studies. Vol.7(3), Aug 2000, pp. 281-299.
column19: Discusses self-constructions of migrant Indo-Dutch females living in the Netherlands. As the progeny of Dutch males and Indonesian females during the centuries of Dutch occupation of Indonesia, Indo-Dutch individuals occupied an ambiguous role, perceived as distinct from and above the native Indonesian population, but subordinate to the dominant White society. Rather than be viewed as assimilated objects, these migrant, Indo-Dutch females are regarded by Dutch Whites as agents who effectively intervene in the construction of national identities through masquerading strategies and ways of communication. Through the model of masquerading, Indo-Dutchness can be conceptualized as a mode of cultural negotiation and intervention. Such masquerading strategies form a part of the conflicted colonial history of Indo-Dutch females. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Tinsley, Howard E. A [Ed]; Brown, Steven D [Ed]. (2000). Handbook of applied multivariate statistics and mathematical modeling.  (pp. 323-352). xxviii, 721 pp. San Diego, CA, US: Academic Press; US.
column19: (from the chapter) Multidimensional scaling (MDS) is a versatile technique for understanding and displaying the structure of multivariate data. This technique has seen wide application in the behavioral sciences and has led to increased understanding of complex psychological phenomena. MDS has been used to assess cognitive developmental theories, study interracial relations among children, determine consumer preferences, and evaluate the dimensional structure and content validity of tests and questionnaires. In this chapter, we limit the discussion to MDS applications founded on distance assumptions; that is, the assumption that the essential features of the proximity data can be represented as a stochastic function of symmetric distances among stimuli in a multidimensional space spanned by continuous, latent dimensions. MDS will continue to be a major tool of perception research. Statistical developments will continue on methods for constrained analyses, methods for estimating the precision of parameter estimates, explicit models for derived proximity matrices, methods for reducing the respondent labor in studies using direct proximity judgments, and for estimating scale values in models. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race in the courtroom: Perceptions of guilt and dispositional attributions. [References].
column9:
Sommers, Samuel R

Ellsworth, Phoebe C
column12: Sommers, Samuel R.: U Michigan, Social Psychology, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. Vol.26(11), Nov 2000, pp. 1367-1379.
column19: Compared the judgments of White and Black jurors in interracial trials. In Study 1, the defendant's race did not influence White college students' decisions but Black students demonstrated ingroup/outgroup bias in their guilt ratings and attribution for the defendant's behavior. The aversive nature of modern racism suggests that Whites are motivated to appear nonprejudiced when racial issues are salient; therefore, the race salience of a trial summary was manipulated and given to noncollege students in Study 2. Once again, the defendant's race did not influence Whites when racial issues were salient but in the non-race-salient version of the same interracial case, White mock jurors rated the Black defendant more guilty, aggressive, and violent than the White defendant. Black mock jurors demonstrated same-race leniency in both versions of the trial, suggesting that racial issues are generally salient in the minds of Black jurors in interracial cases with Black defendants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The nature of mothers' developing relationships with their internationally adopted Chinese daughters.
column12: Solchany, Joanne Elizabeth: U Washington, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(6-B), Jan 2000, pp. 2994.
column19: Mothers who had adopted infant or toddler daughters from China participated in a series of three interviews that explored their history of attempts at making a family, their decision to adopt from China, and the development of the mother-child relationship they subsequently developed with their daughters. Nineteen mother-child dyads were included in this study. A qualitative analysis of the three interviews, which included an initial interview, the Working Model of the Child Interview, and a debriefing interview, lead to the central perspective of Transformation through Reconciliation. Mothers worked towards a transformation to mother-by-adoption while making peace with themselves and embracing their daughters. The two stages of pre-adoption and post-adoption provided the framework within which the mothers worked the specific tasks of this process. This work involved four major tasks including the emotional thread of Resolution of loss, trauma, and fear; the psychological thread of Re-construction of internal working models; the environmental thread of Forging a baby space; and the relationship thread of Relating to the real baby. The quality of the work done by each mother supported the two variations of outcomes, including balanced and unbalanced dyadic relationships. Several quantitative measures were used to provide descriptive data. These included the Parental Stress Inventory, the Infant-Toddler Symptom Checklist, and the Mother-Child Interaction Scale. These instruments provided information on the number of stresses the mothers experienced with regard to the child, themselves and the dyad, the number and quality of sensory difficulties that mothers identified in their children, and the number of specific mother-child interaction qualities identified by the mothers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Value similarity and marital satisfaction among interracially and intraracially married couples.
column12: Guner, Gulay: Miami Inst Psychology Of The Caribbean Center For Advanced Studies, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(5-B), Nov 2000, pp. 2761.
column19: The purpose of this study was to examine the relationship between value similarity and marital satisfaction with regard to race. By using the Dyadic Adjustment Scale (DAS) and the Survey of Interpersonal Values (SIV), the relationship between value similarity and marital satisfaction were determined. Each spouse of the 93 married couples, 31 of whom were Black, 31 White and 31 Interracial (Black-White) were mailed both the DAS and SIV and instructed to work independently. Squared Euclidian distance was utilized to compute value similarity and the total DAS score as a measure of marital satisfaction. The hypothesis presented is that couples who have greater similarity in values will report greater marital satisfaction, regardless of couple type. By utilizing correlational measures, ANOVA, MANOVA, and Tukey HSD Post Hoc analysis, at a chosen alpha level of .05, the hypothesis was not supported. White couples, however did report significantly higher marital satisfaction than did Interracial couples. Further analysis discovered that wives of White couples value Conformity significantly more than wives of Interracial couples. And lastly, wives of Interracial couples value Independence significantly more than wives of White couples. No significant findings with regard to Black couples was found. Lack of similar research makes comparisons difficult. Further research should attempt to conduct qualitative analysis in order to have a greater theoretical basis from which to work (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Parental relationships and ethnic identity of biracial European/Japanese American young adults.
column12: Ono, Lori Jo: California School Of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/Alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(5-B), Nov 2000, pp. 2818.
column19: This exploratory study surveyed 43 biracial European/Japanese American adults retrospectively about the quality of their relationships with their parents and their ethnic identification during their last year of high school. Participants were between the ages of 20 and 45, and were biracial third, fourth, or a combination of third and fourth generation Japanese Americans. Half of the participants had a Japanese American mother and European American father, and half had a European American mother and Japanese American father. Research questions concerned: (a) how gender and ethnicity of each parent relates to the quality of the relationship with the biracial offspring; (b) how gender of the offspring relates to treatment received from each parent; (c) whether the relationship with each parent is associated with the participant's ethnic identity; and (d) whether the type of interracial parental dyad is associated with the parent/child relationship and ethnic identity of the offspring. Multiple 2-way and 3-way ANOVAs, Pearson product-moment correlation coefficients, and independent t-tests were used to analyze the data. Significant differences were found in how mothers and fathers treated their offspring, regardless of race. Participants reported that mothers showed more closeness-caregiving behaviors, separation anxiety, and emotional inter-reactivity toward their offspring than did fathers. Fathers showed more anger/aggression and more authority/dominance toward their offspring than did mothers. These findings highlight the influence of gender roles in family dynamics and seem similar to how parents of all racial groups in the U.S. treat their offspring. Significant correlations were found between respondents' racial appearance, their ethnic identity, and how they were treated by their parents. The more the offspring looked like and identified with their Japanese American parent, the more closeness-caregiving and controlling behaviors they reported receiving from their parents. Also, the more the participant looked like and identified with their European American parent, the more anxious and aggressive behaviors they reported receiving from their parents. Overall, some of the results of this study suggest that qualities of the parent/child relationship are associated with the offspring's physical features and ethnic identification. However, the small sample size (30 female and 13 male participants) makes this study exploratory only, and replication with larger samples is needed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The impact of interracial contact on stereotypical perceptions.
column12: Debose, Joann Watts: U Nevada, Las Vegas, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.61(5-A), Nov 2000, pp. 2052.
column19: Situations involving interracial contact and their impact on the reduction of racist attitudes among whites in America will be examined using the contact theory of prejudice. This perspective maintains that evidence for the continued "social distance" between blacks and whites can be quantified in measures of workplace contact. Racial perceptions in schools, churches and neighborhoods provide additional evidence for the contact theory of race relations. Stereotypic perceptions develop when people are unable or unwilling to obtain all the information needed to make accurate judgments about people or situations. Often, the absence of the "total picture" encourages people to fill in the blanks with little reflection. As a result, this lack of reflection engenders negative social predispositions, including feelings of hostility and bigotry toward blacks. To be effective in reducing racial attitudes among whites, interracial contact should take place within an equal social setting. Moreover, the contact must be sustained rather than temporary. Finally, interracial contact needs to be intimate and informal to be effective in reducing stereotypes. This research is significant in several respects. First the content of racial stereotypes has not been the subject of research for some time. Most research on stereotyping focuses upon the judgments individuals make when they have a limited amount of information about a hypothetical person, usually of a minority or "out-group" member in real-life situations. This study is exploratory in that it seeks to extend the literature on stereotypes in order to determine if increased interracial contact by whites will be associated with less-prejudiced persons. In order to test the hypothesis, a survey questionnaire was utilized to measure interracial contact and exposure. The research hypothesized that interracial contact by whites will be associated with positive racial attitudes and less exaggerated stereotypical perceptions. A self-report survey instrument on prejudice was administered to a sample of 135 personnel at the Northwest Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department substation. Preliminary findings suggest contact is a strong predictor of racial attitudes. The format of the dissertation follows the guidelines of the American Psychological Association. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Biracial identity and social context.
column12: Basu, Andra Marie: City U New York, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(4-B), Oct 2000, pp. 2268.
column19: The goal of the present study was to explore the relationship between social context and identity for biracial individuals. Specifically, it was proposed that a biracial woman's identification choice will relate to her construction and choices of social context. Fourteen biracial college women participated in the study, which used multiple methodologies including the use of personal narratives, focus groups, and personal interviews. Results revealed that participants' identity choices did influence their choices and constructions of social contexts, particularly at the school they all attended. Yet while identification choices did influence participants' perceptions about their social contexts, other factors such as social barriers also influenced them. Family played a role in their identification choices as well, but siblings were found to be more influential than parents. In addition, results showed that educators and biracial mentors had a significant impact on participants. Implications of the findings for parents, educators and future researchers are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A narrative approach to biracial identity development.
column12: Adermann, Charlotte Yen: Indiana U Pennsylvania, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(4-B), Oct 2000, pp. 2188.
column19: As the biracial population in the United States grows rapidly, psychologists, counselors, and educators will be working with increasing numbers of individuals of mixed racial descent. Biracial individuals, those with parents from two different socially designated racial backgrounds, face unique challenges in developing a racial identity. These include: negative or unwanted attention to their "exotic" physical appearance, and feelings of ambiguity regarding racial identity that may lead to difficulty with not only claiming a racial identity, but with the rejection of that identity by society. Existing research has not applied the emerging social science emphasis on the narrative study of lives to biracial identity development. The purpose of this study was to investigate how the application of a narrative framework of conceptualizing identity as a story increases understanding of the complexity and challenges of biracial identity development. Twenty subjects, 14 females and 6 males ages 18 and older, whose parents are of two different socially designated racial groups, were interviewed individually by the researcher. A semi-structured interview guide was developed specifically for this study to elicit a narrative of biracial identity development. Data were subjected to a qualitative analysis in which verbatim transcripts were produced and reviewed to identify relevant themes. Results indicate that a narrative framework offers an in-depth, detailed examination of the challenges and complexities of biracial identity development. Seventy-five percent of subjects were able to describe, at least somewhat, their racial identity development in the form of a story. Two major themes elicited from the narratives were subjects' views on issues relevant to their own racial identity formation, and issues common to the biracial experience. No statistically significant relationships between racial identification and selected categories were found due to the small sample size. In general, narratives progressed from a lack of awareness of race, to identifying racially, to distinguishing between race and ethnicity, to addressing ongoing issues related to ethnicity. Areas for further research include examination of interrelationships between categories, the relationship of racial identity to other salient identities, and expanding the age range of the sample to better explore racial identity development across the lifespan. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Direct, witnessed, and verbally-mediated exposure, fear of interpersonal victimization, dissociation and emotional distress among a biethnic sample of college students: A structural modeling analysis.
column12: Mcgruder-Johnson, Anita Kay: Texas A&M U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(4-B), Oct 2000, pp. 2211.
column19: Structural Equation Modeling analyses (SEM) were used to examine relationships among three modes of exposure to interpersonal violence, dissociation, fear of victimization and distress in a biethnic sample of 344 university students. A four-factor model (with direct exposure as the exogenous variable) was specified on 239 African American and European American females. In addition, the model was respecified (with witnessed exposure and verbally-mediated exposure as the exogenous variables) on a mixed-gender African American sample of the data. For all types of exposure, the structural models supported mediation effects for dissociation. The data suggest that dissociative experiences and subsequent PTSD-related distress are sequelae of direct exposure, witnessed exposure and verbally-mediated exposure to interpersonal violence. In addition, the data suggest that the relationship between witnessed or verbally-mediated exposure to interpersonal violence, dissociative experiences and PTSD-related distress was more relevant for the African American students than European Americans students in our sample. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Psychological distress, African American acculturation and family history of breast cancer: Effects on breast self-examination frequency.
column12: Guevarra, Josephine S.: City U New York, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(2-B), Aug 2000, pp. 1133.
column19: Breast cancer is the most common type of cancer among women. Black women exhibit a lower breast cancer incidence than White women, but their breast cancer mortality is higher. Causes for the racial difference are not known, but the higher breast cancer mortality has been linked to diagnosis at later stages of disease. A possible contributing factor to later stage at breast cancer diagnosis is inappropriate breast cancer screening. Adherence to appropriate breast cancer screening is especially important for women with family histories of breast cancer (FH+) as they are at increased risk for developing breast cancer and have been found to have a higher perception of personal risk for developing the disease and greater psychological distress, both have been linked to inappropriate screening. Evidence from studies with Hispanic women suggests also that level of acculturation plays a role in breast cancer screening. It was hypothesized that psychological factors and acculturation impacts on breast cancer screening. BSE frequency was selected as the breast cancer screening behavior as it is a low-cost behavior that has been found to increase the likelihood of detecting early breast tumors. The study was done in two parts. The first part compared Black women with a first-degree relative with breast cancer (FH+) to Black women without a first-degree relative with breast cancer (FH-) on measures of perception of risk, psychological distress (general, cancer-specific and BSE-specific) and breast self-examination (BSE) frequency (N = 100). The Groups differed on perception of risk, BSE-specific distress and short-term BSE frequency. BSE-specific distress mediated the relationship between family history of breast cancer and BSE frequency. When the FH+ and FH- Groups were combined, avoidance and intrusive thoughts were found to be related to BSE frequency. The second part of the study examined the effects African American acculturation on psychological distress and BSE frequency among a sub-sample (N = 67). Only the Preference for African American Things and Interracial Attitude sub-scales were related to BSE frequency. These sub-scales were unrelated to general or cancer-specific distress. The utility of African American acculturation in understanding BSE frequency and implications for breast cancer screening interventions are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Factors and experiences in biracial and biethnic identity development.
column12: Tomishima, Shelly Ann: U Utah, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(2-B), Aug 2000, pp. 1114.
column19: This study examined the identity development and process of biracial/biethnic adults who have one White parent and one racially different parent. The focus was on evaluating an ecological or contextual theory of biracial/biethnic identity. Participants were asked to choose one of three ways in which they would like to participate in the qualitative portion of the study: (a) in-person interviews, (b) E-mail narratives, and (c) written narratives. In addition, all participants were asked to complete the Demographic Measure, the Racial Experiences Questionnaire, and the Physical Resemblance Scale. The grounded theory approach was used to create a theory that was contrasted against an ecological theory of biracial identity development. The qualitative data were analyzed until redundancy was achieved. Several themes emerged from the results, including oppressions, a sociocultural identity theory, the biracial experience, family, the community, and influential relationships. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The psychological adjustment of transracial adoptees: An application of the cultural-racial identity model.
column12: Baden, Amanda L.: Michigan State U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(2-B), Aug 2000, pp. 1070.
column19: In response to the need for increased understanding of the identity process of transracial adoptees, the Cultural-Racial Identity Model (Baden & Steward, 1995) was developed; however, the model has yet to be empirically validated. The model allows distinctions to be made between racial identity and cultural identity. These distinctions comprise 16 proposed identities of transracial adoptees and are made up of the degrees to which individuals: (1) have knowledge of, awareness of, competence within, and comfort with their own racial group's culture, their parents' racial group's culture, and multiple cultures, and (2) are comfortable with their racial group membership and with those belonging to their own racial group, their parents' racial group, and multiple racial groups. These distinctions are comprised of dimensions: the Adoptee Culture Dimension, the Parental Culture Dimension, the Adoptee Race Dimension, and the Parental Race Dimension. The distinctions made by the model can aid in understanding the counseling needs of transracial adoptees as they are affected by the identification with racial groups other than their own. In this study, the Cultural-Racial Identity of transracial adoptees was determined using the Cultural-Racial Identity Questionnaire (CRIQ; as developed for this study) and a modified version of the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (MEIM; Phinney, 1992). Psychological adjustment was assessed by the Brief Symptom Inventory (BSI; Derogatis & Cleary, 1977) and self-esteem was assessed by Rosenberg's Self-Esteem Scale (SES; Rosenberg, 1965). The sample consisted of 51 transracial adoptees who completed mail survey questionnaires. The exploratory findings supported the Cultural-Racial Identity Model by demonstrating that the modified version of the MEIM successfully yielded variation in the potential Cultural-Racial Identities that the transracial adoptees reported. Findings also did not yield support for differences in psychological adjustment among transracial adoptees having different Cultural-Racial Identities but findings did support a relationship where the Parental Race Dimension and the Adoptee Race Dimension predict the self-esteem of transracial adoptees. The implications that the results have for counseling practice and social policy were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Following the inner compass: A hermeneutic-phenomenological study of visions, dreams, art, and intuition.
column12: Apana, Karen Nani: California Inst Integral Studies, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.61(2-A), Aug 2000, pp. 516.
column19: The purpose of this dissertation is to contribute to the paradigm shift of consciousness; a shift that is currently occurring in the Western world and beyond which is attempting to heal the splits between the mind, body, soul and spirit; between the rational and the intuitive, and the word and the image. Following the Inner Compass is an experiential research document using the researcher's selected dreams, visions, art, and psychic experiences over the course of the last thirty years to show the inner workings of the intuitive world. To quote Dissertation committee member Angeles Arrien Ph.D., "This work represents 'the next step' in the development of intuition. When one reads these intuitive stories, it awakens our own intuitive world and gives us a direct experience of the intuitive." (Committee meeting, December 15, 1997) The intuitive stories and dreams in this dissertation act as catalysts and ignite the readers to recall their own intuitive memories. The researcher uses intuitive art, Rudolf Steiner's seven year cycles of human biography (O'Neil, 1990), and the Experiential Method (Kidd & Kidd, 1990) as research methodologies in examining these intuitive processes. Another unique thread that is woven throughout the work is the dialogue between the indigenous and esoteric-Christian parts of the researcher who is of an interracial heritage composed of Hawaiian-Chinese, German, English, French and Irish. This dissertation is an attempt to show the workings of the inner Compass, that deep sense of knowing that can provide inner guidance. It is one woman's story of making a bridge between her external realities and her inner intuitive world. The basic assumption is that the inner work of a single individual contributes to the development of the consciousness of the collective. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: This study examined the role of the value expressive function in moderating the relationship between values, attitudes toward interracial marriage and the extent to which values are manifested in message production. Strongest associations between values, attitudes and use of value appeals were predicted to occur among high value expressive individuals versus low value expressives. Results did not support the predicted moderating effect; rather post hoc analyses suggest a joint additive effect for value expressiveness and values on attitudes. The viability of a mediating role that attitudes may have on message production is proposed. Additionally, the constructs of other-directedness and extroversion, as indirect measures of the value expressive function were found to be irrelevant in the explication of this process. column5: Racial identity development in biracial individuals: An analysis of therapists' accounts of psychosocial and psychological factors.
column12: Gleason, Diana Jean: California School Of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/Alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(1-B), Jul 2000, pp. 530.
column19: The purpose of this study was to explore the contributions of psychosocial and psychological factors in the biracial persons' racial identity development. The predominant perspective of the existing biracial literature is ecosystemic and has focused mainly on psychosocial factors. While these factors are important to consider, an area that has not been addressed in the literature is the contribution of the individual's unique psychology in racial identity. A qualitative study, of semi-structured interviews, was conducted with three psychotherapists who have worked with biracial individuals in insight-oriented treatments. Therapists were asked to talk about their work with one to two of their biracial patients and share their experiences and impressions of particular themes related to biracial identity, including psychosocial factors and psychological factors such as transference, countertransference, object-relations, intrapsychic conflicts, developmental issues, defensive style, and trauma. Four cases were discussed. The findings supported the literature's suggestion of the general influence of the following psychosocial factors on biracial identity: family, extended family, community, peers, school, personal cultural experiences, physiognomy, and historical and socio-political factors. Several other key psychosocial factors emerged that seemed to impact biracial identity formation including, criticism from others regarding culturally appropriate behaviors. The study explored and supported additional areas to consider in future research on biracial identity: (a) experiences with new family members through re-marriage; (b) roles of dating, partnering, spouse, and parent; (c) socio-economic status; (d) acculturation and assimilation; (e) language; (f) gender roles; and (g) media. The biracial persons' relationships with each of their parents, trauma, and how early life experiences are internalized and managed, including how these experiences shape object-relations, conflicts, and what defenses are employed, were shown to be psychological variables in this study that could have an impact on racial identification. Relationships beyond the family seemed to be ways in which the meaning of one's biracial heritage can be recapitulated. Object-relations theory was extended and applied to the process of racial identity formation. The limitations of this study, including its small sample size and its clinical population are discussed. Recommendations for future research and clinician implications for treating biracial persons are presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race and receptivity: An analysis of the convergent and discriminant properties of the scripted dyadic paradigm.
column12: Durm, Jonathan Craig: U Mississippi, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(12-B), Jun 2000, pp. 6421.
column19: The scientific study of race and racism in the United States has proven to be a controversial and complicated affair. Those researchers who have elected to investigate race have found themselves faced with a host of fundamental and subtle problems of measurement. Techniques designed to assess racism have generally taken either of two forms: direct or indirect. To avoid the limitations of indirect measures, many researchers have focused their efforts on the direct assessment of behavior. One promising procedure to emerge from these efforts has been the dyadic interaction paradigm devised by Ickes (1984). Using Ickes' procedure as a guide, a recent study by the author (Durm, 1996) sought to examine the merits of a revised construct and revised assessment paradigm with regards to black-white interactions. The revised construct, referred to as "receptivity", consisted of the following response elements: eye contact, interpersonal distance, openness of body posture, positive affect, and engaging verbal responses. The study placed white female subjects in a waiting room scenario where they were given the opportunity to interact with either a black or white female confederate. Results indicated that subjects displayed more receptive behaviors when in the presence of the white confederate than when in the presence of the black confederate. The present study was an attempt to refine and expand the procedure developed in the initial investigation. To this end an examination of the convergence of the receptivity construct measures with other subtle and obvious measure of racism (i.e., the Modern Racism Scale, Student Racism scale, Right-Wing Authoritarian Scale, Social-Dominance Orientation Scale, and a memory procedure) was conducted. A cluster of three strong relationships emerged among the measures of eye contact, verbal engagement, and positive affect. A second cluster of three moderate relationships was noted between the weighted distance measure and eye contact, positive affect, and verbal engagement. Positive affect was the sole measure to consistently and strongly correlate with the survey measures. Between group differences failed to achieve statistical significance. Significant analysis is directed towards the difficult nature of studying racism and behavior through observation. Finally, several potential research directions are highlighted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The influence of attributional schema on personality stereotyping in the context of affirmative-action hiring policies.
column12: Evans, David Lee: U Iowa, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(12-B), Jun 2000, pp. 6421.
column19: Since the 1960s, an increasing number of social psychological studies of interracial evaluations have shown that European-Amencans tend to evaluate members of stigmatized minority groups more favorably than they do members of their own ingroup The purpose of this series of studies was to test whether Whites' assumptions about the discriminatory obstacles faced by African-Americans may lead to such minority-favoring evaluations, as predicted by the attributional processes of augmenting and discounting. In three studies involving White participants, the last of which was conducted on the World Wide Web, the obstacles perceived to be faced by fictitious Black and White bank employees were manipulated through the use of affirmative-action or equal-opportunity hiring policies. As expected, Whites working under affirmative action were perceived to face greater obstacles to occupational success than Blacks, whereas Blacks working under equal opportunity were perceived to face greater obstacles than Whites. Supporting the role of attributional processes above and beyond the effects of sympathy or self-presentation, Black targets were rated more favorably than White targets primarily when the Black targets were perceived to face greater obstacles. Further suggesting an attributional process, only those personality domains that were causally related to occupational obstacles (i.e., Conscientiousness, Achievement Striving) were affected by the manipulations, and causal attributions for the employees job performance were found to mediate the ratings on these domains. Results also showed that minority-favoring evaluations were made primarily by participants who acknowledged anti-Black discrimination. Such participants also showed a pattern of attributions opposite of the ethnocentric attribution bias. However, no evidence was found for the contemporary criticism of affirmative action that it leads highly skilled beneficiaries to be perceived as incompetent or unambitious by White evaluators. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: An investigation of a small-group intervention to improve interracial college roommate relationships.
column12: Altschul, Deborah Beth: U Georgia, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(11-B), May 2000, pp. 5829.
column19: The present study was designed to investigate the effects of a six-week, small-group intervention on roommate satisfaction, ethnic pride, and other-group orientation in interracial roommate pairs. The sample for this study consisted of 118 randomly assigned freshman and sophomore African American-White residence hall roommate pairs (59 African American and 59 White) at The University of Georgia. Sixty-eight treatment group participants took part in a six-week small-group intervention, and 50 control group participants received no intervention. Participants ranged in age from 17 to 24, with the majority of the participants aged 18 (64%) and 19 (19%). Thirty-four of the participants were male, and 84 were female. ANCOVAs were conducted to investigate whether roommate pairs who participated in the structured small group intervention differed in roommate satisfaction, ethnic pride, and other-group orientation from roommate pairs who did not participate in the intervention, controlling for entering scores on cognitive flex, behavioral flex, and racial identity Results indicated no significant difference in roommate satisfaction, ethnic pride, and other-group, orientation across the interaction of time and condition. Results indicated differential relationships between the dependent variables and the covariates. One-way ANOVAS were conducted to investigate whether differences existed on roommate satisfaction among participants of the same race who differed in racial identity status. Results indicated no significant difference in roommate satisfaction among African American participants, and a significant difference among White participants. A qualitative short-answer question was analyzed using constant comparative analysis to assess the impact of participation in the small-group intervention on the roommate relationship. Seven categories emerged from the data: (1) greater communication within roommate pairs, (2) greater awareness of other cultural norms and values, (3) greater awareness of one's own cultural norms and values, (4) more general knowledge about roommate, (5) closer relationship with roommate, (6) opportunity to spend time together, and (7) no impact on roommate relationship. The implications of these findings in relation to program development and future research were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The use of internal family systems therapy to treat issues of biracial identity development.
column12: Cooper, Benjamin Andrew: United States International U., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(11-B), May 2000, pp. 5767.
column19: The problem. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effect of Internal Family Systems Therapy on the psychological issues related to biracial identity development. Method. A group of 5 biracial individuals ranging in age from 19-35 were recruited through advertisements in a university newspaper and flyers posted throughout the city where the study took place. Criteria for group membership were that one was the offspring of parents who were of two distinctly different ethnic backgrounds, e.g., Black/White, Asian/White, Hispanic/Black, etc. and did not have a serious mental disorder. Each member participated in a pre-screening interview prior to the beginning of the group to acquire demographic information, psychosocial history and to determine if they met the criteria for inclusion in the group. Internal Family Systems Therapy was used in an eight week, group therapy modality. Self reports and the therapist's observational reports were used as the method of identifying positive effects that Internal Family Systems Therapy had on issues related to biracial identity development. Results. The application of the therapeutic approach met the goals of treatment and effected a positive change on members of the group. Each member's journal writings revealed a greater sense of awareness of the issues they have faced in their biracial identity development and a relief from some of the symptoms manifested from the struggles of solidifying such an identity. Furthermore, the application of Internal Family Systems Therapy proved to be a viable approach in helping the group members achieve these results. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Predictors of satisfaction and resiliency in African American/White interracial relationships.
column12: La Taillade, Jaslean Joelle: U Washington, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(11-B), May 2000, pp. 5779.
column19: Although rates of intermarriage among African Americans have risen dramatically in the last 30 years, interracial relationships experience difficulties that couples who share the same background do not, including discrimination and isolation from family and other support networks. However, research and speculation regarding negative impact of these difficulties have been limited to couples in the early stages of their relationships. The current study examined the influence of constructive communication, partner and social support, and aspects of ethnic identity, as potential moderators of the relationship between experience with discrimination and relationship satisfaction in committed, longer-term African American/white interracial relationships. 20 African American/white interracial couples, 14 African American same-race couples, and 17 white same-race couples completed self-report measures of relationship satisfaction, relationship adjustment and communication, partner acceptance, social support and isolation, multicultural and ethnic identity, and experiences with discrimination. Results revealed that interracial couples are as adjusted and satisfied in their relationships with their partners and supports as couples who share the same racial and ethnic backgrounds. Although interracial couples were more likely to report experiences with covert discrimination than same-race couples, experiences of discrimination and social isolation were generally unrelated to relationship functioning in interracial relationships. Multiculturalism and ethnic pride were less central to relationship functioning for interracial couples, as compared to the more global support and acceptance provided by partners. No moderator effects were found. Overall, findings indicate that clinical assumptions regarding the inevitable unhappiness and distress in interracial relationships may be unfounded. The current study expands upon previous research through its examination of committed, longer-term interracial relationships, inclusion of appropriate comparison groups, utilization of standardized measures employed in couple research, and its integration of the stress and coping, racial and ethnic identification, and marital literatures. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Parent reports of child behavior problems in young Sami children: A cross-cultural comparison.
column9:
Javo, C

Heyerdahl, S

Ronning, J. A
column12: Javo, C.: U Tromsoe, Dept of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, Tromsoe, Norway
column13: European Child & Adolescent Psychiatry. Vol.9(3), Sep 2000, pp. 202-211.
column19: In a general population study of 4-year-olds, using the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL), parent reports of child behavior problems were compared in samples of 67 monoethnic Sami, 52 multiethnic Sami/Norwegian, and 63 monoethnic Norwegian children from the Sami core area in northern Norway. Mean CBCL total problem scores were low for all three groups. No significant differences across ethnic groups were found for the Total Problems scale and the Internalizing and Externalizing scales, nor for the syndrome scales, except for the Withdrawn scale, the Sami/Norwegian sample showing the highest scores. However, signicant ethnicity x gender interactions emerged, indicating that the effect of ethnicity was different for boys versus girls. Sami mothers reported the highest and the Norwegian mothers the lowest scores for girls, whereas the opposite pattern was found for boys. Correlations between mothers' and fathers' reports were generally low. Differences in mean scale scores between 122 pairs of parents were found for boys but not for girls, mothers scoring higher than fathers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The nonverbal mediation of self-fulfilling prophecies in interracial interaction.
column9:
Word, Carl O

Zanna, Mark P

Cooper, Joel
column12: Word, Carl O.: Princeton U, Princeton, NJ, US
column13: Stangor, Charles [Ed]. (2000). Stereotypes and prejudice: Essential readings.  (pp. 226-233). xii, 490 pp. New York, NY, US: Psychology Press; US.
column19: (create) This reprinted article originally appeared in (Journal of Experimental Psychology, 1974, 10[2], 109-120). (The following abstract of the original article appeared in record 1974-30050-001.) Conducted 2 experiments designed to demonstrate the existence of a self-fulfilling prophecy mediated by nonverbal behavior in an interracial interaction. Exp I, which employed 14 white job interviewers (male university students) and 5 trained white and black job applicants, demonstrated that black applicants received (a) less immediacy, (b) higher rates of speech errors, and (c) shorter amounts of interview time. Exp II employed 30 naive, white applicants (male university students) and 2 trained white interviewers. In this experiment Ss received behaviors that approximated those given either the black or white applicants in Exp I. Results indicate that Ss treated like the blacks of Exp I were judged to perform less adequately and to be more nervous in the interview situation than Ss treated like the whites. The former Ss also reciprocated with less proximate positions and rated the interviewers as being less adequate and friendly. Implications for black unemployment are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the cover) Introduces classic and contemporary readings on stereotypes, stereotyping, and prejudice from a social-psychological perspective. Specific topics include the principles of social categorization and the representation of group beliefs in memory, the measurement of stereotypes and prejudice, the underlying motivations for holding and using stereotypes and prejudice, the development and change of stereotypes and prejudice, as well as the impact of stereotypes and prejudice on individuals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Sociodemograpghic influences in the prediction of attitudes toward transracial adoption.
column12: Hollingsworth, Leslie Doty: U Michigan, School of Social Work, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Families in Society. Vol.81(1), Jan-Feb 2000, pp. 92-100.
column19: An exploratory study of attitudes toward transracial adoption was conducted, using data from a 1991 national telephone opinion survey of 916 respondents. Seventy-one percent of those surveyed believed that race should not be a factor in who should be allowed to adopt a child. However, in a logistic regression analysis, respondents in the highest age category (i.e., those older than 64 yrs) were 63% less likely to approve of transracial adoption, compared with 18-29-yr-olds. There was also an interaction of race and sex. African-American women were 84% less likely than African-American men to approve of transracial adoption. Compared with African-American men, Caucasian men were 72% less likely to approve. The importance of considering subpopulation differences in applying such findings to adoption policy, research, and practice is discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of racial socialization and racial identity on acculturative stress in African American college students. [References].
column9:
Thompson, C. Patricia

Anderson, Louis P

column12: Thompson, C. Patricia: Georgia State U, Dept of Psychology, Atlanta, GA, US
column13: Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology. Vol.6(2), May 2000, pp. 196-210.
column19: The aim of this study was to determine if racial identity mediates the relation between racial socialization and acculturative stress in African American university students, once demographic factors are accounted for. 84 17-40 yr-old participants participated in focus groups in which the appropriateness of a racial identity measure was discussed and completed a number of scales addressing acculturative stress, racial identity, racial socialization, and interracial experience. Ss also completed a personal data sheet that asked for standard sociodemographic information. Significant relations were found between racial socialization and acculturative stress, racial socialization and racial identity, and racial identity and acculturative stress. Partial support for a mediational model was found, with the best predictors of acculturative stress being immersion attitudes and internalization attitudes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial dating: The implications of race for initiating a romantic relationship.
column9:
Harris, Tina M

column12: Harris, Tina M.: U Georgia, Dept of Speech Communication, Athens, GA, US
column13: Howard Journal of Communications. Vol.11(1), Jan-Mar 2000, pp. 49-64.
column19: Using the centrality of race within the context of romantic relationships, this study was designed to determine how race influences the communicative process. Q-sort methodology was used, which required 120 Ss to determine what waiting, hinting, direct, and third-party intervention strategies they would use to initiate a date in both same-race and interracial contexts. Findings reveal that when comparing verbal strategies across both contexts and open-ended responses to likelihood or reality of dating interracially, Ss were resistant to the idea of dating a person from another race. External factors, such as family and society, were cited as primary deterrents to involvement in an interracial romantic relationship. In general, Ss used more social distancing strategies for initiating interracial dating relationships than same-race dating relationships. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: This study examined the following questions: (1) What kind of ethnic identities are developed by children who have experienced intercountry, transracial adoptions? (2) What factors appear to be associated with the development of these identities? (3) Is the development of ethnic identity related to other aspects of the child's adjustment? 30 adoptive families, including their 40 South Korean children (aged 9-14 yrs), served as Ss. Multiple regression analysis shows that 2 factors are associated with the extent of ethnic identity in the children: their participation in Korean cultural activities and ease of communication between the children and their parents about the adoption. Between the ages of 4 and 6 yrs, the children began to recognize differences when they entered a new situation. Parents played an important role in exposing their children to Korean culture at this stage. Beginning about the age of 7, the children began to learn that ethnicity and facial structure would remain constant across time. They also were able to identify themselves as Korean. Between the ages of 9 and 11, children either accepted their differences or experienced a dissonance about their ethnic identity. Between the ages of 12 and 14, they began integrating Korean heritage and American culture. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Carstens, Carol: Ohio State U, Coll of Social Work, Columbus, OH, US
column13: International Social Work. Vol.43(1), Jan 2000, pp. 61-73.
column19: Examined ethnoracial awareness in intercountry adoption (ICA) families in the US in relation to a preplacement intervention aimed at increasing parental awareness of the adoptee's ethnoracial heritage. A preplacement visit to the adoptee's country of origin was the primary independent variable measured in relation to the family's identification and utilization of a cultural consultant. The variable of ethnoracial awareness was operationalized as the families' identification of and recourse to a cultural consultant. The sample included couples and single parents residing in ICA families. Data collected on 37 families involved 51 ethnoracially different children. 29 adoptees among the 51 children had a cultural consultant, and precustodial visits were made on behalf of 76% of all ICAs. Of 37 families, 49% reported the presence of a cultural consultant for 1 or more of the ICAs in parental custody. Among the 18 families reporting the presence of a cultural consultant, 66% reported precustodial visits to the country of origin. There was a significant positive relationship between a precustodial visit to the child's country of origin and the presence of a cultural consultant. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: This article is the first-known detailed case report on fakamahaki, a culture-bound syndrome from the Kingdom of Tonga. The syndrome is described in a 13-yr-old biracial girl from the perspective of a child psychiatry fellow. To serve as a teaching case for clinicians in training as well as those in practice, the %DSM-IV% outline for cultural formulation has been used. The article offers a social and developmental history of the patient, as well as a family psychiatric history and the course and outcome of the disorder. Cultural explanations of the illness, cultural factors related to the psychosocial environment and levels of functioning, and cultural elements of the clinician-patient relationship are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: (2000). The interracial experience: Growing up Black/White racially mixed in the United States. x, 153 pp. Westport, CT, US: Greenwood Press/Greenwood Publishing Group; US.
column19: (from the publicity materials) Investigates how mixed race people cope in a world that has shoehorned them into a racial category that denies half of their physiological and psychological existence. The author presents relevant demographic, research, and sociocultural data as well as a series of personal vignettes based on interviews with 119 American-born black/white interracial young adults (mean age of 21.4 yrs) from all walks of life. The author interweaves research findings with these interviews in order to highlight certain psychosocial phenomenon and experiences. The history of interracial marriages in the US is examined, and the scientific and social theories that underlie the racial bigotry suffered by mixed people are discussed. Questions of racial identity, conflict, and self-esteem are addressed and treated as issues of mental health, and the struggle for acceptance in a black and white world and the racist abuses that many interracial people have suffered are discussed as well. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Marital conflict and finances among Filipinas in Australia.
column9:
Woelz-Stirling, Nicole

Manderson, Lenore

Kelaher, Margaret

Gordon, Sara
column12: Woelz-Stirling, Nicole: Griffith U, School of Modern Asian Studies, Brisbane, QLD, Australia
column13: International Journal of Intercultural Relations. Vol.24(6), Nov 2000, pp. 791-805.
column19: Examined cultural issues involved in financial disputes in Filipinas-Australian marriages. 481 Filipina residents of Queensland (mean age 41 yrs) completed questionnaires, with 139 Ss also completing interviews and 90 Ss participating in focus group discussions. Results show that decisions to migrate and marry Australian men were influenced by perceptions of the relative wealth of their future husband and their presumed enhanced ability to provide support for Filipino kin. Finances were a constant point of tension in many Filipina-Australian marriages because of unrealized financial expectations, issues related to the remittance of money to family in the Philippines, the husband's disapproval of his wife's participation in the paid workforce, and financial practices such as the management of the household finances. It is concluded that premigration financial counselling is important for both Filipinas and Australian men. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: "In my mind, we are all humans": Notes on the public management of Black-White interracial romantic relationships.
column12: Datzman, Jeanine: Indiana U, Indianapolis, IN, US
column13: Marriage & Family Review. Vol.30(1-2), 2000, pp. 5-24.
column19: Using the results of 19 in-depth qualitative interviews and observations, the authors suggest that one interpersonal skill involved in maintaining successful interracial Black-White romantic relationships can be the management of public harassment. Specifically, this refers to the management of evaluative, hostile, and discriminatory actions and reactions that couples receive from strangers in public places. Informants (aged 21-40 yr olds) all living in the Midwest, suggested that, at the very least, a continuing interracial relationship must learn to deal with many forms of public harassment. Another theme from the reports of the informants concerned the variety of ways that public harassment was dealt with. The informants (1) reported that harassment behavior fell into the 3 main categories, (2) detailed the management strategies and attitudes they used to deal with harassment, and (3) indicated how important such public harassment was for the partner choice of interracial couples and, symbolically, for the society at large. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Adjustments of transracially and intracially adopted young adults.
column12: Feigelman, William: Nassau Community Coll, Dept of Sociology, Garden City, NY, US
column13: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal. Vol.17(3), Jun 2000, pp. 165-183.
column19: This study follows up a sample of transracial and inracial children adopted in infancy in the mid-1970s. The present report, based on 1993 data, covers parental assessments when children were in their early 20s (mean age 23 yrs). This report compares 37 inracially adopted White young adults with 151 transracially adopted Asians, 33 African Americans, and 19 Latinos. Parental judgments and reports were used to assess problem behavior, and the Global Assessment Scale and an index of dysfunctionality were used to assess problematic adjustments. Comparisons show no significant adjustment deficits for the subgroups of transracial adoptees in comparison with their inracially adopted White peers. Adjustment problems vary considerably among the transracially adopted young adults; discrimination against the transracial adoptee, and discomfort about their appearance are found as significant correlates associated with adjustment difficulties. Parents report fewer adoptees feeling uneasy about their appearances, when adoptive families live in racially heterogeneous settings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Strategies for racial identity development: Narratives of Black and White women in interracial partner relationships.
column12: Hill, Miriam R.: Purdue U, Dept of Child Development & Family Studies, West Lafayette, IN, US
column13: Family Relations: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Applied Family Studies. Vol.49(2), Apr 2000, pp. 193-200.
column19: This exploratory qualitative study used individual interviews and a focus group of 7 women (aged 22-44 yrs) to investigate how women in Black-White interracial heterosexual partner relationships retrospectively described their racial identity development over the course of the relationships. Racial identity development, social constructionist, and feminist theories guided the grounded theory methodology. Participants described a process of restorying constraining narratives of racial identity into empowering racial identities through three types of strategies: blocking strategies, transforming strategies, and generating strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Ethnically heterogamous marriages: The case of Asian Canadians.
column12: Tzeng, Jessie M.: McGill U, Dept of Sociology, Montreal, PQ, Canada
column13: Journal of Comparative Family Studies. Vol.31(3), Sum 2000, pp. 321-337.
column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: Using the Family Public Use Microdata Sample file (PUMS-F) of the 1981 and 1991 Censuses of Canada, this paper examines patterns and changes in propensities to intermarry for Asians in Canada from 1981 to 1991. A logistic response model is used to explore the relative importance of couples' individual characteristics and SES on intermarriage. An upward trend of Asian intermarriage in the past 2 decades was not evident in the Canadian data. Multivariate analyses suggest the individual's achieved socioeconomic characteristics have become more critical in the process of interracial assortative mating over time. More specifically, educational and employment heterogamous couples are more likely to be intermarried, especially when the wife's achievement exceeds that of the husband's. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The structure(s) of racial attitudes among White college students.
column9:
Baldwin, John R

Day, L. Edward

Hecht, Michael L
column12: Baldwin, John R.: Illinois State U, Dept of Communication, Normal, IL, US
column13: International Journal of Intercultural Relations. Vol.24(5), Sep 2000, pp. 553-577.
column19: Examined the structure of racism and racial attitudes among White college students, as based on research that has proposed at least 3 structures to Whites' racial attitudes. These are: (1) a one-dimensional structure in which racism is treated as a whole; (2) target-based factors in which racism towards 1 target group might be different than racism towards another target; and (3) function-based factors in which there are different aspects of racism towards a given target group. Ss were 282 18-45 yr old undergraduates at a large university in the Southwestern US. They completed a demographic questionnaire, and a racism survey with closed-end attitude questions targeting African Americans and Mexican Americans. The survey was based on M. L. Byrd's original racism scale, the Tolerance of Human Diversity Instrument (1993). Results suggest that a 3-factor solution provides the best explanation of the data, suggesting distinct but interrelated views towards intimate interracial relationships, towards social relationships, and towards macro-social/political phenomena. The results failed to support the authors' contention of ethnic/racial target-based racism. Theoretical and policy implications are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Migration, culture conflict and psychological well-being among Turkish-British married couples.
column12: Baltas, Zuhal: U Istanbul, Cerrahpasa Medical School, Dept of Public Health, Istanbul, Turkey
column13: Ethnicity & Health. Vol.5(2), May 2000, pp. 173-180.
column19: Assessed culture conflict within marriage and the psychological well-being of Turkish men and women and their British partners. The hypothesis was tested that among migrants who are well established economically and socially within a new country, the perception of cultural conflict within marriage might override acculturation as a determinant of psychological well-being. Interviews were carried out with 23 relatively affluent Turkish men and 10 women who had been born in Turkey and had been resident in the UK for an average of 12.2 yrs, and with their British partners. A marital cultural difficulties index was constructed from ratings of problems stemming from cultural differences in 22 aspects of daily living. Depression, assessed with the Beck Depression Inventory, was correlated with marital cultural difficulties in both Turkish and British Ss, independently of sex, age and duration of marriage. Depression scores were higher among respondents who reported greater cultural conflict. The results highlight the implications of residual cultural conflict within mixed marriages for psychological well-being. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
