column5: Psychoanalytic group psychotherapy with African American women: The bad mother in all-female groups. [References].
column12: White, Judith C.: Private Practice, New York, NY, US
column13: Jackson, Leslie C [Ed]; Greene, Beverly [Ed]. (2000). Psychotherapy with African American women: Innovations in psychodynamic perspective and practice.  (pp. 208-224). xxii, 298 pp. New York, NY, US: Guilford Press; US.
column19: (from the chapter) This chapter explores the working-through process of the bad mother transference in combined individual and group treatment with all-female groups from an object relations perspective. Attention is paid to how the bad mother transference interacts with issues of race and ethnicity, and to ways of healing the defensive splitting that gives rise to the bad mother transference. B. P. Karon and A. J. Widener (1995) cite the work of M. Klein (1930, 1948) in their definition of splitting as an unconscious defense mechanism that the patient is unable to integrate both the good and bad introjects (images) of mother and/or of self. In relationships, when an individual engages in defensive splitting, the individual experiences other people and themselves as either all good or all bad. The realistic good and bad elements of both the self and others are not integrated and cannot be experienced simultaneously. Clinical vignettes are drawn from two groups in the author's private psychotherapy practice. Group 1, an interracial group, which began in 1984, was an all-female group. Men were integrated into the group beginning in 1991, the group's seventh year. Group 2 is an all-female group of African American women that began in 1992. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The African American supervisor: Racial transference and countertransference in interracial psychotherapy supervision. [References].
column12: Owens-Patterson, Michele: New Hope Guild's East New York Children's Clinic, NY, US
column13: Jackson, Leslie C [Ed]; Greene, Beverly [Ed]. (2000). Psychotherapy with African American women: Innovations in psychodynamic perspective and practice.  (pp. 145-165). xxii, 298 pp. New York, NY, US: Guilford Press; US.
column19: (from the chapter) As an increasing number of people of color have entered the ranks of mental health practitioners, the configuration of treatment dyads (and triads) has changed. Traditionally, White clinicians have treated most patients of any color. With the entry of greater numbers of therapists who are people of color, patients have begun to be treated by persons of a wider range of ethnic backgrounds. Furthermore, as African American clinicians credentialed in the 1970s through the 1980s matured in their careers, the complexion of senior clinicians, teachers, and supervisors changed. Thus, the potential in treatment for a variety of dynamic interactions and unconscious responses will develop in response to this experience of difference. The examination of this inter- and intraethnic experience in supervision is the focus of the chapter. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) This book explores doing psychodynamic therapy with African American women. The authors hope that the readers will develop a broader understanding of what is both useful and problematic when applying psychodynamic theories to African American female clients. The aim of the book is to help mental health professionals identify the differences among intrapsychic, cultural variables, and social constructions, so as to better understand how these interacting variables affect the coping and functioning of African American women. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Converging interracial consequences of exposure to violent rap music on stereotypical attributions of blacks.
column9:
Johnson, James D

Trawalter, Sophie

Dovidio, John F
column12: Johnson, James D.: U North Carolina, Dept of Psychology, Wilmington, NC, US
column13: Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. Vol.36(3), May 2000, pp. 233-251.
column19: Explored how media, specifically violent rap music, may influence Blacks' and Whites' attribution of Blacks through stereotype priming. Ss consisted of 52 female and 38 male undergraduate Whites, and 50 female and 40 male undergraduate Blacks. When compared to controls and Ss exposed to nonviolent Black musicians, those exposed to violent Black musicians reported attributions of a target Black male's violent behavior that was particularly dispositional relative to attributions of a White male's violent behavior or to any other condition. The findings also indicated that the impact of exposure to violent rap music generalized to judgments involving other stereotype-related traits (i.e., intelligence) but not to judgments of nonstereotypical traits (i.e., spatial skills). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Dattilio, Frank M

Jongsma, Arthur E Jr.

column13: (2000). The family therapy treatment planner. xiv, 319 pp. Hoboken, NJ, US: John Wiley & Sons Inc; US.
column19:
(from the introduction) The purpose of this book is to clarify, improve, and accelerate the family therapy treatment planning process and to effectively deal with some of the hurdles that come with obtaining 3rd-party authorization for family treatment. It is also designed to serve as a framework for clinicians to follow as they plot an effective course of treatment with challenging cases.
(from the cover) Organized around 34 main presenting problems, from child/parent conflict and alcohol abuse to divorce/separation, depression, jealousy and more. This sourcebook also features (1) statements that describe the behavioral manifestations of each relational problem, long-term goals, short-term objectives, and clinically tested treatment options, (2) a sample treatment plan that can be emulated in writing plans that meet all requirements of 3rd party payers and accrediting agencies, and (3) a quick reference format that allows the reader to easily locate treatment plan components by behavioral problem or DSM-IV diagnosis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: 620 university students completed an anonymous confidential questionnaire designed to assess attitudes toward interracial dating. Almost one-fourth (24.2%) reported having dated interracially and almost half (49.6%) expressed an openness to become involved in an interracial relationship. Blacks, cohabitants, and those with previous interracial dating experience were significantly more likely to express an openness to become involved in an interracial relationship. Implications for university faculty, therapists, and students are suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Subtractive bilingualism and the survival of the Inuit language: Heritage- versus second-language education. [References].
column9:
Wright, Stephen C

Taylor, Donald M

Macarthur, Judy
column12: Wright, Stephen C.: U California, Dept of Psychology, Santa Cruz, CA, US
column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.92(1), Mar 2000, pp. 63-84.
column19: A longitudinal study examined the impact of early heritage- and second-language education on heritage- and second-language development among Inuit, White, and mixed-heritage (Inuit/White) children. Children in an arctic community were tested in English, French and Inuttitut at the beginning and end of each of the first 3 school years. Compared with Inuit in heritage language and mixed-heritage children in a second language, Inuit in second-language classes (English or French) showed poorer heritage language skills and poorer second-language acquisition. Conversely, Inuit children in Inuttitut classes showed heritage language skills equal to or better than mixed-heritage children and Whites educated in their heritage languages. Findings support claims that early instruction exclusively in a societally dominant language can lead to subtractive bilingualism among minority-language children, and that heritage language education may reduce this subtractive process. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Using eye movement desensitization and reprocessing to treat complex PTSD in a biracial client. [References].
column12: JoAn, Rittenhouse: Private Practice, Las Cruces, NM, US
column13: Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology. Vol.6(4), Nov 2000, pp. 399-408.
column19: A biracial client's recovery from posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) through the use of eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) is discussed to illustrate the interaction between ethnicity and phenotype as well as diagnosis and treatment considerations. This case explores a woman's experience of discrimination in and out of her home and her vulnerability to complex PTSD, and it documents the importance of the therapy focusing on experiences of discrimination and prejudice as well as abuse. It shows how the client structures her environment in a personally creative fashion to include representative features of various aspects of her identity, by her choice of where and who she teaches as well as how and with whom she spends her free time. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Effects of race and victim drinking, on domestic violence attributions.
column9:
Harrison, Lisa A

Willis Esqueda, Cynthia
column12: Harrison, Lisa A.: U Nebraska, Dept of Psychology, Lincoln, NE, US
column19: Examined the mutual influence of race and victim drinking on college students' domestic violence attributions. Participants were 200, predominately White, middle-class college students. Ss read a vignette depicting a domestic violence incident. Manipulated within the vignette were batterer race, victim race, and victim drinking. After reading the vignette, participants completed a questionnaire concerning their perceptions of the domestic assault. Results indicate batterers in interracial relationships are attributed more guilt than batterers in same-race relationships. In addition, when domestic violence victims drink alcoholic beverages before a domestic assault, more responsibility for the assault is attributed to Black victims than to their White counterparts. Results also revealed domestic violence victims who drink alcohol are ascribed more blame and derogation in comparison to abstinent domestic violence victims. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The ways and means of interracial aggression: Modern racists' use of covert retaliation.
column9:
Beal, Daniel J

O'Neal, Edgar C

Ong, Jason

Ruscher, Janet B
column12: Beal, Daniel J.: Tulane U, Dept of Psychology, New Orleans, LA, US
column13: Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. Vol.26(10), Oct 2000, pp. 1225-1238.
column19: Modern racists are theorized to have negative affect and attitudes toward African Americans yet may be motivated to avoid appearing prejudiced. Thus, they may behave toward African Americans in covert ways. This hypothesis was tested using both an overt and covert measure of aggression in a competitive reaction-time task. Exp 1 (n = 87 university students) found that high modern racists were more overtly and covertly aggressive than were low modern racists, regardless of competitor race. In addition, high modern racists displayed a pattern of increasing covert aggression toward African Americans, whereas low modern racists inhibited retaliation even under high levels of provocation. Exp 2 (n = 78 university students) replicated Exp 1 and provided evidence suggesting that covert aggression is a strategic process that cannot be employed under conditions of reduced cognitive capacity. Covert aggression, along with other covert behaviors, is seen as highlighting differences between high and low modern racists. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: In the past two decades a growing body of empirical research has purported to demonstrate that transracial adoption does not negatively impact, and may positively benefit, children of color, particularly Black children. This article critically examines the studies purporting to establish this conclusion. It is argued that several methodological difficulties exist in these studies. In addition, both legal and scientific assessments of children's well-being define adjustment and maladjustment according to Eurocentric norms that define individual well-being in isolation from the well-being of one's racial or ethnic group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Biracial-bisexual individuals: Identity coming of age.
column12: Collins, J. Fuji: U Arizona, Dept of Multicultural Programs & Services, Tucson, AZ, US
column13: International Journal of Sexuality & Gender Studies. Vol.5(3), Jul 2000, pp. 221-253.
column19: There is considerable controversy regarding the means by which bisexual and biracial individuals achieve a sense of identity. In this paper, the concepts of bisexual and biracial identity are reviewed, and the literature on identity developmental models are critiqued. Further, a qualitative study is presented that explored the complexity of biracial identity development in 15 20-40 yr old Japanese-Americans. Ss explored identity options attempting to develop their own meaning of identity, to develop a confident sense of themselves and secure a positive ethnic identity. Based on research and dialogue, there appears to be parallels between bisexual and biracial identity development. A model is proposed that suggests that individuals who are bisexual or biracial go through four phases in their development of their positive identity. These phases are: Phase I-Questioning/Confusion; Phase II-Refusal/Suppression; Phase III-Infusion/Exploration; and Phase IV-Resolution/Acceptance. These phases describe people who have two distinct identities that place them in a position of self-devaluation. From there they move to a position where there is a positive perception of identity based on the coexistence of their identities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A framework for use with racially and culturally integrated families: The cultural-racial identity model as applied to transracial adoption.
column9:
Baden, Amanda L

Steward, Robbie J
column12: Baden, Amanda L.: St. John's U, Div of Human Services & Counseling, Jamaica, NY, US
column13: Journal of Social Distress & the Homeless. Vol.9(4), Oct 2000, pp. 309-337.
column19: Presents the Cultural-Racial Identity Development model (R. J. Steward and A. L. Baden, 1995) for understanding and depicting the unique identity experiences of those reared in racially or culturally integrated families. The model accounts for heterogeneity within groups defined by their racially integrated families. It allows distinctions to be made between racial identity and cultural identity. These distinctions comprise 16 identities of transracial adoptees and are made up of the degrees to which individuals have knowledge of, awareness of, competence within, and comfort with their own racial group's culture. Additionally, the model holds that parents' racial group's culture, and multiple cultures play a role, as well as the degree to which children are comfortable with their racial group membership and with individuals belonging to their own racial group, their parents' racial group, and multiple racial groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Adult foreign adoptees: Reactive attachment disorder may grow into psychic homelessness.
column12: Hoksbergen, Rene: Utrecht U, Utrecht, Netherlands
column13: Journal of Social Distress & the Homeless. Vol.9(4), Oct 2000, pp. 291-308.
column19: Reviews literature concerning the physical and psychological characteristics of foreign-born adoptees adopted by Dutch parents, and examined the prevalence of reactive attachment disorder (RAD) in such adoptees subsequently placed in residential care. Foreign adoption is often accompanied by complex problems, including reactive attachment disorder (RAD) and other serious health problems. The continuation of RAD in adulthood results in feelings of psychic homelessness. Dutch parents of 30 foreign-born adopted children that had been subsequently placed into residential care completed the Child Behavior Checklist (T. M. Achenbach and C. S. Edelbrock, 1983) (CBCL), and 40 adoptees (aged 15-20 yrs) in residential care completed a related questionnaire, the Youth Self- Report. As well, 2,148 adoptive parents with children not in residential care and a large group of 10-15 yr old adopted children completed the CBCL. Results show that nonadopted children, adopted boys, and those aged 12-15 yrs displayed more stealing, lying, cheating, vandalism, and other antisocial behaviors compared to controls. Adopted girls aged 12-15 yrs displayed higher scores related to cruel and aggressive behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Dickinson, Gerald B.: Arkansas State U, Dept of Educational Administration & Secondary Education, State U, AR, US
column13: The Journal of Educational Research. Vol.93(6), Jul-Aug 2000, pp. 391-394.
column19: Are magnet schools diminishing students' resistance to racial interaction? In an attempt to add to the literature addressing this question, the authors of a 6-year study focused on social interactions of 5,965 Black and White 4th-6th grade students in urban magnet schools in a Southern county. The authors used sociograms to analyze students' "work-with" "sit-near," and "play-with" interaction choices. Findings suggested the following: (1) Black students appeared less willing than White students to interact. (2) Racial considerations seemed more pronounced among girls than among boys. (3) Black female students were the most reluctant group to interact across racial lines. (4) No trend toward higher percentages of students choosing to mix across racial lines was detected. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Status exchange in intermarriage among Hawaiians, Japanese, Filipinos and Caucasians in Hawaii: 1983-1994. [References].
column12: Fu, Xuanning: Brigham Young U Hawaii Campus, Social Sciences Div, Laie Oahu, HI, US
column13: Journal of Comparative Family Studies. Vol.31(1), Win 2000, pp. 45-61.
column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: Intermarriage is one of the most salient demographic features of Hawaii. Between 1983 and 1994, 46% of all marriages contracted in Hawaii were racially exogamous. Over 80% of these intermarriages were formed among 4 major ethnic groups in the islands: Caucasians, Japanese, Filipinos and Hawaiians. This paper examines socioeconomic status exchange in outgroup marriage. Status homogamy emerges as the most important pattern of mate selection. In a broad sense, people choose their mate on the basis of equal socioeconomic status, either within or across boundaries of race and ethnicity. Gender differences are very small, indicating that status is equally important for both men and women in choosing a marital partner. However, these patterns suggest that groups of very high and very low status have a very restricted marriage market. Continued intermarriage also raises questions about how to measure race and ethnicity in the islands. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Studied factors associated with the emergence of stereotypes in 25 university students in France. Ss were asked to interview acquaintances they thought were racist and those they thought were not racist about their views on interracial marriages. The interview results were evaluated using discourse analysis techniques. The results indicate that "supposedly" racist Ss format their arguments about interracial marriage as impersonal truths, using passive 3rd person voice ("It is true that..."), while "supposedly" non-racist subjects present arguments about interracial marriage as personal opinions, using active 1st person voice ("I think that..."). The relation of attitude and logical argument style are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology. Vol.20(4), Oct-Dec 1999, pp. 551-573.
column19: Used sociometric questionnaires to examine the relationship between interracial friendships, multicultural sensitivity, and social competence in 170 5th-grade children. Participants completed 4 questionnaires that provided information about who their friends were, friendship quality, racial and ethnic attitudes, and social competence. Results indicate that 5th-grade girls with high-quality interracial friendships indicated less minority rejection, more diverse social networks, and more sociability and leadership characteristics than their peers with no or low-quality interracial friendships. Similar results were not found for boys in the study. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A test of the grapevine: An empirical examination of conspiracy theories among African Americans.
column9:
Parsons, Sharon

Simmons, William

Shinhoster, Frankie

Kilburn, John
column12: Parsons, Sharon: Southern U, Dept of Public Administration, Baton Rouge, LA, US
column13: Sociological Spectrum. Vol.19(2), Apr-Jun 1999, pp. 201-222.
column19: Examined the prevalence and correlates of belief in conspiracy theories among African Americans in Louisiana. Correlates examined were beliefs related to guns, miseducation of Blacks, government promotion of drug use, police harassment, government information about AIDS, criminal justice system bias, government surveillance of Black organizations, and genocide (AIDS, family planning, interracial adoption, needle distribution). Overall results, based on survey responses of 1,104 parishioners of 35 churches, show a strong belief in most conspiracy theories involving government. Over 85% agreed or strongly agreed that African Americans are harassed by police because of their race and that the criminal justice system is not fair to Blacks. The least supported theories involved transracial adoption, family planning, and needle-exchange programs as genocide. Benign theories were more prevalent than malicious intent theories. Church attendance was not significantly related to support for malicious intent theories, whereas it was negatively related to support for benign theories. It is concluded that those who believed that Blacks could influence the political process were less likely to believe in conspiracy theories. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) Begins from the position that the phenotypic characters used to pick out races neither have intrinsic significance nor are correlated with characteristics that are significant, and that interracial variation is far greater than interracial variation. Does this mean that eliminativism is correct? The author argues that it does not, and that, however admirably motivated, eliminativist approaches have failed to recognize more subtle ways in which divisions into races might have biological significance. Further, some of the ways in which concepts of race figure in social discussions are explored, indicating questions that would have to be resolved if the practice of discarding racial divisions were lead to desirable conclusions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Television and prejudice reduction: When does television as a vicarious experience make a difference? [References].
column12: Graves, Sherryl Browne: City U New York, Hunter Coll, Dept of Educational Foundations & Counseling Programs, New York, NY, US
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.55(4), Win 1999, pp. 707-727.
column19: Televised role portrayals and interracial interactions, as sources of vicarious experience, contribute to the development of stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination among children. The 1st section of this article reviews the amount and nature of racial/ethnic content on television, including limited portrayals of racial/ethnic groups and of interracial/ethnic interaction. The 2nd section focuses on theoretical models that help explain television's role in the development, maintenance, and modification of stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination. The 3rd section addresses research on the effects of television in altering stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination, with particular attention given to media intervention programs specifically designed to address these issues ( Sesame Street and Different and the Same). This article concludes with a discussion of suggestions for future research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Organizational effects on race relations in schools. [References].
column9:
Khmelkov, Vladimir T

Hallinan, Maureen T
column12: Khmelkov, Vladimir T.: U Notre Dame, Inst for Educational Initiatives, Notre Dame, IN, US
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.55(4), Win 1999, pp. 627-645.
column19: Identifies organizational structures and practices in schools that influence the frequency of interracial interactions, the likelihood of cross-race friendships, and students' attitudes and behaviors toward members of different racial and ethnic groups. These formal and informal organizational practices include curriculum tracking, assignment to classes, attendance at school level functions, and extracurricular activities. The article discusses how the quality of interracial interactions and the resulting relationships among students is influenced by the contexts of these different organizational practices, including students' status expectations, cooperative vs competitive modes of academic and extracurricular interactions, and educators' views on racial/ethnic issues and their preferences for instructional methods. It is suggested that by taking these effects into account, schools can make significant advances in promoting positive race relations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The American adoption of Indian children from Mother Theresa's orphanages: The parents.
column12: Goodman, Joan F.: U Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, US
column13: Adoption Quarterly. Vol.3(2), 1999, pp. 5-27.
column19: Explores the family backgrounds and personal motives of 70 families who adopted Indian children from Mother Theresa's orphanages in the late 1970s and 1980s. The authors ask what kind of people seek to adopt children of another ethnic group and color who also are highly likely to have chronic disabilities-physical, emotional, behavioral, intellectual. The inquiry, while without formal hypotheses, was informed by depictions of altruists and rescuers of Holocaust victims. Results found a strong resemblance between the adoptive parents, altruists and rescuers in the following respects: (1) the description of their backgrounds and their own life choices as ordinary; (2) the description of early development and early family relationships as extremely mentally healthy; (3) the highly ethical orientation of their lives combined with a lack of specific ideological commitments. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A study of the perceptions of interracial dating and friendship patterns among high school students.
column12: Mayfield-Fleming, Ellen Rae: U Detroit Mercy, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(5-B), Nov 1999, pp. 2411.
column19: This study examined factors which influence interracial dating and friendship patterns among high school students. The possible environmental factors to be investigated included location of the high schools (urban and suburban), and parents attitudes and beliefs regarding race relations with people who may be culturally different. The possibility that interracial friendships and dating choices are the result of a developmental stage adolescents go through was also explored. This study used the original Eriksonian theory as a basic foundation to examine the ego development of high school students to measure their different ego identity statuses as postured by G. Adams, L. Bennion, and K. Huh (1989), and determine if a relationship exists between their cognitive growth and the number of interracial friendships students have. A 192-item survey of background variables, interpersonal attitudes, experiences and choices was developed by P. Christian-Kliger and E. Mayfield-Fleming to ascertain contemporary perspectives on interracial perceptions of dating and friendships, the personal attitudes or motives that support or reject these perceptions of interracial dating and friendship patterns, and the reasons people use to rationalize their friendships and dating choices. A 64-item Objective Measure of Ego Identity Status developed by G. Adams, L. Bennion, and K. Huh (1989) was used to measure the cognitive growth of these students. The results showed the following findings: (1) urban students have more interracial friendships than suburban students; (2) high school students show more diverse patterns in friendships based on their positive attitudes about interracial relationships, but not when it comes to the frequency of them dating interracially; (3) urban and suburban students' perceptions of more tolerant parental attitudes towards other racial groups did correlate with the students' positive attitudes concerning interracial friendships but did not correlate with parents' attitudes about dating; (4) age did not predict ego identity status in the study, hypothesis could not be tested because no students achieved ego identity achieved status in the study; (5) in urban and suburban communities used in the study, perceptions of parental attitudes towards other racial groups were related to their children's attitudes for Marcia's foreclosed identity status and for ego identity diffused status as well. When parents' and students' attitudes were correlated with moratorium, students' attitudes correlated with mothers' attitudes but not with fathers'; (6) no significance was found either in the number of friendships or frequency of dating partners with students classified as ego identity achieved or moratorium and ego identity foreclosed or diffused when correlated with the number of interracial friendships and dating partners. Ego identity status did not make a difference when choosing friends or dating partners. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: 'Ala Kondre' (all countries), but 'na fraga' (no flag)? a multidimensional analysis of the experiences of Surinamese 'Doglas' (multiracials) in the Caribbean.
column12: Van Tuyl, Loraine Yvette: Pacific Graduate School Of Psychology, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(5-B), Nov 1999, pp. 2413.
column19: In this qualitative study, the experiences of fifteen multiracial adults (17-30 years) living in Suriname, South America, were explored through the use of interviews and surveys. The nine female and six male research participants who volunteered to participate in this study were predominantly from the capital of Suriname, Paramaribo. The participants had two to six different ethnic/racial backgrounds that were representative of all the major groups in Suriname (i.e., Amerindian, Chinese, Creole/African, White, Hindustani, and Javanese). The interview questions were based on Root's Ecological Model of Racial Identity Development (1997) and explored the relationship between macro-level contextual factors (i.e., class, gender, and regional race relations) as well as micro-level contextual factors (i.e., generation), social interactions within the community, family influences, and individual traits. A macro-level outer lens was also added to this model to investigate the impact that dominant cultural values regarding vertical and horizontal individualism and collectivism had on the construction of gender, class, and race. These concepts were quantitatively measured by a modified version of a scale designed by Singelis, Triandis, Bhawuk, and Gelfand (1995) and supplemented the interview data. The interview and survey data that were provided by the participants revealed that horizontal and vertical concepts of self seemed to have a differential effect on race relations. The participants, who were mostly horizontally collectivistic and individualistic, believed that their cultural beliefs were reflective of a majority group in Suriname that was multiracial and multicultural, and that was continuously expanding its in-group boundaries. The male participants, who tended to have higher scores on the vertical scales and lower scales on the horizontal scales compared to the female participants, experienced more multiracial conflict (i.e., marginalization, pressure to choose) when interacting with "traditional" people from ethnic and racial groups with a predominantly vertical and collectivistic orientation (i.e., Hindustanis and Chinese), were more likely to rank their cultural values, and more prone to dichotomize their groups of affiliation. Although White supremacy ideologies and Eurocentrism were also significant factors that influenced race relations, the inherent cultural values of the local ethnic groups appeared to play an equally significant role. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Personal, community and familial influences on racial identification choice and positive psychological well-being among biracial adults.
column12: Zwiebach-Sherman, Carol: California School Of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(5-B), Nov 1999, pp. 2414.
column19: Although there has been a significant increase in the biracial population in the US, little empirical research has been conducted relevant to psychological and developmental issues. Consequently, the purpose of this correlational study is two-fold: (a) to examine the personal, familial and community influences on racial identification choice among biracial adults; and (b) to examine the relationship between biracial participants' racial identification choice and well-being. The sample was composed of 86 adults who had a biological parent who was from a racial/ethnic minority group and a biological parent who was white. Participants were recruited through a web page advertisement on the internet, and they completed a questionnaire which was linked to this page. The results showed some support for most of the main research hypotheses. More specifically, participants' perceptions of physical similarity to biracial people were significantly higher among synthesizers as compared to other racial identification groups. Synthesizers had higher scores on items that assessed their degree of knowledge to their white parent's familial and historical culture as compared to minority identifiers. In addition, perceived physical resemblance to their minority parent's racial/ethnic group, degree of knowledge to minority familial and historical culture, contact with white people and male gender accounted for 36 percent of the explained variance in majority group racial identification. Contact with whites accounted for 20 percent of the variance in minority group racial identification. Perceived physical resemblance to whites accounted for 16 percent of the variance in disaffiliate racial identification. Contact with whites and female gender accounted for 15 percent of the variance in synthesizer racial identification. Perceived physical resemblance to whites and to biracial people, female gender, and age accounted for 42 percent of the variance in well-being. In conclusion, the results of this study indicate that personal, familial and community factors significantly influence racial identification choice among biracial adults. Moreover, personal factors and demographic variables significantly predict positive psychological well-being among this group. Future research in this area should continue to refine the new measures and internet methodology to further specify sociocultural variables that are essential in promoting healthy racial identity among biracial people. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Creative differences: The creative decision-making process in group situation comedy writing.
column12: Pritzker, Steven Richard: U Southern California, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.60(5-A), Nov 1999, pp. 1452.
column19: As competition intensifies and jobs become increasingly complex, more people in organizations are working collaboratively. Situation comedy writing offers an ideal opportunity to examine the creative process of a group as it transpires. This case study explores the creative decision-making process in the development of one episode of a half hour network interracially themed situation comedy television script from conception through final production. The qualitative study was designed to understand (a) Management including organizational climate and management style, (b) Creative factors and practical and logistical variables that influenced writing decisions, (c) Group dynamics including interpersonal and intrapersonal factors, and (d) Factors that encouraged or discouraged conditions for creativity. Executive Producers and the writer of the episode were interviewed throughout the process. All written materials were reviewed as well as audio tapes of story conferences. Observations of the reading, run-throughs and final taping were made. This episode was particularly interesting because one of the stories was based on interracial relations and the writer was African American while the Executive Producers were white. A clear contrast in creative decision-making was illustrated between the two stories in this episode. One plot quickly selected was a predictable father-son with a standard resolution. A second story about racial harassment was much riskier because it didn't provide a ready-made resolution. Positive conditions for creative collaboration included a safe atmosphere where members of the group built upon each others ideas and a corporate climate where staff members felt free from studio and network interference. A negative condition was the unwillingness of the Owners to delegate and their proclivity to demand massive rewrites which generated fear of change, fatigue and resulted in less than maximum effort. Another negative was the relationship between the Executive Producers and the writer which included unaddressed disagreements about content and underlying communication style. Unwillingness to resolve this conflict diluted focus and distorted reactions resulting in an avoidance paradox. Implications for lessening the impact of creative differences are suggested including developing clear managerial policy for delegation of authority, timely decision-making and handling sensitive inter cultural and inter gender issues. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Awareness of being White, perceptions about racial minority groups, and interracial contact: A study of Mennonites in America. (White racial awareness).
column12: Stoltzfus, Jill Christine: U Pennsylvania, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(4-B), Oct 1999, pp. 1837.
column19: This study investigates factors affecting the racial perceptions of 492 White Mennonite adults, an American subgroup whose sense of collective identity is rooted in cultural and spiritual similarities rather than in a shared awareness of being White. Theories of White racial identity, contextual experiences and interracial contact are highlighted as they pertain to White Mennonites' racial perceptions. It was hypothesized that White Mennonites experiencing meaningful interracial contacts in different contextual settings would exhibit more positive racial perceptions than other White Mennonites. Hypothesis testing occurred in conjunction with validation of the researcher's Scale of White Racial Attitudes-Mennonite Version. Following item, exploratory and confirmatory analyses, three dimensions resulted: Assumptions about Racial Minority Group Differences, Attitudes Toward Racial Minority Issues, and Personal Feelings About Racial Minority Groups. Repeated-measures ANOVAs supported the hypotheses and yielded significant interactional effects for racial perceptions with age, education, residence, Mennonite status and interracial contacts. Implications for White Mennonites and race relations, as well as possible implications for White Americans as a whole, are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Identity issues of parents who adopt children internationally. (international adoption).
column12: Mccarthy, Dolores Elizabeth: City U New York, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(4-B), Oct 1999, pp. 1902.
column19: This dissertation investigated how parents who adopt children internationally construct their identities in relation to the adoption. Theories of Urie Bronfenbrenner, D. W. Winnicott, Erik Erikson and Stuart Hall frame the research. Within the ecological perspective of environmental psychology, the experience of these parents is seen at multiple levels and the interpretation of the results draws on object relations approaches of psychoanalysis and social constructionist approaches of cultural studies. Intensive case studies were conducted with 26 parents who adopted children internationally, using multiple research methods including a series of in-depth interviews, home visits, behavioral observations, participant observation, reporting of critical incidents and photographing of cultural objects that represented the birth culture of the child. This research found that parents constructed multiple identities, including the identity of parent, the identity of adoptive parent and the identity of internationally adoptive parent. For some parents, these identities also interacted with other identities, including gender, ethnic/national identity, religious affiliation, sexual preference, national origin, family-of-origin relationships, and urban vs. rural identification. Respondents exhibited a range of identifications with the child's birth culture, from mild to strong. Parents used a variety of "transitional objects" to relate to the child's birth culture, including physical objects, people, places and cultural phenomena. Some parents were already identified with certain birth cultures and chose to adopt children from those birthplaces that reflected these identifications; other parents adopted for more "practical reasons" and constructed their identities during and after the adoption. In general, parents whose children most resembled them in appearance were less likely to identify with the birth culture; those parents who had identified with the birth culture prior to adoption and/or whose children were most different from them in appearance were more likely to identify with the birth culture and use more cultural practices that connected them to the birth culture. The results of this research highlighted the social construction of perceived racial differences between adoptive parent, adopted child and US culture. It also explored the influence of "consumerism" on identity development. The research further demonstrated the use of an ecological model to understand identity issues in person-environment transactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial and ethnic identity development in biracial people.
column12: Quintana, Elena Diana: Depaul U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(3-B), Sep 1999, pp. 1313.
column19: Although this country has always had a history of racial mixture, more and more people are defining themselves multiracially than ever before (Root, 1996). This study explored several aspects of multiracial identity. First, within a college population 159 surveys were administered to students between the ages of 18 and 36 to explore the relationship between one's personal ethnic identity and that of one's ancestors. Over seventeen percent of respondents reported having at least one relative in the last four generations who was described as racially different than other relatives. Only a third of these respondents identified themselves as multiracial. Biracial people who identified themselves as monoracial despite having parents of two different racial groups were interviewed to understand the process of their identity formation. Five of the sixteen people interviewed identified monoracially. Most of those who identified monoracially (all identified with their nonWhite reference group) stated that affiliating themselves with their nonWhite culture was siding with the "right" side given the history of oppression in this country against people of color. Other reasons included contact with only one parent, and greater simplicity in reporting status. Second, multiracial participants were interviewed to ascertain the ways in which they came to terms with their racial and ethnic identities. Root's (1996) description of four coping mechanisms were tested. While at least a few examples were found to support all of Root's proposed constructs, participants were most likely to identify as either monoracial or multiracial. Interviews were conducted with sixteen people to attempt to understand the influences on ethnic and racial identity formation. Family appeared to be the largest contributor to ethnic-racial identity development among biracial individuals. Other important influences included peers, messages specific to ethnic and racial identity, community, school, history, language, and phenotype. Limitations to this study were related to sampling. Geographical diversity of participants was lacking, and their were large age differences between respondents. Also, participants had relatively high levels of education. Responses by participants may have also been affected by demand characteristics of the interview process. Further research could address limitations and build upon the findings of the current study. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Multisystemic theory of post adoption services and treatment: A program design.
column12: Kasprzak, Cheryl Jane: Miami Inst. of Psychology of the Caribbean Ctr. For Advanced Studies, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(3-B), Sep 1999, pp. 1303.
column19: More and more families are adopting children from other countries, from different ethnic and racial backgrounds, special needs children, siblings, and older children. Many adoptive families struggle with dissimilarities and disparities as they form a new family, consequently the use of social services beyond the finalization of the adoption has become more common. The problem lies with where adoptive families can turn to for help. Adoptive families have expressed that the mental health community is unfamiliar with issues relating to older child adoption, cross cultural and cross racial adoptions and how forming a family through adoption is a lifelong process. The purpose of this research, was to develop a program suitable for children adopted when older that are also classified as interracially or transculturally adopted and are now displaying externalizing behaviors. The program is referred to as MTPAST, or Multisystemic Theory of Post Adoption Services and Treatment. Every attempt was made to design a unique post adoption program. This program is based on Coelho's (1998) Attachment Guided Multisystemic Theory and incorporates many of the suggested strategies. The target population includes children adopted after the age of 1 year that are now between the ages of 8 to 10, children that were transracially or cross-culturally adopted and that are currently displaying acting out and externalizing behaviors. The program's goals were to promote secure relationships and attachment solidification in adoptive families through structural change. Program objectives were to decrease probability of developing future conduct problems and delinquent behaviors for adopted children currently displaying externalizing behaviors. The philosophy of the program was based on a multisystemic model combining attachment theory With a family systems model to promote healthier family functioning. The details of the program were based on Coelho's (1998) Attachment Guided Multisystemic Therapy model for children at high risk for developing conduct problems and delinquent behaviors. Some of the modifications include incorporating specific treatment issues for work with adoptive families, processing termination issues during the first family contact, grief work for all adoptive family members, use of a genogram and eco map, and providing an educational and mental health professional training component. Project MTPAST includes admission and exclusion criteria, and a means of assessing the progress of each adopted child. An evaluation, budget and sources of funding were also proposed as a guide, were the design to be implemented. Overall, it is believed that, by educating adoptive families and mental health professionals, Project MTPAST would benefit adoptive families having difficulties with their adopted children to achieve healthy integration and growth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Crazy about each other: A qualitative exploration of culture in the context of interracial relationships.
column12: Rangel, Dianna Kay: U Utah, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(2-B), Aug 1999, pp. 0841.
column19: This qualitative study explored the lived experiences of interracially married couples, with a particular focus on issues of cultural identity and expression. Although research on this growing population has been limited, previous findings have underscored the salience of racial/ethnic identity and the richness of qualitative methodologies in capturing participants' meanings. Sixteen interracially married couples served as participants. Each couple consisted of one Caucasian spouse and one spouse from a racial/ethnic minority group. Participants were very diverse with regard to racial/ethnic background, age, socioeconomic status, and length of marriage. Each couple participated in an in-depth, semistructured interview. In addition, nine spouses participated in an optional focus group. Areas assessed included premarital levels of racial/ethnic identification and fluctuations over the course of the relationship, perceived relational effects of cultural differences, styles of communication about racial issues, modes of cultural expression within the relationship, and unique benefits of interracial marriage. All interviews and the focus group, as well as extensive self-reflexive journal entries, were audiotaped and transcribed. Data analysis involved a process of continual inductive-deductive movement which incorporated components of grounded theory and heuristic inquiry. Overall results found that interracial couples' self-perceptions of their relationships were not centered around race. The racial/cultural components of individual spouses' psychological identities were not salient in most cases. The role of culture and the extent of cultural expression within their relationships, therefore, were minimal. Instead, most interracial couples in the present study considered their relationships to be quite similar to relationships of any racial composition. Their differences seemed insignificant, and they certainly were not viewed as sources of conflict. Many participants, however, were aware of culturally influenced behaviors which they shared in their relationships. Such sharing promoted the cultural learning and interpersonal growth viewed by many participants as the most special benefits of interracial marriage. These findings portray interracial couples quite differently than history and social science might predict. The importance of checking assumptions and addressing biases about this population is therefore emphasized. Implications for future research and for mental-health professionals are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Tolerance of ambiguity and marital satisfaction in Chinese Euro-American interracial marriages.
column12: Orgel, Ling Chen: California School of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(2-B), Aug 1999, pp. 0874.
column19: Within the last three decades, the prevalence of Chinese interracial marriages has increased dramatically. The individuals who enter these marriages face the unique challenge of integrating separate ethnic cultures in a society that struggles with difference. Prior research has focused on the sociocultural factors that affect these interracial marriages and has hypothesized regarding their putative differences compared with intraracial marriages. The present study investigated tolerance of ambiguity and its impact on the marital satisfaction of Chinese Euro-American interracial marriages. The sample consisted of 71 participants who were married within the last eight years in Chinese Euro-American interracial Marriages. Most participants were recruited from the marital records data base at the San Francisco City Recorder's Office. Participants completed two measures, the Dyadic Adjustment Scale (Spanier, 1976) and the Multiple Stimulus Types Ambiguity Tolerance (McClain, 1993), as wen as a demographic questionnaire that was mailed to them. The design of the study was correlational and nonexperimental. The predictor variable was Tolerance of Ambiguity and the dependent variable was Marital Satisfaction. There was one main research hypothesis and three secondary hypotheses within this study. All four hypotheses were tested using Pearson product-moment correlation. The main research hypothesis predicted a positive linear correlation between the predictor variable, Tolerance of Ambiguity, and the dependent variable, Marital Satisfaction. This hypothesis was not confirmed. Two of the secondary hypotheses predicted positive linear correlations between the predictor variable, Tolerance of Ambiguity, and the dependent variables, Marital Consensus and Marital Cohesion. The third secondary hypothesis predicted a negative linear correlation between the predictor variable, Tolerance of Ambiguity, and the dependent variable, Marital Distress. None of these hypotheses were confirmed. Implications of these findings for marital satisfaction in Chinese Euro-American marriages and suggestions for future research were discussed. Qualitative findings suggested that Chinese Euro-American intermarried individuals tended to marry at a later age, have fewer children and have a higher socioeconomic status than the general population. The majority of participants reported that they had good relationships with their own families and their in-laws. When cultural conflicts were reported, they were based in differences over traditional expectations of gender roles, pressures to have children, and the degree of extended family involvement. No evidence was found to confirm a relationship between the similarity in spousal levels of acculturation and their marital satisfaction. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: An investigation of the relations between the psychological functioning and coping processes of interracial Black/White young adults and their racial identity outcomes.
column12: Mur, Linda Yudice: New York U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(1-B), Jul 1999, pp. 0403.
column19: This study examined the relations between possible racial identity outcomes proposed by Root (1990) and the psychological functioning and coping processes of interracial young adults who biologically have a Black and a White parent. Research participants consisted of 80 interracial young adults, aged 18-31. A discriminant analysis was performed to analyze the data. Racial identity was the dependent variable, and psychological functioning, coping processes and gender were the independent variables. No significant differences in the psychological functioning and the coping processes emerged among four racial identity outcome groups. No significant gender differences were found. However, in supplementary analyses, a one-way analysis of variance revealed a significant difference in coping process between two of four racial identity outcome groups. Consequently, the results did not contradict racial identity theory, which has suggested that there is not a direct relation between racial identity and psychological functioning. The findings suggest that racial identity may be related to some aspect of coping process. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Degrees of distance: The relationship between White racial identity and social distance phenomena in American society.
column12: Clauss, Caroline Seay: Columbia U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.60(1-B), Jul 1999, pp. 0409.
column19: This study looks at cultural patterns associated with social relationships in American society. The specific pattern explored concerns societal pressure on individuals to stay within the boundaries of their racial group. This trend teaches White Americans in particular to conform to social rules, one of which is to maintain social distance from people of color. This study explores whether racial identity, or individual differences in psychological orientation to race, might lead to different patterns of social distance. Specifically, White racial identity (Helms, 1984, 1990) includes six racial identity development "statuses" for Whites: Phase I statuses that include: Contact (naive about race), Disintegration (conflicted about the salience of race), Reintegration (pro-White/anti-Black); and Phase 2 statuses that include Pseudo-Independence (intellectual understanding of racial difference), Immersion-Emersion (exploration of one's racial heritage), and Autonomy (emotional and intellectual acceptance of race). Three hypotheses examine the relationship between social distance and White racial identity: (1) Phase 1 statuses will predict social distance towards twenty racial/ethnic groups while Phase 2 statuses will predict social intimacy, (2) Phase 1 statuses will predict social distance towards Black Americans, while Phase 2 statuses will predict social intimacy towards Black Americans, and (3) Phase 1 statuses will predict discriminatory behaviors in interracial social scenarios, while Phase 2 statuses will predict nondiscriminatory behavioral options. The subjects were 218 White Americans who completed a questionnaire packet that included: Personal Data Sheet; The White Racial Identity Attitude Scale (Helms & Carter, 1990); The Social Scenarios Scale (Byrnes & Kiger, 1988); The Social Distance Scale (Triandis & Triandis, 1960); and The Social Survey (modified by present author). The results suggest partial support for the hypotheses that White racial identity attitudes will predict social distance for racial/ethnic groups. The results also suggest partial support for the hypothesis that White racial identity attitudes will predict perceptions of behavioral options in interracial social scenarios. The study has implications for the counseling psychology profession as it considers how social distance influences clinical practice, policy, and training. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Identity resolution in biracial Black/White individuals: The process of asserting a biracial identity.
column12: Thompson, Catherine Ann: California School of Professional Psychology - San Diego, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(12-B), Jun 1999, pp. 6498.
column19: The Purpose of this study, "Identity Resolution in Biracial Black/White Individuals: The Process of Asserting a Biracial Identity" was to further the understanding of the process of racial identity development in biracial Black/White individuals by examining how they come to assert a biracial identity in a society that does not readily acknowledge or support their dual racial membership. The primary questions asked of participants included: What life experiences have been influential in the decision to assert a biracial label and identity? What difficulties or challenges were encountered in the process of maintaining a positive biracial identity? What are the perceived benefits of being biracial? And what are the sources of strength that have helped in maintaining a positive biracial identity? This study employed a qualitative research design, utilizing a life narrative approach. Focused, in-depth interviews were conducted with twelve biracial individuals who had one socially designated Black parent and one socially designated White parent. Sensitizing concepts (Blumer, 1969) were used as a way to frame the study, analyze the data, and generate themes regarding the ways in which some biracial individuals come to assert a positive biracial identity. The racial identity development of the twelve individuals who participated in this study was found to be an ongoing, multidimensional process that was strongly affected by the psychosocial context of each individual's life. The most significant components of identity development discussed by all of the participants involved the experience of difference and the process of coming to terms with that difference through connection with other people. Participants relied on positive connections with family and sought affiliation with accepting others as they encountered difficulties associated with societal perceptions of what it means to be biracial. As they were able to validate and assert their biracial identities, participants felt increasingly positive about their heritage and were able to maintain a healthy sense of self that incorporated both sides. Participants indicted that affiliation with other interracial families and biracial peers was extremely valuable and reaffirming. These findings are consistent with Erikson (1950, 1959, 1968) who stressed the need for individuals to see themselves reflected in and validated by others. In addition, the process of racial identity development that occurred among the participants in this study was consistent with the model outlined by Kich (1992). This study showed that for these 12 individuals, regardless of the challenges they faced, the attainment of a healthy biracial identity was possible given the freedom to define themselves and assert their identification with both sides of their heritage. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The role of connection to the native culture in intercultural marriages: Perceptions of Puerto Rican women.
column12: Del Rio, Maria M.: U Massachusetts, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(7-B), Jan 1999, pp. 3768.
column19: This dissertation investigates the migration experience of Puerto Rican women, their connection to the native culture and their perceptions of the role of this connection in their intercultural marriages. Critical issues such as; the degree and quality of involvement that is maintained with one's culture and heritage, and the ways of responding to, and dealing with, a second culture emerge upon migration. Intercultural marriage (Rohrlich, 1988), the marriage where partners are of differing ethnic origins, has been associated with the process of second culture acquisition. It has been visualized as an indicator of minority assimilation and weakening of the cohesion of an ethnic group (Murguia, 1982). Marrying outside one's ethnic group could imply a loss of connection to the native culture, which encourages the person to move more rapidly toward the majority culture. Using a qualitative-descriptive design, data was gathered through in-depth interviews with five interculturally married migrant Puerto Rican women. Data from this study revealed that these women see themselves as competent, assertive, mature, and strong women who are culturally different from their North American counterparts. The women indicated that they constantly draw coping strategies and behaviors from two different cultural contexts (Puerto Rican/North American) and that they feel effective and competent within the majority culture because they have achieved a sense of internal balance where decision making and survival strategies are bicultural. Nevertheless, they feel restrained when they express some feelings and ideas in the presence of North Americans. They also sustain a sense of not belonging in the American culture. Women indicated that they need to feel connected in one way or another to their primary culture. Besides other aspects of connection to the Puerto Rican culture; e.g. the use of Spanish, perpetuation of familism, maintenance of friendships with compatriots, listening and dancing to Hispanic music, and cooking Puerto Rican food, some women reported a metaphysical dimension of connection. Suggested areas of disconnection from the primary culture were related to rebellion towards values that perpetuate parental and male preponderance. Findings indicated that women validate their opposition to these values (disconnection) within the context of their intercultural marriages. The use of some nonverbal behaviors, the relationship with the in-laws, different views in parenting, time and financial planning emerged as areas of marital conflict. Implications for research and practice were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Social interactions between Whites and Blacks: A cycle of racial misunderstanding?
column12: Shelton, Josette Nicole: U Virginia, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(7-B), Jan 1999, pp. 3775.
column19: An experiment was conducted to examine the effects of prejudice suppression and prejudiced expectation on Whites' and Blacks' experiences in interracial interaction. White and Black college students were paired together and discussed several questions. The questions were innocuous questions or related to racial issues. Moreover, during the interactions, White participants either suppressed prejudiced thoughts about Blacks or did not suppress prejudiced thoughts about Blacks while Black participants either expected that the White person was prejudiced against Blacks or did not have such expectations. The data suggest that prejudice suppression and prejudice expectation can lead to favorable outcomes in interracial interactions. The results are discussed in terms of the need for more research concerning on-going interactions between Whites and Blacks. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Self and alma mater: A study of adopted college students. [References].
column13: Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal. Vol.16(5), Oct 1999, pp. 355-372.
column19: Sixteen adopted students' (aged 18-21 yrs) subjective descriptions of their experiences in college were studied via individual interviews in an attempt to provide valuable insight and understanding for clinicians. The college experience of adoptive students involves evaluating relationships with adoptive family members, integrating knowledge of biological family members and histories, and struggling with the ambivalence of whether to search for biological information. Interview responses indicate that adopted college students feel freed up to ask themselves question about their history and open up to other who were adopted as a way of sharing common experiences and expanding levels of understanding. Many feel that, due to their experience of being adopted, they bring to the college experience an enhanced capacity to rely on themselves and think independently as well as to be open to new ideas and diversity. They reported that finding other adopted students is a cathartic experience that provides a bridge of intersubjective understanding. None of the students described an affinity with an extended family member. Students from different racial or ethnic backgrounds than their adoptive families reported greater conflict and confusion about biological connection than other students. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Attitudes of Whites and Blacks towards ethnic humor: A comparison. [References].
column12: Jaret, Charles: Georgia State U, GA, US
column13: Humor: International Journal of Humor Research. Vol.12(4), 1999, pp. 385-409.
column19: Examined the public's attitudes about racial-ethnic humor, especially that which demeans or insults a particular group. Responses by 727 Black and White Georgia residents to survey items on ethnic humor in general and their feelings about a well publicized controversial case of racial humor (the Ted Danson incident) were analyzed. Results indicated that, while there were some interracial differences, Black and White attitudes were not polarized, and more marked differences emerged when data were examined in race and sex categories. Sentiments on ethnic humor correlated weakly with SES and demographic variables, and could not be predicted from indicators of liberal conservative attitudes. Ethnic humor sentiments, however, were related to attitudes toward changing the official flag of Georgia: those in favor of removing the Confederate symbol on the state flag held more negative attitudes towards ethnic humor. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Outlines some of the historical issues regarding transracial placement for fostering or adoption and relates these to the British cultural context. Issues of identity, and the particular placement needs of children of mixed parentage background, where one parent is White and one is Black, are considered. Case study material is used to illustrate the issues involved in assessing White substitute carers and how, on the basis of J. Helm's (1992) work, the assessment of potential substitute carers may be made more objective. Finally, implications for the work of educational psychologists are suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Patterns of attachment and responses to accommodative dilemmas among interethnic/interracial couples.
column9:
Gaines, Stanley O Jr.

Granrose, Cherlyn S

Rios, Diana I

Garcia, Ben F

Youn, Mary S. Page

column12: Gaines, Stanley O.: Pomona Coll, Dept of Psychology, Claremont, CA, US
column13: Journal of Social and Personal Relationships. Vol.16(2), Apr 1999, pp. 275-285.
column19: Partners from 103 heterosexual interethnic/interracial couples (103 men, mean age 33.84 yrs; and 103 women, mean age 32.72 yrs) completed categorical measures of attachment style and continuous measures of responses to accommodative dilemmas. It was hypothesized that the proportion of securely attached Ss would be significantly greater than insecurely attached Ss; that securely attached Ss would display greater accommodative tendencies; and the difference between securely and insecurely attached Ss's accommodative tendencies would be more pronounced for destructive vs constructive responses to accommodative dilemmas. Consistent with the hypotheses, there was a significantly higher proportion of secure over insecure individuals among both sexes. Further, the difference between secure and insecure individuals' accommodative tendencies was greater for destructive responses than for constructive responses (significant among men, marginally significant among women). However, contrary to hypotheses, attachment style per se was not a significant predictor of accommodation responses among either sex. Implications for the study of interethnic/interracial romantic relationships are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Asian American dating: Important factors in partner choice. [References].
column12: Mok, Teresa A.: U Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Counseling Ctr, Champaign, IL, US

column19: The majority of research on romantic relationships has tended to focus on marriage, with relatively less attention paid to dating. This study examined the relationship between Asian American dating, both interracial and intraracial, and a variety of factors thought to be associated with dating in this population, including acculturation, ethnic identity, attractiveness, interracial dating experience, ethnicity of friends, parental influence over dating, and density. 66 female and 91 male Asian-American college students were administered measures of these variables and were asked questions regarding their likelihood of dating both Asian Americans and White Americans. An interesting pattern of results emerged when the variables were put into regression equations to predict both interracial and intraracial dating. Findings are presented and implications discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Symbolic interactionism, African-American families, and the transracial adoption controversy.
column12: Hollingsworth, Leslie Doty: U Michigan, School of Social Work, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Social Work. Vol.44(5), Sep 1999, pp. 443-453.
column19: This article applies a cultural perspective in considering the opposition of some African-Americans to transracial adoption. The article presents a historical review of the transracial adoption controversy, detailing the arguments that have been presented in opposition and the legislation that has evolved. Symbolic interactionism is used to frame African-Americans as a unique and distinct cultural group, in which the socialization of African-American children takes place. The framework presented encompasses the meaning of children, family, and adoption to people of African descent, the racial and ethnic group as the context within which definitions of self and identity develop, and the efforts made in seeking to balance the integrity of concepts. Finally, the author recommends that social workers develop a research agenda that maintains but critically analyzes the role of African-American group identity for framing research for assessing child maltreatment within the context of poverty and resource deficiencies rather than personal failures and for advocating public policies that preserve cultural realities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Child Welfare: Journal of Policy, Practice, and Program. Vol.78(5), Sep-Oct 1999, pp. 673-692.
column15: Child Welfare League of America; US
column19: Examined the effects of skin color and racial attitudes of 10 transracially and inracially adopted African-American adults. Although all Ss felt that their "adoptive families did all that they could for them and sincerely loved them," interviews showed that Ss endured difficulties of racial classification and prejudice. Ss with a skin tone significantly different from adoptive parents and siblings endured difficulties as well. These findings have implications for special needs adoption practitioners, adoptive families, and special needs children; it is essential that all be prepared to deal with issues of racial dynamics as they exist in society. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Who intermarries? Education, nativity, region, and interracial marriage, 1980 and 1990.
column12: Qian, Zhenchao: Arizona State U, Dept of Sociology, Tempe, AZ, US
column13: Journal of Comparative Family Studies. Vol.30(4), Fal 1999, pp. 579-597.
column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: Examined interracial marriage among Whites, African Americans, Hispanics, and Asian Americans using Public Use Microdata Sample data from the 1980 and the 1990 censuses. The level of interracial marriage was related inversely to the size of the racial group and to the proportion of the racial group in each region. Demographic structure, however, did not fully explain the racial differences in interracial marriage. Hispanics and Asian Americans had higher levels of interracial marriage than African Americans, despite greater prevalence of immigrants in the former 2 groups. Interracial marriage differed by educational attainment for each racial group, but spousal educational differences were similar among different types of interracial marriages. Findings suggest that racial differences in interracial marriage by educational attainment do not show that interracial marriage is an exchange of Whites' racial status for minorities' higher educational attainment, but indicate racial differences in educational attainment. Also, immigration status, an indication of acculturation, shows different effects on interracial marriage for each racial group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Of Jewel Heritage: Racial socialization and racial identity attitudes amongst adolescents of mixed African-Caribbean/White parentage.
column12: Fatimilehin, Iyabo A.: Royal Liverpool Children's NHS Trust, Child & Family Services, Liverpool, England
column13: Journal of Adolescence. Vol.22(3), Jun 1999, pp. 303-318.
column19: Investigated 23 British 12-19 yr olds of mixed racial parentage regarding their attitudes about being Black. Most Ss had 1 White parent and 1 African-Caribbean parent.Tests communally administered included the Racial Identity Attitude Scale, the Teenager Experience of Racial Socialization, the Rosenberg Self-esteem Inventory, and the Socio-demographic Questionnaire. Results showed that Ss have a positive sense of racial identity concerning their Black heritage. Older Ss demonstrated more internalized attitudes. Only the racial socialization scales indicated any effect of primary caregiver. Ss living with both parents reported receiving more racial socialization messages, especially in terms of proactive messages. There were no significant differences between males and females. Ss demonstrated a positive racial identity while simultaneously claiming dual identification; this ability increased with age and was associated with high self-esteem. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
