column19: Examined whether members of interracial marriages perceive racial/gender differences between supporters and opponents of their relationship and if these differences depend on the racial/gender composition of the intermarried couple. 200 questionnaires were completed by members of Black-White interracial marriages. Results show that during everyday casual contacts, all people were equally supportive. Respondents felt that people who were of the same gender and race as themselves or their spouse tended to be most supportive of their relationship during these casual interactions. Respondents also felt that people who were of the same race but opposite gender of themselves and their spouse tended to be most opposed to their relationship during casual interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Brooks, Devon: U California, School of Social Welfare, Ctr for Social Services Research, Berkeley, CA, US
column13: Social Work. Vol.44(2), Mar 1999, pp. 167-178.
column19: Passage of the Multiethnic Placement Act of 1994 (MEPA) and the 1996 provisions on Removal of Barriers to Interethnic Adoption (Interethnic Adoption Provisions) provides an ideal opportunity to examine what can be done to increase adoptions of foster children, particularly children of color. To assist states and child welfare professionals in serving children better and meeting legal obligations, this article discusses racial matching, MEPA, and the Interethnic Adoption Provisions. Implications for practice and challenges in implementing the law also are discussed. The article suggests principles for casework adoption practice, recruitment, and placement that provide a framework for simultaneously meeting the requirements of the law and serving the best interests of children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: From miscegenation to multiculturalism: Perceptions and stages of interracial relationship development.
column12: Foeman, Anita Kathy: West Chester U, West Chester, PA, US
column13: Journal of Black Studies. Vol.29(4), Mar 1999, pp. 540-557.
column19: Discusses the unique history of Black-White unions in the US and the theory regarding them, and presents speculative stages of relationship development for Black-White couples. Five areas of mythology surround Black-White couples. Three of these relate to psychological issues: (1) Black sexual acting out, (2) Black status seeking, and (3) White neurotic acting out. The 4th area relates to negative genetic outcomes of interracial coupling, and the 5th addresses psychological shortcomings of interracial children. A new model of interracial relationship development that evolves theoretically toward a new view of interracial families is presented. The stages of this framework include: (1) racial awareness, (2) identity emergence, and (3) maintenance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Intersubjectivity: Expanding our understanding of the worker-client relationship.
column12: Bowles, Dorcas D.: Clark Atlanta U, School of Social Work, Atlanta, GA, US
column13: Smith College Studies in Social Work. Vol.69(2), Mar 1999, pp. 359-371.
column19: This paper focuses on the interactional, relational matrix and other psychotherapeutic processes that exist between caseworker and client. The special experiences the worker and client each bring to the relationship ignites and engages each of their cognitive and emotional capacities so that they respond to each other's verbal and non-verbal cues in a very unique way. The social worker must understand the "here and now," the shared subjective experiences of worker and client, within the relationship to avoid derailment of the treatment process and to ensure the client's capacity to heal. A case example relates the author's personal experiences of these intersubjective psychotherapeutic processes as a Black social worker counseling an adult interracial female who was having conflicts of self-concept in dealing with her Black and White heritage. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Surveyed 260 White and African American participants (aged 18-65+ yrs) of a "race relations" workshop on their perceptions of and knowledge about Africa and African Americans, patterns of interracial interaction, and racial attitudes and stereotypes. Statistical analysis of survey data revealed that the values and behavior of all Ss were influenced powerfully by attitudes grounded in racial stereotypes. Formal knowledge of the culture and history of African Americans and interaction across racial lines diminished stereotypical attitudes for both racially defined groups. Despite increasingly resegregated regions, opportunities for intercultural knowledge acquisition and constructive interaction across racial boundaries are increasingly infrequent. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: African-American, European-American, and biracial couples' meanings for and experiences in marriage.
column12: Dainton, Marianne: La Salle U, Philadelphia, PA, US
column13: Socha, Thomas J [Ed]; Diggs, Rhunette C [Ed]. (1999). Communication, race, and family: Exploring communication in Black, White, and biracial families.  (pp. 147-165). xv, 244 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column19: (from the chapter) Investigates whether there are differences in the meanings for and/or experiences of marriage among African-American, European-American, and biracial couples. A sample of convenience including two African-American, two European-American, and two biracial couples (aged 24-47) was used in this study. There were three parts to the research process. First, demographic information was collected using a standard questionnaire. Then the researchers asked the couple to jointly tell the story of their relationship from their initial meeting to their current experience. Finally, spouses were asked individually to respond to a question regarding his or her meanings for marriage. Findings suggest that the three groups of couples held a positive view of marriage. However, the two African-American couples simultaneously held negative meanings of marriage. In regard to the experience of marriage, results suggest that the tensions expressed by the African-American and European-American couples were quite similar. The problems centered on issues related to the internal dynamics of the couple. In contrast, the biracial couples experienced tensions related to the intrusiveness of friends and family, which they described as external to the relationship. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Communication, race, and family: Exploring communication in Black, White, and biracial families.
column9:
Socha, Thomas J [Ed]

Diggs, Rhunette C [Ed]
column12: Socha, Thomas J.: Old Dominion U, Norfolk, VA, US
column13: (1999). Communication, race, and family: Exploring communication in Black, White, and biracial families. xv, 244 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column19: (from the cover) Explores how family communication influences the topic of race. The editors argue that the hope for managing America's troubles with "race" lies not only with communicating about race at public meetings, in school, and in the media, but also with families communicating constructively about race at home. The authors in this book investigate such topics as how Black families communicate to manage the issue of racism; how Black parent-child communication is used to manage the derogation of Black children; the role of television in family communication about race; the similarities and differences between communication in Black, White, and biracial couples and families; and how family communication education can contribute to a brighter future for all. With the aim of developing a clearer understanding of the role that family communication plays in society's move toward a multicultural world, this volume provides a crucial examination of how families struggle with issues of ethnic cultural diversity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) The study of negotiation has been dominated by laboratory studies. These investigate research questions arising from an economics-oriented paradigm, leading researchers to exclude many variables that impact negotiations. Emotion is one such variable. Anger, in particular, determines the intensity of the conflict between the negotiators, is both a cause and an effect of the process by which the negotiators try to reach agreement, and impacts the implementation of the settlement. Insights from clinical psychology supplement and enrich those available from social psychology, economics, and cognitive psychology. The importance of emotion is illustrated by examining interracial conflicts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Troubles in interracial talk about discipline: An examination of African American child rearing narratives.
column9:

column12: Mosby, Lynetta: Oakland U, Dept of Sociology, Rochester, MI, US
column13: Journal of Comparative Family Studies. Vol.30(3), Sum 1999, pp. 489-521.
column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: This paper examines extended narrative accounts from 6 women elders (aged 59-95 yrs) in the African American community to investigate why physical discipline (PD) as a parenting style is preferred in this community and how it is ideally to be used. The narrative data show extensive intergenerational support for the use of PD. The women delineated a clear distinction between the use of PD and child abuse and definite guidelines that must be followed when using PD. For the mothers and grandmothers in this study, the use of PD was an integral part of child rearing. In their view the attempt to raise children entirely on the basis of verbal reasoning is much more likely to lead to abuse than PD. Even when PD is occasionally excessive, it is generally not seen as harmful, either to the child or to the parent-child relationship, as verbal abuse. The authors suggest that when social workers and others make decisions about families that share these beliefs, they should understand the significance of the preferred child rearing practices of the people involved. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

It also illustrates how racial identity provides a frame of reference or "language" for the client as he struggles to describe his presenting problem, the history of the problem, and to interpret traumatic life events. column5: Whiteness as stigma: Essentialist identity work by mixed-race women.
column12: Storrs, Debbie: U Idaho, Dept of Anthropology/Sociology, Moscow, ID, US
column13: Symbolic Interaction. Vol.22(3), 1999, pp. 187-212.
column19: Explains the reversal of the racial mixing problem as well as the identity work of women as they rearticulate the meaning of race and racial belonging within dominant racial logic. The identification of macro constraints and the illustration of individual agency in the negotiation of identity extends the symbolic interactionist perspective on identity formation. The author captures the micro level social process of racial formation through an analysis of women's ability to rearticulate the meaning of stigma. This research also adds to the symbolic interactionist literature that emphasizes face-to-face interaction, the micro processes, in the construction of self by revealing the dynamic interplay between macro and micro processes in the development of racial identity. The date used are drawn from a larger study that examines the racial and gendered identity constructions of 27 mixed-race women living in the US. The women in this study reject dominant patterns of stigma by reassigning stigma to their European ancestry. Given this reversal, women articulate and embrace non-white identities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Responds to comments by G. Shuler (see record 1999-00345-007) and T. Vecchione (see record 1999-00345-008) on the author's original article (see record 1998-00843-001) on issues in transracial adoption. Hollingsworth addresses Vecchione's assertion that transracial adoption is preferable to a child's placement in an abusive or neglectful home. She also responds to Shuler's concerns that employing a diverse staff, in which people of color are represented, increases the possibility that practices will be more racially and ethnically responsive; his perception of a "better or worse" dichotomy; and his comments about transracial adoptees as ambassadors between the races. column19: Comments on the article by L. D. Hollingsworth (see record 1998-00843-001) on issues in transracial and same-race adoption. Vecchione contends that Hollingsworth's article was lacking in proof that same-race adoption is necessary for children of color to develop their cultural identity and coping skills to deal with the problems faced by people of color, because it failed to present empirical evidence supporting this idea. Vecchione proposes that future research on this issue be focused on how children in same-race vs transracial adoptive families differ in their development of their cultural identity and the strengths needed to deal with the problems faced by people of color. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) This chapter discusses the history and demography of multiracial families, and transracial adoption. Marital and family issues for Black-White multiracial couples are discussed based on a qualitative interview study of Black-White heterosexual couples in Minnesota (P. C. Rosenblatt et al, 1995). This study drew on intensive interviews of 21 couples living in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. The study concludes that cultural and experiential differences can challenge a multiracial couple, and they can also be challenged by all the issues that arise for some race couples; but the greatest challenge seems to be that created by racism in the US. column5: Parenting and child development in "nontraditional" families.
column12: Lamb, Michael E.: National Inst of Child Health & Human Development, Bethesda, MD, US
column13: (1999). Parenting and child development in "nontraditional" families. viii, 365 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column19: (from the preface) The goal of this volume is to discuss in depth the ways in which various "deviations" from traditional family styles affect childrearing practices and child development. Instead of dwelling on the "deviance" of these childrearing modes or styles, the contributors each attempt to illustrate the dynamic developmental processes that characterize parenting and child development in contexts that can be deemed nontraditional because they do not reflect the demographic characteristics of the traditional families on which social scientists have largely focused. Contributors thus deal with the dynamics and possible effects of dual-earner families, families with unusually involved fathers, families characterized by the occurrence of divorce, single parenthood, remarriage, poverty, adoption, reliance on nonparental childcare, ethnic membership (Black, Latino, or interracial), parents with lesbian or gay sexual orientations, as well as violent and/or neglectful parents. All the chapters offer answers to a common question: How do these patterns of childcare affect children, their experiences, and their developmental processes? This book will be of value to social scientists, as well as to those professionals concerned with guiding and advising clients and public policy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Lee, Ching-Fa: China Medical Coll Hosp, Dept of Psychiatry, Taiwan
column13: Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry. Vol.32(1), Feb 1998, pp. 133-136.
column19: Investigated the single dose pharmacokinetics of lithium in Taiwanese/Chinese bipolar patients for future interracial comparisons. Eight bipolar patients (2 females; aged 15-41 yrs) took 900 mg of lithium carbonate after overnight fasting. Blood samples of 5 mL were taken after 15 min, 30 min, 45 min,1 hr, 2 hr, 3 hr, 4 hr, 7 hr, 9 hr,15 hr, 25 hr and 31 hr after dosing. Computer programs were used for pharmacokinetic analysis. Most of the pharmacokinetic parameters were within the ranges reported in investigations of Caucasian Ss. It is concluded that racial differences in lithium pharmacokinetics might not exist. It is suggested that methodological designs, including method of blood sampling, measurement of lithium, and pharmacokinetic and statistical calculations, be standardized if future cross-ethnic comparisons are to be conducted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Let people speak for themselves: Interracial unions and the General Social Survey.
column12: St. Jean, Yanick: U Nevada, Dept of Sociology, Las Vegas, NV, US
column13: Journal of Black Studies. Vol.28(3), Jan 1998, pp. 398-414.
column19: Discusses the quality and problems of the General Social Survey (GSS) that is used as a database for social scientific research, and how it offers limited scope about attitudes toward interracial marriage. First, there are only 2 questions on the survey about interracial marriages and the responses do not clearly define true feelings. Second, the use of the term Black is arbitrary and relative to cultural. In the US, one Black ancestor makes a person Black. The flexibility of color classifications across geographical boundaries and concerns of scholars with the American color dichotomy lead to problems regarding the use of "Black" in the GSS. A study group of 11 couples were interviewed and videotaped regarding their feelings about intermarriage. The findings suggest that Blacks are ambivalent toward the unions and Whites are concerned with the skin color of their children's offsprings and how this may impact on their lives. These reactions are congruent with American beliefs about racial purity and lead White partners to doubt that equality between the racial groups has been achieved or that protective laws guard against injustice. It is concluded that the focus groups provide more access to everyday reality about intermarriage that the GSS. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Review of Multiracial Couples: Black & White Voices.
column12: Salzano, Danielle: New York University, School of Social Work, New York, NY, US
column13: Cultural Diversity and Mental Health. Vol.4(2), 1998, pp. 145-146.
column19: Reviews the book, Multiracial Couples: Black and White Voices by Paul C. Rosenblatt, Terri A. Karis and Richard D. Powell (1995). Couples therapy and the study of couples seems to be of great interest to many in recent years. Multiracial Couples: Black & White Voices is designed to share the experiences of 21 heterosexual, black and white couples from the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. The book focuses more on each couple's experiences rather than the theory of multiracial couples and racism. Minimal interpretation is offered allowing the actual voices of the people interviewed to truly be heard. Taken as a whole, the book does offer a legitimate contribution to the literature. Many works written on cultural diversity and mental health are conveyed through the eyes of professionals not necessarily those that are being helped. This book presents a different perspective on how to view multiracial couples and it might assist professionals in alleviating the confusion and pain that couples face. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Mediated racialism: African Americans and the media. [References].
column12: Brooks, Dwight E.: University of Georgia, Athens, GA, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.43(4), Apr,  1998
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1998, Vol 43(4), 293-295. The reviewer states that this book (see record 1996-97535-000) has four parts-film, print media, television and cable, and radio and music. All but three of the 16 chapters have been published here for the first time. Each chapter provides examples of racialism and the media by addressing such contemporary issues as the films of Spike Lee; Hollywood's "New Ghetto Aesthetic"; newspaper coverage of the Los Angeles racial disturbances and of Senator Carol Moseley-Braun's Illinois campaign; interracial couple intimacy on TV soap operas; African American community radio; and rap music, Black men, and the police. A strength of this book is its exclusive focus on African Americans. Although the issues explored in this volume are of import to media teachers, media scholars, media critics, media practitioners, and media consumers, some of the chapters' treatment of these issues would have benefitted from a more critical interrogation of the texts, discourses, and agents under examination. In conclusion, this book's primary utility would be as a supplementary reader in a course on African Americans and the media. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1998, Vol 43(2), 95-96. Review of Multiracial Couples: Black and White Voices by Paul C. Rosenblatt, Terri A. Karis, and Richard D. Powell (see record 1995-98853-000). The book provides a broad analysis of aspects of relating and having a public identity experienced by people in multiracial couples. The evidence reported only partially relates to the experience of prejudice or loss. The general categories of information obtained by Rosenblatt, Karis, and Powell include how families received the multiracial couples; the treatment couples experienced in interactions in the general public, such as in the workplace or in encounters with strangers while eating or shopping; issues in bringing up multiracial children; learning from each other and from different cultures; and couples finding support in their communities. The study had limits, especially its limited focus to African American and White relationships. At the same time, however, this is a pioneering effort in an area that deserves much greater attention in the relationship and family field. What the reviewers came away with from this book was a better sense of what multiracial couples encounter just "to be" in this society. Further, as is clear in the narratives, many communities are not likely to be as supportive of multiracial couples as is the Twin Cities area. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Power and role-taking: A review of theory, research, and practice.
column12: Forte, James A.: Christopher Newport U, Dept of Sociology, Social Work & Anthropology, Newport News, VA, US
column13: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment. Vol.1(4), 1998, pp. 27-56.
column19: Presents power and role-taking theory arguments that social structural arrangements influence face-to-face communication processes. Specifically, powerful and powerless interactants tend to differ in their motivation to take the other's role and in the accuracy of their interpersonal understandings. Basic concepts of the theory and its interrelated propositions are identified. A comprehensive literature review gauged its empirical support. With some qualifications, a set of 26 quantitative studies supported propositions regarding the relationship of unequal power to role-taking propensity, accuracy, and empathy. Examination of 8 qualitative studies offered fruitful directions for theoretical refinements. A set of 15 practice effectiveness studies suggest that role-taking processes in asymmetrical relationships can be changed. Practice implications for social workers committed to challenging the power imbalances typical to cross-gender, interracial, interclass, and cross-position relationships are suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Changes in motivation for adoption, value orientations and behavior in three generations of adoptive parents.
column12: Hoksbergen, Rene A. C.: Utrecht U, Utrecht, Netherlands
column13: Adoption Quarterly. Vol.2(2), 1998, pp. 37-55.
column19: Discusses changes in motivation for adoption, value orientations and behavior in adoptive parents seeking intercountry and intracountry adoptions. It is hypothesized that in this century a pattern of 3 generations of adoptive parents (in Western countries) has developed: the traditional-closed generation, the open-idealistic, and the materialistic-realistic generation. These 3 generations differ considerably in motives and attitudes concerning adoption. Changes in the adoption field are connected with important changes in society. Adoption has lost its taboo character, domestic adoption is decreasing or has almost vanished (Scandinavia, The Netherlands) and interracial adoption has started. Several figures illustrating changes in adoption patterns during the period 1960-1995 support the hypothesis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Coping with interracial stress in ethnically diverse classrooms: How important are Allport's contact conditions?
column12: Marcus-Newhall, Amy: Scripps Coll, Dept of Psychology, Claremont, CA, US
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.54(4), Win 1998, pp. 813-830.
column19: This study examined desegregated classrooms with an emphasis on how students' perceptions of G. W. Allport's (1954) contact dimensions influence the frequency and effectiveness of their coping strategies for interracial stress, their self-esteem, and their self-reported academic performance. 507 fourth, fifth, and sixth graders from 2 ethnically diverse middle schools participated. Results indicate that students' perceptions of a more positive interracial classroom climate were associated with less frequent and more effective coping strategies, specifically as related to the frequency and effectiveness of positive/approach coping strategies. Positive classroom climate also was related to higher self-esteem and better academic performance. This research highlights the importance of (1) the presence of contact criteria when desegregation is to be a positive experience both academically and socially and (2) the integration of coping strategies as a means of reducing interracial stress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The utility of Allport's conditions of intergroup contact for predicting perceptions of improved racial attitudes and beliefs.
column12: Wittig, Michele Andrisin: California State U, Dept of Psychology, Northridge, CA, US
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.54(4), Win 1998, pp. 795-812.
column19: Tests the predictive power of perception as it relates to G. W. Allport's (1954/1979) classic articulation of the conditions of contact conducive to reducing intergroup prejudice and increasing tolerance (Contact Hypothesis). The authors present results of an evaluation of a prejudice reduction program that trains and places college student facilitators in middle and high school classrooms to lead discussions about race. Survey data was taken from 35 teachers. Results show that a composite of 5 classroom climate conditions that the Contact Hypothesis suggests are conducive to prejudice reduction predicts teachers' and college student facilitators' perceptions of change in 3 aspects of middle and high school student racial attitudes. Students' perceptions of the school interracial climate are modestly predictive of their changes in these 3 aspects of racial attitudes. However, teacher and facilitator estimates of student outcomes are uncorrelated with actual student outcomes. Implications of these results for prejudice reduction theory and practice are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Experiences and processes affecting racial identity development: Preliminary results from the Biracial Sibling Project. [References].
column12: Root, Maria P. P.: U Washington, Seattle, WA, US
column13: Cultural Diversity and Mental Health. Vol.4(3), 1998, pp. 237-247.
column19: Examined what drives the process of racial identity development in general for persons of mixed racial heritage and what experiences account for some differential choices within the same family. 20 sibling pairs of mixed racial heritage (aged 18-40 yrs) completed packets including an extensive background questionnaire, a body image inventory, a racial resemblance inventory, a sibling racial resemblance inventory, a brief mental health inventory, a racial experiences inventory, and an identity questionnaire. Ss also participated in two 2-hr interviews. Four types of experiences surfaced that appear to influence the identity process: hazing, family dysfunction, other salient identities, and the impact of integration. These experiences were explored within the framework of the ecological model of racial identity development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Adjustment and conflict patterns in Black-White interracial marriage: Effects of racism, spiritual well-being, and acculturation.
column12: Vazquez, Veola E.: Rosemead School of Psychology, Biola U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(6-B), Dec 1998, pp. 3126.
column19: This study investigated the marital relationships of 46 Black-White couples of all ages who were married at least 1 year and who lived in various areas across the United States. A correlational approach was used to investigate the relationships between marital adjustment, measured by the Revised Dyadic Adjustment Scale, and (a) racism, measured by a Racism Questionnaire, (b) spiritual well-being, measured by the Spiritual Well-Being Scale, (c) acculturation, measured by the African American Acculturation Scale-33, and (d) communication patterns, measured by the Communication Patterns Questionnaire. It was hypothesized that (a) the degree of racism experienced by couples would be negatively related to marital adjustment, (b) the degree of similarity in spouses' level of spiritual well-being would be positively related to marital adjustment, (c) the degree of similarity in spouses' level of acculturation would be positively related to marital adjustment, and (d) a constructive pattern of communication would be positively related to marital adjustment. Results indicated that acculturation and Religious Well-Being showed no relationship to marital adjustment. Racism experienced by wives was negatively related to the marital adjustment of these women and Black men. Similarity in Existential Well-Being was also positively related to adjustment for White women and Black men but not for Black women and White men. Existential Well-Being itself was also related to marital adjustment for White women and Black men. The Communication Patterns Questionnaire was found to be valid with Black-White interracially married couples and the Constructive Communication subscale was positively correlated with marital adjustment. Implications of these results and future directions for research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Understanding the multiracial experience through children's literature: A protocol.
column12: Torres, Mychelle Marie: California School of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(6-B), Dec 1998, pp. 3126.
column19: In the United States the multiracial population is growing faster than the monoracial populations, yet there has been little acknowledgement of multiracial people in research, media, or in discussions of race and ethnicity in schools. Additionally, few tools have been created to help inform society of the psychological complexities encountered by mixed heritage people. This dissertation examines common psychological dynamics that have been established in research literature. By utilizing these dynamics, a children's picture book was created that conveys the intricacies of being multiracial. The book is intended to help teachers, psychologists, parents, and children to generate conversations that examine questions of race and ethnicity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: White exploiters or White allies: Perspectives from some prominent multicultural psychologists/theorists.
column12: Burton, Margaret Ellen: California School of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(6-B), Dec 1998, pp. 3050.
column19: This study explored the experiences and perceptions of fourteen prominent psychologists/theorists who have been identified as experts in the field of multicultural counseling and psychology. The participants were interviewed utilizing a semi-structured interview protocol for the purpose of describing how a European American in the field of multicultural psychology might be perceived as an ally rather than an exploiter of multicultural populations. Seven European American scholars were asked about motivations and maintenance of their commitment to the field, while seven scholars of Color were asked about their perceptions of White colleagues' motivations. All participants were asked for advice for current White psychology students and professionals who desire to increase racial awareness and multicultural competence. Qualitative methodology was utilized to analyze the participants' responses. An interpretive/constructivist paradigm (Highlen & Finley, 1996), was utilized to deconstruct and reconstruct the linguistic data (Hoshmand, 1989). This involved the generation of themes via a modified idiosyncratic investigator analysis, followed by the development of generalized relations among the themes through interpretation. The result was the development of a coherent model of construed meaning to explain White racism awareness and multicultural competence. Findings from the present study indicated that the most significant aspects of being perceived as a White ally were genuine motivations and efforts to become culturally competent. Additionally, results supported current models of White racial identity development as well as the possibility of increased interracial collaboration through "selective appreciation." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: An ethnographic study of interracial couples, mediating a family identity, and cohesive personal identity development in their biracial children.
column12: Fletcher Stephens, Barbra J.: The Union Inst, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(5-B), Nov 1998, pp. 2471.
column19: The purpose of the study was to determine how interracial couples mediated a family identity. Extensive search of the literature revealed a paucity of literature relative to this process. It is this researcher's belief that couples in interracial marriages bring to the marriage diverse world views that produce strains and even serious conflict that affect the development of a shared family identity. Using an ethnographic research approach, interracial couples participated in structured interviews. Researcher and couples' perspectives about core issues in how the couples mediate their family identity were examined. Based on this study, couples acknowledged the importance of educating their children about being biracial and exposing them to a balanced view of their families, and passing on the positive as well as the negative attributes of both sides of their family in support of helping their children develop a cohesive personal identity. This study also revealed that both parents took on a protective role regarding how their children may be viewed by others in society based on their children's dual identity. Further, as interracial couples continue to create and present a balanced view of their family, their biracial children will experience less core identity conflict and will be able to mediate social marginality. This study has implications for other interracial couples, teachers, and health, mental health, and social service professionals who interact with these families. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The process of acculturation in intercultural marriage: A psychological study of authenticity in immigrant women.
column12: Fechner, Antje Marie: California School of Professional Psychology - San Diego, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(5-B), Nov 1998, pp. 2483.
column19: The purpose of this study was the exploration of the acculturation process as experienced by immigrant women married to an American man, and the applicability of the Existential concept of authenticity to this process. Previous research on immigrant wives has found that the wives feel alienated, unnoticed, isolated, struggling to keep their identity; that development was disrupted, and the wives feel not in step (Barbara, 1989; Espin, 1992; Imamura, 1990; Prawer Jhabvala, 1985; Romano, 1988). Previous works on Identity and the Self have used concepts such as "true self", "false self", "real self", or "autonomous individual" (Maslow, 1970; Masterson, 1985; Winnicott, 1969). Criticism has been that this Western concept of Self does not apply to persons of non-Western cultures (Chu, 1985; Hsu, 1985; Kaschak, 1992). Existentialism purports that the sense of authenticity is independent of the identity bestowed by one's culture (Bugental, 1976; Heidegger, 1962; Kierkegaard, 1959; Nietzsche, 1994; Sartre, 1956). Answers to the following questions were sought: (1) What effect will the immersion in a different culture have on a person's sense of identity? (2) Will this immersion result in a decreased (Barbara, 1989; Imamura, 1990; Romano, 1988) or increased (Taylor 1991; Bugental, 1976) sense of authenticity, or is authenticity independent of culture (Kierkegaard, 1959)? Seven women of Asian and South American background were interviewed. Data were analyzed using coding systems suggested by Strauss and Corbin (1990), utilizing the QSR NUD*IST{TM} computer program, to reveal the most salient and frequent topics. Results include the formation of a stage model of acculturation under headings of "Preliminal" (before marriage), "Liminal" (around time of marriage) and "Postliminal" (after marriage). It is suggested that immigration and acculturation is part of a longer process starting early in the participants' life: the striving to become more authentic by increasing personal potential restricted in the home culture through poverty or the role of women. The Existential concept of authenticity is suggested to be applicable to this process. Further research into the relationship of home culture and the nature of the acculturation process is suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of fear and bias perceptions of interracial cooperation in young males.
column12: Owens, Timothy Knox: Hofstra U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(5-B), Nov 1998, pp. 2488.
column19: Interracial interactions are influenced by racial bias and prejudicial attitudes, as well as reactions based in fear or anxiety (Brewer & Miller, 1984; Fazio, Jackson, Dunton, & Williams, 1995; Gaertner & Dovidio, 1986; Orysh, 1991; Pfeifer & Ogloff, 1991; Sigelman & Welch, 1993; Stephan & Stephan, 1984). African American males, in particular, are frequently the object of racial bias and fear responses (Dembo, 1988). This study was designed to explore several facets of crossracial interactions of young male African Americans and Caucasian Americans. Specific goals were to analyze how the presentation of information that another young male, from a different racial group, displaying either high or low levels of fear in interracial interactions and either high or low levels of prejudicial attitudes would affect rates of cooperative behavior in a mixed-motive game and social impression ratings of identified co-players. In addition, responses on a self-reported measure related to racial attitudes were utilized to regroup participants by theoretical stages of development, and then reanalyze game playing responses. Sixty-seven male African American and sixty-eight male Caucasian American middle school, secondary school and two-year college students (ages 11-20) living in suburban regions of New York State participated in the study. Each participant played four, twenty-five trial rounds of a mixed-motive prisoner's dilemma game with different race co-players identified as demonstrating either high or low levels of fear responses during interracial interactions, and racial prejudice. Participants played the game with identified co-players on a computer making choices according to a randomly generated sixty percent cooperative response rate. The study took the form of a 2 x 2 x 2 design, with race of participant (African American vs. Caucasian American), perception of fear in interracial interaction (high vs. low), and perception of racial bias (high vs. low) as factors. Rate of cooperative responses during each phase of the prisoner's dilemma game was measured as a dependent variable both within subjects and between racial groups. In addition a social impression rating of identified co-players was taken following each round of the game. The Racial Attitude Identity Scale (RIAS) or White Racial Attitude Identity Scale (WRIAS) (Helms, 1990), was analyzed as a non-manipulated independent variable by grouping participants into theoretical identity development stages. Demographic information (parent education, family income) and prior experience with cooperative learning strategies in school settings was also collected. It was hypothesized but not supported that: (1) male African Americans in the high fear-low prejudice condition would have the highest rates of cooperation and those in the low fear-high prejudice condition would cooperate the least across all groups; (2) Caucasian Americans in high fear-low prejudice condition would cooperate at lower rates than African Americans in the same experimental condition. Support was found for the following hypotheses: (1) Across racial groups, participants in low fear-low prejudice conditions rated co-players more positively on the social impression rating; (2) Among African American participants in immersion-emersion stage of racial identity development on the RIAS cooperated at lower levels than other stages; and (3) Caucasian Americans in the reintegration stage on the WRIAS cooperated less than other developmental stages. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: "Getting to yes": Teachers and their choices regarding tolerance.
column12: Mckenna, Brian Joseph: State U New York at Albany, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.59(4-A), Oct 1998, pp. 1118.
column19: We know both intuitively and through research that teachers' attitudes and beliefs influence students and their academic achievement. Teachers, what they believe and why they believe it, impact and influence student development in matters of character as well. This study explores teachers' attitudes and beliefs about four controversial topics: interracial dating, homosexuality as a curricular topic in public high schools, censorship of high school student press, and freedom of expression through dress. These attitudes and beliefs are teased are examined through the combined use of both quantitative and a qualitative methods. The quantitative method, a survey, is made up of fourteen questions borrowed from national polls, twelve similarly constructed questions, and eleven questions related to four "real-life" vignettes. The vignettes are intended to provoke thought and frame the subsequent qualitative component, the use of focus groups. Focus groups began over sixty years ago but have only in the past decade found their niche in social science research. For while they have enjoyed extensive use in marketing, focus groups do not provide the neat and tidy findings common to its quantitative counterparts. What focus groups do provide is depth. They allow a researcher to ask why opinions and beliefs are held. In focus groups, group interaction enables debate and reflection uncommon to other methodologies. In this study, focus groups were used to ask teachers about their responses to the vignettes. Eight focus groups were held with a total of seventy-seven participants, all experienced teachers. In addition two hundred, forty-five students in graduate education programs completed the survey instrument. The data collected enabled an examination of attitudes and beliefs and a determination of whether teachers chose tolerance when it was an option for behavior. Tolerance is a virtue that enables people to live together peacefully in a diverse society. As our society grows ever larger and more diverse, tolerance will become an increasingly necessary component of our young people's character. This study has found that many teachers often choose to avoid offending others and to maintain social order above tolerance. The implications of this are considered and suggestions offered for consideration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Parent-adolescent communication: Differences between adopted and biological adolescents.
column12: Dehaan, Gayle Hoekstra: U Minnesota, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(2-B), Aug 1998, pp. 0895.
column19: This study examined ratings of parent-adolescent communication by parents and their biological and adopted, including transracially adopted, adolescent children. Its purpose was to investigate the relationship between adoption status, gender, intellectual ability, and age and the perceptions of parent-adolescent communication of both parents and adolescents. The data were from the Minnesota Transracial Adoption Project: Follow-up at Adolescence, a study of 93 white, middle to upper-middle class families who adopted African-American and interracial children conducted from 1984 to 1986 and funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF/BNS 8312605). Subjects for this study were 82 fathers and 89 mothers along with 128 adopted and 88 biological adolescents aged 14-24 years, all of whom completed the Parent-Adolescent Communication Scale and either WISC-R or WAIS-R. Parent-adolescent communication in the adopted and biological children in this sample was basically positive. There was low to moderate agreement between parents and adolescents and moderate to strong agreement between mothers and fathers in ratings of communication. With regard to mother-adolescent communication, no significant differences were attributable to adoption status or intellectual ability. Significant differences were attributable to age and gender. Sons rated communication to be better, with more openness and fewer problems in communication, than daughters did and mothers experienced better, more open and problem-free communication with older than younger adolescents. An interaction was found between adoption status and gender for mothers' perceptions of communication problems. With regard to father-adolescent communication, no significant differences were attributable to gender but were to adoption status, intellectual ability, and age. Fathers experienced better and more open communication with biological adolescents. Adolescents with higher IQ scores experienced better and more problem-free communication with fathers. Fathers and adolescents both agreed that older adolescents experienced better and more open communication. Possible explanations for these results were discussed and the limitations of the data due to the sample, the measure, and the lack of causal data were mentioned. Suggestions for future research included investigating the relationship between parent-adolescent communication and behavioral adjustment, especially focusing on father-adolescent communication and longitudinal designs, as well as further elucidation of the role of intellectual ability in communication between parents and adolescents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: How tightly is the knot tied?: Spontaneous use of relationship categories for inter-racial versus intra-racial marriages.
column12: Lewandowski, Donna Annemarie: Michigan State U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.59(1-B), Jul 1998, pp. 0460.
column19: The incidence of interracial marriage between Blacks and Whites has grown from 65,000 in 1970 to 322,000 in 1995 (U.S. Census Bureau, 1970, 1995). The current study sought to determine whether information is spontaneously organized in memory around the marital relationship for inter-racial couples as it is for intra-racial couples (Sedikides, Olsen, & Reis, 1993). It was predicted that it would not be. Couples matched or mismatched on occupation were included since it was predicted that dissimilarities other than race might interfere with a couple being viewed as a social unit. One hundred and eighty participants were randomly assigned to one of the cells of a 2 (attribute: race or occupation) by 2 (relationship: matched on attribute vs mismatched on attribute) between-subjects design. Participants received information about 8 target individuals who comprised 4 couples. Their task was to memorize the information presented about each target. After timed exposure to each target, participants completed recall and recognition tasks, and belief similarity measures. Partial support for the hypothesis that mismatched couples would be less likely to be perceived as a social unit than matched couples was found for within couple and between-couple errors on recognition tasks. However, responses to the free-recall measure did not show greater spontaneous use of the marital relationship category for matched compared to mismatched couples. Belief similarity measures suggested that couples matched on race or occupation were perceived as more similar on a variety of dimensions (e.g., values, morals, attitudes) compared to mismatched couples as expected. Since the same pattern emerged for couples mismatched on occupation as for those mismatched on race, findings suggest that it is not race per se but rather a lack of perceived similarity that discourages the perception of couples as a unit. Implications of the lack of perceived social unity of a couple by outsiders for the success (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The formation of relationships in a multicultural setting at tertiary level.
column12: Harilal, Jodhika Rani Joice: U South Africa, South Africa
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.59(1-A), Jul 1998, pp. 0083.
column19: The increasing cultural and social diversity of South African society necessitates a study of the formation of harmonious social relationships amongst students at multicultural tertiary institutions. Desegregation at educational institutions is still in its embryonic stage and the minimal changes at college campuses are tokenistic. Educators have to make a concerted effort to review the dynamics and complexities of institutional change and to deviate from the straitjacket of upholding only ethnocentric views. A lack of communication and understanding between the different racial and ethnic groups on South African campuses has resulted in conflict and tension. This study takes an in-depth look at the psychology of prejudice, issues of ethnicity, racism and discrimination. A literature study and an empirical research project are used to gain an overview of the ramifications of racism on the formation of friendships in a multicultural milieu. The results of this study indicate the need to create a diversified campus environment which will promote genuine cross-cultural exchange. Working with culturally different students is a challenge that requires an acceptance and appreciation of diversity, flexibility, and improved contact and communication. Structured multicultural models and procedural frameworks have been designed specifically for implementation at institutions of higher learning to enhance social cohesion. The following recommendations are made: (1) Transitions models such as the contact hypothesis and the co-operative learning models promote the need for an interracial contact of people with equal status in co-operative situations. (2) Prejudice-Reduction Workshops will enable participants to learn about prejudice and to develop a positive mind-set towards all racial groups. (3) Specialized Programmes such as intercultural simulation games are ideal for discussions on culture shock, ethnocentrism and enculturation. (4) Mentoring Programmes ought to be designed (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Crossing borders: The negotiation of difference and formation of couple identity in interracial relationships.
column12: Killian, Kyle D.: Syracuse U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.58(12-A), Jun 1998, pp. 4825.
column19: Interracial marriages have proliferated in the United States over the past three decades. This study explores the process by which interracial partners negotiate differences in their attempts to establish a relationship identity. Interviews were conducted with ten black-white couples who had been married for at least one year and had at least one child together. Interviews were semi-structured, featuring open-ended questions, and partners were interviewed separately and together. Data were analyzed inductively using the method of constant comparison. Results reflect interracial couples' experience of their life together, their perception of others' perceptions of them, and their processes of negotiating differences in regard to race, gender, and class. Black partners more than white partners demonstrated an awareness of and sensitivity to public reactions to the couple and reported more concerns about what challenges their children might face. Implications for therapy with interracial couples are discussed, including the significance of therapists' and clients' locations on axes of power. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Intellectual and psychosocial predictors of success in the college transition: A multi-ethnic study of freshmen students on a predominantly white campus.
column12: Sanders, Reliford Theopolis, Jr.: U Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(10-B), Apr 1998, pp. 5655.
column19: This study investigated the predictive utility of gender, standardized test scores, and non-cognitive predictors for academic success and psychological well-being for a racially and ethnically diverse sample of 449 college students. Stress and coping models offered a coherent conceptualization of how non-cognitive factors may operate. Cross-ethnic comparisons revealed both similarities and differences between African Americans, Latino, Asian and White students. Intercorrelations supported the notion that the non-cognitive factors operated as adaptive personal resources, but less as specific social and cultural resources. Multiple regression analyses supported the predictive value of standardized test scores and gender for academic success, but the non-cognitive measures were stronger predictors of psychological well-being. Additionally, exploratory factor analyses within the multi-ethnic sample revealed seven revised non-cognitive factors which may have greater utility for more culturally diverse student populations i.e., support, confidence, initiative, leadership, career efficacy, interracial efficacy, and planning). Limitations of the study were discussed with implications for both future research and professional practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

This study represents the first time that both self-esteem and psychological adjustment have been studied in relationship to ethnic identity in the same study for any minority population. column5: A comparison of the marital quality of Asian-white couples to that of same-race Asian and same-race white couples.
column12: Chan, Anna Yukyee: Cornell U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.58(8-A), Feb 1998, pp. 3319.
column19: The purpose of this study was to examine the marital quality of interracial Asian-white couples. A major goal of this project was to complement and improve upon existing studies of interracial families. This study tested hypotheses generated by marginalization and assimilation theories on the adjustment and well-being of minority groups. These theories predict that individuals in interracial unions will experience more stress and strain and may be at risk for higher marital instability and lower well-being than individuals in same-race unions because: (1) these individuals are more likely to be marginalized and less integrated, and that (2) on an individual level, minority spouses who are less assimilated into their partner's culture will experience more conflicts due to cultural differences than individuals in same-race marriages, while more assimilated minority spouses who have adopted the current majority attitudes toward divorce will perceive lower marital stability if their marriages are unsatisfactory. An alternative hypothesis was proposed using the resiliency perspective. This perspective focuses on the positive functioning and resources of interracial marriages and predicts that the unique challenges of interracial relationships may facilitate personal growth and enhance the stability of such relationships. Husbands and wives in three types of marriages (same-race white, same-race Asian, and Asian-white marriages) were each asked to fill out a self-administered questionnaire. Asian subjects in this study were highly assimilated culturally and structurally. Overall, analyses of their responses on seven measures of their marital quality and perceived instability revealed that interracially married individuals do not differ significantly from intraracially married individuals. Two exceptions are found on two of five measures of marital instability: (1) interracially married Asian males significantly perceive their marriages to be less positive; (2) interracially married white males were significantly less likely to report marital trouble in the past year. In addition, Asian spouses in same-race marriages reported significantly lower marital quality, a higher probability of being maritally distressed, and less positive views of their marital histories than white spouses in same-race marriages. Finally, interracially married Asian husbands perceived significantly lower social integration and support than husbands in other unions indicating that they may be more marginalized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: White racial identity: Its relationship to cognitive complexity and interracial contact.
column12: Look, Christine T: Ball State U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(7-B), Jan 1998, pp. 3955.
column19: This study was conducted in two parts. In the first part, two assumptions presented in Janet Helms' White Racial Identity (WRI) development model (1990) were tested. First, Helms theorized that one's stage of WRI development is positively related to increased cognitive complexity achievement and suggests that later stages require greater complexity. A second assumption of Helms' theory was that continued interracial contact is essential for advancement in WRI stage development. Part one of this study examined the relationship of cognitive complexity and interracial contact (both formal and informal) to WRI, and the relationship between cognitive complexity and interracial contact as they relate to WRI. Part two of this study consisted of a factor analysis of Helms' WRI measure followed by a second set of analyses examining the relationship between the new obtained factors with contact and cognitive complexity. This analysis allowed a comparison to be made between Helms' 5 WRI stages and the obtained factor solution from the factor analysis. It also allowed a comparison of the relationship between the stages and cognitive complexity and contact and the obtained factor solution and these same variables. Three hundred and sixty-eight White undergraduates completed Helms' White Racial Identity Attitude Scale, a 4 x 6 Repertory Grid, measuring cognitive complexity in social settings, and an interracial contact measure, including a measure of both formal and informal types of contact. Results of part one of the analyses indicated that neither cognitive complexity nor cognitive complexity x contact were significantly related to WRI scores. However, contact was significantly related to WRI scores. WRI stage two was positively related and WRI stage four was negatively related to scores on formal contact. Stage 4 was negatively related and stages 2 and 3 were positively related to scores on informal contact. The results of part two indicated again that neither cognitive complexity nor cognitive complexity x contact were significantly related to the obtained WRI factors. However, contact once again was significant. The factor analysis produced a 5 factor solution that while similar in theme and number to the 5 stages, nonetheless indicated a different relationship with contact scores than the stages did. Factor 3 (representing stage 4) was positively related and factor 4 (representing stages 2 and 3) was negatively related to formal contact scores. However, factor 3 (representing stage 4) was positively related and factor 4 (representing stages 2 and 3) were negatively related to scores on informal contact. There were discrepancies across the two parts of the study as to the stages and direction of the relationships between interracial contact (formal and informal) and WRI scores. Some of these results were in opposite directions than either the theory or study expected. These discrepancies are dealt with in chapter 5. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Shared knowledge between partners in premarital relationships: Influences of depth of involvement, similarity of race or ethnicity, and communication.
column12: Batchelder, Michelle Lynne: U Texas at Austin, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.58(7-A), Jan 1998, pp. 2865.
column19: As relationships develop from first encounters to intimate involvements, partners find out about each other and their relationship by observing and interpreting events. Partners' knowledge about their relationship begins as general beliefs and knowledge of past relationships and becomes increasingly more specific as involvement deepens. The more coupled partners communicate with one another and deepen their involvement, the more shared knowledge about the relationship they should acquire. The extent to which partners have similar general knowledge about relationships due to cultural background should also influence whether they interpret events in similar ways, and how much shared knowledge they have. This study examined shared knowledge between coupled partners in their explanations for why they became more or less committed to marriage over time. The random sample consisted of 310 respondents (156 women and 154 men) who had never married and were involved in heterosexual relationships. Respondents were interviewed separately about how their relationship changed over time and completed questionnaires about their personal history and traits, the other partner, and the relationship. Qualitatively different categories of shared knowledge were coded by comparing the accounts of coupled partners for why commitment changed over time. Patterns of shared knowledge were examined in relation to stage of involvement, similarity of race or ethnicity (measured as same race or ethnic relationships and interracial or interethnic relationships), communication between partners, social concern, and communication with the joint network. The results of the study showed that at committed stages of involvement, partners have more related knowledge than at lower stages of involvement, but for women only. Partners involved in same race or ethnic relationships have less unshared shared knowledge than partners involved in interracial or interethnic relationships, but this hypothesis merits retesting. Communication as a correlate of shared knowledge holds only for women: Communication between partners increases as shared knowledge increases. In contrast, communication with the joint network increases as unshared knowledge increases. Positive network concern for the continuation of the relationship was associated with related knowledge, but this association needs further examination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: The purpose of this study was to explore the attitudes of African university students towards interracial marriage. On whether they would choose a black or white person for marriage and whether their parents would approve their marrying a white person, most respondents (first-year undergraduates, 76 women and 63 men) preferred marrying a black person and indicated their parents would oppose their marrying a white person. Such findings were no surprise given the cultural value attached to marriage as well as South African multiracial interrelations marked by differential treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Science in the service of the far right: Henry E. Garrett, the IAAEE, and the Liberty Lobby.
column12: Winston, Andrew S.: U Guelph, Dept of Psychology, Guelph, ON, Canada
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.54(1), Spr 1998, pp. 179-210.
column19: Discusses the politics of Henry E. Garrett, who was the President of the American Psychological Association (APA) in 1946 and Chair of Psychology at Columbia University from 1941-1955. In the 1950s, Garrett helped organize an international group of scholars dedicated to preventing race mixing, preserving segregation, and promoting the principles of early 20th century eugenics and "race hygiene." Garrett became a leader in the fight against integration and collaborated with those who sought to revitalize the ideology of National Socialism. The current author discusses the intertwined history the International Association for the Advancement of Ethnology and Eugenics, the journal Mankind Quarterly, the neofascist Northern League, and the ultra-right wing political group the Liberty Lobby. The use of psychological research and expertise in the promotion of neofascism is examined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Realizing solidarity.
column12: Brueggemann, John: Skidmore Coll, Saratoga Springs, NY, US
column13: Work and Occupations. Vol.25(4), Nov 1998, pp. 436-482.
column19: Describes how 3 Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO) organizing drives achieved interracial solidarity. In 1933, the United Mine Workers (UMW) adopted the "UMW formula" for placing Black workers in positions as union officers and organizers. Adopted from more radical unions, the formula institutionalized racial inclusion, which proved to be a major tactical innovation in realizing class solidarity across racial lines. Faced with similar conditions, the Steel Workers Organizing Committee in 1937 and the United Auto Workers in 1940 adopted variants of the UMW formula to overcome racial barriers to organizing. The authors analyze narratives of these 3 drives using event-structure analysis (ESA), a diachronic method, and qualitative comparative analysis (QCA), a synchronic method. Both approaches reveal the importance of 3 main factors: tactical innovations, political context, and labor market conditions. The 1st 2 factors are explained by political process theory, and the 3rd is predicted by split labor market theory. Among these findings, ESA highlights path dependence of tactical innovations and QCA emphasizes structural conditions in the labor market. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Areview of theoretical, clinical, and empirical literature was conducted regarding the effect of adoptee dissimilarity from the adoptive family. There is empirical evidence of a relationship between dissimilarity and searching for birth parents, satisfaction with the adoption, and adjustment. A theory of an effect of identity-seeking on searching by adoptees has also been formulated. It is suggested, therefore, that an effort to establish one's identity may mediate a relationship between adoptee dissimilarity and searching. Implications are presented for social work practice and research, and for public policy and education, in instances of same race and transracial adoption. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Skin color recognition, preference and identification in interracial children: A comparative study.
column13: (1998). Skin color recognition, preference and identification in interracial children: A comparative study. x, 79 pp. Lanham, MD, US: University Press of America; US.
column19: (from the book) Investigated skin tone recognition, preference, and identification in 25 interracial children (aged 3-5 yrs) using a modified version of the Greenwald-Oppenheim doll technique. Ss along with 50 black and white counterparts matched by sex, age, schooling, number of siblings, and socioeconomic status were asked questions about 3 dolls of different skin tones. Interracial, black, and white children did not differ significantly in the number of correct responses to the recognition questions. There was a slight tendency for the 3 groups to select the brown doll as undesirable and this tendency appeared greatest among white Ss. Significant differences were noted between interracial and black, and black and white Ss' skin tone identifications. Overall, findings suggest that the majority of interracial, black, and white Ss are capable of recognizing skin color differences and this ability increases with age. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) Presents a short history of Asian Americans, and reviews major findings, presents data, and provides a model to understand and to make future predictions regarding interracial marriages. Data were gathered through an examination of marital records from the Los Angeles County Marriage License Bureau. The following groups are covered: Chinese, Filipinos, Japanese, Koreans, and Vietnamese. Although there were differences between groups, it appears that length of time, exposure to American society, and acculturation, all related to generation, begin a process leading to higher rates of out-marriage. The Japanese Americans, primarily a third generation group, had the highest rates of out-marriage. The Koreans, primarily a first-generation immigrant population, had the lowest rates. Females, especially of the American-born generations, also were more likely to marry non-Asians than were those who were born in the old country. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

This handbook provides insights into the diverse and varied nature of Asian American cultures. It will be of use to professionals, students, and academics in ethnic studies, psychology, social welfare, gender studies, family studies, nursing, gerontology, research methods, and interpersonal communication.
(from the preface) This volume integrates descriptions and evaluations of psychological research on all ethnic subgroups of Asian Americans. It begins with an overview of Asian America to provide a historical and contemporary context of U.S. societal treatment of Asians. It provides a basis for understanding the research findings presented in the subsequent chapters. Finally, it provides insight into the diverse and varied nature of Asian American cultures and communities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) Reviews and critiques research on marital relations and stability among interracial couples, focusing on 5 issues: (1) demographic characteristics and social resources of those who marry interracially; (2) the particular racial combination of the partners, including whether the husband or the wife is a member of a more socially dominant group; (3) challenges facing interracial marriages, including rearing biracial children; (4) personal factors that promote the selection of an individual into an interracial marriage and affect commitment, to the marriage; and (5) the social context of interracial marriage, including social prejudice, the availability of same-race marital partners, and social network for the couple. Throughout, there is a particular focus on Asian-White intermarriage, a major proportion of interracial marriages in the US. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

(from the chapter) Eight children (aged 18-34 yrs) of mixed marriages were interviewed. Some reported experiencing problems in being accepted, or wanting to be accepted, by one or other of the cultural groups to which they were affiliated. Physical characteristics denoting obvious difference from the majority seem to be important in identity questions. As a result, friendships with non-kin peer groups have often assumed great importance. Attitudes to gender relations were also mentioned as important, especially for women. Changes occurred for some as they matured, as perceptions and experiences varied significantly, or their place of residence or other circumstances changed. Class and SES were also significant factors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

In this chapter, the authors explore one area of those possible consequences: loss and the feelings associated with loss. They document 3 kinds of loss resulting from racism: the losses of African-Americans resulting from racism, the losses of multiracial couples resulting from racism, and the losses that White partners in multiracial couples experience as they come to understand what White racism does to Whites. Data were drawn from a study of the relationships of 21 Black-White heterosexual couples who were interviewed, using open-end questions focusing on their experiences and perspectives. column19: Examined the prevalence of domestic violence in marriages between Filipino women and Australian men. In in-depth interviews and structured questionnaires with service providers and with 139 Filipinas married to Anglo-Australian and Filipino men, the issue of underreporting physical and emotional violence was a recurring theme. The relationships of power that characterize these marriages, the changes in balance of power that result from the externalization of anger, physical and verbal violence, and stigmatization of domestic violence experienced by Filipinas individually and in the community was explored. It is suggested that social disapproval and stereotypical representations of Filipina-Australian marriages in Australian society, and the consequent shame experienced by Filipinas, has led to underreporting of emotional and physical abuse. column19: The effect of solo status was investigated in 32 same-sex small groups in which the racial status of one of the four members was systematically varied to reflect African American and White group majorities. During one task-oriented session, each group member made ratings of one another and selected one member to be leader on a future task. Judgments of solos varied as a function of their racial status. African American solos were judged more favorably and were more often selected to be leader than were White targets in both African American and White majorities. More generally, these findings indicate that theories of relative numbers and salience effects that explain group processes in gender contexts do not apply in the same way to race contexts. Implications of these findings for organizational settings, and interracial interaction in small groups are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: The prevalence of rape myths contributes to victims' reluctance to report rapes. 30 Black and 96 White US college students (aged 19-58 yrs old) responded to the Rape Myth Scale (M. R. Burt, 1980) and read a scenario of an acquaintance rape; the race of the perpetrator and victim (Black or White) were varied. The respondents assessed the victim's and perpetrator's responsibility and evaluated the incident. As hypothesized, the respondents with strong beliefs in rape myths were more tolerant of the rapist and less tolerant of the victim than were those with weaker beliefs. There was limited support for the myth of the Black rapist and White victim; however, the myth of the Black rapist appeared particularly strong among the Black respondents. The women responded more negatively to the rapist and more positively to the victim than the men did. Such bias in attitudes toward rape could keep women from reporting rapes and accused rapists from receiving fair trials. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Transference and race: An intersubjective conceptualization. [References].
column12: Yi, Kris Y.: Private Practice, Los Angeles, CA, US
column13: Psychoanalytic Psychology. Vol.15(2), Spr 1998, pp. 245-261.
column19: Discussions of race-based transference in the psychoanalytic literature have been infrequent. When present, such transference has been described from the Freudian or Kleinian perspective, as either a manifestation of intrapsychic conflicts or projection of unwanted mental content onto the racial other. These views, although helpful in some situations, exclude other possible meanings of interracial transference. This article describes an approach based on contemporary intersubjective theories in which race-related transference is seen as one aspect of a person's ongoing construction of experience and understanding of the unique meaning of race for each patient is emphasized. The far-reaching influence of the analyst's race and culture in the development of transference is then described, and it is argued that the analyst needs to be aware of the culture embeddedness of her or his therapeutic endeavors. Treatment issues are discussed with clinical examples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).
