column19: Increasing interracial contact is one of the goals of school desegregation policies. However, focusing upon weak ties as 1 important type of interracial contact, this article shows how reallocation of students among schools for desegregation may reduce opportunities for interracial contact. This apparent paradox is analyzed, and it is shown that it is a member of the mathematical family of phenomena known as class size paradoxes. Then, policy implications for schools and theoretical implications for understanding intergroup relations are considered. It is suggested that there is a need for empirical research to determine the practical value of applying the theory in this complex context. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Promoting same-race adoption for children of color.
column12: Hollingsworth, Leslie Doty: U Michigan, School of Social Work, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Social Work. Vol.43(2), Mar 1998, pp. 104-116.
column19: Opponents of policies that protect same-race adoption assert that children of color are languishing in out-of-home care because they are being restricted from entering transracial adoption arrangements. This article argues that transracial adoption is not necessary to ensure that children of color are adopted in a timely manner and sets forth alternative arguments around six issues: (1) policies favoring adoption by foster parents, (2) the availability of same-race families to adopt children of color, (3) the abundance of children in out-of-home care unavailable for adoption or with special needs, (4) disparities in child welfare services related to ethnicity, (5) misleading data on the numbers of children of color who are in foster care, and (6) poverty as an underlying cause of out-of-home placements. This article briefly presents the history of the transracial adoption controversy and discusses its current status; counters assertions typically used to oppose same-race adoption policies for children of color; summarizes the positions of several social work organizations regarding adoption and race; and makes recommendations for education, policy, research, and practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1997, Vol 42(3), 246-247. This edited book (see record 1995-98479-000) provides an extensive and penetrating examination into social and familial issues affecting the lives of ethnic American families. It contains several important organizing themes that represent the book's major strengths. Its most central and consistent theme is the tenet that family's critical functions are the socialization of children, the social and psychological support of family members, and the provision of a stable and beneficial environment for family life. The 23 chapters of the text are divided into four sections that deal with issues of current social, cultural and demographic statuses of ethnic families; cultural patterns in parenting and socialization practices; attitudes surrounding interracial dating and marriage; and the influences of ethnicity, race, and family structure on health and educational outcomes. The reviewer notes that the weakest aspect of the book deals with the analyses on interracial marriages. The quality of the chapters also was noted to vary in strength. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Posted date: November, 1997. In the history of prejudice research in social psychology, there has been a long and arduous search for an unobtrusive methodology for assessing interracial and interethnic prejudice. One of the first reported unobtrusive measures was the bogus pipeline technique (E. E. Jones and H. Sigall, 1971). Jones and Sigall's measure was unequivocal in its ability to covertly assess prejudice. However, because of the great monetary cost and precision that the technique requires, others have attempted to devise more appropriate measures. Rio (1972) devised a technique that was based on the methods of early group conformity researchers. The present study reports a replication of a study by C. Garcia et al (1993) using a more modern sample of 36 female Anglo- and Hispanic-American college students. It was found that an ethnic bias could not be statistically demonstrated using this method. Implications for the validity of the methodology and directions for future research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) Focuses on the needs of the newly immigrated Latino child. Specifically, the Latino child (aged 2-18 yrs) adopted from another country by a family of similar origin or as a part of a family, newly immigrated to this country, who for whatever reason involuntarily lost or voluntarily relinquished their child for adoption. Specifics of the Latino culture in terms of ancestry, language, codes of behavior, values, time orientation, family makeup, gender roles sexuality, work ethic, education, and spirituality are presented in order to understand the needs of a Latino child. Areas of concern are addressed. It is argued that transracial adoptions create a particular set of distinct problems. The author contends that it is in the best interest of the child in all areas of their development, to provide them with a family that is most similar to themselves, racially, ethnically, and culturally. A handout of questions to ask about culture is appended. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Investigated the role that nonracial and racial factors play in spouse selection among those who are married Black/White. This research endeavor attempted to determine if nonracial factors characterized by socioeconomic and commonality variables are more important in the mate selection process in comparison with those related to racial differences. Race, gender, age, and educational achievement of the biracially married individual were introduced as independent variables along with premarital biracial dating history to determine if they mitigate the influence of marital selection factors. A national sample of biracially married individuals was identified through a research advertisement placed in 12 consecutive issues of the Interrace magazine. 371 participants from 38 states within the US completed a mail-out questionnaire and 292 26-54 yr old respondents were included for analysis. The results reveal that nonracial factors are more important than racial factors for spouse selection among Ss. Many Ss stated that common interests and attractiveness of the person, irrespective of racial group membership, were very important factors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:

Macmillan, Ross

column12: Wortley, Scot: U Toronto, Ctr of Criminology, Toronto, ON, Canada
column13: Law & Society Review. Vol.31(4), 1997, pp. 637-676.
column19: Sociologists have long been interested in how reactions to deviance influence social order and consensus. However, classic statements on this subject present contrasting hypotheses. This article extends previous work by examining how the extensive media coverage of an interracial homicide influences public attitudes toward the criminal justice system. Initial results indicate that race, education, and police contact directly affect perceptions of criminal injustice. Perceptions of injustice are especially high among well-educated Blacks who have had recent contact with the police. Further analysis reveals that the media coverage of the homicide seems temporarily to consolidate public confidence in the police and criminal courts. However, this effect varies by race and education. We discuss the theoretical implications of these findings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the socioeconomic and demographic correlates associated with whether biracial children with an Asian parent are racially identified with their Asian parent or with their non-Asian parent. With data from 7,808 biracial children (aged 0-14 yrs), extracted from the 5-percent Public Use Microdata Sample of the 1990 census, the authors take into account explanatory variables at 3 levels: the child's characteristics, the parents' characteristics, and the locale's racial composition. Results indicate that the racial identification of biracial children with an Asian parent is to a large extent an arbitrary option within today's prevailing racial classification scheme. Empirical evidence supports the theoretical proposition that both assimilation and awareness of Asian heritage affect the racial identification of biracial children with an Asian parent. column5: Psychological adjustment of Korean-born adolescents adopted by American families.
column12: Yoon, Dong Pil: U Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.58(6-A), Dec 1997, pp. 2396.
column19: The purpose of the study is to find the intercorrelation among exogenous latent variables (parental support of ethnic background and positive parent-child relationship) and endogenous latent variables (collective self-esteem, and psychological adjustment) for Korean-born adolescent adoptees through structural equation modeling (PROC-CALIS: SAS). Data analysis was based on 241 respondents who were drawn from 28 states of the US. The mean age of the subjects was 14 with males and females comprising approximately 43 per cent and 57 per cent, respectively. Especially, for this study, the measurement scales for parental support of ethnic identity and shame about ethnic origin were developed. The analyses represent an initial attempt to examine the relationship among constructs that potentially influence the transracially adopted child's psychological adjustment. With the success of finding evidence for collective self-esteem on successful psychological adjustment, all hypothesized effects among parent's support of ethnic background and child's collective self-esteem variables were supported by the data. As was the case with results concerning the relationships among the adolescents' psychological adjustment variables, one expected effect of family context factors was also supported. The significant effect of the level of the positive parent-child relationship was positive. In addition to the results associated with the hypothesized model effects, there were statistically significant relationships between parent's support of ethnic background and positive parent-child relationship. The findings of the study stress the transaction between adoptive parents and children in terms of sharing experiences of children's ethnic socialization and establishes that positive relationship is the fundamental factor for children to develop a unique process of identity development. The outcomes of the study suggest that social workers have to continue to study the diverse needs of adoptive parents and develop appropriate intervention strategies in order to improve family functioning. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effects of cultural factors on marital satisfaction among swedish-american couples.
column12: O'Hearn, Margareta Ulla Victoria: California School of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(5-B), Nov 1997, pp. 2753.
column19: The purpose of this study was to begin to better understand the issues that interethnic couples may face, and specifically those faced by Swedish women married to American men and vice versa. Since little research exists in this area, research questions rather than hypotheses were addressed and an exploratory multiple-design case study was undertaken. In the exploratory case-study, a pilot sample was collected prior to the final definition of the research questions. The theory was discovered as the questions were answered. Hence, it was a prelude for further research. Eight couples, consisting of Swedish women married to American men, living in the Bay Area were interviewed on a single occasion for 90 minutes. The couples were selected based upon a snowball procedure in order to get a selection of participants who were unknown to the researcher. Each couple was interviewed together in order to acquire the greatest amount of interactional information from each couple. A set of structured interview questions, which had been designed to answer the research questions, was asked. An opportunity for a follow-up phone call was established in the event that the couple had thought of additional pertinent information. Each participant was given a short questionnaire (see appendix B) before the interview to fill out separately and confidentially. The purpose of this study was to begin to identify the themes of the marriages. The data were summarized for each couple, and among all the couples, in order to make some conclusions about the sample and each question/content area. The cross-comparisons aided in exploring each question and identifying issues and possible commonalities between couples. Differences between the Swedish and American cultures were small in comparison to those between Eastern and Western cultures. Accordingly, I expected to find comparatively subtle or lesser differences than the differences turned out to be. They were so subtle that the couples did not realize their existence at first. Most couples had come to terms with their discrepant views after their first year of marriage. The couples had difficulty pinning down what the differences were since they were resolved a long time ago. The five most frequently mentioned statements were: husband's long work hours, the husbands' desire to speak Swedish, strong Swedish identity, husband's involvement in Swedish events, and differing gender roles expectations. In conclusion, the wives' whose husbands expressed the most appreciation for the added cultural aspects also had the highest marital satisfaction. Most husbands appreciated the cultural diversity their wives brought into their lives. Marrying a spouse from a different country can be challenging but also rewarding depending on how flexible the partners are with each other. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Multiracial identity development: Developmental correlates and themes among multiracial adults.
column12: Adams, Jessica Lyn: The Ohio State U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(5-B), Nov 1997, pp. 2662.
column19: This study examined some of the common experiences that have been theorized to characterize the racial/ethnic identity development of multiracial individuals. The construct of ethnic identity was examined along with factors identified in the literature as influencing racial/ethnic identity development such as family support of multiracial heritage, sense of belonging, coping with discrimination, and racial/ethnic legitimacy testing. An attempt was also made to explore how ethnic identity and other factors such as self-esteem, racial diversity of the community in which one was raised, and choice of self-label are related. Seventy-three multiracial adults completed measures that assessed ethnic identity, self-esteem, racial/ethnic legitimacy testing experiences, family support of multiracial heritage and coping. Results indicated that a majority of participants had experienced racial/ethnic legitimacy testing from those racial groups which were part of their racial/ethnic heritage. While self-esteem was not found to be related to racial/ethnic legitimacy testing as predicted, statistically significant relationships were obtained between self-esteem and ethnic identity, and self-esteem and family support of multiraciality. Family support of multiraciality and racial diversity of neighborhood in which individual was raised were found to be significant predictors of ethnic identity. This finding is consistent with existing literature which has identified these two factors as having a positive impact on racial identity resolution. Participants were asked to identify a stressful situation in which they felt rejected due to some aspect of their multiracial heritage. A component of ethnic identity labeled ethnic identity achievement was found to be related to coping strategies that involved attempts to either alter this stressful situation or create some positive meaning from it. No significant predictors of choice of monoracial or multiracial self-label were identified. Methodological limitations of some of the measures, as well as the small sample size, were identified as reasons for interpreting these findings with caution. Further research using improved measures to assess the constructs of interest was recommended. Implications for counseling were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Shades of community and conflict: Biracial adults of African-American and Jewish-American heritages.
column12: Segal, Josylyn Chan: The Wright Inst, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(4-B), Oct 1997, pp. 2181.
column19: This study of eighteen adults of African-American and Jewish-American heritage explores how biracial subjects of two minority parents negotiates mixed race heritage and identity in a society that maintains a hostile attitude toward interracial unions. Data collection included (1) a semi-structured interview to determine subjects' own sense of racial/ethnic identity, (2) a measure of parental closeness, and (3) a series of twelve anecdotal hypothetical situations as a stimulus to revealing subjects' affective, cognitive and behavioral responses in contexts in which the subjects mixed-heritage might be expected to evoke conflict. A qualitative analysis, incorporating socio-cultural, psychodynamic, and historical perspectives, was utilized to investigate (1) racial and cultural stereotyping, (2) a hierarchy of color and racial categorization, (3) racial tolerance, (4) Black and Jewish relations, (5) biracial (Black and Jewish) identity, as mediated by parental and familial closeness. Factors that influenced racial/identity development in the subjects' lives were identified. Five of the six hypotheses were supported: (1) Phenotype is related to interpersonal perception. The biracial adult phenotypically perceived as African-American is more likely to identify as such, whereas the biracial adult phenotypically perceived as White is more likely to identify as either White or "mixed." (2) Closeness to the African-American parent is not necessary for children of mixed-race/Jewish heritage to identity with African-American heritage. (3) Closeness to the Jewish parent is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for children of mixed-race/Jewish heritage to identity with Jewish heritage. (4) For those who are close to their Jewish parent, the degree of closeness affects the degree to which they identify as Jews. (5) The extent to which respondents experience themselves as integral parts of their extended families will increase the extent to which they identify with that half of their cultural heritage. The sixth hypothesis, which stated that to the degree that respondents express negative stereotypes of one part of their heritage they will also minimize their identification with that part of their heritage was not supported due chiefly to the lack of negative stereotyping by most of the respondents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Between two cultures: Exploring the voices of first and second generation South Asian women.
column12: Tee, Karen Ai-Lyn: Simon Fraser U, Canada
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(4-B), Oct 1997, pp. 2158.
column19: Women of South Asian origins were interviewed in an exploration of their values and beliefs regarding family and gender roles, and acculturation experiences. The participants were 25 first generation and 26 second generation women, representative of the South Asian diaspora in the Lower Mainland of British Columbia. Grounded explicitly in feminist and hermeneutic theories, the methodology of this research consists primarily of an interpretive reading of transcribed interview narratives. In addition to thematic content, five narrative voices emerged as the women described and reflected upon their values and experiences. Moving beyond the dichotomy of "traditional" versus "modern" with respect to gender roles and acculturation, this interpretive method allowed for the multiplicity of women's voices and for the complexity of their subjectivity. Findings were primarily qualitative; however, some quantitative results were obtained. High inter-rater reliability was established between interpreters. Quantitative comparisons between the first and second generations suggested a statistically significant difference in the pattern of voices, and of thematic content associated with the voices (e.g., arranged marriage, spousal roles, dating, authority to parents, parenting practices). Of the numerous themes that emerged in the women's narratives, themes important to both generations include family honour (izzat), daughter as something held in trust (amanat), education, interracial relationships, and the conflict between family and independence. The impact of racism and internalized racism on ethnic identity formation was particularly important for the second generation. Meta-themes that predominated a woman's story (e.g., severe intergenerational conflict) and themes of particular concern for each generation also emerged in the narrative texts. The social context within which South Asian women live in Canada and the clinical implications of these findings are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Inter and intra-racial contact and affective reactions as aspects of recalled white racial identity socialization experiences.
column12: Scarpellini Huber, Jill Marie: U Maryland Coll Park, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(1-B), Jul 1997, pp. 0427.
column19: The present study explored interracial (across race) and intraracial (same race) contact and affective reactions as aspects of recalled White racial identity socialization experiences. Specifically, the present study investigated the relationship of White adults' current White racial identity schemas to their recalled intraracial and interracial socialization experiences, as represented by their affective reactions to and contact experiences with three racial groups (Whites, Blacks, and "minorities"). Three questionnaires were completed by 255 self-identified White American college students (179 women and 76 men). A critical incidents questionnaire (designed for the current study) assessed respondents' affective reactions towards the three racial groups and themselves after the respondents had recounted each of two experiences that they identified as being critical in the development of their race-related attitudes. Respondents also completed the Racial Contact Scale (adapted from Stephan & Stephan, 1989) to assess their recalled interracial and intraracial contact at the time of each incident. White racial identity schemas were assessed by responses to either the standard White Racial Identity Attitude Scale (WRIAS) (Helms & Carter, 1990) or a modified version of the WRIAS in which "minority" was substituted for "Black" as the contrast group in the scale. Multiple regression was used to examine relationships between racial identity schemas and affective reactions and amount and quality of interracial and intraracial contact. Results indicated that, in general, currently expressed White racial identity schemas were related to affective reactions in directions supportive of White racial identity theory. However, the two versions of the WRIAS were differentially related to some of the affective and contact variables in ways that suggest that the two versions of the WRIAS were not necessarily measuring the same racial identity constructs. Also, the results pertaining to the relationships between the White racial identity schemas and the recalled quality and quantity of intraracial and interracial contact were inconclusive because respondents did not have much interracial contact. However, an examination of the critical incidents that participants reported indicated that both interracial and intraracial socialization experiences were related to subsequent racial attitudes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Can we talk about race? the racial discourse of activists in a racially "integrated" neighborhood.
column12: Sternberg, Juliet Anna: Rutgers the State U New Jersey - New Brunswick, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(11-B), May 1997, pp. 7238.
column19: This study investigated "talk about race", a behavior that is being advocated by many, but remains relatively undefined and unexplored. Goals were to: (1) identify and explicate dimensions of racial discourse, (2) explore factors that explain variations in how and whether people converse about race, and (3) generate hypotheses about characteristics of constructive talk about race. Data were collected using qualitative interviews designed to elicit (1) examples of talk about race, and (2) views on talking about race. Informants were African-American and Euro-American men and women highly experienced with interracial contact and dialogue. Inductive and deductive methods highlighted important aspects of the data. Data from the researcher's self-reflections journal aided interpretation. Universal concerns in informants' talk were: how race bears on (1) one's identity, and (2) relations in society. Dimensions of talk about race as it bears on identity were the: (1) nature of its impact, (2) aspects of self attributed to race, (3) feelings associated with being of a certain race, and (4) development of racial self over time. Dimensions of talk about race as it bears on relations in society were the: (1) significance of race as a causal factor, (2) nature of racial differences, (3) nature of racial commonalities, (4) conceptualizations of diversity within racial groups, and (5) assignment of power, responsibility, vulnerability, and victimization. Key variables in informants' perspectives on talking about race were (1) definitions of talk about race, (2) assessments of its value, and (3) contextual factors that hinder and aide constructive talk. Analyses suggested that even for individuals with high levels of experience, competence, and satisfaction in interracial living, talking about race is challenging and fraught with ambivalence. Furthermore, race and gender, as well as generation, location of residence, and the racial constitution of one's family, were related to ways of talking about race and perspectives on talk about race, suggesting differences in the needs, risks, feelings, and modes of coping that people bring to such conversations. Findings suggest avenues for further research and help to identify conditions under which racial dialogue will be possible and meaningful for all participants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: African-American - Caucasian couples: A study of coping mechanisms and coping resources.
column12: Storm, Scott Camburn: California School of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(10-B), Apr 1997, pp. 6637.
column19: This study examined the coping mechanisms and coping resources used by African American-Caucasian couples. Twenty-four couples, with a mean age of 34 years, participated in the research. The subjects were recruited through the Intercultural-Interracial Pride Organization, as well as universities in the San Francisco and Boston Metropolitan areas. All participants responded to questionnaires through the mail. The three measures used in this study were the Ways of Coping Questionnaire, Coping Resources Inventory, and Coping Operations Preference Enquiry. Test scores were analyzed using univariate and multivariate analysis of variance. Results showed that men, regardless of ethnicity, used more planful-problem solving coping strategies then women (p =.017). In addition, Whites used significantly more social coping resources (p =.023) than Blacks. Because the between and within group differences were not significant for 10 remaining variables, it was concluded that gender and ethnicity have only slight effects on the coping strategies and resources used by African American-Caucasian couples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The relationship of academic self-efficacy and ethnic socialization to mental health outcomes in adolescents.
column12: Van Horn, Yolanda Vanessa: Duke U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(9-B), Mar 1997, pp. 5936.
column19: The primary goal of this research was to examine the relationship of academic self-efficacy and ethnicity-related socialization to mental health outcomes in young people. This study relied on a cross sectional survey design to examine the relationship of the independent variables to self-reported symptoms of anxiety, depression, and conduct problems among a sample of middle school students. Correlational analyses, analysis of variance, and hierarchical regression procedures were used to assess the relationship between the independent variables and self-reported symptoms. Correlational analyses showed that exposure to parental information about proactive strategies for getting along with members of other ethnic groups was positively correlated with academic efficacy. Consistent with the research hypotheses, correlational analyses revealed an inverse relationship between academic self-efficacy and conduct problems. Results also revealed an inverse correlation between efficacy and anxiety. The correlation between efficacy and depression was in the expected direction but was not statistically significant. Ethnic socialization scores also showed an inverse relationship to anxiety and conduct problems, except for exposure to messages of interracial distrust, which was positively correlated with higher levels of internalizing and externalizing distress. Analysis of variance showed no ethnic differences in self-efficacy perceptions, but gender differences in efficacy favored Caucasian females. Ethnic differences, but no gender differences, were found in exposure to parental socialization messages, with African-American students reporting more frequent exposure to ethnicity-related messages. Multiple regression analyses indicated that scores on measures of academic efficacy and ethnic socialization predicted symptoms of anxiety and conduct problems. In unexpected findings, higher levels of academic efficacy predicted lower levels of state anxiety and trait anxiety for African-American males and Caucasian females but were associated with higher levels of anxiety for African-American females and Caucasian males. Furthermore, the independent variables did not predict depressive symptoms. The findings of this research provide support for the hypothesized inverse relationship between academic efficacy and mental health outcomes. The results also provide support for the utility of academic self-efficacy perceptions and, to a lesser extent, ethnic socialization experiences to predict mental health outcomes among adolescents. Future research and implications for interventions with children are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Shepherd, Tracey Lynne: State U New York at Buffalo, US

column19: A lack of empirical data coupled with biases in the available research has served to perpetuate many myths, prejudices, stereotypes, and negative attitudes concerning biracial individuals. The purpose of this study is to assess the relationship between racial identification on relevant variables including self-esteem, the degree of social distance, attitude toward biracial individuals, and various life stressors. The major hypothesis is whether or not there are significant differences with respect to individual self-esteem, collective self-esteem, social distance, attitude toward biracial individuals, and life stressors among Blacks, Whites, and biracial people. Significant differences were found for attitudes about biraciality among the three racial groups. Implications of these findings as well as future research are discussed. column5: Sociocultural orientation among talented African-American college students in a race-specific program: Patterns, predictors and correlates.
column12: Greene, Monica Lynne: U Maryland Baltimore County, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.57(8-A), Feb 1997, pp. 3391.
column19: African-Americans must live and function within a bicultural context, i.e., settings dominated by two distinct cultural ideologies (White or Euro-cultural and Black or Afro-cultural). Sociocultural orientation is defined as a general pattern of behaviors exhibited in intraracial and interracial contexts, and attitudes held about one's own race, about other racial and ethnic groups, and about interacting with one's own and other racial and ethnic groups. The present study examined patterns of sociocultural orientation among academically successful African-American students in the Meyerhoff Program, an intensive, multi-faceted program focused on promoting minorities in the fields of math, science, and engineering. Coping strategies are constituent parts of larger patterns of sociocultural orientation. The current study also examined what types of specific coping strategies are exhibited among the Meyerhoff students, and whether they differ by gender. Data were collected from 115 Meyerhoff students at the University of Maryland Baltimore County. Measures of sociocultural orientation, academic and social integration, minority status stressors, and precollege interracial exposure and experience were administered during a Meyerhoff program meeting. A subsample of 34 Meyerhoff students participated in follow-up, in-depth interviews. The results indicated that the majority of Meyerhoff students were exhibiting a general pattern of movement between the Black and White cultural realms; seven distinct patterns of sociocultural orientation were exhibited by students in the interview subsample. Students exhibiting a pattern of movement away from both cultures appeared to experience difficulties in psychological, academic and social functioning. Additional relationships were found between certain predictors (gender, precollege interracial exposure and experience) and college-related correlates (minority status stressors), and components of sociocultural orientation. There was e (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Social support, prior interracial experiences, and network orientation: Factors related to later adjustment among Black freshmen at a predominantly White university.
column12: Graham, Calvin: Old Dominion U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.57(7-A), Jan 1997, pp. 2855.
column19: African-American students (mostly Freshmen) enrolled for the first year at a four-year university completed information about the racial composition of their high school, family income, living arrangements, and stressor prior to entering school. At two times during the first semester they completed measures of social support, network orientation and adaptation to college. Information about Grade Point Average (GPA) for the following term and attendance at the University one year later were also obtained. Racial composition of high school had some affect on social support at the university: Students from integrated and mainly Black high schools reported more social support satisfaction than students from mainly White high schools, but students from mainly Black high schools reported higher level of Mistrust of social support. Adaptation to college was not affected by racial composition of high school. Multiple regression analyses predicting adaptation to college, GPA, and attendance one year later revealed that adaptation to college was predicted by satisfaction with social support, a less negative network orientation, and less stress prior to entering the university. GPA was predicted by less stress and living at home. Attendance at the university one year later (retention) was predicted by GPA, adaptation to college, smaller network size, higher family income, and living on campus. Sex of participants influenced only the reporting of stress; females reported more stressful experiences prior to their first semester. The implications of these results on adaptation to college, academic success, and retention of African-American university students are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the existence of implicit attitudes of Whites toward Blacks, investigated the relationship between explicit measures of racial prejudice and implicit measures of racial attitudes, and explored the relationship of explicit and implicit attitudes to race-related responses and behavior. Exp 1, which used a priming technique, demonstrated implicit negative racial attitudes (i.e., evaluative associations) among 24 White undergraduates that were largely disassociated from explicit, self-reported racial prejudice. Exp 2 replicated the priming results of Exp 1 using 33 White undergraduates and demonstrated that explicit measures predicted deliberative race-related responses (juridic decisions), whereas implicit measures predicted spontaneous responses (racially primed word completions). Exp 3 extended these findings to interracial interactions using 33 White undergraduates. Self-reported (explicit) racial attitudes primarily predicted the relative evaluations of Black and White interaction partners, whereas the response latency measure of implicit attitude primarily predicted differences in nonverbal behaviors (blinking and visual contact). column19: This study of interracial dating rates among Asian Americans sought to examine their rates and patterns of interracial dating and to explain reasons for forming interracial unions. Based on a sample of 559 Asian and White students, the data suggest that studying dating patterns is an important step towards understanding and predicting intermarriage. Many similarities were found between marriage and dating patterns. However, in contrast to the outmarriage literature, no sex differences were found in outdating rates and acculturation did not predict interracial dating. Propinquity was found to be the strongest predictor of interracial dating, while ethnic and sex differences in attractiveness were also important predictors. column19: Compared family relations in inter-racial adoptive and non-adoptive families with a late adolescent and examined the extent to which family relations constitute a protective factor in preventing adolescents' psychosocial risk. The sample consisted of 103 inter-racial adoptive families and 150 non-adoptive families with a child aged between 16 and 19 yrs. Ss completed a self-report questionnaire, which was administered in 3 separate versions for the adolescent, mother, and father. Results suggest the existence of a different relational configuration in inter-racial adoptive and non-adoptive families. They also show that the father-child relationship and the mother-child relationship play different roles in preventing the adolescent's maladjustment in inter-racial adoptive and non-adoptive families. column5: Shades of meaning: Skin tone, racial attitudes, and constructive memory in African American children.
column9:
Averhart, Cara J

Bigler, Rebecca S
column12: Averhart, Cara J.: U Texas, Dept of Psychology, Austin, TX, US
column13: Journal of Experimental Child Psychology. Vol.67(3), Dec 1997, pp. 363-388.
column19: Examined the effects of negative majority-culture stereotypes of race on 56 African American children's (aged 5-7 yrs) intra-racial attitudes. Ss were asked to recall information embedded in stories that were either consistent or inconsistent with cultural stereotypes of lighter- versus darker-complexioned African Americans. Children were given measures of interracial attitudes, self-perceived skin tone, skin tone selection, and classification skill. Results show that children show better memory for stereotypic than counterstereotypic information about skin tone. Individual differences in the extent to which this memory bias was evident varied in relation to children's (1) endorsement of negative majority culture views of African Americans and (2) self-ratings of skin color. Implications for understanding racial attitude and identity development, and implications for the design of multicultural programs for African American, as well as Euro-American, children are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the preface) Our Families, Our Values comprises the viewpoints of 12 women and 8 men representing the spectrum of sexual orientations, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, transsexual, and heterosexual. The essays in this anthology present the authors' imperative to self-advocate by means of the following challenges: The first section of essays challenges the widely accepted and seldom contested assumption that only heterosexual people are entitled to get married, have or enjoy sex, or rear children. The second section challenges popular interpretations of various scriptures used to perpetuate and justify anti-Lavender injustice and bigotry under the auspices of organized religion. The third section challenges the Lavender community, itself, to think clearly and carefully about the course they wish to pursue. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Compared levels of psychological distress in a pre-migratory sample of Vietnamese Amerasians with those in a like-aged, non-migratory sample of Vietnamese (all Ss aged 17-30 yrs) living in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Ss were assessed using 2 measures developed and validated for Vietnamese clinical populations in the US: the Hopkins Symptom Checklist-25 and the Vietnamese Depression Scale. Amerasians had significantly higher symptom levels on the depression scale of the Hopkins Symptom Checklist-25, but not on the other measures utilized.It is suggested that Amerasians' higher levels of depressive symptoms are probably a result of their traumatic lives in Vietnam, but may also reflect acute situational factors or selection bias. column5: Effect of transracial/transethnic adoption on children's racial and ethnic identity and self-esteem: A meta-analytic review.
column12: Hollingsworth, Leslie Doty: U Michigan, School of Social Work, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Marriage & Family Review. Vol.25(1-2), 1997, pp. 99-130.
column19: This paper reports the results of a meta-analytic review of comparative studies of racial identity and self-esteem in transracially/transethnically-adopted, inracially-adopted/same ethnic group, and biologic African-American and Mexican-American children. Six studies, including 1 longitudinal study with 4 phases, met the established criteria. Study level effect sizes were calculated. Twenty-nine dependent measure effect sizes were also calculated. There was an overall effect, in the negative direction, of transracial adoption on a combined variable of racial/ethnic identity and self-esteem. The effect size increased when racial identity was considered separately. Effect size associated with self-esteem was not statistically significant, although a positive direction was noted. Tests failed to achieve homogeneity among included studies. Age of study participant was a moderating variable. Several other potential moderators were also identified. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) First, the author provides a brief historical overview of the policy of school desegregation to set the context for thinking about it as a current social issue. Second, she discusses some bottom-line conclusions that can be drawn from the hundreds of studies on how school desegregation, as it has been implemented in this country, has influenced student's academic and social outcomes. And third, the author makes some observations about what has been learned about the process of interracial schooling from recent research. G. Allport (1954) argued that there are 3 aspects of contact situations that are particularly important in determining whether positive intergroup relations are likely to develop. These aspects are (1) equal status within the context of the situation, (2) an emphasis on cooperative activities within that situation, and (3) the very clear support of authorities in the situation for positive, equal-status relationships. The author discusses these aspects, as well as the color-blind approach to support by authorities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: "Why are all the black kids sitting together in the cafeteria?"
column12: Tatum, Beverly Daniel: Mt Holyoke Coll, South Hadley, MA, US
column13: (1997). "Why are all the black kids sitting together in the cafeteria?" xv, 270 pp. New York, NY, US: Basic Books; US.
column19:
(from the publicity materials) The author explores the issue of racial identity development and a variety of issues at the core of racism and prejudice. Through anecdotes about her own children, excerpts from research interviews she has conducted and essays written by her students, as well as clearly synthesized summaries of the work of eminent social scientists and other scholars, the author presents compelling evidence that suggests that we must all examine our racial identities-whatever they are-if true social change is to take place.
(from the jacket) The author explains that all of us have a racial identity and must strive to affirm it. For people of color, the development of a constructive racial identity requires being able to recognize and reject the bombardment of negative stereotypes and to embrace a history of resistance and empowerment rather than passive victimization. For Whites, the challenge is to engage in a process of racial identity development which leads to an awareness of White privilege and a determination to actively work against injustice-and this requires the strength to reject a system that rewards them, and to reclaim the legacy of White allies. The author extends her ideas about racial identity development beyond the usual Black-White paradigm to embrace the unique circumstances of Latinos, American Indians, Asians, as well as biracial youth. Also included is a list of resources for further reading as well as a list of books for parents and teachers to recommend to children of all ages. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the cover) This book focuses on the give and take of affection and respect in personal relationships as influenced by specific cultural values. Using a wide variety of research from psychology, psychiatry, sociology, and other disciplines, the authors take both a retrospective and a prospective look at ethnicity and the reciprocity of affectionate and respectful behavior, and point the way for new research on African American, Latina/o, and Asian American relationships, as well as relationships among persons from different ethnic groups. Throughout, the reader is challenged to take stock of common misperceptions currently blocking the way to a greater understanding of relational dynamics as a function of ethnicity. column5: Applying racial identity theory to the legal system: The case of family law.
column12: Carter, Robert T.: Columbia U, Teachers Coll, New York, NY, US
column13: Thompson, Chalmer E [Ed]; Carter, Robert T [Ed]. (1997). Racial identity theory: Applications to individual, group, and organizational interventions.  (pp. 219-235). xxii, 280 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column19: (from the chapter) Examines the way socioracial factors affect legal decision making in the context of family law. In particular, the authors examine the allegedly race-neutral ideology used by lawyers, judges, and forensic mental health professionals in custody decisions involving interracial families, summarize the outcomes resulting from application of that ideology, and then analyze those results in terms of J. Helms' (1995) racial identity theory. They argue that there would be a value in applying racial identity notions in family law issues and that to do so would require as well that such ideas be introduced in legal training. The authors think a psychologically based race consideration (i. e., racial identity) has merit and should replace the hidden and unstated use of race as a factor. The chapter utilizes the Supreme Court's decision in Palmore v. Sidoti in 1984 to illustrate these ideas. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) The author examines how psychosocial, economic, political, and cultural factors have influenced the growth of the Filipino mail-order-bride phenomenon in the US. The author analyzes the interplay of these factors with the historical issues of power, gender, class, and race-ubiquitous issues that amplify the injustice and stigma heaped on these women in both nations. In this context, the author will describe the transformation of the mail-order bride into an immigrant Filipino woman and how these factors affect her capability and that of her American husband to integrate into the larger Filipino American society and American society. This chapter focuses on a mail-order-bride community in Long Island, New York City, and New York State that consists of some 40 interracial families. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

The authors examine the evolutionary, perceptual-cognitive, and sociohistorical influences that combine to make the perspective of outside observers of interracial relationships different from that of the relationship members themselves. They argue that tension between these 2 perspectives takes characteristically different forms in different types of interracial relationships.
(from the chapter) The chapter examines 6 types of interracial relationships (i.e., male-male friendships and romantic relationships, female-female friendships and romantic relationships, male-female friendships and romantic relationships). column5: Rationalizing race in thinking about the future: The case of low-income Black men.
column12: Young, Alford A.: U Michigan, Dept of Sociology, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Smith College Studies in Social Work. Vol.67(3), Jun 1997, pp. 432-455.
column19: Reports on the views held by 4 low-income African American men (aged 20-25 yrs) concerning how mobility operates in American society, their sense of their personal life-chance prospects, and how they believe that being African American relates to each matter. The central finding was that the extent of social isolation experienced in life (e.g., lack of direct interracial exposure, lack of intimate exposure to institutions of social power and authority) shaped the capacity to articulate an importance for race in these issues. Thus, while each of the men maintained some of the attributes associated with "the crisis of the Black male" (e.g., lack of consistent employment, involvement in illicit activity, incarceration), their capacity to form contrasting conceptions of the importance of race indicated a crucial dimension of variability in what might initially appear to be a cluster of similar individuals. It is argued that an acknowledgment of the bases for such variability is critical for any attempt at remedial intervention in their lives. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Wickes, Kevin L.: Taylor U, Psychology Dept, Upland, IN, US

column19: Examined psychological issues of self-concept and acculturation for a sample of 174 Korean adoptees (aged 17-39 yrs) who completed the following instruments: Self-Description Questionnaire-III ([SDQ]; H. W. Marsh, 1987), an Asian self-identity acculturation scale, and an Asian American cultural identity scale. Significant differences were found between the authors' sample and the normative sample on the SDQ-III, with the authors' sample scoring higher in Religion, Honesty, Relations with Opposite Sex, Physical Appearance, and General self-concept and lower in Math, Emotional Stability, and Relations with Parents. The later the age at which Korean adoptees were placed, the higher their Math and Honesty self-concept subscores were. The Verbal self-concept score, however, was negatively related with age of placement of Korean adoptees. The findings suggest certain aspects of self-concept were influenced by early or later placement of Korean adoptees. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the initial development of biracial relationships by those who seek out such relationships to see whether these relationships tend to form according to the principles of hypogamy. Personal advertisements were used in an attempt to examine such relationships at their initial contact. 195 female-seeking-male advertisements and 234 male-seeking-female advertisements were used (133 Whites and 296 Blacks). No unexpected relationships were revealed. Males were significantly positively correlated to Whites. There was almost an equal number of Black males and Black females, but significantly more White males than White females. This difference may represent a greater willingness of White males to date biracially. Alternately, it is also possible that there is a cultural difference between Whites and Blacks so that White females are less likely to advertise than Black females. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Culture and conflict: The portrayal of Blacks in U.S. children's picture books through the mid- and late-twentieth century.
column9:
Pescosolido, Bernice A

Grauerholz, Elizabeth

Milkie, Melissa A
column12: Pescosolido, Bernice A.: Indiana U, Dept of Sociology, Bloomington, IN, US
column13: American Sociological Review. Vol.62(3), Jun 1997, pp. 443-464.
column19: Documents the portrayal of Blacks in 3 sets of children's picture books and examines how these portrayals are related to culture, gatekeeping, and conflict in U.S. society. Using quantitative and qualitative methods, the extent and character of the portrayal of Blacks and Black-White interaction between 1937 and 1993 is described. Results indicate the portrayal of Black characters over time is nonlinear and can be divided into reasonably distinct phases: declining representation from the late 1930s through the late 1950s, nearly zero representation from that point through 1964, a dramatic increase from the late 1960s to the early 1970s, and a leveling off after 1975. The depiction of intimate, egalitarian, interracial interaction and the portrayal of Black adults as focal characters are rare. Findings also suggest that gains in multicultural portrayals have not been maintained consistently across the different sets of children's books, with prize-winning books more likely to depict Blacks. These trends are linked to gatekeeping activities and to strains in Black-White relations in the larger society. When African American challenges to the dominant societal norms are strongest, Blacks virtually disappear from U.S. children's picture books. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Poverty, segregation, and race riots: 1960 to 1993.
column9:

column13: American Sociological Review. Vol.61(4), Aug 1996, pp. 590-613.
column19: Examined the effect of residential segregation on racial unrest using event-histories of 154 race riots in 1960-1993. It was found that a combination of high levels of racial segregation followed by interracial contact generates racial competition, which increases the rate of ethnic and racial unrest. In cities where residential contact between African Americans and Whites increases, the rate of race riots increases significantly. A prior history of racial turmoil increases the likelihood of another race riot; the results suggest that the rate of race riots in a metropolitan area depends nonmonotonically on the number of previous riots in that region. These effects remain potent in models controlling for population size, income disparity, ethnic diversity, Black poverty rate, unemployment, and minority composition. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race and sex in Black and White: Essence and ideology in the Spike Lee discourse.
column12: McPhail, Mark Lawrence: U Utah, Dept of Communication, Salt Lake City, UT, US

column19: Contemporary popular and academic commentators have criticized mainstream media for its negative depictions of African Americans and women, and have begun to consider the same phenomenon in the works of communicators of color. This article analyzes the critical consideration of race and gender in the films of Spike Lee that feature depictions of women and interracial relationships. It argues that Lee's films subscribe to essentialist conceptions of race and gender that reify the same ideological and epistemological assumptions and practices that undermine both the representation of race and gender in mainstream media, and the emancipatory potential of Afrocentric and oppositional discourses. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Employing a semiotic framework, this article explores the signification process of the lead character in Alex Haley's Queen. This popular TV miniseries is significant because a bi-ethnic person is the focal point of its storyline. However, instead of transcending the traditional stereotypes associated with bi-ethnicity, the program does little more than portray Queen as a "tragic mulatto." Specifically, three signifiers are discussed: bi-ethnicity as (a) beautiful, yet threatening, (b) inherently problematic, and (c) leading to insanity. column19: (This reprinted article originally appeared in Journal of Child Psychology & Psychiatry & Allied Disciplines, 1995, Vol 36[8], 1399-1410. The following abstract of the original article appeared in record 83-22372.). Theories about "Black identity" are discussed in relation to a study of 58 adolescents (aged 14-18 yrs) with 1 White and 1 African or African-Caribbean parent. Interview findings on their racial self-definition, attitudes to their mixed parentage, and allegiance to Black and White people and cultures reveal a wide range of racial identities and cultural allegiances. Differences are related to type of school, social class, and the degree of politicization of the young person's attitudes to race. The findings are discussed in relation to the issue of interracial adoption and fostering, and to recent debates about the concept of an "essential" Black identity. column5: Family racial socialization and ecological competence: Longitudinal assessments of African-American transracial adoptees.
column9:
DeBerry, Kimberly M

Scarr, Sandra

Weinberg, Richard
column12: DeBerry, Kimberly M.: Temple U, Dept of Psychology, Philadelphia, PA, US
column13: Child Development. Vol.67(5), Oct 1996, pp. 2375-2399.
column19: Ecological competence was assessed longitudinally in 88 African-American transracial adoptees (TRAs). Relations were examined among measures of family racial socialization (FRS), Africentric, and Eurocentric reference group orientations, transracial adoption stressors, and the effects on psychological adjustment. Longitudinal path analyses assessed the relations among these constructs. Path analytic models indicated that in childhood (Time 1) FRS predicted neither Africentric reference group orientation (ARGO) nor Eurocentric reference group orientation (ERGO); by adolescence (Time 2), FRS predicted ARGO but not ERGO. Both ARGO and ERGO contributed significantly to adjustment. Change models indicated that adjustment declined significantly over the 10 yrs. There were multiple determinants of this decline. TRAs experienced difficulty becoming ecologically competent in both ARGO and ERGO. They displayed greater ERGO than ARGO. Discriminant function analyses based on the independent variables yielded hit rates of 71% at Time 1 and over 84% at Time 2 for classifying the TRAs as adjusted or maladjusted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Understanding diverse families: What practitioners need to know.
column12: Okun, Barbara F.: Northeastern U, Dept of Counseling Psychology, Rehabilitation & Special Education, Boston, MA, US
column13: (1996). Understanding diverse families: What practitioners need to know. xv, 376 pp. New York, NY, US: Guilford Press; US.
column19: (from the jacket) Today's mental health clinicians face a rapidly changing clientele. Divorce, remarriage, multiracial marriages, different types of adoption, openly gay and lesbian relationships-all have significantly altered the nature and composition of families. At the same time, clinicians within managed care organizations have less contol over the types of cases that make up their practice. This . . . volume is designed to help practitioners work effectively with diversity in this challenging new environment. It confronts myths and stereotypes about what is considered "normal" and what constitutes a "family," . . . examines a range of healthy families with creative family structures, and expands our notions about how families work. Synthesizing the current literature with information obtained through 1st-person interviews, the book begins with an overview of contemporary family forms. Chapters then provide an in-depth examination of 3 types of families: adoptive, gay and lesbian, and multiracial. Each is considered first in sociocultural context, then from a developmental perspective, and finally with an eye to treatment implications. This volume is intended for practitioners, both novice and experienced. Also, for graduate students and trainees . . . , this book serves as [a] text for courses in counseling and clinical psychology, social work, psychiatric nursing, family therapy, and psychiatry. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Mediated messages and African-American culture: Contemporary issues.
column9:
Berry, Venise T [Ed]

Manning-Miller, Carmen L [Ed]
column12: Berry, Venise T.: U Iowa, School of Journalism & Mass Communication, Iowa City, IA, US
column13: (1996). Mediated messages and African-American culture: Contemporary issues. xviii, 300 pp. Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; US.
column19: (from the cover) Images of African-Americans in our culture abound-on TV, in films, on the radio, and in newsprint. Whether in works by African-Americans, most notably popular music, film, and to a growing degree, TV programs, or works about African-Americans from documentaries to news coverage-strong images pervade our public consciousness. "Mediated Messages and African-American Culture" is the 1st book to examine these images and messages as a whole. Bringing together works by leading scholars, this collection examines such vital topics as the relationship between Black men and the police, the state of the African-American press, and the perpetuation of images of African-Americans as poor, violent, and undereducated. Timely case studies and the combination of theory and practice make this text both up-to-date and thorough in its analysis of the image and portrayal of African-Americans in the media. [This book] will be of great interest to students who study popular culture, Black popular culture, African-American history, and the media. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The interracial friendships of White and Asian college students.
column12: Tuan-Maclean, Katherine T. Y.: Northwestern U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.57(6-A), Dec 1996, pp. 2686.
column19: The study examines the prevalence, context, and nature of interracial friendships among White and Asian college students. It comprises two parts: a written questionnaire which sampled 122 students, and interviews of six focus groups and nine individuals. This study finds that despite a diverse campus context which emphasizes multiculturalism, interracial friendships are low, but increase the less intimate the relationship. So while students have few interracial close friendships, the majority have weekly interracial contact. Culture emerges as a key shaper for both the meanings and content of friendships. A major developmental factor drawing students to same race friendships is the process of identity formation. Ethnic identity issues are particularly salient for Asian students. Students therefore self-segregate within comfort zones and ethnic spaces as they are attracted to those similar and repulsed from those different. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Friendship patterns and peer relations of biracial girls.
column12: Fields, Rachel Hannah: California School of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/alameda, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(6-B), Dec 1996, pp. 4054.
column19: The prevalence of biracial children has dramatically increased in recent years, yet little is known about their normal development. Developing an understanding of the perception of friendships and peer relationships held by biracial children is particularly important given that social relationships may be more complicated for them than for monoracial children. Participants in this study were girls between the ages of 8 and 11. This study compared the friendship and peer relationship perceptions of monoracial (African American) and biracial African American-Caucasian girls. Participants (N = 25) were interviewed using the Cornell Interview of Peer and Friends (CIPF). Their mothers filled out a short racial identity/demographics questionnaire. It was hypothesized that biracial girls face a more complex developmental process than monoracial girls, and thus more difficulties in the areas of friendship and peer relationships. The quantitative analysis found no differences between monoracial and biracial girls on CIPF overall scores. Biracial girls received higher scores on the subscale Developmental Appropriateness, indicating more maturity in this area. In addition, biracial girls reported a more stable experience of themselves with all friends and more general satisfaction with their friendships than did monoracial girls. Other differences were found between participants classified as higher income versus those classified as lower income. Higher income participants received healthier overall scores on the CIPF. They also indicated that it was easier to get children to play with them and they had less negative interactions with their peers. A qualitative analysis revealed a thoughtful and insightful understanding of friendship for both monoracial and biracial girls. Participant mothers also gave cogent accounts of addressing race related issues with their daughters. Results indicated a similar developmental pattern for monoracial and biracial girls and suggested that bi (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial identity development and its relationship to physical appearance and self-esteem in adults with one black and one white biological parent.
column12: Buxenbaum, Kim Una: Rutgers the State U New Jersey, G.s.a.p.p., US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(5-B), Nov 1996, pp. 3430.
column19: An empirical study was carried out to investigate the process of racial identity development in biologically biracial adults with one black and one white parent. The relationship of physical appearance and self-esteem was also investigated. Scales used included: The Buxenbaum Biracial Identity Interview, the Buxenbaum Biracial Identity Questionnaire, the Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventory (Coopersmith, 1975), and a Physical Appearance Scale, modified from the Spivey Physical Descriptions & "First Impression" Categorical Descriptions (Spivey, 1984). Data from 26 biracial adults ranging in age from 18-55 were collected and analyzed using both quantitative and qualitative methods. Qualitative analysis employed grounded theory procedures (Strauss & Corbin, 1990) and quantitative analysis used repeated measures ANOVA, product moment correlations, point biserial correlations, and interrater reliability. Results suggested that biracial identity is a developmental process which is fluid in character across time and situations. Also observed, were the existence of different public and private racial identities for 36% of subjects, black public and private racial identities for 36% of subjects, and biracial public and private racial identities for 28% of the subjects. Several conclusions can be made from these findings. The most important seems to be that recognition of racial identity appears to be a multilevel process. Another conclusion is that there remains a large area of study in regard to the process of racial identity development in general, and that of biracial and multiracial individuals in particular. Limitations of the study, implications for practice and recommendations for future research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Relations of cultural knowledge, racial climate perceptions, and exposure to Anglo-Americans on African-American students' performance to academic competence indicators at a predominantly Anglo-American university.
column12: Holliday, Michelle Yvette: U Maryland Coll Park, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.57(3-A), Sep 1996, pp. 1015.
column19: The purpose of this study was to investigate the relationship between culture-specific and contextual variables and performance on indicators of academic competence. In the present study, levels of culturally-congruent and culturally-incongruent Anglo American and African American knowledge, prior and present exposure to Anglo American culture, and perceptions of campus interracial climate (interdependence, supportive norms, and equal status dimensions) were the culture-specific and contextual variables. Academic competence variables were SAT scores obtained (OSAT) during the administration of this study, self-reported verbal and total Scholastic Assessment Test (SSAT) scores, and college grade point averages (GPA). The hypotheses of this study were that for African American undergraduate participants attending a predominantly Anglo American university: (a) eight cultural knowledge subscales would predict the academic competence indicators; (b) prior and present exposure to Anglo Americans would predict academic competence indicators when cultural knowledge variables were controlled; (c) prior and present Anglo American cultural exposure would predict campus interracial climate when cultural knowledge variables were controlled, and (d) campus interracial climate would predict academic competence indicators when culture-specific variables (i.e., cultural knowledge and Anglo cultural exposure) were controlled. The sample consisted of 165 African American undergraduates who completed an abbreviated verbal SAT and a questionnaire packet including measures of the previously described constructs during the course of the study. As hypothesized, the findings revealed that (a) cultural knowledge significantly predicted obtained SAT and self-reported verbal SAT scores; (b) exposure to Anglo American culture significantly predicted OSATs and total SSATs; and (c) exposure to Anglo culture significantly predicted campus interracial climate when cultural knowledge was controlled. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The experience of Thai women in Thai-Canadian marriages.
column12: Stiramon, Orapin: U Alberta, Canada
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.57(3-A), Sep 1996, pp. 1333.
column19: This study explores the experience of Thai women engaged in Thai-Canadian cross-national marriages. The investigation is exploratory and descriptive in nature. Nine women participated in the study. The researcher used individual interviews to collect data, and looked for themes and issues common to the women studied. The interviews were conducted entirely in the Thai language in order to allow the participants to share their experiences freely. Three developmental stages of the women's experience arose from the data. These were (1) contemplating marriage, (2) adjusting to marriage, and (3) reflecting on one's marriage and needs. Within each of the three stages a major theme emerged: finding a good husband, carrying on the marriage, and considering options. Several topics related to these themes were also identified in the study. The data are discussed in relation to developmental, symbolic interaction, and social exchange theories. Implications for counselling and suggestions for further research conclude the dissertation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Adjustment characteristics and ego formation of transracial Korean adoptees: A phenomenological study.
column12: Reader, Katherine Ann Genna: The Union Inst, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(3-B), Sep 1996, pp. 2181.
column19: Seven Korean born transracial adoptees and their five parental couples are interviewed to explore the essence of each individual's experience of Korean transracial adoption. Each co-researcher has the experience of Korean transracial adoption either as the parent or adoptee. The co-researchers include five females and two male Korean adoptees, age five years to eleven years and their adoptive parents. Different occupations and socio-economic backgrounds are represented. This phenomenological research method delineates ego formation, presenting transracial adjustment and behavioral issues as described and expressed by the co-researchers of this study. In this research, the essence of the phenomena being studied are the core meanings which underlie interpretations of the experiences of the co-researchers. These are the significant elements of the experience of Korean transracial adoptees. Although each interpretation is unique, generalization becomes possible because within every experience there exists a universal truth. Explored are the factors that influence ego development, identity and adoption adjustment, as well as emotional and behavioral patterns. Besides semi-structured interviews, all of the co-researchers completed an in depth survey addressing internal and external modes of behavior reflective of self-esteem, self worth, identity and behavioral issues. Projective testing was also administered to the seven to ascertain personality and behavioral characteristics. All the interviews were recorded, transcribed, and synthesized into textural essays. In order to identify the essential emergent themes of ego development, identity formation and adoption adjustment during transracial adoptions, content analysis is utilized. Themes relating to the phenomena of transracial adoption include the following for the children: meaning of adoption, being adopted and being Korean, prejudices, family, being different/special, self, character traits, coping style, biological (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Person deixis and participation structure in conjoint therapeutic discourse.
column12: Anderson, Laurie Jane: Columbia U Teachers Coll, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.57(2-A), Aug 1996, pp. 0658.
column19: This study focuses on the role of person deixis in the negotiation of participation in six one-hour therapy sessions involving an interracial couple. The viability of competing models of conversational participation, the role of local factors in the assignment of reception roles and the relation between such factors and more stable aspects of participant identity (micro-macro link) are considered. Following a review of theoretical and empirical work on participation structure and person deixis in multiparty contexts and a discussion of the qualitative-quantitative-qualitative analytic approach adopted, the relative merits of product- and process-oriented approaches are explored. While a textual analysis in terms of configurations (operationally defined as stretches of talk during which mutual alignment in interlocutory roles is maintained) was found to provide insights into interactional asymmetries linked to the social roles of therapist-client(s) and husband-wife, it is argued that a dynamic analysis is necessary to illuminate how such asymmetries are interactively constituted. On the basis of an examination of turn formatting and dysfluencies, arguments are advanced in favor of a conversation analytic approach focusing on the impact of local linguistic factors on reception-role assignment. Levinson's (1988) revised version of Goffman's (1988) participation framework model was utilized to investigate the sequential effects of pronominal and nominal address and mention. Second-person address was found to be a more effective technique for next-speaker selection than exclusion through third-person mention; names were more effective than pronouns. Functions of indirect targetting and other-quotation are also discussed. Differences in participation were found to be partially attributable to differences in the frequency and range of use of person deictics. The therapist's ability to manage participation was found to relate to specialized uses of vocatives, dual you a (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
