column5: The experience of families who parent an adopted Romanian child.
column12: Rochford, Christine Patricia: Gonzaga U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.57(2-A), Aug 1996, pp. 0591.
column19: The purpose of this study was to gain an understanding of the experience of parents who have adopted Romanian children. Parenting was conceptualized as a process that includes nourishing, protecting, and guiding the child through the course of development. The methodology was based on the process of heuristic inquiry as described by Moustakas (1990). Heuristics refers to a process of internal search through which one discovers the nature and meaning of experience and develops methods and procedures for further investigation and analysis. The participants were ten married couples who were adoptive parents of Romanian children. They were recruited through contacting support group members and through my personal network. Individual depictions were derived from personal interviews, journal notes, and personal documents, and were then validated by the participants. Data analysis revealed a number of core themes which dictated the quality of the parenting experience. Bonding was an area of concern, with mothers generally reporting bonding more readily than fathers, and those who made the trip to Romania reporting restraining any feelings of attachment until the legal process was completed. All parents, both first-time parents and experienced parents, felt unprepared for the more involved parenting required. Finally, parents of children who exhibited difficult behaviours attributed negative behaviours to the child's genetic background. Parents of children who did not exhibit difficult behaviours attributed positive behaviours to either a mix of heredity and the adoptive environment or due largely to the adoptive environment. Data synthesis showed that at the core of the experience, parenting an adopted Romanian child is not unlike parenting any child, except that it is perhaps more involved parenting. This study provided new meanings of the parenting experience for the participants, for the researcher, for other adoptive parents, and for professionals working in the field (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The relationship between white racial identity development and level of conservatism to perceived emotional intensity and cognitive appraisal of a hypothetical interracial conflict encounter.
column12: Jessum, Rhonda Lee: California School of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(2-B), Aug 1996, pp. 1443.
column19: Richard Lazarus' cognitive-motivational-relational theory of emotion provides a theoretical framework for understanding the influence of various individual variables on the cognitive appraisal of and emotional response to a specific situation: a hypothetical interracial conflict encounter. The individual variables that this author expected to influence the way an individual appraises and emotionally reacts to an interracial conflict encounter were: (a) level of White racial identity development; (b) level of conservatism; and (c) goal relevance. More specifically, the study was designed to explore the variability in White individual's appraisal of threat, blame and their perceived emotional intensity in response to a hypothetical interracial conflict encounter. It is hoped that the results of this study will be useful in increasing the effectiveness of cultural sensitivity courses, thereby contributing to decreased prejudice and greater racial awareness among Whites in the United States. A total of 90 Caucasian respondents participated in this study by filling out a questionnaire package and responding to an interracial conflict encounter vignette. A Step-Wise Hierarchical Multiple Regression analyses was conducted to test the hypotheses. The results of this study gave support to the hypothesis that after controlling for background variables, the total effect of White racial identity development, level of conservatism and goal relevance accounted for a significant amount of the explained variance in the cognitive appraisal of threat in response to an interracial conflict encounter. Although not significant in the initial analyses, exploratory results of this study gave support to the hypothesis that the individual predictor variables also explained variance in the cognitive appraisal of blame in response to an interracial conflict encounter. The results of this study did not give support to the hypothesis that the total effect of White racial identity development, (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Morgan, Nanette Janeane: Pepperdine U, US

column19: This study looks at Adjustment, Racial Identity/Identification and Self-Esteem of Interracially Adopted African/American adults. The subjects included: African/American adults (N = 16) adopted by White families, before 5 years of age. The subjects filled out mailed questionnaires, including: a personal information sheet, the Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventory for adults, and Bell's Adjustment Inventory for adults. Due to the small N size, the results were descriptive in nature. Overall, the subjects demonstrated average to excellent home, health, social, emotional and occupational adjustment. They also demonstrated average to high self-esteem. Although the subjects are knowledgeable about Black history, music, slang, etc. and seek to gain more knowledge about "being Black," they do not feel much like members of the Black community. The outcomes of interracial adoptions for these subjects appears beneficial in economic and educational opportunities, but appears to be lacking in acquiring racial identity/identification. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Psychosocial and academic functioning of African-American college students: Social support, racial climate and racial identity.
column12: Goins, Cynthia Leigh: U Washington, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(12-B), Jun 1996, pp. 7045.
column19: This study investigated the influence of social support, racial identity and racial climate on the psychosocial functioning, intention to graduate and GPA of African-American college students. One hundred twenty four university and 102 community college students participated. MANCOVA analyses indicated that community college students reported less alienation and a more positive school racial climate than university students while university students had higher support satisfaction. When these samples were combined, regression analyses suggested that higher support from peers, family and school as well as satisfaction with support predicted lower alienation. Peer, family and support satisfaction were also related to higher self esteem and psychological well-being. In terms of racial identity, pre-encounter attitudes predicted higher alienation, psychological distress, and lower self esteem. Internalization attitudes predicted positive functioning in these areas. A positive interracial climate, particularly equal status among Black and White students, predicted lower alienation. Contrary to expectations, neither peer or school support nor interracial climate uniquely predicted intention to graduate or GPA. However, higher school support was associated with higher GPA in males and lower GPA in females. Results are discussed in terms of previous findings. Suggestions for interventions are offered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Dillon, Randy Keith: U Florida, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.56(11-A), May 1996, pp. 4202.
column19: This study investigated how clients' predispositions toward counseling interact with counselors' communication styles in initial interracial interactions on evaluations of counseling effectiveness, client satisfaction, communication satisfaction, and likelihood of return to counseling. Specifically, this study tests social exchange theory by proposing two models, (1) uncertainty reduction and (2) power that explain how clients may assess rewards and costs from communication with counselors. Subjects first completed the Predisposition Toward Counseling Scale. Scenario/scripts consisting of one of four possible conditions: (1) same culture for counselor client/direct counselor communication style, or (2) same culture/indirect communication style, or (3) different culture/direct communication style, or (4) different culture/indirect communication style were used as treatment stimuli. Each subject, assuming the role of the client, was randomly assigned to read one scenario/script. Subjects then evaluated the counseling interaction by responding to the Counselor Evaluation Inventory and the Interpersonal Communication Satisfaction Inventory. Each subject also indicated the likelihood he/she would return to a second counseling interaction with the counselor. Results revealed no significant interactions between clients' predispositions toward counseling, cultural composition of the counselor-client dyad, and counselor communication style. Predicted correlations among counseling effectiveness, client satisfaction, communication satisfaction, and likelihood of return to counseling were statistically supported and in a positive direction. Two hypotheses for the uncertainty reduction model were supported. No hypotheses for the power model were supported. The most significant conclusions drawn from this study were that culture did not play a salient role, and that clients' rewards/costs assessments of counselors' communication styles in initial interactions were partially (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: In their own words: Mixed-heritage children in the United States.
column12: Ross, Debra: U Massachusetts, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.56(11-A), May 1996, pp. 4329.
column19: The United States is becoming an increasingly multiracial, multicultural and multilingual society. As social interactions among members of various ethnic groups have increased, so too have the number of mixed-heritage couples. Consequently, there are now many more children of mixed heritage in our country than ever before, and their number is likely to increase. These children have traditionally been viewed by the larger society, and presented in the social science literature, as disturbed, maladjusted or inherently pathological. The purpose of this study was to explore from a phenomenological perspective mixed-heritage children's perceptions about themselves and their heritage. This study attempted to provide a better understanding of mixed-heritage children, by asking them directly about their perceptions and experiences. Using a case study qualitative method, data was gathered through in-depth interviews with twelve children of mixed heritage. A triangulation strategy was used for the data analysis in the search for patterns, categories and themes among participants' responses. There were three major findings of this study. It was found that participants have positive perceptions of themselves and their mixed-heritage. It was found that participants feel that they are sometimes perceived by others in negative and stereotypical ways. It was also found that participants value the role of their family in coping with the larger society. In addition, it was found that participants have experienced racism to different degrees and that some of them have experienced extended family tension because of their parents' mixed-heritage marriage. Participants attributed several advantages to their mixed heritage, including: (1) an ability to see things from different perspectives, (2) being open-minded to different people and situations, and (3) being able to bridge cultures. Some of the participants identified religion and language as key values of their families. Recommend (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: The influence of social desirability and interracial contact on the White Racial Identity Attitude Scale (WRIAS)(Helms & Carter, 1990) was examined. The findings indicated that social desirability is not a serious confound for the WRIAS and interracial contact is an important element in the formation of racial attitudes. Through the use of correlations, regression analyses, and a factor analysis, the nature of the individual stages in Helms' (1990) theory of White racial identity development were examined regarding both social desirability and interracial contact. Adjustments to Helms' theory are proposed and a model that integrates interracial contact and Helms' theory is presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial identity development and self concept in adopted Korean women.
column12: Des Jardins, Kunya S.: Boston U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(9-B), Mar 1996, pp. 5166.
column19: The controversial relationship between racial identity and self concept is one of the most widely researched constructs in the study of racial minorities. This study examines racial identification and its relationship to self concept among transculturally adopted Korean women. Participants for this study (N = 62) were Korean-born women between the ages of 16-43 who were adopted as children by Caucasian families in the United States. It was hypothesized that racial identity and self concept would be significantly positively related for this sample. Two measures of racial identity were included in this study: the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (Phinney, 1992), a continuous scale of mono-cultural ethnic orientation, and the Racial Identity Attitudes Scale (Helms & Parham, 1985), a categorical measure of stages of racial identity that taps both majority and minority mono-cultural orientation, as well as biculturalism. The Tennessee Self Concept Scale (Fitts, 1964) was used to measure personal identity or self concept. The results, using Pearson product-moment correlations, multiple regressions, and discriminant function analyses, indicate that there is a significant correlation between self concept and racial identity, but only when measured by an instrument (the Racial Identity Attitudes Scale) that taps bi-cultural orientation. Bi-cultural orientation was related to higher self concept than either minority or majority focused mono-cultural orientation in this sample. Additionally, it was shown that, on the whole, participants in this study held bi-cultural orientations and were interested in their ethnic/racial identity. Whereas participants in this study had lower physical and behavioral self concept scores than the original normative sample, they had higher self satisfaction and personal identity scores. This finding suggests that adoptees in this sample may have felt self conscious about some aspects of their physical appearance, but tended to feel satisfied wi (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

The interviews focused on the parents' relations with their adopted children and those born to them, children's racial identity, ties to the larger family units, schools, and communities. Findings show that there was an absence of White racial preference by the White and Nonwhite adopted children. Children appeared to be indifferent to the advantages of being white but aware of and comfortable with the racial identity imposed on them by their outward appearance. A few Ss reported the problem of truancy, drugs and drinking, and parental divorce. However, there were no differences in likelihood of such occurrences between adopted and birth children. column5: African American lesbian couples: Ethnocultural considerations in psychotherapy.

column13: Women & Therapy. Vol.19(3), 1996, pp. 49-60.
column19: Argues that African Americans are a marginalized group in American society as are women and lesbians. African American lesbians are marginalized even in the broader gay and lesbian community. Their devalued position in the social hierarchy gives rise to a condition referred to as the "triple jeopardy." They are objects of racial, gender, and heterosexist institutional oppression. As a result of these circumstances, African American lesbians face a range of challenges to their optimal psychological development as do their relationships. The ethnocultural background of African American lesbians and strategies for culturally sensitive therapeutic interventions are explored. Specific considerations are given to African American lesbians in interracial relationships and those in relationships with ethnic peers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

There are distinct challenges which confront the interracial lesbian couple such as homophobia, racism, and limited social support from family and friends as illustrated through the narratives of 2 composite couples. A race, class, and culture sensitive psychotherapy is recommended. This enables clinicians to articulate perspectives which reframe and "unpersonalize" power struggles and disclose cultural differences in values and meanings as well as affirm those special joys and rewards when attraction and intimacy are joined to cultural difference. column19: Using K. column5: The effect of childhood interracial contact on adult antiblack prejudice.
column12: Wood, Peter B.: U Oklahoma, Dept of Sociology, Norman, OK, US
column13: International Journal of Intercultural Relations. Vol.20(1), Win 1996, pp. 1-17.
column19: Examined the impact of interracial contact through government desegregation policies during childhood on adult stereotype adherence and traditional antiblack prejudice. It was believed that equal-status contact in a sanction-free environment, particularly during the formative years, would engender more positive racial attitudes among young persons that would endure into adulthood. Ss were 292 White adults participating in the 1991 Oklahoma City Survey. Findings showed that childhood interracial contact in schools and neighborhoods not only disconfirmed negative racial stereotypes, but had a direct, significant effect on levels of adult antiblack prejudice even controlling for other relevant factors. Results suggest continued support for the desegregation of American schools and neighborhoods as a means of promoting more positive racial attitudes through interracial contact. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Probes to what extent and in what manner interracial contact between Black and White Americans (1) has changed between 1968-69 and 1992 and (2) is shaped by propinquity and personal characteristics. Data are based on a survey of 1,124 residents of the Detroit area conducted in 1992. Interracial contact is more common in the 1990s than it was during the late 1960s, especially for Whites, but still consists primarily of brief, superficial encounters. For Whites, the quantity and quality of contact with Blacks are determined primarily by propinquity. For Blacks, place of residence matters less, and early childhood experiences matter more. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the racial preferences and reasons in liking and disliking classmates in 264 White and Asian boys and girls, aged 8-10 yrs, in 2 studies conducted in the UK. In study 1, Ss were interviewed individually and shown photographs of their classmates. Ss were asked to nominate classmates he or she "liked most" and "liked least." All Ss selected more own-race than other-race classmates as "liked most" choices. For "liked least" choices, White boys and girls selected more other-race classmates, Asian boys more own-race classmates; Asian girls did not differ in own- and other-race choices. Study 2 further investigated the reasons behind the study 1 choices. The most common reasons for liking and disliking their classmates rested respectively on the latter's being cooperative and being bullies. Developing cooperative group work methods may enhance interracial liking and reduce racial prejudice among children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Compared the personal histories, levels of psychological distress, and adaptation to American life of 140 Vietnamese Amerasians, 71 of their non-Amerasian siblings, and a group of 118 unrelated, like-aged Vietnamese immigrants. All Ss were aged 19-33 yrs. Ss completed 2 self-administered symptom checklists and provided demographic and personal history data. Results show that Vietnamese Amerasians differed significantly from the other 2 groups on measures of alcohol use, number of hospitalizations, years of education, childhood trauma, perceived effects of trauma, and score on the Vietnamese Depression Scale. The Amerasians did not, however, differ on measures of social support or in their success at adapting to life in the US. Vietnamese Amerasians appeared to be adapting well to life in the US as well as the other 2 groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: The positive and negative effects of one's school environment (and interracial contact within this environment) have been widely debated. A question of great concern is whether the racial composition (e. g., school environment) of a school affects one's self-esteem. The present study explored whether self-esteem, race-esteem, school commitment, and delinquency differ by the racial composition of a school. Self-report questionnaires were administered to a random sample of 1,100 high school students" in a large midwestern city of the United States. The findings (a) suggest that all four measures differ by school environment, and (b) provide partial support for earlier studies claiming that, within racially homogeneous school environments, African American students, in particular, enjoy higher self-esteem. Moreover, this finding might suggest that racial diversity within certain school environments (e.g., mostly Caucasian or equally mixed) carries with it lower levels of self-esteem. Higher rates of self-reported delinquency, however, were found in the equally mixed school environment than in racially homogeneous school environments. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: The therapist of color and the White patient dyad:Contradictions and recognitions. [References].
column12: Comas-Diaz, Lillian: Transcultural Mental Health Inst, Washington, DC, US
column13: Cultural Diversity and Mental Health. Vol.1(2), 1995, pp. 93-106.
column19: The therapist of color and White patient dyad often involves contradictions and recognitions which are acknowledged through the specific processes and dynamics permeating this dyad. The relationship between self and other is frequently mediated through projection and identification. This article examines this unique interracial and interethnic therapeutic dyad emphasizing its clinical implications through the attribution of otherness, the use of colored screen projection, and the significance of power reversal. Special emphasis is given to the prevalent transferential and countertransferential reactions aided by clinical material. It is concluded that this therapeutic dyad provides a model for cross-cultural encounters where the resolution of contradictions can lead to the recognition of paradoxes, the acknowledgment of ambivalence, and the acceptance of disparate parts of the self. The management of ethnocultural transference and countertransference in the therapist of color and the White patient dyad can provide a model for dealing with cultural diversity and divergent worldviews. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Exploring the determinants of adult Black identity: Context and Process.

column19: Assessed the impact of childhood interracial contact and parental socialization on adult Black identity. The investigation tests hypotheses about the process by which these two factors operate, as well as differentiating between Black and person-of-color identities. Data were drawn from the National Survey of Black Americans (J. S. Jackson and G. Gurin, 1987) which surveyed 2,107 17-101-yr-olds. Evidence was found to support claims that interracial contact in childhood weakens adult feelings of closeness to other Blacks. Mixed support for the impact of parental socialization emerged once a more precise definition of identity was employed. With respect to process, insufficient support was found for the claim that childhood factors affect closeness through Black culture and outgroup orientation. The article concludes by outlining arguments regarding the merits of Black identity and calling for research to help resolve this controversy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial contact and Black racial attitudes: The contact hypothesis and selectivity bias.
column9:
Powers, Daniel A

Ellison, Christopher G
column12: Powers, Daniel A.: U Texas, Dept of Sociology, Austin, TX, US
column13: Social Forces. Vol.74(1), Sep 1995, pp. 205-226.
column15: University of North Carolina Press; US
column19: One of the most serious criticisms of research on the contact hypothesis is the contention that selection bias operates to promote interaction between Whites and Blacks who are already relatively unprejudiced toward one another. Accordingly, attempts to infer the effect of interracial contact on racial attitudes must recognize and correct for this potential source of bias. Endogenous switching regression models are used to estimate the effect of close interracial friendship on selected racial attitude variables while accounting for possible selectivity bias. Each model implies a distinct assumption about the process generating interracial contact and racial attitudes. Using data from the National Survey of Black Americans (J. S. Jackson et al, 1987; n = 2,107), the authors find no evidence of sample selection bias in estimating the effect of close interracial contact on black racial attitudes. Therefore, they do not reject the conventional models used in research on the contact hypothesis that treat interracial contact as an exogenous variable affecting racial attitudes. However, results show the usefulness of a switching regressions approach to reveal the contingent nature of the contact hypothesis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Developing identity formation and self-concept in preschool-aged biracial children.
column12: Morrison, Johnetta Wade: U Missouri, Dept of Human Development & Family Studies, Columbia, US
column13: Early Child Development and Care. Vol.111 Jul 1995, pp. 141-152.
column19: 11 mothers of bi-racial, preschool-aged children (aged 36-60 mo) were interviewed regarding identity formation, self-concept development, and developmental issues and problems for their children. Racial attitude levels of the 9 children studied were ascertained using the Preschool Racial Awareness Measure (PRAM II); nondirective, open-ended questions were used with mothers. Analysis included the presentation of variables that the mothers identified as a part of the child rearing practices to promote the dual heritages of the bi-racial children. These mothers formed 2 perspectives in promoting identity development: self-concept and identity were viewed as paramount issues for development by the mothers. Mothers' child rearing practices included making the children feel that they could accomplish anything, informing them of the difference of their biracial heritage, and providing exposure to racial difference in the general population. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The impact of race on the social experience of college students at a predominantly White university.
column12: Fisher, Bradley: Southwest Missouri State U, US
column13: Journal of Black Studies. Vol.26(2), Nov 1995, pp. 117-133.
column19: Examined the impact of race on the quality of a Black student's overall social experience on campus. 120 Black and 120 White undergraduates were surveyed. Race was a more salient issue for Black students than for White students. Both Black and White Ss stressed the importance of interracial friendships as a means of learning about others and building a sense of understanding between diverse groups. Personally experiencing racial prejudice and witnessing such incidents were both traumatizing. Findings suggest that a student's social life and associated opportunities are affected by his/her racial background. Both Black and White Ss agreed on the importance and necessity of enhancing the multicultural climate on campus. 51% of the White Ss and 74% of the Black Ss agreed there was a need to improve interracial relations on campus. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: "Birth prevalence of malformations in members of different ethnic groups and in the offspring of matings between them, in Birmingham, England": Corrigendum.
column12: Leck, Ian: Victoria U of Manchester, England
column13: Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health. Vol.49(4), Aug 1995, pp. 443.
column19: Reports errors in the original article by I. Leck (Journal of Epidemiology & Community Health, 1995[Apr], Vol 49(2), 171-279). Corrections to Table 1, Table 9, and the footnotes to Table 8 are provided. In addition, the page numbers of the 7th item in the list of references should read 102-6. (The following abstract of this article originally appeared in PA, Vol 83:1887.) Compared the birth prevalence (BP) of malformations in different ethnic groups by examining BP in the offspring of matings between ethnic groups from a register of malformations and register of births in Birmingham, England for 432,778 infants (including stillbirths), born in 1960-1984. Significant differences between ethnic groups were exhibited by the BP of neural tube defects (NTD), cleft palate, cleft lip, oesophageal atresia/fistula, hypospadias, hip dislocation, clubfoot, polydactyly, and syndactyly. In the offspring of matings between parents of European and Caribbean origin, the BP of NTD, cleft lip, hypospadias, hip dislocation, polydactyly, and syndactyly seemed more likely to be influenced by the ethnicity of both parents than by that of the mother alone. The reverse was true for the BP of NTD in Ss with one parent of Irish origin and one of British. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The inheritability of identity: Children's understanding of the cultural biology of race.
column12: Hirschfeld, Lawrence A.: U Michigan, Dept of Anthropology, Ann Arbor, US
column13: Child Development. Vol.66(5), Oct 1995, pp. 1418-1437.
column19: Examined beliefs about inheritability of identity and racial characteristics of mixed-race children. In Exp 1, 32 children (aged 7-21 yrs) and 43 undergraduates described the category membership of mixed-race children and the degree to which they resembled each parent. Exp 2 investigated whether 36 children (age 7-12 yrs) and 18 adults expected mixed-race children to have White, Black, or intermediate features. Exp 3 explored 46 children's (age 7-22) expectations about the inheritability of the same properties in animals. Older children, like adults, believed mixed-race children have Black racial features. Adults believe such children inherit the categorical identity of the minority parent. Exp 4 repeated these tasks with 39 Black and White children (age 7-22) attending an integrated school. Unlike children attending a predominantly White school, Ss in the integrated school expect mixed-race children to have intermediate racial features. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: School Counselor. Vol.43(1), Sep 1995, pp. 52-57.
column19: Contends that, with respect to the growing population of biracial children, developmental school counseling programs are a viable vehicle for promoting awareness of and respect for the factors that differentiate one person from another. The goal of such programs would be to enhance identity development. Addressing issues of biracial children as part of an expanded developmental counseling curriculum would increase sensitivity of all students regarding the appreciation of the many aspects of diversity. Because the message would be communicated verbally and nonverbally by the counselor, it is essential that the counselor examine his or her own attitudes regarding biracial children. column5: Ecological congruence and adaptation of minority youth during the transition to college.
column9:
Adan, Angela M

Felner, Robert D
column12: Adan, Angela M.: U Illinois, Inst of Government & Public Affairs, Ctr for Prevention Research & Development, US
column13: Journal of Community Psychology. Vol.23(3), Jul 1995, pp. 256-269.
column19: Explored notions of ecological congruence and person-environment fit by examining relationships among personal and family background characteristics and the adjustment of 188 freshmen entering either a traditionally and predominantly White college or a traditionally and predominantly Black college. The analysis focused on how Ss' race, prior interracial experience, and the predominant racial characteristics of the college setting being entered related to adaptive outcomes. No relationship was found between prior interracial experience and adjustment for White students. For Black students attending the predominantly Black university, less prior exposure to Whites and greater enmeshment in the Black community were associated with better adjustment. For Black students attending the predominantly White university, prior interracial experience was associated with better adjustment to college. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Conducted a pilot study of (1) the prevalence of physical and sexual abuse and (2) the relation between current psychological distress and a history of abuse in Vietnamese Amerasians bound for the US. 68 male and 34 female 18-28 yr olds were assessed in the Philippines. Ss completed a self-administered questionnaire regarding a history of physical and sexual abuse and the Hopkins Symptom Checklist 25, Vietnamese Depression Scale, and Youth Self Report. 22% of men and 18% of women reported physical or sexual abuse. Abused men reported greater psychological distress on all measures than did nonabused men. (French & Spanish abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Sexual satisfaction among Korean-American couples in the midwestern United States.
column9:
Song, Jung Ah

Bergen, M. Betsy

Schumm, Walter R
column12: Song, Jung Ah: Kosin U, Coll of Human Ecology, Dept of Family Studies, Pusan, South Korea
column13: Journal of Sex & Marital Therapy. Vol.21(3), Fal 1995, pp. 147-158.
column19: Surveyed 100 couples composed of non-Asian American husbands and Korean wives from the midwestern US with respect to sexual satisfaction. Though the responses of spouses were correlated highly, husbands were more satisfied with the quality of the sexual relationship than were wives. As found previously with more general populations, self-esteem and higher levels of positive regard, empathy, and cohesion were related to higher sexual satisfaction for both husbands and wives. For wives, higher SES and younger age were related to higher sexual satisfaction, as was the husband's being a current or retired member of the US military. Conflicts over sexual practices related to cultural differences were related to sexual satisfaction for both husbands and wives. For husbands only, marital conflict over cultural differences and rejection by relatives and friends were related negatively to sexual satisfaction. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column15: Assn of American University Presses/Howard University Press; US
column19: Conducted a telephone survey in the Washington, DC area to examine the extent of support or opposition to multicultural education (MCE) among 348 Black and White adults. Blacks' and Whites' attitudes toward interracial contact, MCE curricular issues, racial/ethnic stereotypes, quotas, and discrimination were compared. Strong support was found for the concept of MCE, but issues of implementation were more controversial; interracial differences were generally larger than intraracial difference. A model incorporating variables to be considered in measuring attitudes toward MCE is proposed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Forensic and policy implications of the transracial adoption debate.
column12: Griffith, Ezra E. H.: Yale U, School of Medicine, Dept of Psychiatry, New Haven, CT, US

column15: American Academy of Psychiatry & the Law; US
column19: Examines the debate concerning the adoption of Black children by White families. Forensic psychiatrists have said little about this form of transracial adoption, and they seem willing to allow other disciplines to map out single-handedly the public policy in this area. This policy is expected to affect an estimated 175,000 Black children nationally who live in some form of out-of-home placement. Forensic psychiatrists should increase their understanding of and involvement in the debate over this special form of adoption. Several principles are highlighted that must be better understood if forensic psychiatrists are to participate in the debate with clarity and understanding. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the cover) In "Multiracial Couples," 21 couples in which one partner is black and the other white talk about their experiences. The book offers a comprehensive . . . analysis based on extensive quotations. It discusses the ways the couples see their relationships as ordinary and their encounters with racism. It also provides a pioneering exploration of couple accounts of how they became a couple, their relationships with families of origin and with the community, how partners define themselves as individuals and as a couple, the ways they defend against racism, their parenting experiences, what the partners learn from each other, how race appears in the couple relationship, and the blessing of being an interracial couple. [This book] will be of value to professionals and scholars in family studies, race and ethnic studies, family psychology, and sociology. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the jacket) [The author] begins by describing how this country's racial purity laws have operated over the past 400 yrs. Then, in a series of autobiographical essays, she addresses how race and color interact in relationships between men and women, within families, and in the larger community. Scales-Trent ultimately explores the question of what we really mean by "race" in this country, once it is clear that race is not a tangible reality as reflected through color. Scales-Trent uses autobiography both as a way to describe these issues and to develop a theory of the social construction of race. . . . Scales-Trent also celebrates the richness of her bicultural heritage and shows how she has revised her teaching methods to provide her law students with a multicultural education. column5: Black-White biracial adolescents: Ethnic identity, self-label, and adaptive functioning.
column12: Larson, Leslie Ann: California School of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(6-B), Dec 1995, pp. 3477.
column19: The purpose of this study was to examine the strength of Black-White biracial adolescents' ethnic identity; whether the strength of identity contributes to adolescents' functioning; and whether the strength of ethnic identity and/or racial composition of neighborhood contributes to how adolescents self-label. Thirty-one Black-White biracial adolescents between the ages of 14 and 18 served as subjects in this within-group design. The variables assessed were: (a) the strength of biracial ethnic identity, (b) the self-label the adolescent used for ethnic identification, (c) the level of adaptive functioning, and (d) the racial composition of the adolescent's environment. The two predictor variables for the dependent variable of adaptive functioning were the strength of biracial ethnic identity and the self-label of the adolescents. The predictor variable for the dependent variable of ethnic self-label was the racial composition of the biracial adolescent's environment. Adaptive functioning was assessed by the Roberts Apperception Test for Children, ethnic identity and self-label were assessed by the Multiethnic Identity Measure, and the racial composition of the adolescent's environment was assessed by the questionnaire. Prior to hypothesis testing, intercorrelations found that no significant relationships existed between SES, age, the Biracial Multiethnic Identity Measure (MEIM), and the Roberts Apperception Test for Children (RATC) data at the.05 level of significance. The results of the simple Pearson correlation between the data from the Biracial MEIM and the RATC adaptive scales were not significant. In a post hoc analysis of the 3 MEIM's (Black, White and Biracial) it was found that the Black MEIM and the White MEIM significantly correlated with the RATC subscale, Resolution, and the total RATC adaptive scale. The results of a t-test found that a significant difference was not found between the Black and Biracial MEIM on the adolescent's self-label. The re (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Comparing the relationships of interracial and same-race couples: Implications for providing couples therapy.
column12: Stevenson, Tracy: Pepperdine U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(6-B), Dec 1995, pp. 3466.
column19: This causal-comparative study investigated whether significant differences exist between African American (Black) and European American (White) interracial couples, same-race Black couples, and same-race White couples in an attempt to gain a greater understanding of the qualities, dynamics, and nature of such relationships. The major relationship variables under investigation were love, attachment style, intimacy, communication, investment, commitment, and adjustment. The sample consisted of 22 same-race White couples, 15 same-race Black couples, and 15 Black-White interracial couples, between the ages of 21 and 65 years, who were either married or in long-term monogamous relationships. This study utilized the Love Attitudes Scale, Attachment Style Measure, the PAIR Inventory, the Marital Communication Inventory, Investment and Commitment Scales, and the Dyadic Adjustment Scale. Furthermore, semi-structured interviews were conducted with a subset of 5 Black-White interracial couples in order to assess the qualitative experience of being in an interracial marriage. The findings revealed no significant main or interaction effects between the racial composition groups on the relationship variables of love, attachment style, communication, investment and commitment. Significant main effects were found for racial composition on the variables of Social Intimacy, Recreational Intimacy, and Dyadic Cohesion. Same-race White couples were found to be significantly higher than same-race Black couples on all three variables, and significantly higher than Black-White interracial couples on Social Intimacy. A significant interaction effect between racial composition and gender was found on the love style Pragma which suggested females from the same-race White group and males from the same-race Black group tended to be higher on the love style Pragma than males and females from other racial composition groups. Results of the interviews indicated that racial differences between spou (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Biracial identity development and alienation in racially mixed adults.
column12: Aikins, Antonia Louise: California School of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(5-B), Nov 1995, pp. 2851.
column19: The Biracial Identity Development Inventory (BIDI) was developed and quantitatively examined to look at the dimensions of biracial identity development. Exploration into the empirical relationship between stages of biracial identity development and perceived alienation was investigated in a sample of 83 biracial (African-American/Caucasian) adults living in Southern California. Subjects were recruited from local and college newspapers. Subjects had the option of completing a questionnaire through the mail or by telephone. The development of the BIDI consisted of establishing a theoretical base and item pool, having experts rate the items, administering the scale, and running statistical analyses. The five subscales included: Lack of Salience, Conflict, Monoracial Identification, Appreciation, and Interaction. Lack of Salience and Conflict exhibited "respectable" internal-consistency reliability scores. A non-experimental method with a correlational and cross-sectional design was utilized. Alienation included the constructs Normlessness, Powerlessness, and Social Isolation. The investigator hypothesized that people at different levels of the biracial identity development stages would differ in Normlessness, Powerlessness, and Social Isolation scores and that the biracial identity subscales would account for a significant portion of the explained variance in Alienation. Results suggest that biracial adults who are high vs. low on the Conflict and Monoracial Identification subscales of biracial identity significantly varied in the degrees of Alienation experienced. Subjects with higher Conflict scores had higher Powerlessness scores, while subjects with higher Monoracial Identification scores had higher Social Isolation scores. However, the low reliability on the Monoracial Identification subscale indicates that these results need to be interpreted cautiously. Appreciation approached significance with individuals higher in Appreciation experiencing less Social Isolatio (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Coping and competence in African American children living in poverty: The role of cognition, locus of control, and racial socialization.
column12: Bing, Vanessa Marie: City U New York, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(5-B), Nov 1995, pp. 2855.
column19: This study sought to ascertain the role which cognition, locus of control, and racial identity had on the use and choice of coping strategies and the resulting sense of competence in poor African-American children. Previous research on children's coping has been limited in addressing cultural variables which mediate coping responses, and a pathology-driven model has typically been used to explain African-American children's reactions to stress. Fifty African-American school-aged children completed a variety of stress, coping and racial identity measures and participated in an in-depth interview to test the hypotheses that children with negative racial attitudes would demonstrate fewer effective coping mechanisms, competent behavior, and would be more influenced by racial context than those with a positive racial identity. Further, it was expected that children's perception of control would influence both the number and variety of coping styles utilized in stressful encounters, and that those holding an internal locus of control would exhibit an increased capacity to distinguish effective coping. Results obtained showed that children who held an internal locus of control displayed greater variability in coping strategy use, were more effective in distinguishing effective coping in interracial situations; and were less likely to utilize the emotion-focused strategy of distancing. Research hypotheses concerning the role of racial identity and racial influences affecting coping style, competency, and effectiveness were not supported. This appeared to be related to the instrument used and the manner in which children were classified racially, as further analyses revealed a relationship between racial identity stage and ability to distinguish effective coping. The findings suggest the need to continue to investigate and support the development of intervention strategies which increase African-American children's internalized beliefs in their abilities and capacity to (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial categorization of multiracial children in the schools.
column12: Chiong, Jane Ayers: U Massachusetts, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.56(3-A), Sep 1995, pp. 0806.
column19: Multiracial children, who are the offspring of multiple racial unions, have unique needs which are possibly not being met in the schools because, among other things, they are racially categorized on the basis of "one race only" on school forms. This monoracial categorization has become a visible symbol that acts as a foundation for a much wider array of experiences and situations in our schools and communities which affect the racial self-image of multiracial children. This incomplete categorization affects awareness and funding for supportive measures which should be available to them. The basic question which this dissertation raises is the question of whether the needs of interracial children are being met in the schools. In order to study this question, the school's racial categorization procedures as predominant cultural forms were investigated by way of its instruments--school forms, curriculum, resources, cultural programming and school material culture. In order to answer these questions, this inquiry utilized predominantly two methods of data collection: (1) documentation analysis of government and school forms and (2) semi-structured interviews with teachers as key informants. To establish a focus for the direction of the research, a theory of radical pedagogy was used to critically analyze the role of the schools in fostering or obstructing a more positive racial identity in interracial children and a theory of classification to provide a framework to analyze both the nature and language of our racial categorization procedures and its' instruments in the schools. This dissertation found that the schools do unknowingly make the normal racial identity development process problematic for at least some of those students who might want to select more than one racial identity. Multiracial children's invisibility in the schools' racial categorization procedures mirrors a wider range of their invisibility in school curriculum, books, cultural programs, class (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Coping with the reality of racism: An African-American/Afro-Canadian perspective.
column12: States, Jolaine Christine: Chicago School of Professional Psychology, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.56(3-A), Sep 1995, pp. 1140.
column19: While no one would dispute that historically racism was freely and perniciously practiced in North America, some persons in mainstream society question whether this practice continues today. However, African-Americans and Afro-Canadians state unequivocally that it does continue; and that having to cope with racism negatively affects their sense of self esteem and racial identity. Several studies support the latter's claim (The Human Relations Task Force Report, 1989; Cose, 1993; Essed 1991), as does the present research. In the present study, a semi-structured interview technique was used with 18 African-American and Afro-Canadian professionals to elicit their perceptions of which key and salient variables cause them to label an experience racist. The study queried these individuals' affective responses to racism, the defenses (strategies) they have developed to cope with racism, and sought to determine if any exhibited a "victim identity" coping style. Additionally, these professionals were asked to identify any factors they believed would improve race relations in their respective countries and asked what advice they would offer youth to help them cope as adults in an interracial environment. Racism was an experience familiar to all the study's participants. They offered highly consistent definitions of racism and highly similar anecdotal accounts of racist experiences. Participants identified three categories of salient variables/cues they believed denoted racism: (a) shifts or changes in sensory behavioral cues viewed as atypical (socially inappropriate) and negatively affecting them personally; (b) atypical behavior in the service delivery/commercial sector where the Black person receives negative differential treatment; and (c) systemic cues in which the Black person observes practices which keep them at a professional disadvantage to their White colleagues. Finally, participants described intense negative affective responses to racism and identified severa (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Prejudice as a determinant of the residential preferences of Whites and Blacks.
column12: Jackson, Tara Diane: U Michigan, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(1-B), Jul 1995, pp. 0566.
column19: Previous studies have shown that intra- and interracial differences in residential preferences are associated with continued residential segregation. However, to date, there has been comparatively little research to ascertain the factors which influence the development of such preferences. This study investigates two causal theories that have been proposed to explain the development of preferences, addressing the general question of whether a causal relationship exists between prejudice and the residential preferences of Detroit area whites and blacks. First, an argument is posited that whites' liberal attitudes about living in integrated neighborhoods may be negatively affected by stereotype use. Here, it is also argued that blacks' experiences and perceptions of discrimination induce their aversion to integrating all-white neighborhoods. The results of the two estimated models--the first for whites and the second for blacks--provide convincing evidence that stereotype use mitigates the liberal residential preferences of whites and that blacks' perceptions of discrimination by white homeowners and their anticipation of encountering racial hostility are causally related to their reluctance to pioneer integration. Other substantive findings about the indirect effects of stereotype use and discrimination on the preferences of whites and blacks, respectively, the interrelationships among the findings from the two models, and general methodological and policy issues are also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Attitudes of cuban undergraduates towards intermarriage as a function of acculturation.
column12: Ben-Ezra, Lori Lederman: U Miami, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.55(7-A), Jan 1995, pp. 2158.
column19: The purpose of this study was to examine the relationship between the acculturation process and attitudes towards intermarriage using M. M. Gordon's (1964) theory. His theory outlines a seven-stage model of acculturation. During the first stage, individuals increase their participation in and preference for activities of the dominant host culture, rather than their native culture. The next stage involves establishing social relationships with members of other ethnic groups and the host culture. Marital assimilation is the third stage and involves large-scale intermarriage. The process continues to the point where there is an absence of prejudice, discrimination, and value and power conflict in the later stages. The focus of this study was on these first three stages. Additionally, the construct of familism, the degree to which one expresses identification with and attachment toward their family, was examined to understand how this variable relates to the acculturation process and attitudes towards intermarriage. The participants in this study were 161 Cuban undergraduates attending college in South Florida. The students completed instruments that measure the various steps in the acculturation process, social desirability, familism, and attitudes towards intermarriage. Correlational analyses yielded several interesting results. There was a significant positive relationship between the extent to which the participants engaged in Anglo-American cultural activities and positive attitudes towards intermarriage. Additionally, gender differences in attitudes towards intermarriage were found to be significantly related to the students' level of acculturation. As males increase their participation in and preference for activities of the dominant host culture, their positive attitudes towards intermarriage also increase. This relationship was not found with the female students whose attitudes towards intermarriage remain the same across levels of behavioral acculturation. T (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The resolution of infertility and the acceptance of adoptive reality.
column12: Downs, Ernest Roddy: U Florida, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.55(7-B), Jan 1995, pp. 3010.
column19: Adoptees display markedly higher rates of developmental disturbances than do nonadoptees. Particularly prevalent in the adoptee population are antisocial characteristics such as criminality, aggressiveness, youthful pregnancy, and adjustment reactions. Various explanations for this tendency have been posited. The current research focused on the resolution of infertility issues of adoptive parents, and the relationship between such resolution and the willingness to both openly acknowledge the differences between adoptive and biological parenting and to interact with others regarding adoptive issues. It also considered the hypothesis that these adoptive parent experiences and behaviors are related to certain demographic conditions through a mechanism termed "role handicap" in past investigations. Adoptive parents of three adoption agencies were asked to respond to a mail questionnaire, which included a demographic section, an acceptance of adoptive reality questionnaire, and a resolution of infertility questionnaire. Confidentiality procedures insured that individual responders would not be identified with their responses. Resolution of infertility was measured with the Adjustment to Infertility Scale. Parental beliefs and behaviors regarding adoptive issues were calibrated on the Adoptive Parenthood Questionnaire. The relationship of resolution of infertility to acceptance of adoptive reality was the measurement of primary concern. Other relationships examined were those of both resolution of infertility and acceptance of adoptive reality to postinfertility stage, gender, religion, religiosity, and differentiating adoptee characteristic (interracial, foreign, and/or handicapped). No significant relationships were obtained for any of the hypothesized relationships. A factor analysis of the Adoptive Parenthood Questionnaire yielded three discrete factors. One of these, the celebration of and voluntary association around adoption, had a significant positive relationship (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Why don't they stay at home? Prejudices against ethnic minorities in Italy.
column12: Kirchler, Erich: Vienna U, Dept of Psychology, Austria
column13: Journal of Community & Applied Social Psychology. Vol.5(1), Feb 1995, pp. 59-65.
column19: Examined attitudes concerning ethnic minorities and emotions experienced in intergroup relations in 222 adult residents of Bologna, Italy. Stereotypes of North African immigrants were investigated as a function of proximity to Black people (living in the neighborhood of Black immigrants vs living in districts without immigrants) and origin (natives of Bologna vs Ss who moved from Southern Italy to Bologna). Ss completed a questionnaire derived in part from a study by A. J. Dijker (see record 1988-29307-001) measuring attitudes toward Black immigrants. The most positive stereotypes were found among native Ss living in the same neighborhoods as immigrants, while the most negative prejudices occurred among South Italians not living in the same districts as Black people. Living in the same neighborhood as immigrants fosters more favorable attitudes toward Black immigrants, encourages more direct contact, and promotes more positive action tendencies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

The model consists of 5 stages: personal identity, choice of group categorization, enmeshment/denial, appreciation, and integration. Studies are broken down into 3 categories: early childhood, focusing on early developmental and post-adoption adjustment; later childhood and early adolescence, focusing on school and behavioral adjustment; and late adolescence and early adulthood, focusing on ethno-cultural identity formation. column19: Examined the relation between White racial identity attitudes and reactions to interracial situations at work. Participants were 1 Black and 97 White full-time employees who were part-time MBA students. Ss completed the White Racial Identity Attitude Scale and the Reactions to Interracial Situations at Work Questionnaire. As predicted by White racial identity theory (J. E. Helms, 1990), Ss with high levels of autonomy attitudes had more positive reactions to interracial situations at work, and Ss characterized by high levels of disintegration and reintegration attitudes had more negative reactions to interracial situations at work. Findings for contact and pseudo-independent attitudes were less straightforward. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

A T-group model was used. Formation of coalitions within and across racial groups is illustrated. Ss participated in small groups for 10 sessions before taking on roles as group facilitators in later sessions. Racial identity attitudes shifted in group interactions. The author encourages counselors to move away from stereotypical racial thinking and to focus more on understanding members in the context of the group environment. Listening for comments reflecting racial identity attitudes is 1 way of understanding coalitions and levels of interaction. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Splitting as a consequence of severe abuse in childhood.
column12: Burland, J. Alexis: Philadelphia Psychoanalytic Inst, PA, US
column13: Psychiatric Clinics of North America. Vol.17(4), Dec 1994, pp. 731-742.
column19: Two extensive psychoanalytic vignettes are presented that suggest that a splitting, similar to that described by O. Kernberg (1966) in borderline patients, occurs in some patients suffering from the after effects of childhood abuse, even though these patients do not appear otherwise to be borderline. Case 1 involved a 7-yr-old interracial boy in residential placement because of inability to adjust to foster care. Case 2 involved a 30-yr-old man with complaints of anxiety, insecurity, underachievement, low self-esteem, impulsiveness, and conflicted family relationships, along with unpredictable and uncontrollable rages. The cases are compared and contrasted. Both Ss reported feeling split. The ability of the Ss to form a facilitating attachment to the therapist allowed them to achieve enough distance from primary objects to heal the split. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial-group differences in IQ in the Minnesota Transracial Adoption Study: A reply to Levin and Lynn.
column9:
Waldman, Irwin D

Weinberg, Richard A

Scarr, Sandra
column12: Waldman, Irwin D.: Emory U, Dept of Psychology, Atlanta, GA, US
column13: Intelligence. Vol.19(1), Jul-Aug 1994, pp. 29-44.
column19: Responds to comments by M. Levin (see record 1995-32649-001) and R. Lynn (see record 1995-32652-001) on the R. Weinberg et al (see record 1992-34580-001) study of IQ and achievement in transracial adoptees and their families that supported a genetic etiology for racial differences in IQ. Issues addressed include the magnitude of adoptee racial-group differences in IQ and achievement, inclusion of White and Asian/Indian adoptee groups, the confounding of early environmental influences with race differences, confusion of within and between-group influences on IQ, regional US differences in African-American norms for IQ and achievement, and the nature of the available evidence on a genetic hypothesis for racial differences in intelligence. It is reaffirmed that the Minnesota Transracial Adoption Study provides little or no conclusive evidence for genetic influences underlying racial differences in intelligence and achievement. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Some reinterpretations of the Minnesota Transracial Adoption Study.
column12: Lynn, Richard: U Ulster, Coleraine, Northern Ireland
column13: Intelligence. Vol.19(1), Jul-Aug 1994, pp. 21-27.
column19: Questions inferences drawn by the R. Weinberg et al (see record 1992-34580-001) study of the intelligence of transracially adopted children. Results do not confirm strong effects of rearing or social environment or age of adoption on IQ, nor can the IQ decline figures be trusted because different tests were used at Time 1 and 2. Correlations with natural and adoptive parent education and IQ measurements are also misconstrued when suggesting no support for the genetic hypothesis, which is in reality strongly supported. Contrary to Weinberg et al's conclusions, results indicate that adoption by White middle-class families has not benefitted the intelligence of Black, interracial, or White children at an average age of 17 yrs. It is suggested that the positive correlations between the IQs of the adoptive parents and those of the Black and interracial adopted children present one anomalous result that should be more fully examined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Comment on the Minnesota Transracial Adoption Study.
column12: Levin, Michael: City U New York, City Coll, Dept of Philosophy, US
column13: Intelligence. Vol.19(1), Jul-Aug 1994, pp. 13-20.
column19: Reanalyzes the Minnesota Transracial Adoption Study by R. Weinberg et al (see record 1992-34580-001), suggesting that hereditarianism is more probable than it was before and environmentalism less probable, implying consistency with the hypothesis that the mean Black/White difference in IQ is significantly genetic in origin. There is evidence that the birth cohort was not genetically typical of the White population. The comparisons most relevant to hereditarianism are between the Black/Black cohort and the birth children and between the Black/Black adoptees and the White cohort. Genotype-environment interaction offers an ordering and rough magnitude of the gaps predicted by hereditarianism. Transracial adoption design can control for a number of environmental variables commonly cited to explain race differences in phenotypic intelligence. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

West, Elizabeth
column12: Olzak, Susan: Stanford U, Dept of Sociology, CA, US
column13: American Journal of Sociology. Vol.100(1), Jul 1994, pp. 196-241.
column19: Prior research emphasized either resource mobilization or grievance explanations of antibusing activity. This article argues that both explanations imply that racial competition generated collective action against busing. It suggests that increases in interracial exposure in schools and neighborhoods trigger racial and ethnic conflict. These competition arguments are examined using data on antibusing events, school desegregation, and interracial residential exposure in SMSAs from 1968-1990. Results suggest that the amount of school desegregation significantly raised rates of protests against busing. Furthermore, there is little evidence that the federal origin of court-ordered busing increased antibusing activity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Applied Psychology. Vol.79(6), Dec 1994, pp. 993-997.
column19: Campus racial harassment provided the context for an experiment, replicated over 3 different campus samples, regarding the effects of social influence on Whites' reactions to racism. Hearing someone condemn racism led Ss to express significantly stronger antiracist opinions than occurred following exposure to a no-influence control condition. Furthermore, hearing someone condone racism led Ss to adopt significantly less strong antiracist positions than when no other opinions were introduced. The robust social influence effects were obtained regardless of whether the source was White or Black or whether Ss responded publicly or privately. A social context approach to interracial settings is discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The impact of race and ethnicity on transference and countertransference in combined individual/group therapy.
column12: White, Judith C.: Postgraduate Ctr for Mental Health, Adult Psychoanalytic Inst, Group Therapy Dept, New York, NY, US
column19: Interracial group psychotherapy is workable. Psychodynamics get cathected onto race; as this paper will show, the group process elicits feelings about racial and ethnic differences with greater intensity than in individual therapy. Analysis of race/ethnicity can be both problematic and growth enhancing for treatment. The process of identifying conscious and unconscious feelings and thoughts of race/ethnicity can stimulate major resistance, which can engender difficulties in maintenance of a working alliance. However, the working through of these feelings/thoughts may have a catalytic effect and lead to a more rapid unfolding of core psychodynamic issues. Case material from a multi-racial/multi-ethnic therapy group illustrate these issues. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Discusses implications of interracial marriages and relationships for the mental health counselor, focusing primarily on relationships involving African-Americans and European Americans. The historical antecedents of interracial relationships in the US are reviewed, and barriers to and trends in interracial relationships are discussed. Attitudes and views concerning interracial marriages and the issues confronting interracial couples are also addressed. Suggestions, including those regarding the role of support groups, are provided to help the mental health counselor better serve the needs of these couples and families. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racism and sexism in interracial pornography: A content analysis.
column12: Cowan, Gloria: California State U, Dept of Psychology, San Bernardino, US
column13: Psychology of Women Quarterly. Vol.18(3), Sep 1994, pp. 323-338.
column19: Racism and sexism were examined in interracial (Black/White) X-rated pornography videocassettes. Five female coders coded 119 White and 133 Black women and 98 White and 126 Black men in the sexually explicit scenes in 54 videos. Characters were coded on aggregate measures of physical and verbal aggression, inequality cues, racial cues, and intimacy cues, as well as other specific indices. Sexism was demonstrated in the unidirectional aggression by men toward women. Racism was demonstrated in the lower status of Black actors and the presence of racial stereotypes. Racism appeared to be expressed somewhat differently by sex, and sexism somewhat differently by race. For example, Black women were the targets of more acts of aggression than were White women, and Black men showed fewer intimate behaviors than did White men. More aggression was found in cross-race sexual interactions than in same-race sexual interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The contact hypothesis and racial attitudes among Black Americans.
column9:
Ellison, Christopher G

Powers, Daniel A
column12: Ellison, Christopher G.: U Texas, Dept of Sociology, Austin, US
column13: Social Science Quarterly. Vol.75(2), Jun 1994, pp. 385-400.
column19: Used data in the National Survey of Black Americans (N = 2,107) to explore the relevance of the contact hypothesis for the distribution of racial attitudes in the Black population. Interracial friendship was among the strongest predictors of Blacks' racial attitudes. Childhood and adult interracial contacts were weakly and inconsistently related to Blacks' perceptions of Whites and White-dominated society. Interracial contact, especially when it occurred early in life, enhanced the likelihood that Blacks will develop close friendships with Whites. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial and intraracial quasi-counseling interactions when counselors avoid discussing race. [References].
column9:
Thompson, Chalmer E

Jenal, Stephanie T
column12: Thompson, Chalmer E.: U Southern California, Div of Counseling Psychology, Los Angeles, US
column13: Journal of Counseling Psychology. Vol.41(4), Oct 1994, pp. 484-491.
column19: Dyadic interactions composed of Black clients and White or Black race-avoidant counselors in 1-time quasi-counseling sessions were influenced by myriad factors, including how these clients responded to influential purveyors of a race-neutralizing climate. Using C. E. Thompson, R. Worthington, and D. R. Atkinson's (see record 1994-30597-001) data set, 24 of these interactions were analyzed to identify significant patterns in the counseling process. The following core categories related to interactional quality were uncovered: smooth, exasperated, constricted, and disjunctive. The following factors explicated these interactional quality categories: (1) whether and how the client introduced race or race-related concerns, (2) client racial identity perspectives; and (3) client affiliation (or lack thereof) with the counselor based on race. The implications of these findings are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) examine the oral narratives of 5 African-American women and men who were active in the civil rights movement in the deep south in the 1960s / at various times in their 5 yrs with the movement in New Orleans and rural Louisiana and Mississippi, these individuals experienced terrorism and violence from segregationist Whites, and some suffered from battle fatigue due to continual exposures to danger and loss / mid-life interviews with 7 former members of New Orleans' chapter of the pacifist, interracial Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) and 2 of their lawyers-known collectively in New Orleans as the CORE family-illustrate the incorporation of collective and individual trauma into mature personal narratives argue that activists have developed 2 narrative forms to encapsulate their complex experiences within the civil rights movement-trauma narratives and narratives of redemption / argue that mid-life narratives indicate that activists have used these episodes of trauma and redemption to frame and contextualize their life trajectories as consistent with their youthful politics (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the book) With the appearance of [this book], the first genuinely interdisciplinary anthology of significant contributions to feminist theory, teachers will finally have a volume that does justice to their topic. This timely reader illuminates the historical development of feminist theory as well as the current state of the field. Emphasizing common themes and interests in the humanities and social sciences, the editors have chosen those topics that have been central to feminist theory in many disciplines. The contributors include leading figures from psychology, literary criticism, sociology, philosophy, anthology, art history, law, and economics. This is [a] text for any advanced course on interdisciplinary feminist theory. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the book) This volume marks the end of [a] 20-yr study of transracial adoptees and their families. We began our study in the fall of 1971 by interviewing parents and their children (adopted and birth) who were between 4 and 7 yrs old, and conducted the last set of interviews with the adult children (adopted and birth) in 1991. We surveyed the families 4 times-in 1971-72, 1979, 1983, and 1991. [This study examined and measured] racial attitudes, racial awareness, and racial identity among the adopted and birth children. Throughout the study, we also described how the birth children were reacting to the transracial adoption experience. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the introduction) "Inside the Mixed Marriage" is about the personal experiences of people in mixed marriages. . . . Here the marital partners consider the changing sets of advantages and constraints mixed marriages have imposed on them and their children. And, in addition to discussing the impact of society on [their] marriages, [they] speculate on the impact [their] marriages have had on the attitudes of others. It is the view from inside the mixed marriage which makes these [personal] narratives significant. They provide sharp contrasts to those who understand mixed marriages solely in the context of intergroup relations, social control, and social dominance. They hit directly at popular myths and fears. These narratives illustrate the artificiality of social constructs like ethnicity, race and culture. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
