column19: Assessed the perceptions of 453 master's degree students in 28 graduate programs in student affairs regarding their interracial experiences, knowledge, and skills. Five items assessed Ss' comfort with their skills in working with students of color and whether or not they possessed skills in 4 areas concerned with race. Ss reported limited experiences and knowledge about persons of color, yet reported comfort with their skill level in working with visible racial and ethnic group students. Two-thirds or more of the Ss indicated no knowledge in 14 of the 24 knowledge areas represented. 62.9% of the Ss felt comfortable with their skill level, 85% felt capable of identifying individual racism, and 71% felt capable of identifying institutional racism. Ss reported the most knowledge in demographics, racism, and cultures of different racial and ethnic groups. Two-thirds of the Ss reported feeling in need of more knowledge. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examines the concept of marital satisfaction (MAS) as it relates to intermarried couples and defines intermarried couples as married individuals from differing cultural, racial, or ethnic backgrounds. Theoretical issues and challenges pertinent to intermarried couples and relevant research are discussed. MAS is defined as an individual's subjective impression of the specific components within his/her marital relationship. General factors related to MAS as identified by I. D. Glick et al (1987) include roles, interpersonal relationships and reciprocities, proprieties, and time and relationships. Varying motivations, intermarital contention factors, sociopolitical structures, and economic themes may all have some influence on the intermarried couple. Counselor implications for work with this type of dyad are addressed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Conformity to social pressure and racial prejudice among White South Africans.
column12: Duckitt, John: U of the Witwatersrand, Dept of Psychology, Johannesburg, South Africa
column13: Genetic, Social, and General Psychology Monographs. Vol.120(2), May 1994, pp. 121-143.
column19: Determined whether conformity to social pressures is an important determinant of racial prejudice, particularly in social groups where prejudice is normative. 303 White undergraduates (mean age 19.3 yrs) in pre-reform South Africa completed measures of interracial attitudes and authoritarianism, perceived normative pressure from immediate family and close friends, and conformity. Measures of perceived normative pressure to hold prejudiced attitudes correlated positively and substantially with Ss' prejudiced attitudes. However, correlations between social pressure and racial prejudice were not due to conformity and probably reflected mechanisms such as socialization and homophilic selection. Conformity proneness also showed little association with overall racial prejudice or deviation from modal prejudice levels. Authoritarianism was a powerful correlate of prejudice regardless of the degree of normative pressure experienced. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: Discusses the problem of parental abduction in relation to interracial and cross-cultural marriages. A national survey of 371 parents whose children were abducted by the other parent reveals an over-representation of interracial and cross-cultural marriages among the families involved in family kidnapping. Interracial and interethnic couples make up 12.7% of the sample, but they only make up 8.4% of the US population as a whole. The literature concerning marital conflict, particularly over childrearing and intermarriage, is reviewed. The methodology and relevant findings of the national study of parental kidnapping are presented, and the implications of the literature and research findings for professionals providing psychosocial services to interracial and cross-cultural couples are explored. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1993, Vol 38(4), 433. Reviews the book, Love in Black and White: The Triumph of Love Over Prejudice and Taboo by Mark Mathabane and Gail Mathabane (1992). This book is an autobiography of a love affair. It is told by a husband and wife who describe their struggles as an interracial couple living in various parts of the United States during the last two decades. The book reports on instances of prejudice encountered by the couple and how outside forces led to family tumult and self-doubt. This work would be a useful supplementary source for classes on prejudice and racism taught at the undergraduate level. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Beyond Black and/or White: A New Paradigm for Multiracial People. [References].
column12: Huang, Larke Nahme: American University, Washington, DC, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.38(3), Mar,  1993
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1993, Vol 38(3), 306-307. Reviews the book, Racially Mixed People in America by Maria P. P. Root (Ed.) (see record 1992-97305-000). In this edited volume, Root presents a new paradigm for the emerging multiracial population in America. The call for deconstruction of existing theory and the creation of new paradigms for understanding and investigating the multicultural experience is a major premise of this book. Existing social, political, and theoretical frameworks--based on monocultural, monoracial, linear models of social relations and social identity--have forced biracial individuals to choose one or the other culture and to deny significant parts of their heritage and existence. These models mirror the dichotomous, forced choice schemes of racial classification. This volume seeks to correct these practices and perceptions by presenting alternative approaches to social identity and racial classification based on the incorporation of simultaneous membership and multiple, fluid identities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial Sexuality and its Discontents. [References].
column12: Leary, Kimberlyn: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.38(11), Nov,  1993
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1993, Vol 38(11), 1181-1182. Reviews the book, A Completely New Look at Interracial Sexuality: Public Opinion and Select Commentaries by Lawrence R. Tenzer (1990). Tenzer begins his discussion with the unstartling and uninspiring conclusion that White women have "various beliefs" about interracial sexuality, a conclusion no more edifying than stating "I will or will not leave town tomorrow." It signifies nothing. A rather anorexic presentation of these data (largely reports of the percentage of his sample's agreement with the validity of belief statements) follows and is coupled with sociocultural commentary by the author that draws on a mixture of sociological theory, psychoanalysis, historical exegesis, and personal opinion. Tenzer's book does achieve a measure of interest when he advances his central thesis that interracial sexual relations have been a pervasive and unacknowledged facet of interpersonal life since Europeans first encountered Africa and the Americas. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Administered IQ tests to 101 transracial adoptive families with children (mean age 7 yrs) and again later (mean age 17 yrs) using the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale-Revised (WAIS-R) or Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children-Revised (WISC-R). Results of parent-child IQ correlations and midparent-child IQ correlations were higher for biological offspring than for adoptive parents; correlations between adoptive parents and their adoptive offspring did not decline. This suggests that biologically related family members tend to resemble each other intellectually more than adoptive members. The pattern of IQ correlations for unrelated siblings suggests that familial environmental influences on IQ decline from childhood to late adolescence. Minimal effects of selective placement were found on familial IQ correlations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: The quest for self-identity has been more complex for African-Americans than for all the groups in American society. This quest has been especially troubling for children where one parent is African-American and the other parent is White. The scholarly literature is replete with themes on Black identity and self-esteem, but this literature does not speak to the issue of biraciality since societal attitudes decree that any person with a "drop of black blood" is Black. There is a move afoot by biracial (Black and White) young adult children to claim both parts of their ethnic heritage. This paper suggests that the issue of biracial identity must be revisited and reexamined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:

Leinart, Mary

Rowe, Sandra

Rogers, William
column12: Hymes, Robert W.: U Michigan, Dearborn, US
column13: The Journal of Social Psychology. Vol.133(5), Oct 1993, pp. 627-634.
column19: Examined whether or not jurors in an acquaintance rape case would demonstrate a pattern of bias based not only on the race of the defendant but also on the racial nature of the defendant-victim relationship. 54 male and 42 female White undergraduates read a trial transcript that established defendant-victim familiarity and sexual contact but was ambiguous about the victim's consent. Race of defendant and of victim (Black or White) were varied on a 2 x 2 design. Ss were asked to rate the guilt of the defendant and to recommend a sentence. Both Black and White defendants were rated as more guilty when the victim's race differed from their own. Sentence recommendations made by males did not differ across defendant-victim race combinations. However, females recommended more severe sentences for defendants in intraracial combinations than for defendants in interracial combinations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Describes a women's interracial encounter weekend held in Johannesburg, South Africa, aimed at bringing together Black and White women, providing a group experience to encourage them to confront their concerns about South Africa, and enabling them to explore practical ways in which they could contribute to peaceful social change. Consciousness-raising was an essential component of the encounter and included both personal and broader social dimensions. Three levels of empowerment were addressed, including the personal, the interpersonal, and the political. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Social Behavior & Personality. Vol.8(6), 1993, pp. 155-163.
column19: Replicated the findings of J. Bernard (1966), which showed that the majority of the partners in Black-White marriages were similar educationally. In the present study, the inclusion of data from the US Census indicates that educational similarity in Black and White marriages continued from 1960 through 1980. In 1970, 67.79% of the White female-Black male marriages were homogamous, compared to 64.29% of the White male-Black female marriages. In 1980, the percentage of educationally homogamous White female-Black male marriages was 66.45%. At the same time, slightly more of the marriages between White males and Black females were homogamous (66.65%). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Quinn, Sandra C.: U Maryland, Minority Health Research Lab, College Park, US
column13: Health Education Quarterly. Vol.20(3), Fal 1993, pp. 305-320.
column19: Describes risk factors for HIV infection and the AIDS educational needs of women at risk, especially African-American women. The interaction of race, gender, and social class is explored. The controversy over medical manifestations of HIV is addressed within the context of the social reality of African-American women at risk. Reproductive rights and public policy issues are discussed. Health educators must overcome their fear, class prejudice, and racial bias to form the interracial coalition necessary to stop the devastation of AIDS among African-American women and children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Stress, hypertension, and young Black Americans: The importance of counseling.
column12: Livingston, Ivor L.: Howard U, Washington, DC, US
column13: Journal of Multicultural Counseling and Development. Vol.21(3), Jul 1993, pp. 132-142.
column19: Discusses interracial differences in blood pressure (BP), the etiological significance of stress in the onset and possible exacerbation of elevated BP, and the importance of counseling in addressing the issue of stress in the lives of Black youth. Topics addressed include interracial differences in BP at early ages, the relationship between stress and hypertension, and stress management intervention through counseling. The sociopsychophysiological model of the stress process is described and is offered as a guide for counselors when they are discussing stress management. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: (1993). Ethnic variations in dying, death, and grief: Diversity in universality. xxii, 226 pp. Philadelphia, PA, US: Taylor & Francis; US.
column19: (from the preface) This volume has three aims. First, it is directed especially to those professional persons who regularly work in occupations related to death and dying. There is a need to recognize, understand, and adapt to the needs of clientele with cultural patterns that deviate from the standard and dominant patterns in the United States and Canada. The second function advances the first. Illustrative episodes and in-depth presentations of selected ethnic patterns and materials for personal reflection about death and dying and multicultural issues are included. A third goal is manifest in the fact that each of the ethnic chapters has been prepared almost exclusively by representatives who share the cultural traditions they describe. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: They don't all look alike: Individual impressions of other racial groups. [References].

column12: Zebrowitz, Leslie A.: Brandeis U, Waltham, MA, US
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.65(1), Jul 1993, pp. 85-101.
column19: Reliability, content, and homogeneity of own- and other-race impressions were assessed: US White, US Black, and Korean students rated faces of White, Black, or Korean men. High intraracial reliabilities revealed that people of one race showed equally high agreement regarding the traits of own- and other-race faces. Racially universal appearance stereotypes (the attractiveness halo effect and the babyface overgeneralization effect) contributed substantially to interracial agreement, which was only marginally lower than intraracial agreement. Moreover, similar attention to variations in appearance yielded similar degrees of own- and other-race trait differentiation. When own- and other-race differences in the differentiation of faces on babyfaceness were statistically controlled, differences in trait differentiation were eliminated. Despite the individual impressions of other-race faces, certain racial stereotypes persisted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Hayes, Peter: Iowa State U, Coll of Liberal Arts & Sciences, Ames, US
column13: Child Welfare: Journal of Policy, Practice, and Program. Vol.72(3), May-Jun 1993, pp. 301-310.
column15: Child Welfare League of America; US
column19: Both supporters and opponents of transracial adoption agree that minority children available for adoption have a right and need to develop a sense of their ethnic identity and a knowledge of their cultural heritage. Questionable social and psychiatric assumptions are used to justify this position and deny the legitimacy of rearing minority children with values that deemphasize heritage and ethnicity. The roots of this ideology lie in the political opposition of African American separationists to the humanist philosophy of the civil rights movement. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Bagley, Christopher: City Polytechnic of Hong Kong, Kowloon, Hong Kong
column13: Child Welfare: Journal of Policy, Practice, and Program. Vol.72(3), May-Jun 1993, pp. 285-299.
column15: Child Welfare League of America; US
column19: Reports the findings of a British, 12-yr follow-up study (C. Bagley et al, 1979) of 27 Afro-Caribbean and mixed-race children (mean age 19 yrs) adopted by Caucasian parents, and 25 Caucasian children (mean age 19.2 yrs) adopted by same-race parents. Ss completed questionnaires, including the Crown-Crisp Experiential Index, Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventories, and a measure of identity. Outcomes for both groups of adoptees in terms of adjustment and identity were generally excellent, although 10% of both groups had poor adjustment. There was no evidence from this or other studies that intercultural identity leads to unfavorable adjustment. Ss seemed well prepared by transracial adoption to participate effectively in a multicultural, multiracial society. Transracial adoptions should be considered for all children who cannot be placed inracially. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Studied the developmental processes and attitudes of 34 children (aged 8-20 yrs) from 15 biracial families. Results from semi-structured interviews indicate that the children consistently felt torn between selecting 1 parent's racial identification over the other's. 82% felt obligated to assume a monocultural racial designation. Some had feelings of being a traitor to the parent with whom they did not racially identify. 32% desired to establish family rituals/celebrations that recognized the uniqueness of their family. Ss consistently believed that their parents had not sufficiently prepared them for the realities of prejudice and racism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Sigelman, Lee: George Washington U, Washington, DC, US
column13: Social Forces. Vol.71(3), Mar 1993, pp. 781-795.
column15: University of North Carolina Press; US
column19: Presents a test of the contact hypothesis (the idea that contact between members of different races fosters positive racial attitudes), drawing on a national survey of 376 Blacks and 1,315 Whites conducted in 1989. Analysis reveals that Blacks are more likely than Whites to perceive Black-White relations as problematic. Blacks perceive more widespread White hostility toward Blacks and more widespread Black hostility toward Whites. By contrast, Whites are more likely to perceive Black-White relations as smooth and congenial. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Folaron, Gail: Indiana U School of Social Work, Indianapolis, US
column13: Child Welfare: Journal of Policy, Practice, and Program. Vol.72(2), Mar-Apr 1993, pp. 113-125.
column15: Child Welfare League of America; US
column19: Reviewed the case records of and conducted interviews with 62 families who had children placed in foster homes for their protection, were reunified following services to improve family conditions, and had children reenter placement after 18 mo. 30 families had children who were White, 22 had African-American children, and 10 had children of African-American and White parentage. Children of mixed parentage entered the foster care system at the youngest age. The majority of the mothers of these children had mixed or negative feelings about their child's racial identity. Racism existed within all 10 extended families. Children typically responded to the racist attitudes of their families by denying their own racial identity or by trying to look White, and none received services addressing racial identity. Selection, preparation, and support of foster care placements were also inadequate. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Communication stereotypes: Is interracial communication possible?
column12: Leonard, Rebecca: North Carolina State U, US
column13: Journal of Black Studies. Vol.23(3), Mar 1993, pp. 332-343.
column19: Argues that one of the more pervasive hindrances to authentic interracial communication is racial stereotyping. 120 Black and 106 White college students chose from a list of communication traits those that they regarded as best characterizing the communication behavior of the other racial group. Having completed their list of traits, Ss were asked to choose words from their list that they believed to be most representative of the communication behavior of the other racial group. Whites most frequently chose the traits noisy, ostentatious, demanding, manipulating, and boastful to describe Blacks. Blacks most frequently chose demanding, manipulative, rude, aggressive, noisy, and critical to describe Whites. Black and White communicators must work to make interracial communication possible, despite the stereotypes inherent in the situation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial identity in biracial children: A qualitative investigation. [References].
column9:
Kerwin, Christine

Ponterotto, Joseph G

Jackson, Barbara L

Harris, Abigail
column12: Kerwin, Christine: Fordham U, Graduate School of Education, NY, US
column13: Journal of Counseling Psychology. Vol.40(2), Apr 1993, pp. 221-231.
column19: Describes a qualitative study of issues salient in the development of racial identity for schoolchildren of Black/White racial heritage. Semistructured interviews were conducted individually with 9 Black/White biracial children and their parents (a total of 6 families). Major findings from this study tend to run counter to problems conjectured in the counseling and related literature. For example, in contrast to deficit models, participant children and adolescents did not appear to perceive themselves as "marginal" in 2 cultures. The majority of participant children, adolescents, and adults demonstrated sensitivity to the views, cultures, and values of both the Black and White communities. Developmental transitions associated with different ages were identified. Emergent themes yielded hypotheses with implications for future research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Gonzalez, Gerardo M.: U Florida, Gainesville, FL, US
column13: (1993). Challenges of cultural and racial diversity to counseling, Vol. 2: Latin America and the United States. x, 105 pp. Alexandria, VA, US: American Counseling Association; US.
column19: (from the preface) The mission of the conference in Mexico City in June 1990 was to bring together counselors and other human development specialists, including theorists and researchers, to examine the challenges posed by the increasingly diverse Spanish-speaking populations located throughout the Americas. An attempt was made to clarify the roles of helping professionals as mediators and advocates for persons of Latino/Hispanic origin, with particular attention to ethnic/cultural identification and within-group differences. An effort also was made to consider the contribution that indigenous practices make to counseling in Latin America and the social and economic consequences of majority-minority relations in both Latin American and North American cultures. This conference promoted and facilitated important dialogue about the broad issues of community, diversity, communication, and spiritual concerns that affect Latino/Hispanic groups. Indeed, numerous presentations and discussions focused on each of these broad topics; thus, this monograph is organized around these four areas of emphasis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Review of Adoption: International Perspectives.
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.37(9), Sep,  1992
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1992, Vol 37(9), 958. Reviews the book, Adoption: International Perspectives by Euthymia D. Hibbs (Ed.). Professionals from many countries and different disciplines address new issues that have surfaced in the field of adoption over the past decades--open versus closed adoption, independent adoption, international and cross-cultural adoption, and the adoption of children with special needs. Contributors also examine how nuclear families accept a nonblood "relative" into the family, the best way to raise a special needs child, and the need for adoptees to know the history of their family of origin. Included in the book are sections on developmental issues in adoption, assessment of prospective parents, the preparation of special needs children, adoption research, and legal aspects of adoption. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: From narcissistic disarray to desperation: Effects of social disintegration on the psychic economy. [French].
column12: Freire-Costa, Jurandir: U Rio de Janeiro, Inst de Medecine Sociale, Brazil
column13: Psychanalystes. Vol.45 Win 1992, pp. 219-226.
column19: Relates the case of a 45-yr-old man of mixed blood, successful in his profession and happy in his marriage, but obsessed with his racial status as the son of a White mother and a Black father, perceiving himself rejected by Brazilian middle-class society, where a disintegrating economy has revived half-forgotten racial divisions and enmities. The S had internalized White prejudices, living an identiy drama and caught in a paroxysm of narcissistic humiliation and despair. Nurturing a White ego idea, the S despised the Black traits in his body and hated his parents. The author notes that the S was, at the time of writing, studying to become a labor mediator so as to give a voice to the voiceless and powerless. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Biracial children: An increasing concern for elementary and middle school counselors.
column12: Herring, Roger D.: U Arkansas, Little Rock, US
column13: Elementary School Guidance & Counseling. Vol.27(2), Dec 1992, pp. 123-130.
column19: Discusses problems and identity conflicts faced by biracial children (BRC) and the role that elementary and middle school counselors can play in mitigating these difficulties. BRC are vulnerable, face social rejection by their peers, and receive ambivalent attention in their schools and communities. They also face conflicts about biracial identity, social marginality, sexuality, separation from parents, and career aspirations. Counselors must develop a positive working relationship with BRC and their families and must help BRC to build their self-esteem as unique individuals by identifying and supporting the children's positive coping mechanisms, abilities, and interests independent of racial heritage. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Explored the relationships of media news, drama, and sports exposure, and direct interracial contact to beliefs about the relative socioeconomic outcomes and contributions of Black and White Americans among 2 samples of White university students surveyed in 1980-81 and 1985-86. Different types of media content were related differently to beliefs about the socioeconomic standing of Black Americans. Greater exposure to TV entertainment content was associated with beliefs that Black Americans enjoy a relatively higher socioeconomic position with respect to average income, social class, and educational achievement. In contrast, higher exposure to TV news was associated with perceptions that in comparison to Whites, Black Americans are relatively worse off socioeconomically. Media effects were stronger in 1985-86 and among Ss from backgrounds affording few opportunities for direct interracial contact. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Root, Maria P. P [Ed]. (1992). Racially mixed people in America.  (pp. 91-107). viii, 387 pp. Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; US.
column19: (create) Discusses two ways in which some biracial individuals have tried to resist White dominance in U.S. society, as enforced by a "policy of hypodescent" that has designated as Black everyone who is not "pure" White. One type of individual resistance has taken the form of "passing," a radical form of integration whereby individuals of a more European phenotype and cultural orientation make a break from the African American community, temporarily or permanently, in order to enjoy the privileges of the dominant White community. The other form of resistance is the formation of pluralistic elites within the African American community, as seen in the phenomenon of blue-vein societies, or the formation of pluralistic enclaves on the periphery of the African American and European American communities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column21: discusses passing & pluralism as forms of resistance to White dominance over biracial individuals

column5: Racially mixed people in America.
column12: Root, Maria P. P.: Private Practice, Clinical Psychologist, Seattle, WA, US
column13: (1992). Racially mixed people in America. viii, 387 pp. Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; US.
column19: (from the cover) America has been the breeding ground of a "biracial baby boom" for the past 25 years. Unfortunately, there has been a dearth of information regarding how racially mixed people identify and view themselves and how they relate to one another. "Racially Mixed People in America" steadily bridges this gap, and offers a comprehensive look at the social and psychological adjustment of multiracial people, models for identity development, contemporary immigration and marriage patterns, and methodological issues involved in conducting research with mixed-race people, all in the context of America's multiracial past and present. Including contributions by ethnohistorians, psychologists, and sociologists, this powerful volume will provide the reader a tool for examining ideologies surrounding race, race relations, and the role of social science in the deconstruction of race. "Racially Mixed People in America" is essential reading for researchers and practitioners in cross-cultural studies, psychology, family studies, sociology, and social work. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column21: examines the state of biracial people in the US

Dedication
Part I: Racial ecology
* Within, between, and beyond race / Maria P. P. Root

* The human ecology of multiracial identity / Robin L. Miller / 24-36
* Developmental pathways: Toward an ecological theoretical formulation of race identity in Black-White biracial children / Deborah J. Johnson / 37-49
* Mixed-heritage individuals: Ethnic identity and trait characteristics / Cookie White Stephen / 50-63
* The quiet immigration: Foreign spouses of U.S. citizens, 1945-1985 / Michael C. Thornton / 64-76
* Beauty and the beast: On racial ambiguity / Carla K. Bradshaw / 77-88
Part II: Recovering the multiracial past
* Passers and pluralists: Subverting the racial divide / G. Reginald Daniel / 91-107
* Blood quantum: Native American mixed bloods / Terry P. Wilson / 108-125
* La Raza and the melting pot: A comparative look at multiethnicity / Carlos A. Fernandez / 126-143
* From dust to gold: The Vietnamese Amerasian experience / Kieu-Linh Caroline Valverde / 144-161
* An invisible monster: The creation and denial of mixed-race people in America / Cynthia L. Nakashima / 162-178
Part III: What of the children?
* Back to the drawing board: Methodological issues in research on multiracial people / Maria P. P. Root / 181-189
* Identity development in biracial children / James H. Jacobs / 190-206
* Between a rock and a hard place: Social adjustment of biracial youth / Ana Mari Cauce, Yumi Hiraga, Craig Mason, Tanya Aguilar, Nydia Ordonez and Nancy Gonzales / 207-222
* Negotiating ethnic identity: Issues for Black-White biracial adolescents / Jewelle Taylor Gibbs and Alice M. Hines / 223-238
* Offspring of cross-race and cross-ethnic choices for biracial individuals / Ronald C. Johnson / 239-249
* Please choose one: ethnic identity choices for biracial individuals / Christine C. Iijima Hall / 250-264
* Interracial Japanese Americans: The best of both worlds or the end of the Japanese American community? / Amy Iwasaki Mass / 265-279
* Prism lives: Identity of binational Amerasians / Teresa Kay Williams / 280-303

Part IV: Challenging the census

column5: The effect of children on parents.
column12: Ambert, Anne-Marie: York U, Dept of Sociology, Professor, North York, ON, Canada
column13: (1992). The effect of children on parents. xiv, 308 pp. New York, NY, England: Haworth Press, Inc; England.
column19: (from the cover) Author Anne-Marie Ambert takes a unique interdisciplinary approach, examining child effect from various disciplines-sociology, psychology, psychiatry, and others. An easy-to-read book, "The Effect of Children on Parents" looks deeply into these subjects and voices perspectives not previously or rarely considered or published. Actual case studies add a human interest touch and clearly illustrate the specific themes discussed. A sophisticated tool to aid researchers in child development, family studies, and sociology of childhood and family, it will also be an extremely beneficial addition for upper-level undergraduate and graduate students due to the analytical nature of the book. Students in the fields of sociology, family studies, child development, and women's studies will find the topics interesting and valuable as they seek to better understand and help families and children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Using the Brock Pleasuring Machine in 2 experiments, 171 White male Ss (primarily undergraduates) administered graded waves of pleasurable vibrations to a Black or White female recipient (a confederate) who appeared to have similar or dissimilar attitudes to the S. Ss tended to administer more intense pleasure (in response to correct answers in a learning situation) to similar White recipients than to similar Black recipients, but there was no difference in the intensity of pleasure administered to dissimilar White and dissimilar Black recipients. There was no consistent evidence that attitudes toward interracial marriage affected pleasuring. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The Minnesota Transracial Adoption Study: A follow-up of IQ test performance at adolescence.
column9:
Weinberg, Richard A

Scarr, Sandra

Waldman, Irwin D
column12: Weinberg, Richard A.: U Minnesota, Inst of Child Development, Minneapolis, US
column13: Intelligence. Vol.16(1), Jan-Mar 1992, pp. 117-135.
column19: Restudied members of 93 transracial adoptive families 10 yrs after initial research by S. Scarr and R. A. Weinberg (see record 1977-07996-001) and reported on IQ scores and school achievements of the Black and interracial children and other adopted children, and the biological offspring of the adoptive families at mid- to late-adolescence. Because of changes in tests and in norms, members of the adoptive families, including parents, scored lower at Time 2 follow-up than at Time 1. There were no differences between the transracial adoptees and the biological offspring of the adoptive parents in IQ score change from Time 1 to Time 2. Results support the original finding that being reared in the culture of the tests and the culture of the schools benefits all children's IQ scores and school achievements and that social and genetic variables contribute to individual variations among them. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Democratic attitudes in multicultural settings: A cross-national assessment of political socialization.
column12: Dash, Shrikant: Vanderbilt U, TN, US
column13: Youth & Society. Vol.23(3), Mar 1992, pp. 313-334.
column19: Investigated the attitudes toward multiculturalism of 350 high school (HS) students in India, 190 HS students in Canada, and 584 HS students in the US. Students in India and Canada who saw conflict in diversity (CID) most often favored a national religion. In Canada and the US, the CID group least often favored government's neutrality in religious matters and were least encouraging of Native American culture. In Canada, the CID group least often felt that racially segregated neighborhoods stand in the way of racial harmony. In both the US and Canada, the CID group advocated the imposition of English as the national language, opposed interracial marriages, and attributed racial conflict to irreconcilable differences. Despite social and cultural cleavages in India, Indian students appeared to have adopted democratic principles to a greater extent than had Canadians and Americans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1991, Vol 36(12), 1033-1035. Reviews the book, The Psychology of Adoption edited by David M. Brodzinsky and Marshall D. Schechter (see record 1990-97583-000). Brodzinsky and Schechter have delivered in this volume a valuable collection of chapters dealing with a wide range of theoretical, empirical, and practice issues related to adoption. The section on research in adoption includes revised versions of two landmark research projects. One is by Bohman and Sigvardsson of their well-known longitudinal research conducted in Sweden. Similarly, there is an updated overview of adopted adolescents in residential treatment by Grotevant and McRoy. Chapters on interracial adoption and adoption disruption complete second section. The third section of the book, concerning clinical issues, opens with Hartman and Laird's discussion of common themes presented by adoptive families in therapy. This is followed by the presentation of two therapeutic approaches. The book concludes with a section on social policy and casework issues in adoption. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Guess who's Coming to Marital Therapy. [References].
column12: Christensen, Andrew: University of California, Los Angeles, CA, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.36(11), Nov,  1991
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1991, Vol 36(11), 946-948. Reviews the book, Intermarried Couples in Therapy by Man Keung Ho (1990). This book on intermarried couples in therapy focuses specifically on interracial and interethnic marriages but excludes inter-religious or interfaith marriages. His goal is to provide theory-based, practical material that can assist therapists and students in helping couples involved in these intermarriages. Unfortunately, very little or very poor editing was done on this book. This is an annoyance to the reader, although it does not interfere with overall comprehension. Despite my criticisms of the book, I think it does have quite a bit to offer the practitioner who treats intermarried couples. This usefulness is heightened by the fact that Ho's book is, to my knowledge, the only one of its kind. His ideas can enlighten the therapist not attuned to ethnic differences in couples. His therapeutic suggestions often provide useful and innovative ideas for treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Marketplace economy: The evaluation of interracial couples.
column12: Wade, T. Joel: Bucknell U, Lewisburg, PA, US
column13: Basic and Applied Social Psychology. Vol.12(4), Dec 1991, pp. 405-422.
column19: G. Elder's (1969) marketplace theory and E. Porterfield's (1978) concept of status incongruity were tested as possible explanations for 80 female and 80 male White Ss' perceptions of and behavioral propensities toward a Black male-White female couple in a 2 (sex of S) x 2 (race of male) x 2 (status of male) x 2 (attractiveness of female) design. Results show somewhat greater support for the marketplace concept than for the status incongruity concept. While evaluations of the interracial couple were negative overall, race x attractiveness interactions suggest that the couple was evaluated on perceived equity of the exchange of these variables. The Black male-unattractive White female couple received the best evaluation. By inference, this couple was perceived as an equitable exchange of assets. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined the extent to which Asian/White late adolescents are an at-risk group whose identity development is significantly different from Asian or White identity development. 51 Asian/White, Asian, and White college students were administered Marcia's Identity Interview (1966), with a section on race, and J. Mar's Asian Values Scale (unpublished manuscript). Asian/Whites did not possess significantly different identity statuses than Asians or Whites. Asian/Whites held values similar to Asians on the Asian Values Scale, but rated race as significantly less important in identity formation than did Asians. In some contexts, Asian/Whites may not be as at-risk as previously thought. In the present study, Asian/Whites had positively resolved racial issues such that race was no longer a matter of daily contention. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Teaching methods for reducing prejudice and enhancing academic achievement for all children.
column12: Singh, B. R: Sunderland Polytechnic, School of Education, England
column13: Educational Studies. Vol.17(2), 1991, pp. 157-171.
column19: Focuses on the jigsaw cooperative learning method for reducing interracial prejudice, which is useful in facilitating peer-tuition, developing self-esteem, and fostering interdependence and academic achievement. Members in a cooperative learning group work toward a common goal, are more motivated to help weaker group members, and impose sanctions for inadequate effort and poor contributions to group goals. This method induces cooperative efforts to achieve joint goals, which allows liking and respect to develop among group members when they are from different ethnic backgrounds. Cooperative learning increases cross-race friendships equally for students of different sexes, races, and achievement levels. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Presents research findings based on 20 clinical case studies of biracial/bicultural adolescents (aged 14-18 yrs). Conflicts experienced by biracial and bicultural adolescents in their attempts to master developmental tasks are identified. Seven case examples are presented. The cases include a wide spectrum of adaptive and maladaptive behaviors, ranging from mild anxiety and depressive symptomatology to eating disorders, substance abuse, delinquency, and sexual promiscuity to major psychiatric impairment and suicidal behavior. Issues of assessment, intervention and treatment, and training and practice are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial Panjabi in a British adolescent peer group.
column13: Language in Society. Vol.20(3), Sep 1991, pp. 391-422.
column19: Analyzed the use of Panjabi by 62 British adolescents (aged 11-13 yrs in 1984 and 13-26 yrs in 1987) of diverse ethnic backgrounds through observations, interviews, and recordings of natural interactions. Informant reports suggest that Panjabi crossing was common, though assessments varied according to its contexts of occurrence. Analysis of spontaneous speech indicated 2 major contexts: (1) agonistic interactions in which Panjabi played an auxiliary role in familiar playground practices, primarily among males (n = 40) and (2) bhangra, in which predominantly White females (n = 6) looked toward a nascent youth culture with Panjabi at its core. Despite major differences, bilingual sponsors and nonconversational structures were crucial in both settings. Multiracial Panjabi was very much a language of local association and seemed more likely to be linked to the development of pluralist, antiracist understandings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: New trends in Black American interracial marriage: The social structural context. [References].
column11: Tucker, M. Belinda: U California, Ctr for Afro-American Studies, 160 Haines Hall, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA, US, 90024-1545
column12: Tucker, M. Belinda: U California, Ctr for Afro-American Studies, Los Angeles, CA, US
column13: Journal of Marriage and the Family. Vol.52(1), Feb 1990, pp. 209-218.
column15: National Council on Family Relations; US
column19: Current rates of intermarriage differ dramatically on the basis of both region (i.e., rates are substantially higher in the West) and gender (substantially higher among men). This study addresses the underlying demographic correlates of interracial marriage as distinct among 7,023 Black women and 7,038 Black men in a western location. Logistic regression analyses indicated that the structural correlates were nearly identical for men and women: the interracially married tended to be younger, more likely to have been married before, and more distant in age from their spouses. Furthermore, persons born in the North (both northeast and north central regions) and in foreign countries were more likely to be married to non-Blacks, which seemingly indicates that moves away from communities of origin to environments that are relatively tolerant regarding race facilitate interracial marriage. Findings are interpreted as indicative of the strength of social control in mate selection. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Beyond contact theory: The impact of community affluence on integration efforts in five suburban high schools.
column12: Miller, Randi L.: California State U, Human Services Program, San Bernardino, US
column13: Youth & Society. Vol.22(1), Sep 1990, pp. 12-34.
column19: Examined a causal model designed to test whether attendance in schools in more affluent communities accounted for less positive desegregation experiences for 69 minority students from 5 schools participating in a voluntary desegregation plan. The model includes 5 theoretical constructs: inequality, community wealth, interracial attraction, integration conviction, and school involvement. Analysis of Ss' interview data demonstrated that the more affluent the community, the less welcome the minority students were. This finding is consistent with a conflict perspective that argues that the larger the class disparity, the more likely minorities are to feel unwanted, both in school or in the community at large. According to the model, inequality produces negative interracial attraction and also indirectly determines negative integration conviction through its effect on community wealth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A completely new look at interracial sexuality: Public opinion and select commentaries.
column13: (1990). A completely new look at interracial sexuality: Public opinion and select commentaries. xiii, 196 pp. Manahawkin, NJ, US: Scholars' Publishing House; US.
column19:
(from the cover) Dr. Tenzer's timely book presents a completely new look at interracial sexuality. Part One includes the findings of a never before published nation-wide public opinion survey regarding contemporary beliefs about interracial sexuality in America. Part Two is comprised of eight scholarly commentaries which discuss the beliefs addressed in Part One in terms of past and present sociohistorical perspectives. The issues considered include color symbolism, dating and marriage, antebellum history, psychological phenomena, sexual misunderstandings, future research, and more.
(from the book) Ten belief statements designed by the author were presented [to a sample of 444 white women], each addressing a particular aspect of this complex subject. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race bias in diagnosis and treatment of juvenile offenders: Findings and suggestions.
column9:
Martin, Todd W

Grubb, Henry J
column12: Martin, Todd W.: Fuller Theological Seminary, CA, US
column13: Journal of Contemporary Psychotherapy. Vol.20(4), Win 1990, pp. 259-272.
column19: Discusses evidence that Black juvenile delinquents have received biased differential treatment in mental health care systems. Research shows that the White juvenile offender often is assessed as having a psychological problem. The Black juvenile offender is more often seen as exhibiting behavior characteristic of his culture and more often than not receives inadequate psychological counseling. Information on juvenile delinquency, interracial diagnosis, and cross-cultural understanding is integrated. This information is intended to aid the forensic psychological professionals to better understand culturally different children and youths as well as examine their own cultural biases that may interfere with the appropriate assessment and treatment of Black juvenile offenders. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Biodemography and Social Biology. Vol.37(1-2), Spr-Sum 1990, pp. 44-51.
column15: Society for the Study of Social Biology; US
column19: Comparison of intra- and interethnic divorce rates in Hawaii from 1985 to 1987 showed that interethnic marriages resulted in a higher proportion of divorces than did intraethnic marriages. A sizeable portion of marriages in Hawaii were of nonresidents who, if they divorced, probably divorced elsewhere. Nonresident marriages were chiefly intraethnic marriages of Caucasians. Within-group marriages were more at risk than interethnic marriages. Persons who married members of other racial/ethnic groups tended to marry persons from groups with income levels similar to their own. Group income was a predictor of risk. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:

de Fileo Crespo, Andrea

Patel, Sanjiv

Ceravolo, Anita
column12: Potash, Herbert M.: Fairleigh Dickinson U, Madison, NJ, US
column13: Journal of Personality Assessment. Vol.55(3-4), Win 1990, pp. 657-662.
column19: Certain sentence stems in the 73-item Miale-Holsopple Sentence Completion Test by J. Q. Holsopple and F. R. Miale (1950) can be interpreted as open-ended attitude questions, revealing world views in particular societies. Sentence Stem #7, "The easiest way to get money," #8, "Twenty years from now," #18, "The white girl who married the black man," #48, "A naked man," and #54, "A woman's body," were selected for cross-cultural study. Ss were 39 American and 60 Brazilian students. American Ss gave more positive work ethic responses to Stem #7 and #8 and more negative responses to interracial marriages than did Brazilian Ss. Brazilian women gave more positive responses to Stem #54 than did American women. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Chinese American intermarriage.
column12: Sung, Betty L.: City U New York, City Coll, US
column13: Journal of Comparative Family Studies. Vol.21(3), Fal 1990, pp. 337-352.
column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: Examined Chinese-American intermarriage in New York City based on 1980 census data, marriage license applications, and personal interviews with 50 intermarried couples. Information on sex, age, generation, education, occupation, income, and ethnicity of the marital partners was obtained. The strongest factor affecting intermarriage was the generation (in the US) of the partners. Between 1972 and 1982, intermarriage rates declined for Chinese grooms but increased for Chinese brides. Intermarried Chinese men and women tended to be older, better educated, and to have better jobs and incomes than average. Also, intermarried Ss tended to be rebellious and unconventional but better equipped to handle marriage; the greatest hurdle was dealing with family objections. Rate of divorce was average. (French & Spanish abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Mothering the biracial child: Bridging the gaps between African-American and White parenting styles.
column12: Miller, Robin L.: New York U, Ctr for Community Research & Action, US
column13: Women & Therapy. Vol.10(1-2), 1990, pp. 169-179.
column19: Highlights issues of relevance to raising children of Black-White marriages. These couples must socialize their children to function in the mainstream while coping as a minority group member. Ethnic socialization refers to the communication of an ethnic identity; the necessity of fostering resilience and adaptive coping mechanisms is critical for caste-bound minorities who must function in a world of ambiguity. Existing literature suggests that self-esteem for African-American children is related to personal support and encouragement in the home, but achievement is related to factors outside family socialization. The balance between majority values and African-American culture struck by the presence of a minority agenda becomes the deciding factor for positive vs negative socialization outcomes and overall mental health. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:
Jeong, Gyung J

Schumm, Walter R
column12: Jeong, Gyung J.: Kansas State U, Human Ecology Program, Manhattan, US
column13: Journal of Comparative Family Studies. Vol.21(3), Fal 1990, pp. 325-336.
column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: Assessed the effects of acculturation on the family life satisfaction of 35 19-63 yr old Korean women married to American men. Ss completed surveys that included the Kansas Family Life Satisfaction Scale (W. R. Schumm et al and E. E. McCollum et al; see PA, Vols 74:23866 and 76:3607). Ss' English proficiency and education were significantly related to both marital and family life satisfaction but not to parental satisfaction. Total family income was positively related, while time since last visit to Korea was negatively related to marital satisfaction. In controlling for relevant variables, most initial correlations became nonsignificant except those for S's education, which remained very substantial. Results highlight the importance of education in acculturation to US society. (French & Spanish abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Toward a psychology of improving justice: Research on extending the equality principle to victims of social injustice.
column12: Cook, Stuart W.: U Colorado, Inst for Behavioral Science, Boulder, US
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.46(1), Spr 1990, pp. 147-161.
column19: Presents findings from 2 quasi-experimental and 2 experimental studies of cooperative, equal-status, interracial contact between Blacks and Whites, which show increases in favorable beliefs about and liking for Blacks by formerly prejudiced Whites. Such changes were accompanied by greater readiness to extend equality of social benefits (e.g., unsegregated housing, education, employment) to Black persons. This illustrates one approach to the goal of extending the scope of social justice to subordinate groups from whom it is often withheld. Research relevant to other approaches to the goal is also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Acting it out: 74 short plays for starting discussions with teenagers.
column13: (1990). Acting it out: 74 short plays for starting discussions with teenagers. vii, 357 pp. San Jose, CA, US: Resource Publications; US.
column19:
(from the cover) Getting teenagers to talk about how they're feeling can be frustrating. "Acting It Out" offers a new approach: 74 short plays for starting discussions with teenagers. Teens act out a short play and then, through questions provided with each drama, they discuss how the characters in the play dealt with the particular issue. The attention is focused on the characters and the issue rather than the teens themselves. These dramas address challenging subjects: abortion, suicide, child abuse, gangs, home life, drugs, etc. They don't gloss over the realities teens face today; rather they present the issues in a straightforward manner and will encourage your teens to talk about them in the same way.
(from the preface) "Acting It Out" is aimed at teenagers-both in groups and in classes-in schools, agencies, institutions, or churches. Its purpose is to provide, through drama and improvisational theatre, a means for resolving conflicts, for establishing high self-esteem, and for promoting acceptable behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Intermarried couples in therapy.
column12: Ho, Man Keung: U Oklahoma, Professor of Social Work, Norman, OK, US
column13: (1990). Intermarried couples in therapy. xiii, 141 pp. Springfield, IL, England: Charles C Thomas, Publisher; England.
column19: (from the preface) The content and the organization of this book can provide practitioners and students with a comprehensive, up-to-date examination of therapy with the intermarried. The book also provides an analytical and functional format that lends itself to the systematic ordering of information and a promising challenge of quality for transcultural therapy with this often overlooked, high-risk, but underserved population. Practicing family therapists will find that the book presents practical information and guidelines that they can readily use in their work with intermarried couples and families. In the academic arena, a specification of knowledge, techniques, and skills in intermarriage therapy should facilitate the learning process of both undergraduate and graduate students. An important new alternative to marital therapy with the intermarried is introduced that considers the cultural background of both the couple and the therapist. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The psychology of adoption.
column9:
Brodzinsky, David M [Ed]

Schechter, Marshall D [Ed]
column12: Brodzinsky, David M.: Rutgers U, Dept of Psychology, New Brunswick, NJ, US
column13: (1990). The psychology of adoption. xviii, 396 pp. New York, NY, US: Oxford University Press; US.
column19: (from the jacket) In this volume David Brodzinsky, who has conducted one of the nation's largest studies of adopted children, and Marshall Schechter, a noted child psychiatrist who has been involved with adoption-related issues for over forty years, have brought together a group of leading researchers from various disciplines to explore the complex, interdisciplinary subject of adoption. While recent empirical work has shown that adopted children are more vulnerable to a host of psychological and school-related problems compared to their nonadopted peers, and that the rate of referral of adopted children to mental-health facilities is far above what would be expected given their representation in the general population, our understanding of the basis for these problems remains unclear. In this book, theoretical, empirical, clinical, and social policy issues offer new insights into the problems facing parents of adopted children, and especially the children themselves. A comprehensive study, "The Psychology of Adoption" will be of interest to child psychiatrists, developmental and clinical psychologists, social workers, social service providers, and adoptive parents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined school and neighborhood friendships of 292 Black and White children in Grades 7-9 of an integrated school. column5: Applying social psychology to desegregation and energy conservation.
column12: Aronson, Elliot: U California, Santa Cruz, US
column13: Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin. Vol.16(1), Mar 1990, pp. 118-132.
column19: Presents 2 examples of social psychology in action in dealing with an immediate crisis and a gradual problem. The immediate crisis occurred when a school system was desegregated, and interracial conflict was exacerbated. After observing the competitive situation in an elementary school classroom, the author and colleagues suggested that students be placed in a jigsaw classroom. This method structured student interactions such that cooperation was required for success and achievement. In responding to an energy crisis, some of the home energy auditors of a gas and electric company were trained to communicate with homeowners about energy conservation, based on strategies of social and cognitive psychology. As a result, these auditors persuaded 60.9% of the homeowners they visited to weatherize their homes, a figure significantly higher than that of the control group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Black and White in school: Trust, tension, or tolerance?
column12: Schofield, Janet Ward: U Pittsburgh, Learning Research & Development Ctr, Senior Scientist, Pittsburgh, PA, US
column13: (1989). Black and White in school: Trust, tension, or tolerance? xvi, 255 pp. New York, NY, US: Teachers College Press; US.
column19: (from the cover) "Black and White in School: Trust, Tension, or Tolerance" takes a probing, much needed look at interracial relations in one particular school, a paradigm of the urban educational environment. "Wexler Middle School [a pseudonym] opened amid great fanfare and high hopes," the book begins. Desegregation, promoted not only as a necessary corrective, but even as a cure-all for society's racial discord, was the cornerstone of Wexler's establishment as a model school. Dr. Schofield's four-year ethnographic study, documented in this volume, revealed unforseen problems as well as hope that desegregation can benefit both black and white students. This book provides a wealth of information for those interested in the sociology of education, intergroup relations, peer group behavior in early adolescence, educational equity, and desegregation. It offers rich insights for social scientists, administrators, counselors, educators, and community leaders. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Investigated whether 69 minority students from 5 high schools who were participating in a voluntary busing program, Project Concern, were assimilated into their White high schools. Data were collected through nonparticipant observation and structured interviews. Findings revealed that Ss used 4 distinct strategies to cope with racial antagonisms in school: being a model student, interracial attraction, school involvement, or integration conviction. Desegregation was found to have different effects for Ss at each school. Ss bused to some communities reported more positive desegregation experiences than did Ss bused to others, contradicting the prevailing assumption of desegregation that busing to White schools necessarily fosters positive race relations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Relying on social psychological theories of interpersonal attraction, the authors predicted that individual- and school-level factors that affect the bases of attraction would influence adolescent friendship choices. Data from the sophomore and senior cohorts of the High School and Beyond Survey were used. Results show that students were only one-sixth as likely to choose a cross-race than a same-race peer as a friend, and controls for school and individual variables accounted for only a third of this differential. While personal characteristics of individual students and pairs of students had the strongest effects on friendship choices, organizational characteristics of the school (e.g., tracking) were also important. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The Rise and Fall of Transracial Adoption: Science Meets Politics. [References].
column12: Grotevant, Harold D.: Division of Child Development and Family Relationships, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.33(10), Oct,  1988
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1988, Vol 33(10), 853-855. Reviews the book, Transracial Adoptees and Their Families: A Study of Identity and Commitment by Rita J. Simon and Howard Altstein (1987). The scientific and political issues that shaped the rise and fall of transracial adoption provide the backdrop for this monograph. The stated purpose of the book was to report the results of the third wave of data collection from a sample of transracially adoptive families in order to answer questions about the long-term effects of transracial adoption on the adoptees and their siblings, about the adoptees' racial identities and self-esteem, and about the strength of the loyalties and commitments the parents and children have toward each other. On the basis of their interviews, the authors concluded that, while permanent inracial placement was preferable, transracial adoption continues to be a viable alternative for Black children that should be explored on a case-by-case basis. The design of the study and measures used in it, however, leave the results open to multiple interpretations. Although the study is longitudinal by design, no inferential statistics were used to link data across the different waves of data collection. Furthermore, the book is silent on critical psychometric issues such as reliability of coding and internal consistency of scales. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Creating positive television images.
column12: Fairchild, Halford H.: Assn of Black Psychologists, Washington, DC, US
column13: Applied Social Psychology Annual. Vol.8 1988, pp. 270-280.
column19: Describes the development of a concept for an educational TV program that would address the concerns emerging from research on the effects of media violence, the portrayal of minorities and women in the media, and the prosocial potential of TV. The pilot TV program involved an interracial and cross-gender team of skilled young adults, cast in counter-stereotypical roles, who traveled to other planets to solve problems of intergroup conflict. To reduce prejudice, the team of protagonists shared equal status and common goals, they cooperated in a fairly intimate context, and they enjoyed successful outcomes. Evaluation of the program is described. It is argued that TV can be a pathway to peace by creating a sense of world community, promoting intercultural understanding, and impeding the formation of the enemy image. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Conducted 3 experiments in which 96 Latin American adults, 76 White Canadian-born undergraduates, 53 Israeli student teachers, and 14 Ethiopian vocational students who recently immigrated to Israel were administered an interracial facial expression test. Overall results support both the universality and culture-racial specific hypotheses. In Exps 1 and 2, Latin Americans and undergraduates made significantly more errors in identifying the facial expressions of Black West Indians compared with White Anglo-Saxon faces. Bilingual Latin Americans outperformed unilinguals in decoding facial expressions of emotions. In Exp 3, there were no significant differences in errors between Black and White facial expressions for the Israeli and Ethiopian Ss. Results are discussed in terms of procedures for training people from the host culture to be better decoders and to develop greater empathy for visible minority groups. (French & Spanish abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Contends that the child of a Black-White union can be seen as suffering all the disadvantages of being Black, including diminished opportunities in both education and employment; discrimination in housing; economic disadvantages; and racism in its cultural, individual, and institutional forms. The biracial identity, racial identity problems, and development of the self in the biracial child are discussed. A clinical illustration of a 7.5-yr-old girl in psychotherapy is presented. It is suggested that a self-psychological perspective may illuminate some aspects of development of self-identity in the biracial child and that such a model may serve to explain emotional problems experienced by the biracial child. column19: Developed a scale to measure student perceptions of school interracial climate. Items were written to reflect contact theory criteria for successful desegregation. Nearly 3,100 5th-8th graders responded to a pool of Likert-format items. The scale correlated highly with measures of proportion of other-race friends, cafeteria integration, classroom racial balance, and teachers' perceptions of successful desegregation. Ss' (n = 767) responses to the school interracial climate scale were used to predict their attitudes in other school-related areas. Ss who believed the contact theory criteria were met in their school had higher quality of school life scores, a higher sense of academic efficacy, and for Whites, fewer perceived differences between a White and a Black friend. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Assessed the relative importance of the following variables in influencing the outcome of interracial contact in an intercultural contact situation: amount of contact, length of time living in the country, norms, personal association, initial attitudes toward the country (expectations and first impressions), and attitudes toward people in general. Ss were 199 US 12-19 yr olds living in Germany and enrolled in on-base American schools for military dependents. Analyses of questionnaire data were controlled for past intercultural experience and the age, sex, and ethnic group of the Ss. Results show that norms, first impressions, expectations, and attitudes toward people were the major influences on attitudes toward members of another culture. Suggestions are made for the preparation of educational programs and for family, group, and individual counseling for families with adolescents who are transferred to new cultural environments. column19: Investigated the effect of shared beliefs on the reduction of prejudicial attitudes in an interracial contact setting, using 74 White male undergraduates. Ss participated in discussion groups, each including 2 Black and 2 White confederates instructed to agree or disagree with the S. Prejudicial attitudes toward Blacks were assessed with a stereotyped attitude scale and a personal perception questionnaire before and after the discussion sessions. It was hypothesized that agreement conditions would result in more positive interpersonal perceptions and greater prejudice reduction than disagreement conditions. Results show that prejudice reduction occurred in both conditions and suggest that group discussion procedures may reduce prejudice in the absence of belief congruity. column19: (from the preface) To begin with, I wanted to write a text that gave a balanced presentation of the principles of adjustment. Beyond this, I had two major goals for this book. The first was to provide students with a text that focuses not only on adjustment problems but also on adjustment successes. . . . Furthermore, I knew that the readers of this book would be a basically healthy population and I wanted to emphasize situations and aspects of adjustment that would relate to their experience. Each chapter opens with an outline of the major topics that will be discussed and closes with a point-by-point summary of the chapter contents. The key terms are listed at the end of the chapter for review purposes. These terms are again listed at the end of the book in a complete glossary. column19: Examined the effects of individual-, dyadic-, group-, and classroom-level variables on cross-race friendship (CRF) choices. It is argued that structural and organizational characteristics of a student's environment influence the likelihood of interracial friendliness. Hypotheses about the nature of these influences were tested with longitudinal data from 358 4th-7th grade students. Personal characteristics (e.g., gender, age, social status, reciprocity) affected the likelihood of CRFs just as in same-race friendships. The presence of different races in the same ability groups and activities had a substantial effect on CRF choices. The influencing factors had differential effects on Blacks and Whites. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Williams, Richard A

column13: American Sociological Review. Vol.52(5), Oct 1987, pp. 653-664.
column19: Examined the determinants of the stability of schoolchildren's interracial and same-race friendships. The hypotheses that classroom organizational features and student characteristics affect the cohesiveness of social ties with consequences for friendship stability were tested on longitudinal data from 375 4th-7th grade students in 16 desegregated classrooms. Descriptive and inferential analyses showed that interracial friendships were almost as stable as same-race ones. While the stability of interracial and same-race friendships was influenced by classroom characteristics, it was more strongly influenced by ascribed and achieved characteristics of students. School policies that promote stable friendships between Black and White students are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Examined adjustment and identity development in transracially adopted children. In-home interviews were conducted with 26 transracial and 26 intraracial families. Telephone interviews were conducted with 11 additional transracial families. All children had been adopted when they were less than 3 yrs old, and most when under 1 yr old. About 75% of the transracially adopted children were judged to be doing well, to enjoy close relationships with their families and friends, and to be relatively free of symptoms of emotional distress; this was true for 80% of the in-racial adoptees. On measures of racial preference and identity, in-racial children's sense of Blackness exceeded that of transracial children by age 8 yrs. column19: Examined the effects of classroom characteristics on the interracial friendliness of students in desegregated classrooms, using questionnaire data from 229 Black and 226 White students in 16 4th-7th grade desegregated classrooms. column5: Transracial adoptees and their families: A study of identity and commitment.
column12: Simon, Rita J.: American U, School of Justice, Dean, Washington, DC, US
column13: (1987). Transracial adoptees and their families: A study of identity and commitment. xii, 150 pp. New York, NY, England: Praeger Publishers; England.
column19: (from the introduction) The heart of this volume is Part II. It reports the results of the third phase of our study of transracial adoption, in which we interviewed 96 parents and 218 children, 111 of whom have been transracially adopted, 91 of whom have been born into the families, and 16 of whom have been adopted. This third phase occurred four and a half years after our last contacts with these families and twelve years after we interviewed them for the first time. . . . In phases one and two, we reported that the parents were optimistic that their children would have integrated and wholesome personalities and the emotional security sufficient to allow them to make their way and gain acceptance among both black and white communities. Rather than becoming the pariahs that the Black Social Workers warned about, these children would also become part of a small but growing integrated community in which race was not a major basis for acceptance or evaluation. Phase three assesses the likelihood that the parents' hopes have and will be realized and that the transracial adoptees are aware of their "special status" and capable of coping with it. We begin this volume by providing, in Part I, what statistical data are available on the numbers of transracial adoptions nationally, practices of adoption agencies, and recent court rulings. Part I also discusses the positions of the National Association of Black Social Workers, Child Welfare League, and other agencies, public and private, involved in the placement of nonwhite children. Part III examines alternative forms of adoption such as single parent adoption. It reports the effects of contraceptive practices and abortions among teenagers on birth rates and adoptions; and it provides data and analysis about intercountry adoptions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Casework contacts with Black-White couples.
column12: Brown, John A.: San Jose State U, School of Social Work
column13: Social Casework. Vol.68(1), Jan 1987, pp. 24-29.
column19: Presents case examples of Black-White (BW) couples who are involved in conflict situations. It is suggested that although race is not necessarily a critical dimension in the problems of BW couples, race is a variable, and its possible contribution to problems must be assessed. Treatment techniques are discussed. Supervision is emphasized as important in helping the case worker to identify racist attitudes that may creep into the therapeutic relationship. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Measuring and explaining high school interracial climates.
column9:
Davidson, James D

Hoffmann, Gerhard

Brown, William R
column12: Davidson, James D.: Purdue U
column13: Social Problems. Vol.26(1), Oct 1978, pp. 50-70.
column19: Proposes a method for measuring schools' "interracial climates" and examines the extent to which variations in these climates are related to schools' racial compositions, rates of change in their racial compositions, and the social and academic status of Black and White students. Results from 8 Indianapolis public high schools suggest that rates of racial change have the most effect, followed by students' social and academic status arrangements. Racial composition (measured in terms of racial balance) seems to have little or no predictable effect. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: What generation gap? A comparison of some generational differences among blacks and whites.
column12: Brunswick, Ann F.: Columbia U
column13: Social Problems. Vol.17(3), 1970, pp. 358-371.
column19: Examined data from 7 national surveys for age differences in black and white populations regarding 3 kinds of attitudes: (a) outlook on life, (b) interracial tolerance and hostility, and (c) attitudes toward the advocacy of violence. In each of these attitude areas, populations showed differences by education as well as by age. But the interaction between education and age was not always the same in the black and white populations. This analysis indicated that education may be at least as important a determiner of generations as age is; introducing education as a variable interacting with age adds precision to the discussion of generational differences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).
