column5: Verbal attitudes, overt acts, and the influence of social constraint in interracial behavior.
column9:
DeFriese, Gordon H

Ford, W. Scott
column12: DeFriese, Gordon H.: U. Kentucky
column13: Social Problems. Vol.16(4), 1969, pp. 493-505.
column19: Studies racial attitudes as related to an indicated willingness to accept open occupancy in white residential neighborhoods. An attempt is made to ascertain whether the predictability of the overt response of a given individual to a publicly salient issue can be increased by knowing the individual's personal attitudinal position toward Negroes in general, and the influence of certain of his significant reference groups with respect to the same issue. Results of a field study show that proportional reductions in error are greater in efforts to predict overt response to the open occupancy issue when both attitudinal position and reference group influence are employed than when either attitude or reference group are employed separately. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial social contact and middle-class white reactions to the Watts riot.
column12: Jeffries, Vincent: San Fernando State Coll
column13: Social Problems. Vol.16(3), 1969, pp. 312-324.
column19: With data collected shortly after the Watts riot, the reactions of a sample of white middle-class respondents were studied. It was found that prior social contact with Negroes is an important determiner of white attitudes toward the disorder. Those lacking contact are more fearful of Negroes, cite more outside agitator explanations, evidence more feelings of increased social distance, and voice more punitive responses than those having contact. This study suggests that relatively tolerant people who have experienced social contact with Negroes will be more likely to support the recommendations of the President's Commission on Civil Disorders than tolerant people lacking social contact. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Aftermath of a race riot: The emergent norm process among Black and White community leaders. [References].
column12: Gordon, Leonard: Department of Sociology, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ, US
column13: Sociological Perspectives. Vol.26(2), Apr 1983, pp. 115-135.
column19: In the years immediately following the 1967 racial disorder crisis in Detroit, there existed between black and white community leadership ideological and policy polarization. Over the next decade such polarization transformed itself into a nonideological pragmatic accommodationist orien tation. This analysis draws on Turner's emergent norm theory to interpret stages evident in the normative shift in black and white leadership attitudes and behaviors within a context of continuing stressful city conditions. Employing a combination of decisional, functional, and positional selection criteria, 14 black and 22 white community leaders were periodically interviewed and observed between 1968 and 1980. As posited in emergent norm theory, the crystallization and recrystallization of norms held by black and white community leaders involved multiple competing leadership ideas before a dominant norm emerged. While there are signs that a possible new emergent norm stage of repolarization may be developing, this analysis focuses on the interactionist process that resulted in a shift from interracial community leadership confrontation toward policy and pragmatic cooperation for a period of over a decade. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Assertive behavior in Black and White American undergraduates.
column9:
Lineberger, Marilyn H

Calhoun, Karen S
column12: Lineberger, Marilyn H.: Emory U
column13: The Journal of Psychology: Interdisciplinary and Applied. Vol.113(1), Jan 1983, pp. 139-148.
column19: Compared the assertive responses of 30 Black and 30 White undergraduates to an assertiveness battery and hypothetical intra- and interracial situations. Results indicate significant differences in the assertive responses of Blacks and Whites. Blacks scored higher on the Rathus Assertiveness Schedule and tended to be rated as more assertive by raters on the Social Response Inventory. Whites made more requests in interpersonal interactions and showed more positive assertion toward Blacks than Blacks toward Whites. Blacks were also more likely to respond differently to members of the opposite race by frequent use of Black-English vernacular with Blacks and more aggressive responses toward Whites. The only sex difference was a more positive attitude toward assertion by females. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Reducing interracial aggression: Inhibiting effects of victim's suffering and power to retaliate.
column9:
Griffin, Betsy Q

Rogers, Ronald W
column12: Griffin, Betsy Q.: U South Carolina
column13: The Journal of Psychology: Interdisciplinary and Applied. Vol.95(1), Jan 1977, pp. 151-157.
column19: A 2 * 2 * 2 factorial experiment employing 64 White male university students investigated the aggression-inhibiting effects of 3 characteristics of a victim: race, expression of pain, and potential to retaliate. A modified Buss aggression machine was used. As predicted, pain cues effectively inhibited aggression. A triple-order interaction effect extended previous findings by demonstrating that the expression of suffering reduced aggression (a) even if the victim had no power to retaliate and (b) even if the victim was a member of a racial minority. In contrast to the suppressive effect of suffering, potential retaliation was a relatively ineffective deterrent of physical attack. Additional factors limiting the aggression-inhibiting power of threatened retaliation were the victim's expression of suffering and expectations of weak counteraggression. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Williams, Robert L.: U. Tennessee, Coll. of Education

column19: Appraised the effects of 5 treatment conditions (contingent teacher reinforcement, peer reinforcement, role modeling, group process) and control on 2 major dimensions of interracial harmony, biracial sociometric measures and biracial behavioral interaction. 60 racial isolates in 5 racially balanced classes of a metropolitan junior high school served as Ss. A main effect positive change was obtained on both the sociometric and behavioral measures. Differences between groups in amount of change were statistically nonsignificant. However, the raw data indicate that the control group made the least improvement of any treatment group on both dependent variables. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The role of intermarriage in the acculturation of selected urban American Indian women.
column12: Wagner, Jean K.: Long Island U
column13: Anthropologica. Vol.18(2), 1976, pp. 215-229.
column19: Considers intermarriage with Whites as a measure for estimating extent of acculturation. 17 American Indian women living in New York City were classified in 3 groups: 4 were tradition-oriented, 2 were American middle class, and 11 were transitional. Classification was based on personal interviews, participant observation, voluntary association in meetings and other groups, and a sociocultural schedule. Strong association was noted between acculturation level and frequency of contact with the Indian community. Another strong indicator was choice of companions. Tradition-oriented women sought out other Indians, whereas the more assimilated tended not to socialize with Indians except for immediate kin. No close correspondence appeared between degree of Indian blood and intermarriage. Degree of individual acculturation appears to depend on several factors, including the influence of the Indian parents, some of whom desire assimilation for their children, and contact with White leaders. Modifying influences include family relationships and personal identification as an Indian, plus 2 factors assuming added importance today: mass media emphasis on freedom in choice of life-style and the Pan Indian movement. (French summary) (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Reports the successful treatment of 3 Black women patients of widely differing psychopathology for whom a traditional analysis was the treatment of choice. In all cases the onset of persistent erotic and masochistic feelings towards the analyst was rapid. Color difference was a central focus of transference resistance. Detailed knowledge of early traumata and their specific associations with color are considered valuable in assessing feasibility of interracial analysis. Countertransference must be closely scrutinized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial dynamics in a Southern rural senior center.
column9:
Yearwood, Ann W

Dressel, Paula L
column12: Yearwood, Ann W.: Westwood Academy, Thomaston, GA
column13: The Gerontologist. Vol.23(5), Oct 1983, pp. 512-517.
column19: Examined interracial dynamics among White and Black participants in a Southern rural senior center who had been socialized to a paternalistic model of race relations. Data were collected through participant observation over a period of 2 yrs and through formal interviews with 11 participants and 3 staff members. Findings show that general cooperation was interspersed with sporadic racial antagonism. Cooperation was promoted at first through shared activities and later through shared antagonism toward the center manager. Participants used a variety of justifications for their attendance at an integrated setting, including religion, the perception that age was a leveler of individuals, and the claim of being a helper rather than a receiver of services. Implications for the management of senior citizens' centers are discussed. (31 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:
Thune, Jeanne M

Webb, Celia R

Thune, Leland E

column19: Interracial prejudice as it occurs within young, middle-aged, and old blacks and whites and the degree to which prejudice is affected both by episodes of civil violence and by the passage of time have been the focus of a continuing program of research in the Southern city of Nashville, Tennessee. Data indicate that while age affects racial attitudes, particualrly the attitudes of white Southerners, race is an even stronger determiner of prejudice. There were significant differences in the degree of prejudice expressed by blacks and whites of all age groups, the magnitude of these differences increasing systematically across age groups due primarily to the higher prejudice of older whites. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Explores what happened when members of 3 ethnic groups spent 18 hr. together in an encounter weekend. A facilitation style that placed the major responsibility for group progress on the group itself brought about marked behavioral changes among group participants as the group progressed from distrust, suspicion, and violent rhetoric to effective communication and understanding. The interracial encounter is considered a powerful tool in the development of humanity and respect for others. Excerpts of dialog are included. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effects of classroom racial composition on students' interracial friendliness.
column9:
Hallinan, Maureen T

Smith, Stevens S
column12: Hallinan, Maureen T.: U Notre Dame
column13: Social Psychology Quarterly. Vol.48(1), Mar 1985, pp. 3-16.
column19: Examined the effects of the racial composition of a classroom on 257 Black and 216 White 4th-7th grade students' cross-race and same-race friendships. Two theories of interracial sociability were considered. The 1st argues that interracial friendliness is affected primarily by the number of opportunities students have for cross-race interaction relative to same-race interaction; it predicts that students in the numerical minority are likely to make more cross-race friendship choices than those in the majority. The 2nd theory claims that the racial minority is socially threatened by the majority and tends to isolate itself from the more dominant and powerful other race. These predictions were examined over a school year in a longitudinal data set of Ss in 18 desegregated classes. The results of sociometric questionnaires given at 6 time points over the school year provide strong support for the opportunity hypothesis and show little evidence that being in the racial minority diminishes interracial friendliness. Cross-sectional analyses showed that as the proportion of 1 racial group in the classroom increased, the friendlier the Ss of the other race were toward members of that racial group. (32 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Cooperative groups, weak ties, and the integration of peer friendships.
column12: Hansell, Stephen: Rutgers U, New Brunswick
column13: Social Psychology Quarterly. Vol.47(4), Dec 1984, pp. 316-328.
column19: Investigated the strength of ties between students of different races and sexes and tested a cooperative-group intervention designed to increase weak ties between naturally occurring peer groups. Ss were 5th- and 6th-grade students from an inner-city school; 117 Ss were in control classrooms, and 200 were in experimental classrooms. The sample was 53% White, 47% Black, 56% male, and 44% female. All classes studied a 10-wk language mechanics curriculum on grammar, punctuation, and English usage. The treatment was composed of an interdependent cooperative-task structure and a cooperative-reward structure that enabled the Ss to learn about each other as individuals. Results support several hypotheses derived from the theory of the strength of weak ties. Friendships between races and sexes tended to be weak rather than strong, and ties between peer groups also tended to be weak. The cooperative-group intervention stimulated new weak ties between students of different race and sex. However, these did not form a bridge between groups but instead were concentrated within existing peer groups. Findings confirm that cooperative groups stimulate new weak ties between individuals of different race and sex but raise doubts about whether this intervention directly improves intergroup relations among preexisting peer groups. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The racial context of Black self-esteem.
column12: Krause, Neal: U Texas Medical Branch, Galveston
column13: Social Psychology Quarterly. Vol.46(2), Jun 1983, pp. 98-107.
column19: Tested the thesis that increased contact with Whites results in a decrease in feelings of self-worth among Blacks. A more precise measure of racial contact and a more rigorous statistical approach than previous researchers have employed was used to examine a structural equation model of the effects of interracial contact on Black self-esteem. Data from M. Rosenberg and R. Simmons's (1972) study were analyzed. 761 elementary school Blacks, 302 junior high school Blacks, and 202 Blacks in high school in 1968 served as Ss. Negative and positive self-esteem were analyzed, and measures of racial content included a component that reflected both Black and White students. Findings indicate that interracial contact was not related to self-esteem, suggesting that increased contact with Whites has little systematic effect on Black self-esteem. (26 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Producing equal-status interracial interaction: A replication.
column12: Riordan, Cornelius: Providence Coll
column13: Social Psychology Quarterly. Vol.43(1), Mar 1980, pp. 131-136.
column19: Reports a replication study of a recent experiment by E. G. Cohen and S. S. Roper (1972) that attempted to produce equal-status contact between Black and White junior high school boys in a controlled laboratory setting. Ss' interactions during a criterion task game were analyzed. The present findings from 320 Black and White junior high school boys lend general support to those abtained by Cohen and Roper. Results indicate that equal-status contact should not be assumed when Blacks and Whites interact, even when variables like socioeconomic status, age, and sex are controlled. Rather, equal status is a condition that can be achieved when the expectations of both Blacks and Whites are treated in advance of the interaction, or (though not found in the original experiment) when Black expectations alone are given a particularly powerful treatment. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Social Psychology Quarterly. Vol.42(3), Sep 1979, pp. 280-284.
column19: Interracial interaction patterns were observed in a new school that was selected for study because its 6th and 7th grades came close to meeting the conditions G. W. Allport (1954) specified as conducive to improved intergroup relations. The school's 8th grade, however, did not meet these conditions since its students were divided into a predominantly White accelerated track and a predominantly Black regular track. A previous study by the author and H. A. Sagar (1977), which was carried out during the school's 1st yr, found that racial clustering in the school's cafeteria decreased over the course of the year in the 7th grade, but increased in the 8th grade (Schofield and Sagar, 1977). The present paper reports on the interracial behavior of the previously studied 7th graders as they moved through the essentially segregated 8th grade. Compared to students who entered the school's 8th grade the previous year from largely segregated schools, these students interacted more across racial lines. Nevertheless, they showed decreasing interaction during the 8th grade, as had their counterparts the previous year. (12 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Singer, Leslie M.: Rutgers U
column13: Child Development. Vol.56(6), Dec 1985, pp. 1543-1551.
column19: Combined data from 2 samples using M. D. Ainsworth's (1978) strange situation paradigm to assess the quality of attachment relationships in adoptive and nonadoptive mother-infant pairs. Infants were aged 13-18 mo at the time of observation. Ss included 27 nonadopted infants, 27 intraracial adopted infants, and 19 interracial adopted infants. Results indicate no differences in mother-infant attachment between nonadopted and intraracial adopted Ss or between intraracial and interracial adopted Ss. Interracial adoptive mother-infant pairs did show a higher incidence of insecure attachment in comparison to nonadoptive pairs. Mothers of interracial adopted infants also were less comfortable having others care for their babies and perceived less emotional support from extended family and friends for their decision to adopt a child prior to the actual adoption than did other mothers. No relation was found, however, between quality of mother-infant attachment and either perceived social support, infant development quotient, infant temperament, number of foster homes experienced by the infant, or infant's age at the time of adoption placement. It is suggested that the higher incidence of psychological problems found among adoptees in middle childhood and adolescence cannot be explained in terms of insecure attachment relationships during the infancy years. (53 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Recognizing the complex social and psychological forces involved in certain current social problems, some of the intrapsychic factors involved in sexual interest between races, I.e., the preference of a white woman for a black partner, are considered. Through the use of a case example of a 25-yr-old white female with a history of promiscuity with preference for black men is discussed in reference to the concept "black is beautiful." this is described as an elaborate disguise of the s's incestuous interest in her father as well as an ego-syntonic means of expressing both libidinal and aggressive impulses. Her degradation of the man is concealed by her elevation of him to a special position of beauty. The polarities of black and white are discussed in relationship to concepts of beauty and attitudes toward good and evil. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Investigated the role of 2 types of similarity (attitude similarity and dialect style) on interpersonal attitudes and behaviors in a face-to-face interaction. Sixty White female undergraduates interacted with an experimental confederate who was either Black or White, spoke either standard White English or a Black dialect, and whom the S perceived as agreeing or disagreeing on an attitude questionnaire. Ss' nonverbal behavior during the interaction was coded using immediacy cues, and attitudes toward the confederate were measured through a questionnaire following the interaction. Ss showed more favorable attitudes toward the White than Black confederate and had more positive attitudes toward the Black confederate when she spoke White English. Contrary to previous findings, no significant main effect was found for belief similarity. While no significant mean differences were obtained between conditions for the nonverbal measures, correlations between these measures and a measure of liking/friendship indicated that this relationship differed depending on the race of the confederate and the dialect used. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Do "They all look alike"? The effect of race, sex, experience, and attitudes on the ability to recognize faces.
column12: Brigham, John C.: Florida State U
column13: Journal of Applied Social Psychology. Vol.8(4), Oct-Dec 1978, pp. 306-318.
column19: Legal scholars and social scientists have long assumed that there is a racial bias in facial recognition and eyewitness identifications, with persons being much more accurate in identifying persons of their own race, but corroborative research evidence is scanty. In the present study, 86 Black and 76 White college students attempted to identify which of a series of facial photos they had seen earlier. As predicted, a strong Race of S by Race of Picture interaction was found; both Black and White Ss were significantly more accurate in identifying pictures of their own race than pictures of the other race. However, contrary to assumptions made by many legal and criminal justice personnel, neither racial attitude nor reported amount of quality of interracial experience were related to ability to recognize pictures. Implications for eyewitness identifications of these and related findings are discussed. (23 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: In Phase I, black and white adolescent males made semantic differential ratings of 14 concepts representing a wide range of values. Mother, father, girls, TV, God, police, and next year yielded profiles significantly different for the 2 racial groups. In Phase II, 28 blacks and 28 whites each attempted to decode the profiles of 1 black and 1 white other. For combined racial groups, accuracy was greater when the other was semantically similar. Disregarding semantic similarity, accuracy was greater when the other was of the same race. Semantic similarity made little difference, however, when both encoder and decoder were black. Whites excelled in decoding the profiles of other whites where concepts were commonly encoded by both racial groups, while blacks were more accurate interracially where concepts were differentially encoded by the 2 racial groups. Results are related to the assumption of a standard set of meanings for whites and a standard-nonstandard dual system for blacks. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Data were collected from 677 students in 2 schools serving Grades 6, 7, and 8. The 1st school provided formal and informal cross-group contact opportunities similar to those described by G. W. Allport (1954) as essential in the reduction of prejudice. The 2nd school did not provide contact opportunities. Multivariate analyses of variance (MANOVAs) revealed significant differences between the 2 schools in both cross- and within-race communication. In both schools, White and Black females were found to occupy distinctive social roles. column5: The impact of school desegregation programs on White public-school enrollment, 1968-1976.
column12: Wilson, Franklin D.: U Wisconsin, Ctr for Demography & Ecology, Madison
column13: Sociology of Education. Vol.58(3), Jul 1985, pp. 137-153.
column19: Examines the findings of a national study of the impact of school desegregation programs on White public school enrollment trends in school districts grouped according to region, metropolitan status, and source of pressure to desegregate. The analysis showed that the increased exposure of White pupils to Black pupils (or interracial contact) substantially affected the demography of school systems and led to reductions in White enrollment. Moreover, the adverse effect of increased interracial contact was not limited to school districts that had implemented desegregation programs, although these districts experienced an accelerated rate of White enrollment decline. White enrollment losses appeared to be short-term, limited primarily to the year a desegregation program was implemented. Findings imply that White enrollment trends are sensitive not to the programmatic components of desegregation strategies but rather to the amount of change in interracial contact that such strategies bring about. (49 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Discusses behavioral science as it relates to planned change, the significance of symbols and metaphors for analyzing problems, the value of individualism, and relationships and networks. For example, rather than eliminating racism in individuals, one must alter the structure and opportunities of interracial interaction. When people become aware of better economic opportunities, the young, the old, the uneducated, and the unemployed express more depressive symptoms upon realizing that there are some structural barriers to a better way of life. column5: The significance of the colors black and white in the dreams of Black and White patients.

column19: Spontaneous references to the colors black and white in 308 dreams from 3 Black females (2 in analysis and 1 in psychotherapy) and 294 dreams from 2 White males and 1 White female (all in analysis) were analyzed. Ss exhibited a low incidence of spontaneous mention of colors other than black and white in their dreams. The relationship of this phenomenon to problems encountered in interracial analysis are discussed. Results of the reference analysis indicate that Ss unconsciously used the colors black and white in dreams and fantasies as transference resistance in interracial analysis. Ss also had unconsciously organized problems in self-object differentiation, identity sense development, and intrapsychic conflict in dreams and fantasies through the use of black and white imagery. These colors were also utilized by Ss for defensive camouflage and to depict contrasting moods such as depression and elation. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Data on interracial behavior and opinion change were obtained from large samples of Black and White students in all the public high schools in Indianapolis. Results show that negative behaviors (avoidance and unfriendly interaction) were affected most by factors such as personal aggressiveness, initial racial attitudes, and racial attitudes of family and peers, all of which have little to do with the amount and conditions of interracial contact. Friendly interactions, on the other hand, were affected by opportunities for interracial contact within and prior to the high school. Equal status between students of different race was not important in determining positive or negative outcomes of interracial contact. It is concluded that the determinants of interracial behavior may differ in important ways from determinants of opinion change about members of another race. column19: Conducted a field experiment with 70 Black and White early- and pre-adolescents to contrast 2 treatments ("expectation training" and "learning center") for producing equal-status behavior in the 2 groups. It was hypothesized that expectation training would be more powerful than learning center. Effects of treatment were measured immediately after the intervention and again after 3 wks of classroom experience with a cooperative curriculum. It was also hypothesized that the experience of social interaction in these specially structured classrooms would act to maintain the effects of the initial treatment. Results show equal-status behavior in the students experiencing both treatments on the 1st measurement. The final measurement indicated some treatment differences, with a pattern of White dominance reappearing in the female learning center. There was a tendency toward Black-domination in male expectation training in the long run. Test of the 2nd hypothesis indicated that the classroom phase was associated with no significant changes in Black initiation rates over time. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial ratios and proximity in dormitories: Attitudes of university students.
column12: Bennett, Don C.: Indiana U
column13: Environment and Behavior. Vol.6(2), Jun 1974, pp. 212-232.
column19: Surveyed 432 white and 92 black undergraduates, integrated in university dormitories, and representing 5% of the whites and 20% of the blacks in the dormitories, regarding their opinions about interracial proximities and proportionalities. Both groups indicated they could feel comfortable with a higher percentage of the other race present than they preferred. However, blacks required fewer persons of their own race on their floors or in their buildings to feel comfortable than did whites. Both groups agreed that it was uncomfortable to be the only person attitudes their race on a floor or in a building. Both groups expressed preference for at least 50% occupancy by persons of their own race on their floor or in their building. A sizable minority in each group preferred own-group numerical dominance to 75% or more of the total. Interracial room-sharing, an unfamiliar experience for Ss, was acceptable, but objections to room-sharing were greater among blacks. A majority of both groups believed that voluntary segregation had occurred in the dormitories. Voluntary segregation was perceived as desirable by blacks, undesirable by whites. Previous interracial contacts, and intraracial sex differences in attitudes, are also presented. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Describes pilot studies in which an instrument to measure belief polarity, the Belief Polarity Scale, was developed and validated. This instrument and the Rokeach Dogmatism Scale were administered to 42 Black and 34 White educators prior to an interracial human relations workshop. Several days following the conclusion of this 2-wk conference, the Belief Polarity Scale was again administered. column19: Examined the effect of racial dissimilarity on the evaluative attitude of Black Ss. 186 males and females participated in a simulated jury experiment in which the race of the victim, the race of the defendant, and the amount of evidence against the defendant were varied. Ss read transcripts of either an interracial or an intraracial forcible rape case against the defendant and then evaluated the defendant on certain trait dimensions. Results indicate that the racial similarity of the defendant and/or the victim to the S jurors influenced the level of negative traits attributed to the defendant. Results strongly indicate that prejudicial social evaluation of the outgroup is a 2-sided phenomenon. Interaction effects indicate that factors such as the context under which the evaluative behavior took place, sex affiliation, the victim's race, and the level of evidence tended to influence trait attribution to a dissimilar other. The results are discussed in the context of prejudicial trait attribution to a dissimilar defendant and the possible effects of such attitude on jury decision-making. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Reviews the book, Transracial Adoption: A Follow-Up by Rita J. Simon and Howard Altstein (1981). Embedded in the subject of transracial adoption is one of the key paradoxes of treatment programs: can a service be good for the individual but bad for the group? Or, conversely, good for the group but bad for the individual? Furthermore, can criteria for program evaluation incorporate the variable of time? Good for now but bad for later? In this book, however, Simon and Altstein boldly take on the paradox and try to deal with both interpersonal and policy questions. Not surprisingly, they do not come up with definitive answers, but it is to their credit that the attempt is made. Although they are candid in reporting problem areas, the authors continue to see transracial adoption as a means of helping to counteract the problems of homeless children. They emphasize, however, that their survey is not finished and the answers are not all in. This volume, then, is essentially an interim progress report, bolstered with background information on current adoption issues. It is useful for professionals who wish a balanced current view of issues, and who want current data on continuing research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Contact and conflict in intergroup encounters.
column12: Hewstone, Miles: U Bristol, Lecturer in Psychology, Bristol, England
column13: (1986). Contact and conflict in intergroup encounters. xiii, 231 pp. Cambridge, MA, US: Basil Blackwell; US.
column19: (from the jacket) It has always been assumed that contact between members of different groups does improve relations between them. Indeed, this view has been the basis of many social policy decisions advocating integration in schools, housing and sports. Yet the reported effects of this contact hypothesis have often been inconsistent. Many studies have failed to find a reduction of prejudice following interracial contact; others have yielded more positive results. Perhaps the most persistent problem is that all too often interpersonal contact fails to reduce intergroup conflict. The contributors to this book assess the contact hypothesis in situations of intergroup encounter. They pay close attention to the durability of positive effects-whether harmony between groups endures-and present an incisive and realistic picture of social-psychological contributions to the reduction of conflict. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Presents a case in which riot-melee charges were brought against 5 teenage members of an all-Black church in southern Arizona. A sociological expert witness was requested by the legal defense team. The discussion includes the following: (1) the nature of the request; (2) the definition of the situation to determine if serving as a sociological expert witness was an appropriate role; (3) excerpts from the recorded testimony, demonstrating the use of symbolic interactionist emergent norm theory, as an explanation for the defendents' behavior; (4) the disposition of the case; (5) the inherent interventionist advocacy role in expert witnessing; and (6) the implications of sociological intervention by means of the sociological expert witness role, which has long been the primary province of psychology and psychiatry. column19: Reviews the US Supreme Court's decisions concerning factors that should be taken into account in evaluating the validity of eyewitness evidence. column19: Suggests that the racial dilemma may be the number one mental health problem in the US. Unusually intense projection processes and group-related paranoias initiate and maintain slave and ghetto cultures and determine behaviors related to them. Causes of discrimination are discussed as primary causes in biology, secondary causes in socialization processes, and tertiary causes in contrived social structures. Black-White interactions in the US are discussed as analogous to marital and family interactions. column19: Presents an assessment and intervention program designed to serve mixed-race children who experience racial identity problems, with emphasis on the linkage among the school, home, and community. A case example of a 7-yr-old boy with a White mother and a Black father shows the role of school social workers in assessing problems and assisting these children to develop positive racial self-concepts and successful school adjustment. Two basic processes involved in the development of racial identity are discussed-racial conception and racial evaluation. To promote prevention, school social workers should develop ways to identify students who are at-risk for racial-identity problems even before those problems may be manifested, and develop skills for assessing and intervening in family and organizational dynamics related to racial-identity issues. column13: American Journal of Sociology. Vol.91(6), May 1986, pp. 1409-1430.
column19: Tested several hypotheses derived from P. M. Blau's theory of social structure (1977) on data with 2 distinct forms of intergroup association-interracial marriage (IM) and interracial crime (IC)-for 25 US metropolitan communities. The results show considerable support for Blau's theory, suggesting that the general macrostructural framework can be profitably applied to disparate forms of social behavior. Moderate, positive correlations are found between rates of IM and IC. Both IM and IC are influenced significantly by at least 1 of the following social structural conditions: group size, heterogeneity, intergroup inequality, and segregation. However, the effects of social structure vary by the form of association. The rate of IM is positively affected by the degree of racial income equality, whereas IC rates are more strongly influenced by relative group size and racial residential segregation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Investigated the incidence of psychological problems among offspring (mean age 16.87 yrs) of interracial/intercultural marriages. As part of a study of cognitive abilities, members of biological families from 4 of the major racial/ethnic groups living in Hawaii were also administered the Adjective Check List. Offspring of within-group (n = 1,024) vs across-racial/ethnic (n = 180) marriages generally did not differ in personality test scores. Male offspring of across-group marriages scored higher on a factor measuring socially desirable traits and lower on a factor measuring intraception, while female offspring of across-group marriages were more extraverted. Community acceptance of across-group marriages in Hawaii is discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Studied intraracial and interracial robbery victimization rates for a sample of 25 cities to test hypotheses derived from economic deprivation and macrostructural opportunity theories. Robbery victimization rates were computed separately for 4 race-of-victim/race-of-offender combinations. The effects of variables important to the 2 theories were evaluated through multiple regression analysis. Results provide strong support for the macrostructural theory but little support for the economic deprivation theory. It was found that, while both relative group size and residential segregation were related to victimization rates in a manner consistent with macrostructural theory, neither the poverty measure nor the measure of racial inequality exhibited associations with the dependent variables. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: In a survey of 34 female and 44 male Black unmarried college students attending 2 largely White Southern universities, it was hypothesized that Black men would engage in interracial dating more frequently than Black women and that students who preferred to date Blacks would have more favorable perceptions of Blacks than students who preferred to date both Blacks and Whites. Responses to a dating survey and the Adjective Checklist showed that more Black males preferred to date interracially than Black women but were not currently doing so. The 2nd hypothesis was not confirmed. Overall, most Ss, regardless of sex, seriously and casually dated within their race. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Communication: A unique significance for law enforcement.

column13: (1986). Communication: A unique significance for law enforcement. xvi, 216 pp. Springfield, IL, England: Charles C Thomas, Publisher; England.
column19:
(from the cover) The premise that everything the law enforcement officer does either employs or is accomplished through effective communication is the basis of this important work. Maintaining that improvement in the quality of communication will improve the quality of law enforcement, the authors examine the practical application of listening, interviewing, small-group communication, public speaking and nonverbal elements of communication; and address such inherent barriers as cultural, racial, and personal differences. Other problems of communication-ethics, psychological and semantic barriers, and territorial imperatives-are also discussed. Attention is focused on specific problems and solutions within law enforcement departments, between departments, and in community relations.
(from the preface) It is, therefore, the intent and purpose of this book to provide for law enforcement officers a textbook that can aid in the improvement of all of their communication activities, especially oral communication. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The social psychology of education: Current research and theory.
column12: Feldman, Robert S.: U Massachusetts, Dept of Psychology, Amherst, MA, US
column13: (1986). The social psychology of education: Current research and theory. ix, 381 pp. New York, NY, US: Cambridge University Press; US.
column19: (from the jacket) This book examines the ways in which the theory and data of social psychology can be applied to teaching, learning, and other experiences in schools. Its focus ranges in level from the individual (e.g., student attitudes and attributions), to teacher-student interaction, to the impact of society (e.g., racial and cultural influences on school performances). This book has 2 major purposes. The first is to illustrate the scope and sophistication of the emerging field known as the social psychology of education. The second is to provide solid, informed suggestions to educators for the amelioration of current educational problems. To that end, each author explicitly discusses implications for educational practice. This book is intended for psychologists and educational researchers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Helping and the avoidance of inappropriate interracial behavior: A strategy that perpetuates a nonprejudiced self-image. [References].
column9:
Frey, David L

Gaertner, Samuel L
column12: Frey, David L.: U Delaware
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.50(6), Jun 1986, pp. 1083-1090.
column19: Investigated the view that racial prejudice among White Americans today is often expressed in subtle, indirect, and rationalizable ways. Whites may therefore regard themselves as unprejudiced and nondiscriminatory as they continue to disadvantage minorities. It was hypothesized that Whites would be less helpful to Blacks only when normative guidelines within the situation suggest that the failure to help would be justifiable and not necessarily inappropriate. However, Whites would not discriminate against Blacks when the failure to help would be clearly inappropriate. In the present experiment, the normative guidelines regarding the appropriateness of helping was varied by manipulating the causal locus of the recipient's need (internal or external) and the source of the helping request (the recipient or a 3rd-party observer). Supportive of the hypotheses, Ss' (130 White female university students) helping behavior discriminated against Black recipients only in the condition in which the recipients' needs were caused by their failure to work hard and the requests were issued by the recipients themselves (i.e., when the failure to help would not be regarded as particularly inappropriate). (46 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Behavior, motivation, and achievement in desegregated junior high school science classes. [References].
column9:
Hall, Vernon C

Merkel, Steven

Howe, Anne

Lederman, Norman
column12: Hall, Vernon C.: Syracuse U, Coll of Arts & Sciences
column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.78(2), Apr 1986, pp. 108-115.
column19: To locate possible antecedents for racial differences in science achievement, measures of mathematics and reading achievement, causal attribution, attitude toward school success, and in-class behavior were acquired from 40 Black and 40 White junior high school students, both groups evenly divided between males and females. Significant group differences were limited to mean achievement test scores and science grades. Achievement scores were significantly related to grades, but classroom behaviors also accounted for a significant and unique portion of the variance. There were no significant relationships between behaviors and other student measures. Teacher ratings of effort, ability, course difficulty, and environment were also acquired. Teachers rated Whites as smarter and believed that Black females exerted the greatest effort and Black males the least. As a secondary interest, number and type of student interactions were recorded. Few hostile interracial encounters were observed, and interactions were predominately within race. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Problems in the study of interracial interaction: Pseudo-interracial dyad paradigm. [References].
column12: Chidester, Thomas R.: U Texas, Austin
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.50(1), Jan 1986, pp. 74-79.
column19: Reviews 3 lines of research that describe behavior in interracial settings in terms of hypothesis-testing, compensation strategies, or repressed affect. It is argued that the perspectives make divergent predictions about the process and outcomes of interracial interaction, but these predictions have not been tested because of the differing paradigms associated with each perspective's supporting research. An experiment employing pseudo-interracial dyads is reported that appears to resolve some of the competing hypotheses. 70 White undergraduates participated in indirect target-perceiver dyads in which the stated race of the target was varied. In 2 additional phases of the experiment, 6 undergraduates rated the target or both the target and perceiver on the basis of audiotapes. Problems with the procedure suggest that the pseudo-interracial dyads paradigm cannot answer several important questions about Ss' use of stereotypes and responses to requests to evaluate Black targets and lacks external and construct validity. (12 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1985, Vol 30(2), 146-147. Reviews the book, Black Marriage and Family Therapy edited by Constance E. Obudho (1983). There has clearly been a paucity of published, empirically based research on Black unions. The editor of this book set out to expand on the literature by assembling a collection of chapters on the complexities of Black couples' relationships and on marital therapy with Black males and females. Overall, the editor succeeds in highlighting the fact that Black marital relationships can be maintained successfully in spite of the demand to cope with oppressive conditions, and she underscores some of the limitations of traditional thinking and research on Blacks. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: (from the chapter) This chapter evaluated the insulation hypothesis by assessing whether levels of self-esteem among Black school children decrease as the amount of contact with Whites increases. If this hypothesis is true, the mechanisms by which this effect operates also must be examined. In the analysis, the three aspects of the dissonant school environment were used to explain why Blacks experience lower levels of self-esteem as they come into contact with Whites. A random sample of Black students (grades 3-12) responded to the influence of self-esteem and racial contact. Results reveal that although racial contact does exert a slight effect on self-esteem, in no instance are any of the effects statistically significant. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

McAdoo, Harriette Pipes [Ed]

column12: McAdoo, Harriette Pipes: Howard U, School of Social Work, Washington, DC, US
column13: (1985). Black children: Social, educational, and parental environments. 279 pp. Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; US.
column19: (from the preface) This book was designed to explore in depths what unique experiences and situations that are common to Black children and their parents. The volume was developed within the framework that all children during their childhood-regardless of race, ethnicity, social class, or gender- must complete similar developments tasks if they are to become competent adults. Therefore, the book does not attempt to duplicate the information that will be found in a comprehensive developmental textbook. Instead, it documents how these developmental tasks are uniquely experienced in the environments of children's growth and development.-PP This book has been developed around the themes of the significant environments within the lives of Black children. There are two major assumptions made as this book is developed: One is related to the economic environment of many Black children and the other is related to the negative images that are carried about Black children by members of the wider society. The environments that were selected to be developed in detail are as follows: the theoretical environment; the socioeconomic environment; the educational environment; the parental environment and racial socialization; and the internal environments of children's racial attitudes and self-esteem. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: A comparative study of swingers and nonswingers: Attitudes and beliefs.
column12: Jenks, Richard J.: Indiana U Southeast, New Albany, IN, US
column13: Lifestyles. Vol.8(1), Fal 1985, pp. 5-20.
column19: Using cognitive dissonance theory it was hypothesized that swingers would be more liberal on items which directly relate to sex and sexual "deviance." As the issues become less relevant to sex, however, this liberalism was hypothesized to disappear. 114 swingers and 114 nonswingers completed a questionnaire containing groups of items ranging from directly relevant to totally irrelevant to sex. Results indicate general support for the hypotheses, with the biggest differences between the two groups occurring on the sexual items (premarital sex, birth control, abortion, homosexuality, pornography, sex on TV, and satisfaction with own sex life). Differences also appeared on issues related to marriage and the family (divorce, interracial marriage, and sex) and religion. Three questions relevant to women's roles produced contradictory results. Eleven items concerning political and economic issues revealed four significant differences. Here, swingers were more liberal on the legalization of marijuana but more conservative on capital punishment, welfare, and controlling business. Finally, a breakdown on all the items by sex revealed the females to be more satisfied with their friends and their sex life, and the males to be more in favor of the women staying at home. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column19: Incorporating scholarship in interpersonal, intercultural, and media communication, a model of TV interracial interactions is presented that discerns 3 attributes of relational messages: independent, dependent, and interdependent. Each attribute is typified by behaviors that indicate the quality and levels of involvement between interactants. An application of the model indicates that the model can be usefully employed and suggests that TV viewers are watching and learning communication practices and patterns that do not facilitate deep friendships, intimate relationships, and close cooperation between Blacks and Whites. column5: Effects of sex and race on interracial dating preferences.
column12: Korolewicz, Mitchell: City U New York, City Coll
column13: Psychological Reports. Vol.57(3, Pt 2), Dec 1985, pp. 1291-1296.
column19: 32 undergraduates from New Jersey and 32 undergraduates from Mississippi, evenly divided between Black and White and male and female, completed an interracial dating-preference questionnaire consisting of dating scenarios involving White and Black participants, White participants only, and Black participants only. A 2-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) showed that sex and race affected interracial dating preferences. Blacks, particularly Black females, were more apt to prefer interracial dating than Whites. Among the Whites, males tended to prefer interracial dating more than females. Findings do not confirm the findings of F. Petroni (1973), who reported that Black females were the least likely to date interracially. It is suggested that the present results may differ from those of Petroni because Petroni investigated behavior and the present study examined attitudes. The scenarios used on the questionnaire are appended. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: How ethnicity and religion affect attitudes towards mixed marriages.
column12: Caltabiano, Nerina J.: James Cook U of North Queensland, Townsville, Australia
column13: Australian Journal of Sex, Marriage & Family. Vol.6(4), Nov 1985, pp. 221-229.
column19: A survey schedule of Townsville and Thuringowa Shire (Australia) residents allowed attitudes on interethnic and interreligious marriages to be assessed. 411 15-82 yr old respondents selected on an equal probability basis were interviewed. Attitudes toward mixed marriages were assessed by investigating 2 independent variables-ethnicity and religious denomination. Both age and ethnicity were found to have independent effects on attitudes toward mixed marriages. The religious denomination/mixed marriage relationship was significant for the middle socioeconomic status (SES) group, for those involved in a relationship, and for the religious. Overall, respondents were willing to encourage nationally mixed marriages and did not perceive religious intermarriages to be serious problems. Both types of mixed marriages were equally acceptable. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Ginter, Melanie A
column12: Trickett, Edison J.: U Maryland, College Park
column13: American Journal of Community Psychology. Vol.13(6), Dec 1985, pp. 617-643.
column19: Evaluated the impact on 236 students in New Haven, Connecticut public schools who requested attendance at a public alternative high school. By lottery, half the students were assigned to the alternative school and half remained in the traditional school. Two cohorts of students, in 2 consecutive years, were evaluated with standardized instruments as well as with instruments developed within the study's context. The nature of the alternative school environment is described, and the outcome of the experiment is defined in terms of reactions to school, social attitude change and personal qualities, and student achievement. In general, the alternative school positively affected Ss' satisfaction with a variety of aspects of school life and induced some positive changes in interracial attitudes, while not harming student achievement. Effects linked to race were found in the areas of achievement and interracial attitudes. (45 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Investigating ethnic prejudices among boys and girls in a therapeutic community for maladjusted children and modifying some prejudices: Can basic prejudices be changed?
column13: School Psychology International. Vol.6(4), Oct-Dec 1985, pp. 239-243.
column19: Studied ethnic prejudices by administering a 10-item scale of interpersonal tolerance 4 times to 40 9-16 yr olds who were placed in a UK residential community because of maladjustments. Ss were either assigned to 1-2 weekly group therapy sessions on such topics as developing racial tolerance and received individual sessions or received no firm regime encouraging interracial tolerance. At 3 and 6 mo and on leaving the community, Ss in the experimental group showed increased racial/personal tolerance that was maintained and increased throughout the period. Possible reasons for the change in the experimental group include strong leadership, staff backing, and warm but firm treatment while modifying prejudices and including Ss in regular formal and informal discussions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racist attitudes about intimate relationships between Blacks and Whites in the Netherlands.
column12: With, J.: State U of Utrecht, Inst of Social Psychology, Netherlands
column13: Gedrag: Tijdschrift voor Psychologie. Vol.13(6), 1985, pp. 10-28.
column19: Questioned Black and White males and females living in Amsterdam, Rotterdam, The Hague, and Utrecht about their attitudes toward heterosexual noncasual intimate relationships between Blacks and Whites in the Netherlands. Data from 660 responses to a questionnaire assessing the degree of hypogamy and data from another questionnaire assessing racist attitudes were analyzed in 2 projects, and subjected to analysis of covariance (ANCOVA). Results indicate that men and women, regardless of whether they are Black or White or whether they have a White or Black partner, tend to reject extreme racist attitudes toward intimate relationships between Blacks and Whites. Black males reported more often than did Black females that they had an intimate relationship with a White partner of the opposite sex. Efforts to correlate these and other findings to the various exchange theories have only been partially successful. (Danish abstract) (43 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Postsecondary educational attainment among Whites and Blacks.
column12: Wolfle, Lee M.: Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State U
column13: American Educational Research Journal. Vol.22(4), Win 1985, pp. 501-525.
column19: Examined interracial differences in the educational attainment process between 6,825 White and 433 Black high school seniors using data from the National Longitudinal Study of the High School Class of 1972 (J. Riccobano et al, 1981). K. G. Joreskog and D. Sorbom's (1981) general method for the analysis of covariance structures, a statistical procedure that allows for the control of differential measurement errors in the estimation of structural parameters. The basic model of educational attainment used in the analysis considered education to be a function of father's occupational status, father's education, mother's education, respondent's ability, high school curriculum, and high school grades. Results indicate that social background played a similar role for Whites and Blacks. Increments in background social status variables led to similar increases in educational attainment for Whites and Blacks. Moreover, the effects of personal characteristic variables (ability, curriculum, grades) of Whites and Blacks as they influence educational attainment were also similar for both groups. (48 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Presents an operant paradigm to illustrate a sequential interaction between a Black client and a psychotherapist. The justifiable, defensive reactions of the Black client often are triggered by unconscious racist behaviors and stereotyped attitudes in the White therapist. Paradoxically, the therapist may misinterpret and label this pseudotransference phenomenon on the part of the Black client as pathological. Implications in 4 critical areas are discussed: theory explication, research methodology, assessment models, and graduate training. column5: Breaking the race barrier: The White therapist in interracial psychotherapy.
column12: Minrath, Marilyn: U North Carolina, Chapel Hill
column13: Journal of Psychosocial Nursing and Mental Health Services. Vol.23(8), Aug 1985, pp. 19-24.
column19: Argues that racial and ethnic stereotyping is a defensive maneuver used by patient and therapist to cope with the anxiety aroused by the interracial nature of the relationship. It is noted that through the reflective process of analyzing his/her feelings and reactions to the ethnic minority patient, the White therapist can develop an inner clarity that serves as a resource for coping with the unique conflicts presented in interracial psychotherapy. It is also suggested that exploring the patient's cultural background and inquiring about customs, lifestyle, language, and the use of idioms express the therapist's desire to learn about and understand the sociocultural world of the patient and communicate a genuine interest while nurturing the development of empathy. The case histories of 2 Black males (aged 16 and 28 yrs), a 35-yr-old Black female, and a 24-yr-old Puerto Rican female are presented to illustrate the importance of accepting the patient's individuality in the development of the interracial therapeutic relationship. (13 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Reactions to being helped in cooperating interracial groups: A context effect. [References].
column12: Cook, Stuart W.: U Colorado, Inst of Behavioral Science, Boulder
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.49(5), Nov 1985, pp. 1231-1245.
column19: The respect and liking felt by a member of an interracial work group for a groupmate who provided unreciprocated help was investigated in a 3 x 2 x 2 factorially designed experiment with 84 White male US Air Force trainees. Each S participated with 2 other confederate groupmates (Black or White) in 2 management games involving a simulated railroad business. The 3-member team filled freight orders, kept records of maintenance and shipping expenses, earnings, fines, and the location of all cars. Each S was purposely overloaded with duties, and the confederate reacted with voluntary help, helping only after comments by the observing experimenter, or no help. Group task outcome was varied by arranging for half the team to experience failure and half to experience success. Ss, who were from small towns and rural areas of the southern US, developed significantly greater respect and liking for a groupmate who helped voluntarily than for one who did not help. Respect and liking for a groupmate who helped because instructed to do so by the experimenter was intermediate. There was a nonsignificant trend for Black helpers to be liked more than White helpers. Both Black and White helpers were liked as well when the group failed in its task as when it succeeded. Discussion focuses on the effect of a cooperative group context in reversing the usual decrement in liking for a similar peer who provides unreciprocated help on a task that involves the recipient's self-respect. (61 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Conceptions of racial prejudice: Symbolic racism reconsidered.
column9:
Weigel, Russell H

Howes, Paul W
column12: Weigel, Russell H.: Amherst Coll
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.41(3), Fal 1985, pp. 117-138.
column19: Examined the concept of symbolic racism by measuring continuity and change in racial prejudice in 92 White voters (mean age 42 yrs) in Study 1 and ideology, personality, and generalized prejudice in 110 White residents (mean age 42 yrs) of a rural New England town in Study 2. Instruments were administered during interviews. Results show that (a) the conceptual and empirical distinctions between symbolic racism and "old-fashioned" prejudice have been exaggerated and (b) symbolic racism may be best understood as a symptom of generalized tendencies to derogate out-groups-tendencies associated with a configuration of personal attributes that reflect commitments to conservative sociopolitical values and conventional standards of conduct. Findings are discussed in reference to the persistence of racial prejudice and their implications regarding exposure to and the effects of interracial contact. (64 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interspecific dominance and the foraging behaviour of juncos.
column9:
Millikan, George C

Gaddis, Philip

Pulliam, H. Ronald
column13: Animal Behaviour. Vol.33(2), May 1985, pp. 428-435.
column19: Observed mixed groups of dark-eyed juncos (Junco hyemalis) and grey-headed juncos (Junco caniceps) at baited sites in northern Arizona during the nonbreeding season. In interspecific and interracial conflicts, J. caniceps dorsalis was dominant to J. caniceps caniceps and to 2 races of dark-eyed juncos. J. caniceps dorsalis also fed significantly faster than the other juncos. For both species, feeding rates were approximately the same in large and small mixed-species groups. In larger groups, however, individual grey-headed juncos won conflicts at a higher rate, and individual dark-eyed juncos lost conflicts at a higher rate. Also, dark-eyed juncos fed at a significantly lower rate in groups of grey-headed juncos than in groups of similar size but composed mostly of conspecifics. Residency times and recapture probabilities were similar for the 2 species, suggesting little difference in overwinter survival. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Sexual behavior differences between Black and White students.
column12: Belcastro, Philip A.: City U New York, Borough of Manhattan Community Coll
column13: Journal of Sex Research. Vol.21(1), Feb 1985, pp. 56-67.
column15: Society for the Scientific Study of Sexuality; US
column19: Investigated similarities and differences in sexual behavior patterns of 38 male and 60 female Black undergraduates and 209 male and 258 female White undergraduates. A sexual behavior inventory was utilized to collect data regarding the onset and frequency of numerous sexual behaviors. Overall, the 2 racial groups were more similar than dissimilar in their sexual behavior patterns. A few differences did emerge. Black males had more interracial coital experience than White males, and White males had more masturbatory experience than Black males. White females, when compared to Black females, were more likely to have performed fellatio, used coitus interruptus, and have masturbated a partner. Results suggest that grouping Blacks and Whites into sexual permissiveness categories would be highly reactive to which variables are chosen as criteria. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Describes a program aimed at racial integration that was conceived and implemented by a group of students at the University of Virginia. The organization that grew from the initial concerns of 10 freshmen is outlined, and its purposes-to provide a regular forum for discussion of interracial relations in the university community; to conduct and promote social, political, and informational activities among various racial groups; and to foster interracial understanding and unity-are outlined. Suggestions for establishing similar organizations at other educational institutions are presented. (2 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Nonverbal behavior, race, and the classroom teacher.
column12: Feldman, Robert S.: U Massachusetts, Amherst
column13: Theory Into Practice. Vol.24(1), Win 1985, pp. 45-49.
column15: The Ohio State University Press; US
column19: Discusses differences between Black and White nonverbal communication that can lead to misunderstandings in the classroom. Research on Black and White nonverbal behavior reveals that White and Black North Americans show different patterns of eye-gaze, head nodding, and "back channel" behaviors. The results of research investigating interracial interaction in educational contexts suggest that both White and Black teachers behave more positively toward members of their own race than toward members of other races and that the nonverbal behaviors of teachers are related to their racial attitudes. The mere presence of a White or Black student may be sufficient to evoke the nonverbal behaviors associated with particular attitudes. Teachers should be aware of the fact that students of different races may possess differing communicative codes and of the likely nature of such differences. Teachers should also be aware of their own attitudes and behavior and those situations in which they are likely to display negative behaviors. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Factors influencing adjustment of White faculty in predominantly Black colleges.
column9:
Smith, Susan L

Borgstedt, Kaye W
column12: Smith, Susan L.: Illinois State U, Coll of Arts & Sciences
column13: Journal of Negro Education. Vol.54(2), Spr 1985, pp. 148-163.
column15: Assn of American University Presses/Howard University Press; US
column19: 94 White faculty members (aged primarily 25-64 yrs) at 6 Black colleges completed a mailed questionnaire designed to assess their experiences and attitudes related to their minority/majority role. Items addressed basic demographic data (including professional life), interracial interactions, and current job characteristics. Analysis revealed that White Ss born in the US represented as little as 15% of the faculty. Factor analysis (using data from 81 Ss) yielded 10 dimensions of experience and adjustment. The majority of Ss felt they were socially accepted, had a personal commitment to the goals of the college, were limited in their career advancement, worked under a more rigid administration than would be experienced at a White college, could discuss racial differences with Blacks, and had difficulty separating subjective feelings related to racial disadvantage in grading. Tenured Ss were significantly less likely than nontenured Ss to feel socially accepted and comfortable with administrative policies. Data indicate that race and interracial interaction are more complex than simple predictive relationships with social class or parental attitudes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Development of Interracial Peer Relations. [References].
column12: Ogbu, John U.: Department of Anthropology, University of California, Berkeley, CA, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.29(5), May,  1984
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1984, Vol 29(5), 373-374. Reviews the book, Black and White in School: Trust, Tension, or Tolerance? by Janet Ward Schofield (1982). The book is certainly a good example of ethnography of schooling: the author admirably combines participant observation, interviews, and field experiments to present an intimate portrait of a desegregated school. The author found that interracial relations that developed over a period of three years was "neither the optimistic prediction that would quickly and easily lead to very major gains in interracial harmony and friendship nor the pessimistic one that racial strife would be widespread and disruptive." In conclusion, the book is an important contribution on desegregated schools and interracial relations. The many significant contributions of author's study, however, cannot be overemphasized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Discusses the difficulties experienced by racially, religiously, and/or culturally exogamous stepfamilies and seeks to sensitize mental health professionals to issues specific to treating such families. Effective therapy with these families requires that therapists be sensitive to their personal attitudes, feelings, and beliefs with regard to intermarriage and cognizant of how these can intrude and negatively affect both the therapeutic process and its outcome. The following guidelines for therapy are offered: resist ethnocentric biases, resist temptation to narrow, gain exposure, be sensitive to societal pressures, and be accepting. (25 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Education and intergroup attitudes: Moral enlightenment, superficial democratic commitment, or ideological refinement?
column9:
Jackman, Mary R

Muha, Michael J
column12: Jackman, Mary R.: U Michigan, Ann Arbor
column13: American Sociological Review. Vol.49(6), Dec 1984, pp. 751-769.
column19: It has commonly been assumed that an advanced formal education bestows a more enlightened perspective that is less vulnerable to the narrow appeals of intergroup negativism. Other investigations have argued that education increases commitment to democratic norms, but only at a superficial level. These arguments are reviewed in the present paper and are then tested using national survey data (N = 1,914) on intergroup beliefs, feelings, predispositions for personal contact, and policy orientations of men toward women, of Whites toward Blacks, and of the nonpoor toward the poor. Analysis of the data failed to support the view either that education produces liberation from intergroup negativism or that it produces a superficial democratic commitment. It is argued that in paternalistic relationships that are relatively devoid of conflict, intergroup ideology has a simpler articulation, and the well educated are as unguarded as anyone else in affectionately delineating sharp distinctions between groups. However, when subordinate challenge forces more hostility into the relationship, the well educated are intellectually equipped to lead in the generation of a more sophisticated, refined ideology. In the race context, the well educated are slightly ahead of less educated Whites in developing interracial beliefs, feelings, and personal predispositions that pull back from making sharp categorical distinctions while maintaining critical racial boundaries. (60 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Rape and racial patterns.
column12: LeBeau, James L.: Indiana State U, Terre Haute
column13: Journal of Offender Counseling, Services & Rehabilitation. Vol.9(1-2), Fal-Win 1984, pp. 125-148.
column19: 612 lone-assailant rape cases reported in 1 city between 1971 and 1975 were analyzed to determine whether a temporal variation in racial characteristics of rape within a single city would be evident. A factor controlling for the number of rapes committed by the same offender was entered into the analysis. An overview is presented of previous efforts to identify the racial characteristics of rapists and their victims, focusing on the intraracial assumption, the West phenomenon of Black-White interracial rape, changes in interracial rape, and numerical distortions in offender activity. Results of the present analysis indicate that rape was primarily intraracial during all years except 1971, in which it was predominantly interracial. Further variations were revealed when the racial interactions were classified according to the extent of an offender's assaultive activity. The serial offender, committing at least 2 assaults, complicated the relationship between race and rape, and the extensive assaults of a few individuals influenced the racial characteristics of the crime. Serial assaults by Black offenders suggested that interracial rape is not a unitary concept. Findings illustrate how failing to control for the activities of the series offenders distorts the actual number of offenders of any racial group and consequently over- and underestimates the representation of different racial groups. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Compared the interracial experiences of 112 Black and 82 Hispanic undergraduates attending Texas Tech University and the University of Maryland, College Park. Ss' perceptions of counseling services offered by each institution were also compared. Findings show that Hispanics were more likely than Blacks to have dated or to be currently dating someone of another race and that Blacks were more uncomfortable than Hispanics in 2 of 10 hypothetical situations. Some differences between the students at each of the 2 schools were also found. Overall, Blacks tended to be more similar in behaviors and perceptions across institutions than were Hispanics. Implications for student-affairs administrators are discussed. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Socio-psychological dynamics in pathological Black-White romantic alliances.
column12: Spaights, Ernest: U Wisconsin, Milwaukee
column13: Journal of Instructional Psychology. Vol.11(3), Sep 1984, pp. 132-138.
column19: Many of the problems associated with Black-White romantic alliances are rooted in sexual stereotypes that grew out of slavery and Black oppression, primarily in the South. Although there are many psychologically healthy relationships between Whites and Blacks, there are many pathological alliances as well. It is this racially based pathology that allows partners in an interracial romance to view each other as sexual objects. The specific pathological dynamics in each alliance depend on various combinations of race and sex as well as each partner's socio-psychological make-up. The different types of reactions faced by interracial couples are described, and the stresses imposed on such couples by racism are examined. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: 53 Black and 64 White male varsity high school athletes completed a questionnaire assessing their attitudes toward and their involvement in interracial interactions. Both Whites and Blacks expressed a preference for desegregated schools and a desire for more friends of a different race. However, about a third of both groups reported no interactions with players of a different race during practice or games. In addition, 62.5% of Whites reported no interaction with Blacks outside of sports, and 49% of Blacks had no interactions with Whites except for sports. Findings suggest that interracial social interaction habits may be firmly established at the high school level or earlier. (French abstract) (19 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
