column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.47(5), Nov 1984, pp. 1146-1154.
column19: Investigated the relation between prior interracial experience and adjustment of 42 Black freshmen to 2 predominantly White colleges. Interracial experience was defined in terms of ethnic composition (mainly Black, integrated, or mainly White) of a student's neighborhood, high school, and high school friends. A scale measuring adjustment to college, providing indices of several aspects of that adjustment, was administered at 3 times during the academic year. A positive relation was found between amount of prior interracial experience and effectiveness of adjustment. Improvement in adjustment as the year progressed provided additional evidence of the beneficial effect of interracial experience for adjustment to this type of college. Differential rate of improvement for Ss with varying amounts of interracial experience-greatest for those with least experience-indicates that consequences of such prior experiences are not immutable. (55 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial contact experience and attrition among Black undergraduates at a predominantly White university.
column12: Bennett, Christine: Indiana U, School of Education, Bloomington

column15: National Council for the Social Studies; US
column19: Explored the relationship between interracial contact experiences and attrition and persistence by administering a survey to 498 Black, 69 Latino, 62 Asian-American, and 321 White undergraduates during 1981-1982. During the spring and summer of 1983, 52 Black persisters (enrolled for the past 3-4 yrs) were personally interviewed, as were 41 Black student dropouts. Analysis showed that positive interracial contact experiences were related to Black student persistence in this predominantly White university. Persisters had more non-Black friends and high school classmates prior to college and expressed more positive feelings about Whites in general. However, they also expressed more negative feelings about their White professors and classmates than did their Black classmates who had dropped out. More dropouts than persisters participated in exclusively Black campus activities. Dropouts tended to experience more problems than persisters in financial concerns. Seven suggestions for changing the total educational environment to lower the rate of Black undergraduate attrition are given. (36 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:
Moore, J. William

Hauck, William E

Denne, Thomas C

column13: Journal of Experimental Education. Vol.52(3), Spr 1984, pp. 168-173.
column19: Examined the relationship of the racial prejudice of school-age children to the actual race of the child, interracial contact, grade, sex, intelligence, locus of control, anxiety, and self-concept. A scale was devised to measure 5 facets of racial prejudice: a total index of racial prejudice, dating and marriage, school, social relationships, and racial interactions in restaurants. The Ss were 93 Black children and 307 White children in Grades 6, 8, 9, and 10. Results indicate that White Ss appeared to be more prejudiced than Blacks in situations requiring prolonged interracial contact; however, no differences were noted in circumstances involving minimal intimate social relationships for short periods of time. No differences in prejudice were found among grade levels; however, females were generally less prejudiced than males. Black males of low prejudice were more intelligent, more external, and less anxious than Black males of higher prejudice. It is suggested that integration in schools should be gradual and that personality factors, not external circumstances, may make major contributions to the development of prejudice. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: An assessment tool for early intervention in cases of truancy.
column12: Levine, Renee S.: U Pennsylvania School of Social Work, Philadelphia
column13: Social Work in Education. Vol.6(3), Spr 1984, pp. 133-150.
column19: Describes the development of a topological system to enumerate factors that need remediation within the child, the home, the school, and the community to prevent truancy. School phobia, interpersonal skills, ethnic or racial dissonance, failure to learn, learning style, learning disabilities, and health problems should be evaluated in the child. The home study includes parental knowledge; family attitude, SES, and situation; child abuse or neglect; and parenting skills. Assessing the school factors requires adequate reporting, recording, and follow-up, and knowledge of appropriate school placement, school transitions, suspensions and/or expulsions, teacher competence and concern, and school environment. The effects of peer influence, street gangs, and interracial tensions are evaluated in the community study. It is concluded that parental involvement is a crucial factor in achieving compliance with school attendance laws. (51 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Discusses the experiences of 2 Black clients (a 43-yr-old male policeman and a 35-yr-old mother) who sought help from White pastoral counselors and of a 22-yr-old White female with an eating disorder assigned to a Black pastoral counselor. Racism is perceived in many subtle manners by Black Americans. Their responses to racism may include anger, rage, frustration, and depression. It is suggested that interracial pastoral counseling with Black Americans must take into account the environmental factors that have helped shape the lives of the clients and the variety of lifestyles of Black people. The counselor should not overidentify with the Black client, nor be rejecting, if confidence and trust are to be established. It is suggested that the counselor must have the expectation that the client can grow in Christ as a result of their work together. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Sampson, Robert J.: Carnegie-Mellon U, School of Urban & Public Affairs, Urban Systems Inst
column13: Social Forces. Vol.62(3), Mar 1984, pp. 618-639.
column15: University of North Carolina Press; US
column19: Two theorems derived from P. M. Blau and colleagues' (1977, 1982; see also PA, Vol 72:1221) theory of social structure were tested with data on the interpersonal crimes of rape, robbery, assault, and larceny for 2 important parameters in Blau's theory-race and age. The data base was taken from the National Crime Survey from 1973 to 1978. The theories predicted that (1) the relative size of the same group in different neighborhood contexts is inversely related to extent of outgroup victimization, and (2) neighborhood heterogeneity is positively related to rates of intergroup victimization. Results support the hypotheses and show that while ingroup victimization is highly prevalent in the US, interracial and interage criminal encounters are strongly and positively related to neighborhood heterogeneity. (21 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Compositions in Black and White: Determinants of interaction in interracial dyads. [References].
column12: Ickes, William: U Texas, Arlington
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.47(2), Aug 1984, pp. 330-341.
column19: Examined the initial, unstructured interactions of 40 interracial (Black-White) dyads in which 3 factors were systematically varied. These factors were the disposition of the White dyad members to either seek out or shun interaction with Blacks, the race (Black vs White) of the experimenter, and the gender composition (male-male vs female-female) of the dyads. Results show that within dyads, White dyad members displayed more interactional involvement than their Black partners but experienced the interactions as more stressful and uncomfortable. Whites predisposed to avoid interaction with Blacks looked and smiled at their partners less than those predisposed to initiate interaction. Both Black and White members of these avoidance dyads reported heightened feelings of anxiety and concern about their interactions, but the moderating influences of the Whites' approach-avoidance dispositions on interaction behavior were essentially limited to conditions in which the experimenter was Black and the White S was a "solo minority." It is suggested that Black-White partner effects are attributable to differing amounts of cross-race contact typically experienced by Blacks and Whites. Black-White experimenter effects are interpreted in terms of S. E. Taylor's (1981) hypothesis that stereotypes and related dispositions are activated in social contexts in which group membership is made salient. (38 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial inequality and salience: An examination of Blau's theory of social structure.
column12: Blum, Terry C.: Tulane U
column13: Social Forces. Vol.62(3), Mar 1984, pp. 607-617.
column15: University of North Carolina Press; US
column19: Evaluates several hypotheses derived from P. M. Blau and colleagues' (1967, 1977, 1982; see also PA, Vol 71:1221) theory of social structure. Central to this theory are the concept of proportional size and the properties that emerge from the distribution of people's positions. Three important properties-heterogeneity, inequality, and intersection/consolidation-form the basis for the proposed hypotheses. These hypotheses hold that increasing heterogeneity increases the probability of intergroup relations; the intersection of nominal by graduated parameters integrates groups by raising the rates of social association among them; and the lower the positive correlations between parameters, the more extensive are the intergroup relations. Data from the 1970 US Census from metropolitan areas were used to test the hypotheses, with the result that rates of interracial marriage were inversely associated with various measures of racial inequality. Racial inequality was associated with racial salience, the predominance of ingroup relations, in the positive direction. The concept of salience was explicitly incorporated in the examination of a theoretical paradox in Blau's theory, namely, the failure to find a positive association between heterogeneity of race and intermarriage. It is concluded that the choice of mates is not completely free from the constraints of social structure. (28 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Data on intermarriage rates in the 125 largest US metropolitan areas were used to test the theory that intersecting social differences promote intergroup relations. 10 forms of intermarriage, including those between Ss of different races, birth regions, or education, were analyzed. The theory is respecified on the basis of preliminary analysis to stipulate that multiple intersection of social affiliations fosters intermarriage. Eight empirical tests were used to corroborate the notion that multiple intersection of social differences furthers profound and lasting intergroup relations. (30 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Presents several case accounts, drawn from public schools, of misunderstandings between Blacks and Whites that resulted from culturally based differences in communication styles, including impersonal vs personal interactive modes, use of titles and surnames, and Black boastfulness vs White bashfulness. Misperceived verbal messages and nonverbal cues, which lead to estrangement among students and staff members, may be identified and clarified by school social workers. The authors offer prescriptions for the achievement of understanding and conversational clarity between racial groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Marriage and the Family. Vol.46(1), Feb 1984, pp. 179-190.
column15: National Council on Family Relations; US
column19: Presents data on the rates of in- and outmarriage for Chinese, Japanese, and Koreans in Los Angeles and Hawaii. Data were obtained from marriage licenses with Asian surnames. In 1979 in Los Angeles, the Japanese rates of outmarriages were the highest (60.6%), followed by the Chinese (41.2%), and the Korean (27.6%). The figures were reversed for Hawaii in 1980, with the Korean rates of outmarriage the highest (83%), followed by the Chinese (76%), then the Japanese (59%). Females of all 3 groups outmarried at a higher rate than males. A social-psychological model based on the ethnic group and its interaction with the dominant community was developed. Variables considered included historical factors, the family, the community, personal factor, and the receptivity of the dominant community. Generation was found to be the most important variable related to outmarriage, with the 3rd generation outmarrying at a higher rate than the 1st. (38 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Zurcher, Louis A

Lauderdale, Michael L

Anderson, Rosalie E
column12: McRoy, Ruth G.: U Texas Ctr for Social Work Research, School of Social Work, Austin
column13: Social Casework. Vol.65(1), Jan 1984, pp. 34-39.
column19: Examined familial and contextual factors that influenced the development of racial self-perceptions among 30 Black or mixed-race children and adolescents (aged 10-21 yrs) who had been adopted by White parents. Questionnaires and interviews with both children and parents revealed 3 ways that families dealt with racial identity issues. 18 of the families rarely discussed racial issues or associated with Blacks, and the children perceived themselves as different from other Blacks in terms of attitudes and culture. These children also held strong feelings of "differentness" and negative attitudes toward other Blacks. A 2nd group of 6 families acknowledged the child's racial identity and the need to provide Black role models for the child. These families lived in integrated neighborhoods, and the children expressed an interest in contact with other Blacks and often discussed racial identity issues with parents and peers. A 3rd group, in which parents generally had adopted several Black children, were characterized as interracial, and children were taught to emphasize their Black heritage. These families also provided a psychological support network for the adopted children. Findings suggest that transracial adoptions require special efforts on the part of parents and children and postplacement work on the part of the adoption agency. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1983, Vol 28(6), 469-470. Reviews the book, Ambiguous Ethnicity: Interracial Families in London by Susan Benson (1981). This work addresses the individuality of the couples while identifying the commonalities of their struggles and the consequences In most couples a consciousness of color and its social meaning was apparent. Yet each couple and each partner apparently dealt with this issue differently Rather than being emancipated from racial stereotypes, these couples were faced with many ambiguities and contradictions in their racial attitudes. The author compensates for the methodological limitations of her study by carefully noting its modest scope and intent, by carefully linking her observations of the behavior of her subjects with population patterns and social-role theories, and by conducting her analysis at the levels of both the individual and the social structure. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Women in interracial relationships.
column12: Faulkner, Janette: U California, Langley Porter Neuropsychiatric Inst, San Francisco
column13: Women & Therapy. Vol.2(2-3), Sum-Fal 1983, pp. 191-203.
column19: Describes the activities, experiences, and concerns of members of 7 support groups that helped participants work on issues related to different- or mixed-race living during a 3-yr period. 25 White, 12 Black, and 1 Chinese Ss lived with partners and/or children of a different or mixed race. Initial group encounters were intellectual and somewhat educational as Ss shared their life experiences. Armoring was used by Black and other Ss of color to promote self-caring during direct encounters with racist experiences. Co-leaders of the group were a Black clinician (the author) paired with a graduate student who had or was experiencing a mixed race relationship. Most Ss moved to the host environment of the spouse upon marriage. Group activity focused on establishing a definite identity for children and reinforcing it with models to support pridefulness. Group concerns about childrearing practices were racial: White Ss were criticized for being too permissive with children, and Black Ss were criticized by spouses for being too strict and by their families for being too permissive. Ss needed support and clarification around the question of what is developmental and what is cultural. Ss were trained to take leadership roles and continued meeting in their homes. A 5-item bibliography is appended. (1 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Applied Social Psychology Annual. Vol.4 1983, pp. 199-216.
column19: Evaluated the effects of a cooperative game intervention on interracial interactions of schoolchildren in a pilot study in 1 6th-grade class and in field tests with girls from 8 5th- and 6th-grade classes in 2 desegregated schools. In the pilot test, interracial interaction rates increased from 13% at pretest to 74% and 65% for Black and White girls, respectively. Posttreatment rates declined at 4 wks to 16% for Blacks, and 25% for Whites. A subsequent intervention used a pretest/posttest design, a more extended intervention, and compared the effects of cooperative vs individualistic games. Results in this case provided little evidence for an effect of cooperative games on cross-racial social interactions. The possible contributions of differences in the games and in the roles, skills, and characteristics of the activity directors in the 2 studies to the absence of treatment effects are discussed. (23 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The racially different psychiatrist: Implications for psychotherapy.
column12: Varghese, Frank T.: Royal Park Psychiatric Hosp, Parkville, Australia
column13: Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry. Vol.17(4), Dec 1983, pp. 329-333.
column19: Contends that the race of the therapist can play a significant role in the manifestation of transference and countertransference phenomena in interracial psychotherapy. References to the race of therapist may be the first sign of a developing transference relationship. Failure to appreciate the impact of racial difference can impede therapeutic progress, while sensitive confrontation may be a valuable tool in the recognition and communication of emotionally charged feelings in therapy. Dream material is influenced by the race of the therapist who may be less easy to disguise in dreams, and the therapist may avoid certain dream interpretations because of unacknowledged discomfort about race. Three case studies illustrate how the author's racial difference influenced psychotherapeutic interactions. These observations have implications for the supervisory process in training and for the general issue of the influence of the person of the therapist on the process of psychotherapy. (13 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Comments on the prospects for a nomothetic theory of social structure.
column12: Blau, Peter M.: Columbia U
column13: Journal for the Theory of Social Behaviour. Vol.13(3), Oct 1983, pp. 265-271.
column19: Responds to comments by D. V. Porpora (see record 1984-20274-001) concerning the possibility of establishing a nomothetic theory that can describe social structure in terms of general principles. The present author argues that such a theory is necessary if sociology is to explain rather than merely describe social life and that Porpora misinterprets sociology as wholesale psychology. The distinction between psychological and sociological explanations is illustrated through a discussion of Durkheim's analysis of conditions correlated with suicide and a study by the present author et al (1982) of conditions associated with interracial marriage. column19: Schools that are desegregated only to the extent that a certain numerical racial balance is achieved in enrollment may find that racial stereotypes are reinforced and intergroup hostility still exists. In order for all races to react and learn comfortably in the same environment, the contact among students must provide (1) equal status for all, (2) strong institutional support for positive relations, and (3) cooperative interaction aimed toward achievement. Contingency management, in which rewards are made on a group basis, is one way to encourage interracial interaction. Another successful technique has been the use of cooperative teams of students organized to learn or perform together. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Statistical analysis of multiracial group characteristics and interracial conflict.
column12: Vaid-Raizada, Vishist K.: California State U
column13: Psychological Reports. Vol.52(1), Feb 1983, pp. 39-42.
column19: Examined the relationships between interracial conflict and various racial group characteristics such as relative size, average age, difference in earnings, educational level, and length of association with multiracial organizations. 79 Black and White maintenance employees of a university who worked in 5 different sections served as Ss. The following 6 hypotheses were tested: (1) The greater the number of Blacks in the multiracial group, the higher the level of interracial conflict. (2) The greater the difference in earnings between Blacks and Whites in a multiracial group, the higher the level of interracial conflict. (3) The greater the average age of Whites in the multiracial group, the higher the level of interracial conflict. (4) The lower the average age of Blacks in the multiracial group, the higher the level of interracial conflict. (5) The higher the average education of the multiracial group, the lower the level of interracial conflict. (6) The higher the average years of association of multiracial group members with a multiracial/ethnic organization, the lower the level of interracial conflict. Results show strong support for the 1st hypothesis and weak support for the 6th one. All other hypotheses were not supported. (5 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The Minnesota Adoption Studies: Genetic differences and malleability.
column12: Scarr, Sandra: Yale U
column13: Child Development. Vol.54(2), Apr 1983, pp. 260-267.
column19: The Transracial Adoption Study (TAS) tested the hypothesis that Black and interracial children reared by White families would perform as well as other adopted children on IQ and school achievement tests. The sample included 176 adopted children (130 Blacks) and 143 biological children of the adoptive parents. All Ss were aged 4-11 yrs. Among the adoptees, 111 were adopted in the 1st yr of life and 65 after 12 mo of age. The Adolescent Adoption Study (AAS) assessed the cumulative impact of differences in family environments on children's development at the end of the childrearing period. The sample included 194 adopted children in 115 adoptive families and a comparison group of 237 parent-age- and IQ-matched biological children in 120 other families. All the adoptees were adopted in the 1st yr of life and were 18-22 yrs old at the time of the study. In the TAS, Black and interracial children scored as well on the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale or the WISC as adoptees in the other studies. Individual differences among them, however, were more related to differences among their biological than adoptive parents, whether they lived together or not. Young siblings were intellectually similar, whether genetically related or not. In the AAS, Ss' IQ test scores were similar to those of their parents and siblings only if they were biologically related. It is concluded that younger children are more influenced by differences among their family environments than older adolescents, who are freer to seek their own niches. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: An analysis of 18 reviews revealed 6 school practices associated with effective racial (and ethnic) integration: racial mixing and fairness, staff models and support, security, and multicultural exposure. Integration and educational outcome measures were regressed on measures of student perceptions of the 6 school practices, 13 aspects of school climate, and 16 control variables including sex, ethnicity, family intactness and socioeconomic status, and amounts of prior and present interracial experience in a sample of 1,484 high school juniors randomly selected from desegregated high schools in 3 northeastern states. Partial correlations revealed many significant, small-to-moderate controlled associations of practices and climate with integration and educational outcomes; school practices were moderately associated with integration attitudes and behavior when controlled for student characteristics and interracial experience. (12 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Padilla, Amado M
column12: Salgado de Snyder, Nelly: U California, Los Angeles
column13: Spanish Speaking Mental Health Research Center Occasional Papers. Vol.15 1982, pp. 18.
column15: Spanish Speaking Mental Health Research Center; US
column19: Interviewed 84 Mexican-Americans married in 1963 to non-Mexican spouses. Males' and females' mean ages were 24.7 and 22.4 yrs, respectively, in 1963. Ss were asked about their participation in Mexican cultural activities, ethnic identification of self and offspring, perceptions of interethnic marriages, and involvement of their children in Mexican cultural activities. Results indicate that participation in Mexican cultural activities decreased between the 1st and 3rd (or later) generation. However, the majority of both male and female Ss of all generations self-identified as being of Mexican origin and believed that their offspring also self-identified as Mexican. Children of female Ss spoke more Spanish and more often had a best friend who was Mexican that did offspring of male Ss. Data challenge the assimilation theory of interethnic marriage espoused by some social scientists. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial inequities in the delivery of social services.
column9:
Chesney, James D

Engel, Rafael J
column12: Chesney, James D.: U Michigan
column13: Journal of Sociology and Social Welfare. Vol.9(4), Dec 1982, pp. 602-612.
column19: Examined the racial factor in the delivery of social services to White and non-White clients by 127 White and 38 non-White service providers. Data from a survey of the registered social workers indicate inequities in the delivery of social services. Providers serving non-Whites tended to spend less time providing casework services and more time on providing welfare services than did providers serving Whites. These interracial differences may be explained by income or employment auspice. The major racial inequity became apparent when providers serving primarily non-White clients were analyzed. White providers serving non-Whites spent more time on welfare activities and less on casework services than did non-White providers serving non-Whites. These differences cannot be explained by income or the providers' education and experience. Such patterns of delivery raise issues for the profession and have implications for the needs, usage, and training of qualified personnel. It is concluded that research aimed at evaluating the consequences of these differences and programs to eliminate inequities should be of the highest priority. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Intermarriage and the "blending of exiles" in Israel.
column12: Rosen, Sherry: Henrietta Szold Inst, Jerusalem, Israel
column13: Research in Race & Ethnic Relations. Vol.3 1982, pp. 79-102.
column19: Discusses the relationship between intermarriage (IM) and ethnic integration in Israeli society. From a sociological perspective, the concept of "absorption of immigrants" into Israeli society has elements of both a fusion or melting-pot model and an assimilationist-integrationist model. Israelis stress the solidarity that emerges from a common Judaic heritage, but as the author notes, the foundations of the social and political State of Israel rest firmly in modern European values and institutions. Israelis with European roots assumed that Oriental immigrants would renounce their "Levantine" background and conform to the values of a Western, industrialized society. While IM has contributed to the creation of a genetically mixed population, it has not necessarily fostered widespread integration. It is suggested that there must be a conscientious and serious effort to restore the historic legitimacy of the Oriental culture to its proper place in the current value system. There must be a reaffirmation of the Oriental experience in Jewish history, literature, and religious philosophy in a manner that will make even the youngest pupil proud of his/her heritage. (54 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Participant observations and survey data from 392 students from 3 fraternities provide insights on the interracial act as a transformation; the "White syndrome," by which S was judged on his capacity to think and act "White"; the specifics of S's acceptance by others; and the links between the interracial act and other audiences. A set of directives for studying the interracial act is presented. (89 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Male power and female victimization: Toward a theory of interracial rape.
column12: LaFree, Gary D.: U New Mexico, Albuquerque
column13: American Journal of Sociology. Vol.88(2), Sep 1982, pp. 311-328.
column19: Tested 2 models of Black offender-White victim (BW) rape on a set of 443 rape victimizations collected by the National Crime Panel from 1973 to 1977. The normative model interprets BW rape as a correlate of increased social interaction between Black men and White women. The conflict model interprets BW rape as a correlate of increased Black politicization. Discriminant analysis of statistics did not support the normative model's predictions that victims of BW rape would be younger, more educated, and more likely to be single than other rape victims. Partial support was offered for the conflict model's predictions that BW rapes were more likely than other rapes to involve strangers and to occur outside the home and less likely to occur at night. Implications for a sexual stratification theory of interracial rape are discussed. (67 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race, social class and ability patterns on the WISC-R.
column9:
Jensen, Arthur R

Reynolds, Cecil R
column12: Jensen, Arthur R.: U California, Inst of Human Learning, Berkeley
column13: Personality and Individual Differences. Vol.3(4), 1982, pp. 423-438.
column19: Used the national standardization sample of 1,868 White and 305 Black 16-26.5 yr olds' performance on the WISC-R as the basis for a detailed analysis of the psychometric nature of racial and social class differences on the original 13 subscales of the WISC-R. The profiles of subtest scores of Whites and Blacks were compared directly and also after the racial groups were equated on Full Scale IQ. Results show that the largest differences favoring Whites were performance tests involving spatial-perceptual ability, whereas the tests favoring Blacks involved short-term memory. The profile of White-Black differences on the WISC-R subtests was markedly different and negatively correlated with the profiles of social class differences within each racial group, indicating that the pattern of racial differences is not explainable in terms of the difference in the average socioeconomic status of Blacks and Whites. Analysis of factor scores shows that the largest proportion of the variance between races is attributable to the general factor common to all the subtests, whereas the group factors (Verbal, Performance, and Memory) contributed only minutely to the interracial variance. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Describes 13 parenting groups, the purpose of which was to help the parents raise their children with strong, positive Black identities and self-concepts. To facilitate this, the White parents were helped to examine their self-esteem and self-concept issues, identify their personal racism, and to understand individual and institutional racism in society and how it affects their lives. The purpose, goals, recruitment process, composition of the group, coleadership issues, issues of the parents, and the format used are outlined. Groups were initially targeted for specific parents, such as unmarried mothers of biracial children, White adoptive parents, and White foster parents. Each group met weekly for 8-24 sessions from 1974 to 1981. The first groups had a primarily educational format; the last 3 were primarily therapeutic. column19: Investigated the same-race and cross-race friendship choices of Black and White students (N = 536) in 4th-7th grades that differed in racial composition. In 20 desegregated classrooms in 6 schools, Blacks showed a stronger tendency than Whites to segregate racially in the selection of friends regardless of the racial composition of the classroom. Both races were most integrated in their friendships in White majority classrooms. Segregation by Whites decreased over the school year, while Black segregation remained constant. Blacks were friendlier toward both races than Whites, with the greatest difference in Black and White friendliness occurring in White majority classrooms. Results illustrate some of the complex ways in which classroom racial composition affects the formation of interracial friendships. column5: Expectation states and interracial interaction in school settings.
column12: Cohen, E. G.: Stanford U, School of Education
column13: Annual Review of Sociology. Vol.8 1982, pp. 209-235.
column19: Expectation states theory (EST; J. Berger et al, 1966) has been used as the basis for applied research on race and its effects on interracial interaction (IRI). EST can be used to describe the process by which high-status members of IRI groups come to dominate group interaction. Using this theory, there are a number of interventions designed to modify status effects in settings where they are judged undesirable. In the classroom, expectation states affect observable behaviors of practical importance: (1) a pattern of White dominance in IRI on valued intellectual tasks: This pattern is undesirable because racist expectations for less competence from minority students are reinforced. (2) Expectation states also affect the participation, task engagement, and effort of the minority student on school tasks. If a student has generally low expectations for academic competence, he/she will be less likely to put out the requisite effort to become a more successful student. The author reviews the literature based on EST that deals with race as a status characteristic in educational settings, focusing on interventions that can shift IRI toward "equal status behavior" and away from dominance of the group by high-status members. Two of the interventions include the use of inconsistency to produce equality and the use of referent actors. (39 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

There had also been a significant and reliable variance in the way biracial stimuli have been perceived, from which a range of interracial attitudes within any population can be inferred. In behavioral tests, White children showing negative feelings toward Blacks also demonstrated less positive attitudes toward White peers in cooperative tasks. column5: An observational study of peer interaction in racially mixed "accelerated" classrooms. [References].
column9:
Schofield, Janet W

Francis, William D
column12: Schofield, Janet W.: U Pittsburgh
column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.74(5), Oct 1982, pp. 722-732.
column19: Observed the peer interactions of 69 White and 32 Black 8th graders each week of a semester. The race and sex of the person with whom S was interacting were coded, as were the behavior's mutuality (one-sided, mutual), affective tone (positive, neutral, negative), and orientation (task oriented, ambiguous, social). Considerably more cross-race interaction was noted than found in previous studies conducted in nonacademic settings in interracial schools. Ss interacted significantly more with peers of their own race than with peers of the other race. This was due to the females' strong own-race preference. Males interacted cross-racially at approximately the rate that would be expected if race were not a factor in interactant choice. Male interactions were predominantly mutual in nature, whereas those of females were predominantly one-sided. There were no major differences in the tone of the inter- or intraracial interactions of Ss in the 4 sex-race subgroups. Negative behaviors constituted less than 1% of all interactions. Cross-race interactions of all groups were more task related than within-race interactions, within-race interactions were more social than cross-race interactions. (37 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Initial interaction of American Blacks and Whites in interracial and intraracial dyads.
column12: Shuter, Robert: Marquette U, Coll of Speech
column13: The Journal of Social Psychology. Vol.117(1), Jun 1982, pp. 45-52.
column19: Explored racial differences in initial interaction by focusing on the 1st 4 min of conversation in inter- and intraracial interactions. A repeated measures design was used with 32 Blacks and Whites (21-29 yrs old) each interacting with 4 stimulus persons orthogonally varied by race and sex. Ss' conversations were unobtrusively recorded and analyzed to determine the number and types of questions asked and the length of Ss' speaking time. Blacks and Whites significantly changed initial interaction depending on the composition of the dyad. Males and females varied question patterns depending on the partner's race. It is suggested that initial interaction for Blacks and Whites may be governed by different conversational rules. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The InterFace Project: Behavior modeling as social technology in South Africa.
column13: Personnel Psychology. Vol.35(3), Fal 1982, pp. 557-581.
column19: Describes the InterFace Project, a pilot study to improve race relationships between supervisors and employees in South African industry. The ultimate intent of the project was to find a path for more extensive research aimed at improving interracial attitudes and behavior, especially in work situations. Behavior modeling training was used as the vehicle for attempting to change the behaviors. Ss were 131 employees (mean age 39 yrs) and 12 supervisors (mean age 41 yrs). Several measures were used because it was uncertain how change would be found. A questionnaire and expectation scale did not reveal significant change, possibly because of the small sample size and the reluctance of supervisors to be candid. Structured interviews, however, indicated dramatic improvements in interrace attitudes and observations for both supervisors and employees. Second posttest improvements (20 wks after training) were, in fact, even greater than improvements noted at the 1st posttest (six wks after training). Before and after training, comments by employees and supervisors provided strong evidence of the extent of change that occurred. (13 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Social psychological research on school desegregation: Toward a new agenda.
column12: Longshore, Douglas: System Development Corp, Santa Monica, CA
column13: New Directions for Testing & Measurement. Vol.14 Jun 1982, pp. 39-52.
column19: Argues that social scientists have failed to provide consistent findings on desegregation because they have concentrated too much on the outcomes of desegregation and neglected the wide range of conditions under which desegregation occurs and the development of useful theoretical perspectives. The assessment of short-term outcomes needs to be shifted away from sociometric measures and toward methods such as unobtrusive observation of play groups or classes. Future conceptualization should distinguish between interracial avoidance and actual unfriendly contact as well as between prejudice as aversion and prejudice as ambivalence. (53 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Attitudes of French women toward Black African men in French universities. [French].
column12: Vinsonneau, Genevieve: U Tours, France
column13: Ethnopsychologie. Vol.36(1), Jan-Mar 1981, pp. 21-51.
column15: Institut Havrais de Sociologie Economique et de Psych. des Peuples; France
column19: 62 French female university students (aged 20-25 yrs) completed questionnaires assessing their knowledge of African history, current events, and culture and their attitudes toward interracial marriage to investigate Ss' attitudes toward Black African male university students. Ss were primarily from middle- or working-class families and in schools of medicine, human sciences, or letters, with an average of 3.5 yrs of university-level education. Following administration of the questionnaire, the present author interviewed 25 of these Ss, using tables to record and correlate results. It was found that, overall, Ss had a reasonable grasp of African affairs and culture. However, they rejected the notion of marriage with Black African males on the grounds that marriage between 2 individuals from different cultures would be unstable. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Perception of the success of integration in a multiracial high school among social groups defined by social interaction.
column12: Dagenais, Fred: U California, San Francisco
column13: The Journal of Educational Research. Vol.75(2), Nov-Dec 1981, pp. 78-86.
column19: Cluster analysis applied to the reported frequence of interracial mixing for 309 high school seniors yielded 3 item-clusters with high reliabilities and 6 distinct and meaningful object-groups based on race of respondent and degree of reported social integration. Asian and Black Ss perceived the success of the integration program independently from reported degree of social integration, whereas the perception of program success by White Ss was moderated by degree of social integration. The technique of applying cluster analysis to behavioral data to establish independent groups and constructs is discussed. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Personality attributes of males and females marrying within vs. across racial/ethnic groups.
column9:
Ahern, Frank M

Cole, Robert E

Johnson, Ronald C

Wong, Brenda
column12: Ahern, Frank M.: U Hawaii, Honolulu
column13: Behavior Genetics. Vol.11(3), May 1981, pp. 181-194.
column19: Obtained Adjective Check List scores from 543 couples in Hawaii who had married within their own ethnic group and from 83 who had not. Females who married across ethnic groups generally scored higher in 1 domain of personality (dominance) than did females who married within their own ethnic group. Males who married cross-ethnically also differed in dominance from those who did not, but in different directions in different ethnic groups. In the group that had the highest status (Whites) in the decades in which these Ss married, they were less dominant; in the other groups, to varying degrees, they were more dominant. In general, males and females in cross-ethnic matings were more similar in personality test scores than males and females who married within their own ethnic groups. Spouse correlations were generally positive, with little difference in personality between homogamous and heterogamous couples. The average difference in personality between those who married within and outside their own ethnic group was associated with the rarity of outmarriage for the sex and ethnic group concerned. (19 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of school organizational structure on interracial friendships in middle schools.
column9:
Damico, Sandra B

Bell-Nathaniel, Afesa

Green, Charles
column12: Damico, Sandra B.: U Florida
column13: The Journal of Educational Research. Vol.74(6), Jul-Aug 1981, pp. 388-393.
column19: 889 White and 437 Black 6th-8th graders evaluated a White and Black friend on a modified semantic-differential scale and reported the number of their other-race friends. Results show that the organization of a school (team vs traditionally structured) affected the number of other-race friends for Whites; those with some Black friends were more positive in their perceptions of Blacks. However, Blacks rated White and Black friends the same regardless of the organizational structure of the school. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Brause, Werner: U South Alabama, Mobile

column19: Administered to 40 Black and 40 White students of a southern university the Racial Differential Scale to measure the following 6 bipolar adjective dimensions: polite-rude, cold-warm, interesting-boring, attractive-ugly, intelligent-dull, and industrious-lazy. No significant differences were found between both groups' racial perceptions. As previously demonstrated for northeastern students, ethnocentrism and positive group identification exist for southern college students. column5: Deindividuation and anger-mediated interracial aggression: Unmasking regressive racism. [References].
column12: Rogers, Ronald W.: U Alabama, University
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.41(1), Jul 1981, pp. 63-73.
column19: Investigated the effects of deindividuation, anger, and race-of-victim on aggression displayed by 96 White male undergraduates. Deindividuating situational cues produced an internal state of deindividuation that mediated aggressive behavior. Deindividuation theories are extended by the finding that the internal state of deindividuation was composed not only of the factors Self-Awareness and Altered Experience, but also Group Cohesiveness, Responsibility, and Time Distortion. As predicted, nonangered Whites were less aggressive toward Black than White victims, but angered Whites were more aggressive toward Blacks than Whites. Interracial behavior was consistent with new, egalitarian norms if anger was not aroused, but regressed to the old, historical pattern of racial discrimination if anger was aroused. This pattern of interracial behavior was interpreted in terms of a new form of racism: regressive racism. (36 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of social behavior on interracial acceptance. [References].
column9:

column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.73(1), Feb 1981, pp. 51-56.
column19: To test children's use of race and social behavior as cues in social acceptance, 128 Black and White male kindergartners and 1st graders rated 6 unknown videotaped target children for likability. Targets varied factorially on race (Black or White) and exhibited either positive, negative, or neutral classroom social behavior. Across age, socioeconomic status, and race, Ss used behavior as a cue, accounting for 50% of likability variance. Positive targets were liked equivalently, but Black neutral and negative targets were liked less than White counterparts. Racial but not socioeconomic status differences in the use of behaviors as social cues were found. Negative targets were liked more by Blacks than Whites and neutral targets were liked more by Whites than Blacks. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: (1980, reprinted 1995). Friendship and social relations in children. xxxix, 396 pp. Piscataway, NJ, US: Transaction Publishers; US.
column19: (from the preface) This volume sets out to give an account of different facets of friendships throughout childhood. It is a compilation of review chapters written by some of the leading researchers who have drawn together current findings and ideas in the major research areas of children's friendships and social relations. The volume is designed for all those with academic and applied interests in children's social development. Amongst psychologists it will be of particular interest to those working in the flelds of social, developmental, and educational psychology. It will also appeal to sociologists and ethologists whose interests lie in the aetiology, culture, and organization of children's social groups. For those who are professionally concerned with children in teaching, in child care, or in social work there is also much of value in the book. Several chapters deal specifically with children's relationships in the classroom, their conceptions of their peers and the development of friendship cliques. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Following the author's (1979) paper that described "culture-shock marriages" in Hong Kong-i.e, marriages between a Chinese male returned from overseas and a Western female, and the problems faced by such a couple-3 successful intercultural marriages are described in terms of P. S. Adler's (1975) 5-stage model of cultural shock. As the husbands were inaccessible for cultural reasons, only the wives were interviewed, using personal construct theory and the repertory grid technique. The factors in each of the 3 exceptional cases that influenced the marriage favorably are pointed out. (8 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: How Senegalese secondary school students feel about Euro-African mixed marriage.
column12: Vandewiele, Michel: U Dakar, Ecole Normale Superieure, Senegal
column13: Psychological Reports. Vol.46(3, Pt 1), Jun 1980, pp. 789-790.
column19: Interviewed 882 students from all public secondary schools with 7 forms (Lycee) in Senegal. Supporters and opponents of mixed marriages were of equal importance. The reasons put forward in favor of such marriages were material (11%), affective (if "partners love each other strongly enough," 19%), and cultural ("struggle against racism," 15%). The latter argument was also used by detractors but under a different form ("loss of cultural identity," 16%). About 21% of the Ss were against mixed marriages because they add difficulties to an already risky situation. Sex, age, and socioeconomic status of Ss' fathers were significant. Comparison with previous studies suggests a much more accommodating attitude towards interracial marriage among the present Ss. (5 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Describes the methodological problems arising in a field study of psychosocial processes in mixed couples-Black African men and French women. In the research, emphasis was placed on the mechanisms directing the elaboration of the images through which such men and women approach one another. The ambiguity in the relationships between the female researcher and the male Ss of the survey are analyzed, and the use of classical methodological precepts is questioned. An attempt is made to clarify the complex meanings deriving from the position of researcher in an investigation involving a population formerly colonized by France. column5: Naturalistic observation of sex and race differences in visual interactions.
column12: Gielen, Uw: St Francis Coll, NY
column13: International Journal of Group Tensions. Vol.9(1-4), 1979, pp. 211-222.
column19: In 2 studies, frequency of mutual gazing in dyads was observed in natural settings. In Study 1, with 23 pairs of 18-50 yr old White undergraduates and college staff members, White males glanced significantly more often at each other than did White females. Study 2, with 49 pairs of Black and White Ss, replicated the finding of Study 1 for White dyads, but not for Black or interracial pairs. Interracial female dyads and White male dyads visually interacted the most, while interracial male and male-female dyads interacted the least. Overall, Whites looked at each other more frequently than Blacks. Same-sex pairs exchanged glances more often than opposite-sex pairs. Interracial female dyads and White male dyads reflected the highest degree of mutual trust and liking, while interracial male and male-female dyads expressed the least. (24 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Culture-shocked marriages in Hong Kong.
column12: McCoy, Mildred: U Hong Kong
column13: Bulletin of the Hong Kong Psychological Society. Vol.2 Jan 1979, pp. 9-16.
column15: Hong Kong Psychological Society; Hong Kong
column19: Discusses "culture-shocked marriages"-couples consisting of Hong Kong Chinese males and Western females who met and married elsewhere, but who now reside in Hong Kong-in terms of the husband's experience, the wife's experience, and the interaction of these experiences on the marriage. Although the author was unable to isolate any one of the above factors, the wife's experience in moving to Hong Kong as an expatriate is the primary focus. A culture shock model is proposed as a view of the transitional experience precipitated by exposure to a 2nd culture. The model has 5 stages, each associated with a typical behavior and affect: (1) contact, (2) disintegration, (3) reintegration, (4) autonomy, and (5) independence. Data were collected from 20 expatriate wives, using the case study method. The benefits of using such an approach are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: 60 White male undergraduates observed a model behave in a nonaggressive or highly rewarding manner toward a Black target. The model was either free to act in this way or was forced to behave positively. An examination of Ss' aggressive and rewarding responses indicates that the models were effective in reducing aggression and increasing reward toward the Black target. However, the effect occurred only when the model was seen as acting under his own volition. There was also evidence that the effects of the modeling experience could be generalized to another type of behavior. (21 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Beliefs about Black males' sexuality are pervasive in this society, but little studied. This investigation used a semantic differential to measure 360 White undergraduates' perceptions of Black and White characters in sexually explicit stories, some of which depicted interracial pairings. The perceptions were then examined in relationship to authoritarianism and sexual repression as measured by an F scale (R. Lee and P. Warr, 1969) and the Sex Guilt Scale. Results suggest that Black males are stereotyped as more potent than White males. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: 165 undergraduates were asked to perform several interracial behaviors (e.g., volunteering to take a group of new Black students on a tour of the campus). Half of the Ss were committed to their decisions prior to volunteering; the other half were not. Committed Ss volunteered for fewer behaviors and evaluated the behaviors less positively than did uncommitted Ss. Multiple regression analyses revealed that committed Ss placed the most weight on attitudinal considerations, whereas uncommitted Ss placed the most weight on personal norm considerations in making their behavioral decisions. column5: Classroom climates and students' intergroup behavior. [References].
column12: Serow, Robert C.: North Carolina State U School of Education
column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.71(5), Oct 1979, pp. 669-676.
column19: Conducted observations in 99 desegregated elementary school classes (kindergarten through 6th grade) to determine the relationship between classroom conditions and pupils' interracial behaviors. Results of factor and regression analyses indicate that 2 types of observed interracial behavior were associated with different classroom environments. Diffuse positive intergroup contacts were more likely to occur in classes in which teachers emphasized interpersonal concerns. Although businesslike environments impeded overall cross-racial association, they had no effect on more purposeful intergroup contacts, which were facilitated by teacher patience and by diversity in instructional arrangements. These findings suggest that tensions between the social and academic objectives of multiracial education might be resolved by emphasizing purposeful interactions among children of different racial backgrounds. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Black Children Need Permanent Homes.
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.23(8), Aug,  1978
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1978, Vol 23(8), 567. Reviews the book, Mixed Families: Adopting Across Racial Boundaries by Joyce A. Ladner (1977). This study on transracial adoption brings a new point of view to a controversial issue. It is an attempt to describe a broad cross section of white families who adopted Black and interracial children. The trend started in the early '60s and reached its highest point 10 years later. It slowed down almost to a standstill when the Association of Black Social Workers came out strongly against placement of any Black children in White homes where they would not be able to develop a sense of racial identity. Ladner takes a different position. She believes that the controversy between the advocates of transracial adoption and their opponents overshadows the real issue. She feels that White parents with special qualities of sensitivity, self-awareness, and maturity can be permitted to adopt Black children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The fall and resurrection of transracial adoption.
column12: Kreinik, Phyllis S.: University of Denver, Denver, CO, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.23(8), Aug,  1978
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1978, Vol 23(8), 602-603. Comments on the review by Ruthanne K. S. DeWolfe and Alan S. DeWolfe (see record 2006-06391-010) of the book, Transracial Adoption by Rita James Simon and Howard Altstein (1977). Neither the authors nor the reviewers seem to have taken into account the impact of the dramatic rise in foreign adoptions. Moreover, the reviewers are correct in pointing out that single parent adoption (also on the increase) is rarely regarded as an alternative to transracial adoption. On the contrary, single adoptive parents are major consumers of cross-racial adoption. The continued longitudinal analysis of children in transracial families is to be encouraged, not out of mere academic curiosity, but as an issue of vital practical concern. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1978, Vol 23(2), 80-81. Reviews the book, Transracial Adoption by Rita James Simon and Howard Altstein (1977). This book represents an excellent review of the general history of adoption issues and policy as well as of transracial adoption. Because of the sensitivity and honesty with which the authors confront current sociopolitical pressures, the book should stimulate discussion rather than acrimonious dispute. It is hoped that Simon and Altstein will follow these children through adolescence and adulthood to determine whether their development continues as their parents and the authors now expect. Such a longitudinal analysis could provide significant insights into the currently active dispute over genetic versus environmental determinants of intelligence. The reviewers recommend the book to everyone interested in adoption generally and transracial adoption in particular, both professionals and concerned laypersons. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1978, Vol 23(10), 769-770. Reviews the books, Stereotypes, Distortions and Omissions in U.S. History Textbooks by Robert B. Moore (1977); and Undoing Sex Stereotypes: Research and Resources for Educators by Marcia Guttentag, Helen Bray, Jane Amsler, Virginia Donovan, Gordon Legge, Wendy Willson Legge, Ronnie Littenberg, and Sandra Stotsky (1976). The authors' purpose was to describe a field survey and intervention program for changing sex stereotyping in children and to explain the results of that program. The project, funded by the Ford Foundation and conducted by Harvard and Radcliffe faculty and students, was aimed at answering two major questions: (1) What can be done to make a classroom nonsexist? and (2) What works in helping students adopt nonstereotyped views? The Council on Interracial Books for Children developed Stereotypes, Distortions and Omissions in U.S. History Textbooks in order to stimulate thought about and engender respect for, the experiences, viewpoints, and aspirations of Third-World people and women throughout our history--and today--by "providing a comprehensive instrument for analyzing the content of U.S. history "textbooks in terms of their treatment of women and third world people." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The development of interpersonal attraction in cooperating interracial groups: The effects of success-failure, race and competence of groupmates, and helping a less competent groupmate.
column9:
Mumpower, Jeryl L

Cook, Stuart W
column12: Mumpower, Jeryl L.: U Colorado, Boulder
column13: International Journal of Group Tensions. Vol.8(3-4), 1978, pp. 18-50.
column19: The effects on the development of interpersonal attraction of group outcome, race, and helping a less competent member of a cooperating interracial group were investigated in a 3 x 3 x 2 factorially designed experiment. The level of competence of group members was also varied. The Ss, who were White military servicemen from small towns and rural areas of the southern US, expressed significantly greater attraction for more competent than for less competent groupmates, and for White groupmates than Black. Comparison of these data with the findings of an earlier study suggests that receipt by a group of a meaningful reward for success is a significant factor in promoting feelings of satisfaction and the development of intermember attraction in such groups. In the absence of such a reward, Ss in this study did not differ in the attraction they expressed for groupmates as a function of group outcome (success, failure, and neutral outcomes) or of personally helping less competent groupmates. Implications of these findings for management of the integration process are discussed. No evidence was found of self-enhancing or self-defensive biases in the attribution of responsibility for group outcomes. (61 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Sex roles at the Indian-majority interface in Minnesota.
column12: Westermeyer, Joseph: U Minnesota, Minneapolis
column13: International Journal of Social Psychiatry. Vol.24(3), Fal 1978, pp. 189-194.
column19: Discusses the patterns and distribution of biases against Minnesota Indian men. Census data show that unlike the majority population in which men outnumber women in higher education, numbers of Indian women exceed men. An informal survey of businesses catering to Indians found that 2 (both women) of 137 workers were Indian. Similar data show that Indian men were poorly represented in health service positions, as clergymen, or as law enforcement officials. To explain why these social phenomena are perpetuated, it is hypothesized that (a) majority men feel threatened by Indian men; (b) parent-child relationships prevail when the interracial boundary is tense; (c) Indians feel threatened by the majority society; and (d) Indian women serve as buffers between Indian men and the majority society. Remedial measures are proposed to help the 2 groups relate to each other as equals in a plural society. (5 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interpersonal and attitudinal outcomes in cooperating interracial groups.
column12: Cook, Stuart W.: U Colorado
column13: Journal of Research & Development in Education. Vol.12(1), Fal 1978, pp. 97-113.
column19: Reviews research on cooperation that has been based on the "contact hypothesis," which in its present form predicts that when an individual has personal contact with members of a group he dislikes, a favorable change in attitude will take place under certain specified conditions. Results of most of the studies support the hypothesis as qualified. Situation-specific characteristics of the experimental treatments tended to influence study outcomes. An individual's improved attitude toward members of the contact group does not necessarily generalize to the entire group; liked members are perceived as exceptions to the group from which they come. Studies are needed that will introduce an element to increase generalization. (12 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Social Casework. Vol.59(4), Apr 1978, pp. 221-226.
column19: Describes a 6-wk pilot counseling program for Korean-American couples at a military base in Korea. The aim of the project was to identify problems and offer counseling. Because of marked differences in cultural values as well as frequent personal problems, such marriages have a high risk of conflict and failure. Areas of difficulty include language differences, the Korean value of suppression of feelings, and expectations that the American will offer financial and other support to the wife's Korean family. Caseworkers often lack understanding of these problems. Including at least one couple with a successful intercultural marriage as a model for other group members is recommended. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The relationship of attraction and sex composition to performance and nonperformance experimental outcomes in dyads.
column12: Rosenthal, Saul F.: Creighton U
column13: Sex Roles. Vol.4(6), Dec 1978, pp. 887-898.
column19: Compared same- and mixed-sex dyads of undergraduates to investigate the relationship of interpersonal attraction and dyad sex composition to performance and nonperformance experimental outcomes. 90 dyads each performed a verbal and a quantitative problem-solving task. Significant differences in speed of performance were found for dyad sex composition but not for attraction. Attraction had its strongest impact on dyadic satisfaction, a nonperformance outcome of the experiment. Among the all-female dyads, racial composition of the dyad was significantly related to satisfaction: Interracial dyads had higher levels of satisfaction than intraracial dyads. Results fail to demonstrate a significant association between attraction and performance but do confirm that attraction and satisfaction are related, which is an assumption of the social exchange framework. (25 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Equal-status interracial contact: A review and revision of the concept.
column12: Riordan, Cornelius: Providence Coll
column13: International Journal of Intercultural Relations. Vol.2(2), Sum 1978, pp. 161-185.
column19: The existence of equal-status interracial interaction often has been taken for granted, despite the existence of negative and contradictory research results. A major problem lies in the fact that the equal-status concept has remained vague and inconsistently defined. In the present paper, a reformulation of the equal-status concept is proposed, and a critical review of previous research is developed. Studies in which equal status is confirmed, questionable, and nonexistent are differentiated. Many studies that obtained favorable results were found to have a questionable basis for their claim of equal status. It is suggested that these studies can be explained with reference to far less problematic variables that are also identified with the theory of contact (e.g., intimacy, common goals, institutional support, and racial/ethnic balance). Studies in which equal status is confirmed invariably result in positive change. Some research was uncovered in which the existence of equal status, although questionable, was maintained even in the face of negative results. A more critical and systematic approach is advised, and a reformulation of the equal status concept is offered. (Spanish & French abstracts) (5 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Sex differences in physical attractiveness preferences.
column12: Feinman, Saul: U Wyoming
column13: The Journal of Social Psychology. Vol.105(1), Jun 1978, pp. 43-52.
column19: Investigated the validity of stereotyped beliefs about sex differences in preferences for opposite sex coloration. The likes and dislikes of 482 female and 549 male Caucasian college students for eye color, hair color, and complexion color of the opposite sex were investigated by means of sexual selection questionnaire. Results indicate sex differences in both likes and dislikes for all 3 features. Males indicated somewhat greater preference for lighter female coloration, while females indicated somewhat greater preference for darker male coloration. These results are discussed in terms of the "kernel of truth" hypothesis of stereotyping, and the possible relationship to earlier research on semantic meanings of color and gender words. Special attention was paid to the aversion of both sexes to redheads, and to the implications for understanding the predominance of Black male/White female couplings in Black-White interracial marriage in America. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Nonverbal communication of affect in interracial dyads. [References].
column9:
Feldman, Robert S

Donohoe, Lawrence F
column12: Feldman, Robert S.: U Massachusetts, Amherst
column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.70(6), Dec 1978, pp. 979-987.
column19: Two experiments investigated the relationship between nonverbal behavior and the racial composition of a teacher-student dyad. The Multifactor Racial Attitude Inventory was used to measure prejudice. In Exp I, 36 high- and low-prejudiced White female undergraduates, acting as teachers, were led to praise successful White and Black students (confederates). Analysis of samples of nonverbal behavior showed that high-prejudiced teachers nonverbally discriminated between White and Black students (favoring Whites) significantly more than low-prejudiced teachers. In Exp II, 40 White and Black teachers (female undergraduates) taught successful White and Black students (confederates). Results show that both Whites and Blacks behaved nonverbally more positively to a student of their own race than to a student of the other race, although only same-race judges (12 White female undergraduates) could distinguish the differences in affect displayed by the Ss. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Modification of children's racial attitudes. [References].
column9:
Katz, Phyllis A

Zalk, Sue R
column12: Katz, Phyllis A.: Inst for Research on Social Problems, Boulder, CO
column13: Developmental Psychology. Vol.14(5), Sep 1978, pp. 447-461.
column19: Compared the relative efficacy of 4 short-term intervention techniques for modifying negative racial attitudes in 140 White 2nd and 5th graders in 2 city and suburban schools. These included (a) increased positive racial contact, (b) vicarious interracial contact, (c) reinforcement of the color black, and (d) perceptual differentiation of minority group faces. Ss were given a battery of attitudes indices and behavior measures, including the Koslin Social Distance Scale, the K-Z Test, the Friendship Questionnaire, and social distance, picture imitation, and discrimination tasks. Ss who were high in prejudice were randomly assigned to an experimental condition or a matched control group. Race of examiner was varied. Posttests were administered after 2 wks and again 4-6 mo later. Results reveal a significant short-term reduction in prejudice for all experimental groups on combined measures. Vicarious contact and perceptual approaches were more effective than the other 2 methods. Some interaction effects with grade and race of examiner were found. Long-term treatment effects were less pronounced, although some gains were maintained in the vicarious contact and perceptual differentiation groups. (32 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Contact theory and racial tolerance among high school students.
column12: Bullock, Charles S.: U Georgia
column13: School Review. Vol.86(2), Feb 1978, pp. 187-216.
column19: Studied the conditions under which school desegregation is related to racial tolerance. The relationships among several types of interracial contact and tolerance were examined for teenagers from schools with varying degrees of racial balance. 5,800 Georgia high school students, Black and White, of both sexes, responded to a paper-and-pencil survey measuring interaction with classmates of the other race. The schools were selected on the basis of racial sex from urban and rural districts. Factor analysis determined that all 8 survey questions measured the same dimension. Mere classroom attendance at a desegregated school was not associated with greater White tolerance for Blacks, but contact implying equal status did increase such tolerance. There were some sex differences in degree of contact associated with tolerance in both races. (50 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Direct and vicarious censure in the control of interracial aggression.
column12: Donnerstein, Marcia: Iowa State U
column13: Journal of Personality. Vol.46(1), Mar 1978, pp. 162-175.
column19: Explored the relative effectiveness of 2 strategies for controlling interracial aggression: observing other individuals censured for aggression and potential direct censure of the aggressor. 36 White male college students were provided with an opportunity to aggress under conditions designed to maximize or reduce each type of censure. A principal components analysis of the data revealed 2 orthogonal variates: direct aggression and indirect aggression. It was found that both observed censure and potential direct censure were effective in modifying directly aggressive responses. However, these forms of censure interacted in their effect on indirect aggression, such that observed censure was effective in reducing indirect aggression only under conditions of potential direct censure. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial attitudes and behavior at a summer camp. [References].
column9:
Clore, Gerald L

Bray, Robert M

Itkin, Stuart M

Murphy, Pamela
column12: Clore, Gerald L.: U Illinois
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.36(2), Feb 1978, pp. 107-116.
column19: Studied interracial attitudes and behavior during a series of week-long sessions at a summer camp. The camp involved prolonged, intimate contact between 92 Black and 104 White children of equal status. The situation was structured so that each living unit had a Black and a White counselor and equal numbers of Black and White campers. Measures of racial attitudes and behavior included a verbal attitude assessment, a series of interpersonal choices, and an analysis of photographs taken by the Ss. All 3 measures showed some significant and positive changes. Consistent with other studies, males generally showed more positive interracial attitudes and behavior than females. As a consequence of the elevated pretest scores of males, only females showed significant changes in attitudes and interpersonal choices. Possible rival hypotheses for the obtained changes are analyzed and rejected, and it is suggested that intergroup attitudes and behavior depend on the relative power and status of the groups in the social situation within which they interact. (21 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Describes an existing course on counseling ethnic minorities. Such topics as planning, goals, and content of the course are discussed. The 20 2-hr sessions involve (a) an awareness group experience, (b) training in facilitating interracial groups, (c) minority student panels, (d) counseling ethnic minorities individually, and (e) an ethnic dinner. Examples are presented of resultant student behavior and feedback following the course. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Social Perceptions in Black (?) and White.
column12: Teasley, Harold: University of Illinois, Chicago, IL, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.22(1), Jan,  1977
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1977, Vol 22(1), 13-14. Reviews the book, Variations in Black and White Perceptions of the Social Environment edited by Harry C. Triandis (see record 1977-05638-000). This book represents one of the better attempts at delving into the Black "psyche." The book is very successful and stands as one of the most thoughtfully planned and researched volumes on interracial differences yet written. The book's stated purposes are to learn about the ways of thinking found in the Black ghetto and to develop a map of this way of thinking that could be compared with the corresponding map of middle-class Whites. The idea is that if we teach Whites to understand the way of thinking of Blacks, they will get along better. In spite of the wealth of information that the book provides, it fails at an interpretive level to provide the map of ghetto thinking it seeks to provide. A far more disappointing aspect of the book is its usage of the concept of "ecosystem distrust" as an explanatory paradigm for summarizing the data on the subjective perceptions of the Black sample. The book is well worth reading because it provides a wealth of information about what Black people think. Whether it provides an accurate rationale for the reason why Black people think the way we do is debatable. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
