column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.69(5), Oct 1977, pp. 472.
column19: In "Motivation, Race, Social Class, and IQ" by W. Samuel, D. Soto, M. Parks, P. Ngissah, and B. Jones (Journal of Educational Psychology, 1976, 68, 273-285), there are two inaccuracies pertaining to Table 4. First, the standard deviation reported for low-socioeconomic status Whites with a Black tester in the low expectation-evaluative condition was misprinted as 2.89 instead of its true value of 19.24. Second, the F ratio for the Atmosphere x Socioeconomic Status x Race of Subject x Race of Experimenter interaction should be 2.84 (p < .10) rather than 8.76, as reported on p. 282 (first column, fifth line from the bottom). This interaction was peripheral to the main hypotheses of the article and does not affect its conclusions. All other F ratios are accurate. (The following abstract of the original article appeared in record 1976-23080-001.) Administered the Performance subscales of the WISC to 208 male and 208 female junior and senior high school students (aged 12-16 yrs) to test the prediction that if performance responded to the manipulation of the testee's motivation state, the size of interracial differences in mean IQ would be more flexible than was suggested by A. R. Jensen's (1969) review of the literature. The variables of test atmosphere (evaluative or gamelike), tester expectation (high or low), race of tester (Black or White), and race of S (Black or White) were manipulated. The pattern of mean IQ scores as well as self-ratings of mood indicated that test performance was optimal at moderate levels of motivational arousal. A replication of the experiment employing 208 male Ss increased cell sizes to the point that socioeconomic status could be treated as an independent variable. Results suggested that interracial differences in mean IQ might be erased depending upon the social psychological characteristics of the test setting and the socioeconomic background of the testee. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Internal evidence of cultural bias, in terms of various types of item analysis, was studied in the Wonderlic Personnel Test using large, representative samples of Whites and Blacks totaling approximately 1,500 Ss. Essentially, the lack of any appreciable Race by Items interaction and the high interracial similarity in rank order of item difficulties lead to the conclusion that the Wonderlic shows very little evidence of cultural bias with respect to the present samples, which, however, differed appreciably in mean scores. The items which accounted for the most variance within each racial group were, by and large, the same items that showed the largest interracial discrimination. column5: Personality characteristics and interracial contact as determinants of Black prejudice toward Whites.
column12: Foley, Linda A.: U North Florida, Coll of Arts & Sciences
column13: Human Relations. Vol.30(8), Aug 1977, pp. 709-720.
column19: Investigated how interracial contact affects the attitudes of Blacks towards Whites. The personality characteristics predictive of prejudice and prejudice changes, and how these characteristics differ between Blacks and Whites were also examined. 63 Black and 49 White male inmates newly admitted to a medium security state correctional institution served as Ss. Over a 1-mo period every new inmate was requested to answer a series of questionnaires to assess his cognitive complexity, self-esteem, attitudes toward people, and prejudice. Three weeks after his 1st session each S was requested to respond to a 2nd measure of prejudice. Results indicate that initially Whites were much more prejudiced than Blacks. The contact situation increased prejudice in Blacks and decreased prejudice in Whites. Within each group positive attitudes toward people in general predicted a decrease in prejudice. This was the only variable that functioned alike for both races. Simple cognitive structure, highly predictive of prejudice in Whites, was predictive of a very low level of prejudice in Blacks. Low self-esteem predicted a decrease in prejudice in Whites but an increase in prejudice in Blacks. It is concluded that implementation of contact situations should not be undertaken without adequate insight into the effects on both races. (28 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of team play on racial prejudice.
column9:
Edinger, Jack D

Bailey, Kent G

Lira, Frank T
column12: Edinger, Jack D.: Virginia Commonwealth U
column13: Psychological Reports. Vol.40(3, Pt 1), Jun 1977, pp. 887-898.
column19: Previous research has suggested that intrateam cooperation and interteam competition serve to increase attraction among teammates. The present study employed a card-game paradigm to investigate the efficacy of these factors in enhancing interracial acceptance. 32 Black and 32 White male volunteers (average age 23.5 yrs) in a drug abuse program were randomized in a 3 (type of game) x 2 (level of competition) x 2 (race) design. Results suggest the importance of both cooperation and competition in increasing interracial acceptance. Anticipation of a highly competitive situation proved to be more important than the actual team-interaction process. Results suggest that the generalizability of the treatment effects may vary across the races as a function of the racial balance in the daily social milieu. Further research must assess the reliability and significance of this generalization. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Homosexuality. Vol.2(3), Spr 1977, pp. 269-279.
column19: 45 male and 46 female undergraduates were shown a videotaped discussion of interracial dating by 5 heterosexual biological females and 1 cross-dressed male transsexual. Experimental Ss, who had been previously informed of the presence of the transsexual, were all able to identify her, significantly more often than control Ss who had not been told. Ratings obtained on 8 personal attributes of the transsexual and the 5 biological females prior to the Ss' attempts to identify the transsexual indicated that detection of the transsexual was related to perceived femininity and happiness. Based on these results and Ss' reports of how they correctly identified the transsexual, suggestions are made for a therapy package to assist transsexuals in minimizing the probability of their detection. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Modeling in the control of interracial aggression: The problem of generality.
column12: Donnerstein, Marcia: Iowa State U
column13: Journal of Personality. Vol.45(1), Mar 1977, pp. 100-116.
column19: Conducted a study to determine the degree of response generality associated with the observation of a nonaggressive or highly rewarding model in an interracial context. 48 White male undergraduates were given an opportunity to administer shock or rewards (points) to a Black target (student) via the Buss aggression machine in a context designed to promote negative responses. Prior to responding, one-third of the Ss observed a White peer model administer low level shocks, another third observed the same model administer high level rewards, while a final third did not observe the specific responses of the model. To examine the effects of modeling in comparison to an inhibitory strategy, half the Ss were informed that the target would have an opportunity to retaliate. While retaliation reduced aggression and increased reward, it also led to an increase in an indirect form of aggression (i.e., shock duration). Observation of either model, however, reduced aggression without increases in indirect aggression. In addition, observation of one type of model's response generalized to another response (e.g., observation of low aggression increased reward, while observation of high reward reduced aggression). Results are discussed in terms of strategies to reduce interracial aggression and the effectivenes of nonaggressive models as a means of aggression control. (21 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Encounters between Blacks and White liberals: The collision of stereotypes.
column12: Poskocil, Art: Hollins Coll
column13: Social Forces. Vol.55(3), Mar 1977, pp. 715-727.
column15: University of North Carolina Press; US
column19: Contends that interracial communication and cooperation are impaired by a generally high level of distrust on the part of Blacks toward White liberals, and that the idea that the typical White liberal is a hypocritical, sub-rosa racist is widely held. Research supporting this idea is discussed and findings are reinterpreted from symbolic interactionist and situationalist points of view. The position is developed that much of interaction dynamics between Blacks and liberal Whites is situationally determined. Such interaction is characterized by strong situationally specific cues, both internal (e.g., anger, fear, guilt), and external (e.g., color of other). In conjunction with behavioral demand factors, emanating from cultural myths which set up expectations for specific behavior patterns from self and other in such encounters, these cues operate to elicit stereotypical behavior from Blacks and Whites as "interracial interactants." From the perspective developed, a reconceptualization of interracial interaction is presented, and its implications are discussed. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Reviews the book, Understanding social psychology by Stephen Worchel and Joel Cooper (see record 1976-27751-000). The authors have "attempted to provide the student with a comprehensive view of experimental social psychology and with a glimpse of how the findings from this field may (or may not) be applied to understanding such social phenomena as aggression, interracial understanding, advertising, attraction, emergence of leadership, propaganda campaigns, love, altruism, and environmental problems." The 14 chapters cover the usual topical areas of mainstream experimental social psychology, summaries to each chapter are provided, and an appendix on "Experimentation and Ethics" is included. column5: More Ado About Psychology and Race.
column12: Jones, Reginald L.: Department of Afro-American Studies, University of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.21(1), Jan,  1976
column19: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1976, Vol 21(1), 31-32. Reviews the book, Psychology and Race edited by Peter Watson (1974). This book was written to present an objective account of race and racism from various social science perspectives. It is divided into two parts: Part One, Aspects of Interracial Interaction, has three sections. The first, Focus on the Majority Group (Section A), consists of papers on the development of racial awareness and prejudice in children, the measurement of prejudice, cognitive and affective dimensions of prejudice, and techniques for reducing prejudice. Section B, Focus on the Minority Group, consists of papers on Negro self-identity, race and marginality (mixed bloods and Jews), and the problems of adjustment and assimilation of immigrants. The four papers in Section C focus on Interaction, treat various dimensions of behavior, attitude, and performance in interracial situations. Part two is titled The Race Variable and Key Issues in Social Psychology. This title is misleading. In reality the 10 papers, under the four subheadings of The Interaction of Personality and Culture, Education, Language, and Miscellany of Other Key Issues (including psychiatric disorders of minority groups, crime and delinquency in immigrant and minority groups, and tests as sources of discrimination in personnel decisions) only in part deal with issues in social psychology as generally conceived. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Dissent in small groups.
column9:
Bradley, Patricia H

MacHamon, C

Harris, Alan M
column12: Bradley, Patricia H.: Indiana U
column13: Journal of Communication. Vol.26(4), Fal 1976, pp. 155-159.
column19: Studied the social influence of a deviate on members of the majority in small informal discussion groups. Ss were 48 college students. The deviate positions on each of the issues for discussion were (a) opposition to the legalization of abortion, (b) opposition to interracial marriage, (c) opposition to living together before marriage, and (d) advocacy of violence as a legitimate means of political protest. 12 deviates were selected. They were asked to formulate arguments concerning a topic, and each was provided with arguments to supplement his or her own ideas. 12 groups, each containing a deviate and 3 other participants, initially discussed 1 of the 4 topics for 30 min. Each naive member of these groups was later assigned to a new group in which the same topic was discussed. Arguments presented by the deviates were identified from tapes of the sessions, and their use by members of the original group in the successive groups was traced. Analysis of the data showed that the arguments presented by the deviates were repeated in the successive groups with a frequency significantly greater than chance. Arguments presented by the "violence" deviate were repeated with significantly greater frequency than those of the other deviates. It is concluded that arguments presented by a deviate do influence the choice of arguments by majority members in subsequent discussions on the same topic. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Issues in the treatment of sexually dysfunctioning couples of Afro-American descent. [References].
column9:
Wyatt, Gail E

Strayer, Richard G

Lobitz, W. Charles
column12: Wyatt, Gail E.: U California Neuropsychiatric Inst, Los Angeles
column13: Psychotherapy: Theory, Research & Practice. Vol.13(1), Spr 1976, pp. 44-50.
column15: Division of Psychotherapy (29), American Psychological Association; US
column19: Delineates the myths of Black sexuality and the issues involved in the use of an interracial therapy team which must be considered in applying directive programs to the treatment of sexually dysfunctioning Afro-American couples. Myths concerning the hypersexuality of Blacks depict Black males as sensual, aggressive, and easily aroused lovers who have unusually long latencies to ejaculation, and depict Black females as requiring intercourse for sexual gratification and being able to dispense with foreplay. Interracial therapy teams raise issues connected with differences and similarities in the life styles of therapist and client, antagonism of the client toward the therapist, and excessive consciousness of race on the part of the therapist. Furthermore, the special factors involved in a behavioral approach to sexual dysfunctioning raise issues connected with (a) the therapist being placed in the role of sexual expert, (b) dilution of the therapeutic presence by the therapist's attempt to compensate for stereotypic reactions to Black sexuality, and (c) behaviors that are accepted as normal within the client's culture being treated as sexually deviant by the therapist. A case history elucidating management of the myths and issues is presented, and implications for treatment and research are discussed. (34 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of helping a less competent member of a cooperating interracial group on the development of interpersonal attraction. [References].
column9:
Blanchard, Fletcher A

Cook, Stuart W
column12: Blanchard, Fletcher A.: Smith Coll
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.34(6), Dec 1976, pp. 1245-1255.
column19: Investigated the effects of helping a less competent member of a cooperating interracial group on the helper's attraction for the recipient of his help. A 2-3 factorially designed experiment was conducted with 64 White US Air Force airmen. The success or failure of the group and race of the recipient served as additional independent variables. Ss, who were from southern small towns and rural areas, felt significantly greater satisfaction with the group experience and greater attraction for a less competent group member when they were induced to help him than when help was provided by another member of the group. Ss also felt greater satisfaction with the group experience and developed greater attraction for their groupmates when their group was successful than did Ss who participated in failing groups. Each of the effects held for both White and Black recipients of help. Implications of these findings for the management of the integration process are discussed. (36 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The weakening of authoritarianism in Black and White college students.
column12: Baker, Therese L.: DePaul U
column13: Sociology & Social Research. Vol.60(4), Jul 1976, pp. 440-460.
column19: Tested the hypothesis that the culture shock Black students experience in attending a predominantly White college leads to a greater weakening of authoritarianism in these students as compared with their White peers. The question of how far interracial contact is related to the liberalizing or narrowing of attitudes was also examined. The study discusses how the culture shock process might work in a predominantly White college, how it might bring about a weakening in authoritarian attitudes over time for Black students, and what processes would encourage or mitigate the effects. Longitudinal data on 407 Black and White college freshmen are analyzed. Weakening in authoritarianism was measured by the Autonomy scale of the Omnibus Personality Inventory. In support of the culture shock hypothesis, Black students who were protected from the unfamiliarity of a predominantly White college by close, dependent relationships with faculty were less subject to liberalizing attitudinal change than Black students not so protected. Having a greater number of student friends (i.e., greater exposure to the unfamiliar environment) was, however, associated with greater change towards nonauthoritarian attitudes. These relationships varied for White students in a way generally suggested by the hypothesis. (2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Group methods for reducing racial prejudice and discrimination.
column9:
Breckheimer, Steven E

Nelson, Rosemery O
column12: Breckheimer, Steven E.: U North Carolina, Greensboro
column13: Psychological Reports. Vol.39(3, Pt 2), Dec 1976, pp. 1259-1268.
column19: To compare the efficacy of various group methods in reducing racial prejudice, Black and White high school students were assigned to a no-treatment control group and to 4 experimental groups of 5 Ss each: game-playing, school-issues discussion, racial discussion, and racial role-playing. After 6 sessions, all experimental groups reduced their verbal prejudice on the Respect factor of the Behavioral Differential, the game-playing group increased their interracial behavioral interactions, and the racial discussion and racial role-playing groups increased their interracial choices of project partners. Implications for various theories of the origin and treatment of prejudice are discussed. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Children's evaluation of the colors black and white and their interracial play behavior.
column9:
Stabler, John R

Zeig, James A

Rembold, Anne B
column12: Stabler, John R.: Georgia State U
column13: Child Study Journal. Vol.6(4), 1976, pp. 191-197.
column19: Previous research has demonstrated that the connotations of the color white are positive and the connotations of the color black are negative. The present study investigated the relationship between children's response to these colors and their interracial behavior. 20 Black and White male and female 4-5 yr olds were observed in a free play situation on a school playground. Color preference and color attitudes were measured in 3 different ways. A correlation was found between playground behavior (i.e., positive or negative play with peers) and response to the colors black and white as measured in a situation in which Ss guessed the locus of origin of positive and negative self-evaluative statements broadcast simultaneously from black and white boxes. The correlation was substantially higher for females than for males. The high correlation for females is discussed in terms of a difference between the sexes in rate of perceptual and linguistic development. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The occupational class of couples entering into interracial marriages.
column12: Monahan, Thomas P.: Villanova U
column13: Journal of Comparative Family Studies. Vol.7(2), Sum 1976, pp. 175-192.
column15: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column19: A review of the literature and the miscellany of statistics and studies raises a question as to the substantive validity of the untested thesis that, on the whole, caste and class positions have been traded off in White marriages with Blacks and that such marriages are peculiarly lower class. Based on an examination of all occupational information given for couples and their parents on the Philadelphia marriage license records in recent years (1960-1962 and 1965-1970), it was found that all socioeconomic groups significantly participated in interracial marriages, with professional and white-collar groups remarkably well represented. Generally, there was no distinguishable degree of "marrying up" or "marrying down" by Whites and Blacks with one another. A case by case study of the relative occupational position of husband and wife indicated a prevalent position of equality; but when there was a difference between Blacks and Whites, Whites more often married Blacks of lower status. Other races in mixed marriages present a different picture which merits separate and further analysis. (55 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Effects of teachers' attitudes on discipline problems in schools recently desegregated.
column12: Peretti, Peter O.: Kennedy-King Coll, City Coll Chicago
column13: Education. Vol.97(2), Win 1976, pp. 136-140.
column19: Responses to open-ended and forced-choice questionnaires by 48 elementary school teachers indicated that the effects of integration on classroom interracial associations, as well as disciplinary climate, were dependent on the Ss' attitudes toward the program and, subsequently, on behaviors directed toward the children involved. It was observed that positive attitudes toward busing for integration tended to modify teaching and social techniques, leading to reduction of the strain which might occur at least during the 1st yr of desegregation. An S's ability to think and act positively were found to lead to favorable interracial classroom interactions. Positive factors also decreased the probability of interracial classroom discipline problems. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Personality and situational influences on changes in prejudice: A replication of Cook's railroad game in a prison setting. [References].
column12: Foley, Linda A.: U North Florida
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.34(5), Nov 1976, pp. 846-856.
column19: Attempted to replicate S. W. Cook's (1972) laboratory study of racial prejudice in a natural setting. The objective was to determine the influences of personality and situational factors on changes in prejudice. The environment studied was a maximum security state prison for males. Ss were 83 Black and White inmates admitted to the institution during a 1-mo period. The different environments within the institutions were defined in terms of the norms as perceived by the residents of the different living areas. Ss were pretested for cognitive complexity, self-esteem, and attitudes toward people in general. Interracial attitudes of these Ss were measured at 2 time periods: as the Ss entered the institution and 3 wks later. Results indicate that an individual tends to change racial attitudes toward the norms of his living area, and the amount of change is dependent on the individual's cognitive complexity, self-esteem, and attitudes toward people in general. (24 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Variables in interracial aggression: Exposure to aggressive interracial interactions.
column12: Donnerstein, Marcia: Drake U
column13: The Journal of Social Psychology. Vol.100(1), Oct 1976, pp. 111-121.
column19: An experiment employing 90 White male college students examined the influence of observing certain aggressive Black-White interactions on subsequent interracial aggression. Before aggressing against a Black target themselves, Ss were exposed to a White person aggressing against a Black person using high, low, or unspecified electric shocks, and to the Black person counteraggressing using 1 of the same 3 response patterns. Prior to statistical analysis, 2 orthogonal variates were identified: direct and indirect aggression. Less direct aggression was delivered to a Black target when Ss witnessed a White person delivering low level shocks to a Black than when Ss witnessed unspecified White behavior. Except for a decrement in direct aggression produced when Ss viewed unspecified shocking by a White and low shocking by a Black, Ss' aggression was not influenced by Black counteraggression. The usefulness of observational experience in modifying interracial aggression is discussed. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: IQ test performance of Black children adopted by White families. [References].
column12: Scarr, Sandra: U Minnesota Inst of Child Development
column13: American Psychologist. Vol.31(10), Oct 1976, pp. 726-739.
column19: The poor performance of Black children on IQ tests and in school has been hypothesized to arise from (a) genetic racial differences or (b) cultural/environmental disadvantages. To separate genetic factors from rearing conditions, 130 Black and interracial children adopted by advantaged White families were studied. The socially classified Black adoptees, whose natural parents were educationally average, scored above the IQ and the school achievement mean of the White population. Biological children of the adoptive parents scored even higher. Genetic and environmental determinants of differences among the Black and interracial adoptees were largely confounded. The high IQ scores of the socially classified Black adoptees indicate malleability for IQ under rearing conditions that are relevant to the tests and the schools. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Dimensions of racial ideology: A study of urban Black attitudes.
column9:
Turner, Castellano B

Wilson, William J
column12: Turner, Castellano B.: U Massachusetts, Amherst
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.32(2), Spr 1976, pp. 139-152.
column19: Analyzed 6 dimensions of racial ideology, using interview data from 1,934 Blacks in a Northern and a Southern city. Blacks who favored separatism tended to be more alienated, fearful of race genocide, race conscious, and supportive of racial violence than those who endorsed interracial cooperation. Suspicion, distrust, and estrangement toward White society were particularly evident in the sentiments of Blacks less than 30 yrs old who lived in the Northern city and who had low socioeconomic status. Younger persons and males were substantially more in favor of racial violence than older persons and females. Results did not uphold the view that less privileged Blacks are more conservative in their assessment of race relations or the view that the depressed ghetto experience restricts their knowledge about and responses to racial subjugation. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Dimensions of verbal racial attitudes: Interracial marriage and approaches to racial equality.
column9:
Brigham, John C

Woodmansee, John J

Cook, Stuart W
column12: Brigham, John C.: Florida State U
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.32(2), Spr 1976, pp. 9-21.
column19: The empirical approach to the analysis of attitude organization suggests that verbal racial attitudes are not organized in terms of cognitive, affective, and conative (or behavioral) components, but rather in terms of content areas that cross-cut this structural trichotomy. A racial attitude inventory made up of 9 empirically identified dimensions successfully predicted Whites' membership in attitudinal criterion groups. Two additional dimensions were hypothesized: (a) reactions to interracial marriage and (b) preference between 2 approaches to racial equality for Black Americans, one stressing changes in society and one stressing changes in Blacks themselves. Cluster analyses confirmed the existence of these 2 additional dimensions as well as the original 9. A validation study indicates that both new dimensions as well as the original 9 successfully differentiate groups of Whites known to differ in racial attitude. (11/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The today and likely tomorrow of American race relations.
column12: Ashmore, Richard D.: Rutgers U, Livingston Coll, New Brunswick
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.32(2), Spr 1976, pp. 1-7.
column19: Briefly reviews the interest in race relations shown by social psychologists since the 1950s. Current interest focuses on the research process itself in the study of race relations, particularly the role of the researchers' attitudes and values. The present Journal issue is organized into 3 sections. The 1st 5 articles deal with how White Americans perceive, evaluate, and respond to Black Americans. The 2nd series (3 articles) deals with the reverse: how Black Americans relate to White Americans. Two articles in the 3rd section directly compare and contrast the attitudes of Blacks and Whites. It is felt that as a group the papers offer some new methods and concepts that seem promising for the reduction of interracial conflict, but that conflict will nevertheless continue in the immediate future. (33 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Tokenism, reverse discrimination, and egalitarianism in interracial behavior.
column12: Dutton, Donald G.: U British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.32(2), Spr 1976, pp. 93-107.
column19: Research is reviewed which demonstrates the existence of reverse discrimination (majority group members treating other majority group members worse than members of a minority group) and tokenism (a decrease in compliance with large interracial requests after complying with smaller requests). While both phenomena can be demonstrated experimentally, within-S evidence also exists for egalitarianism (equal treatment to both majority and minority group members). It appears that when Ss are given a means of monitoring their own behavior toward majority and minority group members, egalitarianism results. In the absence of an opportunity for monitoring, reverse discrimination occurs. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race and the counseling process: An overview.
column12: Bryson, Seymour: Southern Illinois U Rehabilitation Inst
column13: Journal of Employment Counseling. Vol.13(2), Jun 1976, pp. 68-77.
column19: Discusses racial issues in client analysis, counselor analysis, and the counseling process which suggest that present counselor training programs do not provide adequate preparation for meeting the Black population. The counseling profession can no longer assume that methods and strategies effective with one group will be equally successful with another. Students must be given opportunities for contact with individuals from varied backgrounds. Counselors must learn to adjust to the needs and attitudes of clients, and must become aware of social conditions, of the insensitivity of counselors to Black clients' reactions to negative interracial experiences, and of the basic distrust felt by many Black clients for White counselors. (32 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: William, Samuel: California State U, Sacramento
column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.68(3), Jun 1976, pp. 273-285.
column19: Administered the Performance subscales of the WISC to 208 male and 208 female junior and senior high school students (aged 12-16 yrs) to test the prediction that if performance responded to the manipulation of the testee's motivation state, the size of interracial differences in mean IQ would be more flexible than was suggested by A. R. Jensen's (1969) review of the literature. The variables of test atmosphere (evaluative or gamelike), tester expectation (high or low), race of tester (Black or White), and race of S (Black or White) were manipulated. The pattern of mean IQ scores as well as self-ratings of mood indicated that test performance was optimal at moderate levels of motivational arousal. A replication of the experiment employing 208 male Ss increased cell sizes to the point that socioeconomic status could be treated as an independent variable. Results suggested that interracial differences in mean IQ might be erased depending upon the social psychological characteristics of the test setting and the socioeconomic background of the testee. (33 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Classroom unit sociometric indices of inter-racial cohesiveness: Psychometric characteristics.
column12: Busch, John C.: U North Carolina, Greensboro
column13: Journal of Instructional Psychology. Vol.3(2), Spr 1976, pp. 20-24.
column19: Describes a procedure by which sociometric choice data are used to construct an index of cross-racial cohesiveness when the classroom is the unit of measurement. Two separate indices, derived from student work and play choices, were computed for each of 28 classrooms in Grades 1-6 of 3 rural schools. The reliability (stability) of the indices over a 7-mo period, intercorrelation of indices at 2 time periods, and normality of distributions were investigated. Reliability was judged to be satisfactory, and 3 of the 4 distributions were judged normal. The index is considered to be an acceptable measure useful in interpersonal relations curricula assessment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race, sex and social example: An analysis of character portrayals on inter-racial television entertainment.
column9:

column12: Donagher, Patricia C.: State U New York, Stony Brook
column13: Psychological Reports. Vol.37(3, Pt 2), Dec 1975, pp. 1023-1034.
column19: Nine regularly broadcast programs having bi-racial representation with at least 1 male and 1 female portrayal were selected and a total of 60 characters analyzed according to 8 categories of interpersonal and self-control behaviors. White males were aggressive and persistent but nonaltruistic and unable to resist temptations to break the rules of society or repair the damage they caused to others. Black males were nonaggressive, persistent altruistic, and more likely than any other group to make reparation for injury. White females were nonaggressive, likely to make reparation for damage to others, and altruistic; they displayed resistance to temptation but little delay of gratification-task persistence. Black females exhibited the same self-control pattern as White women and also were nonaggressive, nonaltruistic, and not inclined toward reparation for damage to others; their most outstanding behavior, however, was a high level of explaining feelings to increase understanding, resolve strife, and reassure others. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

However, data from American 8th, 10th, and 12th graders and their teachers show that both racial prejudice and antisemitism are rampant in these age groups. Causes, solutions, and implications for educators are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: The Urban Review. Vol.8(2), Sum 1975, pp. 137-144.
column19: Proposes 5 political and 8 educational conditions which might produce an increase in well-being among Black Americans greater than the limited increase that took place between 1954 and 1974. School desegregation and integration are distinguished, and it is suggested that the latter would be enhanced by (a) racial equality in access to the physical and social resources of the schools, (b) classroom desegregation, (c) abolition of nonflexible ability grouping, (d) adequate school services and remedial training, (e) commencement of desegregation in early grades, (f) interracial staffs, (g) substantial percentages of Blacks within institutions, and (h) distinguishing between issues of race and class through enrollment of both middle- and working-class Blacks as well as Whites. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effect of attitudinal similarity on interracial aggression.
column12: Donnerstein, Edward: Iowa State U
column13: Journal of Personality. Vol.43(3), Sep 1975, pp. 485-502.
column19: Examined the influence of expected retaliation and attitudinal similarity on aggression and reward delivered by 122 male undergraduates to Black and White targets. Results show that both retaliation and attitudinal similarity increased the level of reward and reduced the level of aggression delivered to Black targets. However, modifications in these direct behaviors induced through retaliation were generally accompanied by increases in less direct forms of aggressive behavior. No such increase accompanied modifications induced through attitudinal similarity. Results are discussed in terms of the usefulness of instigation-based vs inhibition-based strategies in the control of interracial aggression. (25 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial imitation at a summer camp. [References].
column9:
Eaton, Warren O

Clore, Gerald L
column12: Eaton, Warren O.: U Illinois, Champaign
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.32(6), Dec 1975, pp. 1099-1105.
column19: Collected imitation data at week-long summer camp sessions involving prolonged and intimate contact between Black children and White children of equal status. As part of an initiation ceremony, 57 Black and 55 White 8-12 yr olds observed the behavior of unfamiliar Black adult and White adult models responding to the commands of an Indian chief. In 3 separate camp sessions, the proportions of responses imitative of racially different models were 0.40, 0.42, and 0.37 for campers observed on the 1st day and 0.52, 0.49, and 0.53 for those observed on the 5th day. The overall difference between low and high contact groups was significant (p < .05). A separate-sample pretest-posttest design ruled out threats to the internal validity of the study, and the observation of behavior in a naturalistic context enhanced the ecological validity. It is concluded that interracial contact effects were not limited to changes in behavior among the children themselves but generalized to unfamiliar adults encountered in the same setting. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Administered a demographic and attitude questionnaire to 1,131 Black and White students in a newly integrated junior high school in Berkeley, California. Social class origin, race, and grade level did not have any effects on student responses to 11 of 19 items dealing with work in school, attitudes toward school, or making new friends. column19: Describes intergroup classroom experiences in 2 Washington, D.C. colleges, one largely Black and one largely White. 12 interaction sessions occurred in pairs over 3 academic years, each college acting as host for 1 session of each pair. Interactions were designed to provide interracial experiences and to facilitate classroom learning through group participation. Preparations for sessions were made jointly by the 2 instructors to insure appropriate scheduling, objectives, techniques, evaluation, feedback, and integration of group experiences with content of courses. Results were that students (a) grasped group-interaction principles, (b) related group experiences to subject matter, and (c) interacted meaningfully with the teachers and each other. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effect of relative competence of group members upon interpersonal attraction in cooperating interracial groups. [References].
column9:
Blanchard, Fletcher A

Weigel, Russell H

Cook, Stuart W
column12: Blanchard, Fletcher A.: Smith Coll
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.32(3), Sep 1975, pp. 519-530.
column19: Examined the effects of competence of group member and group success-failure on interpersonal attraction of White Ss for both White and Black group mates in cooperating interracial groups. Ss were 60 military service men from southern small towns and rural areas. Ss exhibited less attraction for a Black group mate when he performed less competently than when he performed competently. No parallel effect for competence was found on attraction to White group mates. Ss liked and respected both their White and their Black group mates more following group success than following group failure. There was a Competence * Success-Failure interaction on attraction for Black group mates; the combination of low competence and group failure produced the least liking and respect. The lowered attraction expressed toward a less competent Black group mate is explained in terms of fulfilling the Ss' stereotypes. The lack of a competence effect when White Ss rated White group mates is discussed in relation to other cues that become important when interaction extends beyond first-impression situations. The Competence * Group Success-Failure interaction on attraction to Black group mates is interpreted with regard to the scapegoat hypothesis. (47 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Jewish liberals in transition: Ambivalence toward ethnic integration.

column13: Sociology & Social Research. Vol.59(3), Apr 1975, pp. 274-287.
column19: White liberals believing in ethnic integration were questioned on (a) busing in schools, (b) entrance of Blacks into their occupations, (c) Blacks entering predominantly White neighborhoods, (d) quotas in colleges, (e) apartment rentals to Blacks, (f) and hiring Blacks; the Jewish portion of the sample responded to questions on Black anti-Semitism. These interracial situations thrust Jewish liberals more often than their non-Jewish counterparts into brief dilemmas and role conflicts which they resolved by mechanisms redefining liberal roles. It is argued that although the 204-person sample was representative of only the upper range of statuses among Jews and non-Jews, it permitted rigorous test of an ethnic identification hypothesis among those most committed to racial liberalism. (23 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Peer acceptance and school-related variables in an integrated junior high school. [References].
column9:
Carter, Donald E

DeTine, Susan L

Spero, June

Benson, Forrest W
column12: Carter, Donald E.: State University Coll New York, Buffalo
column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.67(2), Apr 1975, pp. 267-273.
column19: Interracial peer acceptance at the junior high school level was related to 9 predictor variables: grade point average (GPA), IQ, attendance, self-concept of academic ability, sex, race, age, years in the school, and classroom racial composition. 322 7th- and 8th-grade students from predominantly lower-middle-class backgrounds were administered modified Syracuse Scales of Human Relations, measuring academic and social acceptance. Analysis of variance results show that White Ss slightly preferred Whites for the satisfaction of their academic and social needs. However, with stepwise multiple regression analysis, race was not a significant predictor variable for academic or social acceptance by White Ss. GPA and sex were the most prominent predictors of acceptance. Black Ss accepted both Black peers and White peers equally for academic interaction but preferred Blacks for social interaction. Race was a significant predictor variable for academic and social acceptance by Black Ss. However, race was secondary to GPA and/or sex for academic acceptance by Black females and Black males. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Blanchard, Fletcher A

Adelman, Leonard

column12: Blanchard, Fletcher A.: U Colorado
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.31(6), Jun 1975, pp. 1020-1030.
column19: The effect of group success and failure upon interpersonal attraction in cooperating interracial groups was investigated in a 2 * 2 * 2 factorially designed experiment. The level of participation in the group's decision making (high or low) and race (Black or White) served as the additional independent variables. 56 18-21 yr old White male Ss from small southern US towns exhibited significantly greater attraction for groupmates under the success as opposed to the failure condition. No main effects for the race of the group member being evaluated or the level of participation in decision making were obtained, nor were there interactions among any of the 3 independent variables. Separate analyses of the attraction ratings given the White and the Black groupmates further revealed that whatever elevated or depressed the ratings for one, similarly affected the ratings for the other. A general satisfaction-dissatisfaction interpretation is offered to explain the effect of group success-failure on interpersonal attraction. Implications for the scapegoat hypothesis are discussed. (56 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: To provide unambiguous evidence for racial discrimination in apartment rentals, a total of 6 male and 6 female Black and White confederates visited 18 apartment house managers. They inquired about the availability of an apartment and the amount of rent and other fees. While no racial discrimination with respect to rents and fees was found, data revealed substantial discrimination with respect to apartment availability. Results are discussed in terms of research by D. A. Johnson et al (1971) on interracial interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Attempted to study what activities black and white students jointly engage in when they attend desegregated schools. For 6 mo the authors attended classes a few days a week. Data were collected through informal interviews, background material, and scheduled formal interviews. Interracial interaction occurred only when the students were academically motivated and the teacher was highly structured. Generally there was significant separation between the races and evidence of deep racial hatred. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Night school students from 2 racially homogeneous Southern universities (37 white and 20 black students) participated in a simulation exercise-Inter-Nation Simulation-for 4 wks. All 10 prototype nations in the game were of mixed racial composition. The only significant differences between blacks and whites were on questions evaluating simulation as a learning device (with white students rating the exercise much higher). No differences between blacks and whites were found on other variables, including approval or disapproval of the interracial nature of the simulation and the value of the simulation as a device for improving racial understanding. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: C. Korte and S. Milgram (see record 1970-12489-001) previously found a high completion rate for acquaintance chains started by whites when the target person was white vs black. Results of the present study rule out the explanation that lower completion rate to blacks was due to lack of information as to the target person's race; in fact, white "starters" reached black targets more readily than white targets. column19: Presented the block-design subtest of the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children in 2 forms, the standard red/white and an alternative blue/yellow, to 2 groups of 4th- and 5th-grade children. 20 black and 20 white children performed the red/white task with no significant differences between their scores. Another 20 black and 20 white children performed the blue/yellow task showing a significant interracial difference. Within the group of black children there was also a significant difference between the red/white design scores and the blue/yellow design scores. It is proposed that genetically determined differences in the pigmentation of the fundus oculi account for these results. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Longer, more intense programs specifically focused on modifying the attitudes of both white and black participants might be more effective in reducing prejudice. column19: Conducted 2 experiments designed to demonstrate the existence of a self-fulfilling prophecy mediated by nonverbal behavior in an interracial interaction. Exp I, which employed 14 white job interviewers (male university students) and 5 trained white and black job applicants, demonstrated that black applicants received (a) less immediacy, (b) higher rates of speech errors, and (c) shorter amounts of interview time. Exp II employed 30 naive, white applicants (male university students) and 2 trained white interviewers. In this experiment Ss received behaviors that approximated those given either the black or white applicants in Exp I. Results indicate that Ss treated like the blacks of Exp I were judged to perform less adequately and to be more nervous in the interview situation than Ss treated like the whites. The former Ss also reciprocated with less proximate positions and rated the interviewers as being less adequate and friendly. Implications for black unemployment are discussed. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Administered psychological tests at 8 mo and at 4 yrs of age to 129 children of interracial (black-white) matings in the longitudinal Collaborative Study. Ss were divided into 2 groups, depending on whether the mother was the white or the black partner. Stanford-Binet IQs of the 4-yr-old Ss of white mothers averaged approximately 9 points higher than those with black mothers (p < .01). The only behavioral difference on the Bayley Scales of Infant Development at 8 mos of age was in favor of the interracial children of black mothers (p < .05). Results support the hypothesis that postnatal environmental factors make a very substantial contribution to racial differences in intelligence test performance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Lennox, Vicki L
column12: Dutton, Donald G.: U. British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.29(1), Jan 1974, pp. 65-71.
column19: Gave false autonomic feedback to 3 groups of undergraduates (n = 25 each), leading them to believe that they might possibly be prejudiced. After leaving the laboratory, 1 group was panhandled by a black and 1 group by a white, while the 3rd group was not panhandled. On the following day, all Ss were asked by a person not ostensibly connected to the prior study to donate their time to an interracial "brotherhood" campaign. Those who had been panhandled by the black donated less time than the nonpanhandled group. Those panhandled by the white tended to donate more time than did the nonpanhandled group, although this difference was not significant. Results are discussed with reference to reverse discrimination (particularly "tokenism") and to the "foot-in-the-door" technique of J. L. Freedman and S. C. Fraser (see record 1966-10825-001). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Conducted an attitudinal and demographic poll of 1,391 undergraduates at a large state university, 84% of whom were white. Results show that 39% of the freshmen indicated they had no close friends of another race, with upperclass responses showing a similar pattern. Most black Ss reported having spent most of their lives in the city, whereas Ss from the other groups (white, Oriental, Spanish-American, and American Indian) indicated they had spent most time in the suburbs. Only 9% of all Ss disagreed that it would be enjoyable to have a roommate of another race, and no sex differences or Sex * Race interactions were observed in responses. Data indicate the existence of a cultural parallelism among students from various minority groups, and emphasize the need for continued interracial contact. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Silverman, Irwin: York U., Downsview, Ontario, Canada

column19: Ascertained the extent to which black and white 7th-12th graders interacted socially on school grounds and their attitudes toward each other across time during the 1st semester of an integration program in 3 southern secondary schools. Data were obtained in the 3rd, 8th, and 13th wks by 2 graduate assistants who counted the total number of students interacting and the number who were interacting in racially mixed groups, separating these into same- and opposite-sex interactions. Every S interacting with one or more others was counted. Ss also completed racial attitude questionnaires at the 3rd and 13th wk of the semester. Interracial interactions remained sparse throughout the semester and over time showed no increases approaching significance, although attitudes did become more tolerant. Several effects on both interactions and attitudes related to race, sex, and grade level are reported. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Changes in sociometric choices following forced integration of an elementary school.
column12: Shaw, Marvin E.: U. Florida
column13: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.29(4), 1973, pp. 143-157.
column19: Administered sociometric questionnaires to all pupils in the 4th, 5th, and 6th grades in an elementary school in February 1970 (soon after forced integration had occurred), again in June 1970, and again to 5th and 6th grade pupils in February 1971. Both blacks and whites at all 3 grade levels chose significantly more members of their own race than members of the other race; blacks rejected whites significantly less than would be expected by chance, an effect which increased over time for older pupils; and, initially, whites rejected blacks less frequently than expected by chance, but shifted to approximately chance rejection of blacks. In January and February 1971, 2 observers counted interactions among pupils in each grade for 10 min for 5 wks. As expected, interactions increased significantly with grade level; however, subsequent analysis revealed that the primary variable determining interracial interactions is the proportion of blacks to whites in the classroom. A relatively low proportion of minority members (black or white) appears to be most effective in improving interracial relations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Black and white Marine squad leaders' perceptions of racially mixed squads.
column9:
Hill, Walter H

Fox, William M
column12: Hill, Walter H.: U. Florida
column13: Academy of Management Journal. Vol.16(4), Dec 1973, pp. 680-686.
column19: Administered a questionnaire to 7 black and 22 white US Marine Corps squad leaders concerning their attitudes and actions toward 87 white, 35 black, and 16 Puerto Rican members of their squads. Non-task-prescribed dimensions (e.g., uncertainty, avoidance of failure, administration of reprimands and praise, and evaluation of subordinates) were measured. Results indicate that white Ss gave proportionately more reprimands to their white subordinates and better performance ratings to their black subordinates than did the black Ss. They also gave more praise to the Puerto Ricans. Blacks reported better relations with white subordinates than did white Ss. It is concluded that recent emphasis on racial harmony in the Armed Forces has resulted in (a) white leaders treating their black subordinates with special care and (b) black leaders working to make their interracial relations free of discrimination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:
Dutton, Donald G

Lake, Robert A
column12: Dutton, Donald G.: U. British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.28(1), Oct 1973, pp. 94-100.
column19: Tested the notion that "reverse discrimination" (i.e., more favorable behavior by whites toward minority group members than toward other whites), may result from whites' observations of "threatening cues of prejudice in their own behavior." Ss were 40 white male and 40 white female undergraduates who had evaluated themselves as relatively unprejudiced and had ranked the value "equality" as high on a series of questionnaires and rating scales (including Rokeach's ranking of terminal values). Under the guise of an investigation of "involuntary control of autonomic behavior," Ss in the high-threat condition were led to believe, through the use of false physiological feedback, that they had displayed physiological responses indicative of prejudice. In the low-threat condition, the false feedback was similar to that given to neutral stimuli and thus was indicative of a lack of prejudice. Following the laboratory session, Ss were panhandled by either a white or a black confederate. As hypothesized, a significant Race of Panhandler * Threat condition interaction was obtained; the black panhandler received more money from Ss in the high-threat condition than from Ss in the low-threat condition, while no difference was observed in the contributions to the white panhandler by Ss in the 2 threat conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Geneticists and the biology of race crossing.
column12: Provine, William B.: Cornell U.
column15: American Assn for the Advancement of Science; US
column19: Presents an historical review of the attitudes of British and American geneticists on the social significance of race crossing. The influence of the studies of F. Galton and of G. Mendel on late 19th and early 20th century thinking is discussed, emphasizing the stress on "disharmonious combinations" caused by intermingling the genetic traits of different races. Serious questioning of this thesis is traced from the mid-1920s. A change in published statements on race crossing from condemnation to agnosticism to a certitude that race crossing is not biologically dangerous and may even lead to increased vigor is noted from the mid-1930s to 1951 when the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization published its favorable review. It is pointed out that a similar controversy related to race crossing is now taking place concerning hereditary mental differences between races, pivoting around A. Jensen's 1969 study. It is concluded that changing social attitudes will probably influence this area of biology, regardless of the existence of little new scientific evidence, because history has shown that genetic views are closely meshed with social and political considerations. (44 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Kaplan, Robert M

Goldman, Roy D
column12: Kaplan, Robert M.: U. California, Riverside
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.28(3), Dec 1973, pp. 383-389.
column19: 33 black, 35 Mexican-American, and 65 white high school students participated in a study of perceived belief similarity and accuracy of social perception. One-third of the Ss within each ethnic group responded to a 20-item questionnaire as they thought a black student would respond; 1/3 responded as they thought a Mexican-American student would respond; and 1/3 responded as they thought a white student would respond. The black Ss perceived both their white and Mexican-American classmates as being dissimilar to themselves, but the Mexican-American Ss did not demonstrate differential perception between themselves and the other 2 groups. All 3 groups had relatively veridical perception of how black and Mexican-American students would respond to the questionnaire. Blacks and Mexican-Americans were substantially inaccurate in their perception of whites. These data suggest that blacks and Mexican-Americans are more aware of each other's personality characteristics than they are of the characteristics of white students. (28 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Administered the Multifactor Racial Attitude Inventory (MRAI), and the Marlowe-Crowne Social Desirability scale to 123 undergraduates. Persons, rather than items, were subjected to factor analysis according to responses on the 13 MRAI dimensions. Each S was assigned to 1 of 4 resulting typological groups. Ss in 1 group (n =18) held clearly less negative racial attitudes. The other Ss differed from each other in areas in which the most expressed racial hostility was evident. Thus Ss in the 2nd group (n = 54) seemed most concerned with the economic or social situation facing blacks; a 3rd group (n = 36) appeared most concerned with aspects of personal interracial contact, while the 4th group (n = 15) was concerned with hierarchical status relationships between races. column19: Studied the question of white vs black superiority in learning, viewing such differences in sociocultural terms. Ss were 128 black female and white female undergraduates. Ss were contrasted in paired-associate learning in which the consonant-vowel-consonant lists employed had been idiographically prerated for association value (AV) which tapped word quality, and reinforcement value (RV) which tapped affective assessment. Blacks were found to be more sensitive to RV than whites, who in turn were more reliant on AV than blacks. Blacks compared most favorably to whites when RV-positive materials were under comparison. The nonfrequency theory of human learning on which RV study is based, and the ramifications of this theory for interracial intelligence are discussed. (25 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Concepts of teacher-centered consultation. [References].
column12: Broskowski, Anthony: Harvard U., Medical School, Lab. of Community Psychiatry, Boston, Mass.
column13: Professional Psychology. Vol.4(1), Feb 1973, pp. 50-58.
column19: Presents a model of the school as an organization and a model of consultation suited to such an organization. A program of consultation to an inner-city junior high school faculty based on these 2 models is described and evaluated. In applying process consultation and open systems theory, the school consultant strives for active participation by all in the problem-solving process, leading to self-assessment and self-directed change. Process consultation involves the organization and the consultant in the "joint assessment" of the problems, with particular focus on the "processes" within the system that need improvement. The consultation program occurred in 1969 when the principal of a racially mixed junior high school requested a program for graduate students to do counseling for the emotionally disturbed children in his school. The tentative plan was for graduate students to enter the system as consultants to teachers around issues and concerns at the level of the classroom. There were 8 projects in the program: (a) development of teacher skills in small-group techniques, (b) behavior modification, (c) videotape recording and playback of teaching styles, (d) motivational development in a special reading class, (e) systems analysis and sociometric patterning in the classroom, (f) use of psychodrama technique for classroom communication, (g) teacher and counselor discussion group for interracial issues, and (h) environmental engineering and control in the classroom. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Variables in interracial aggression: Potential ingroup censure. [References].
column12: Donnerstein, Edward: Southern Illinois U
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.27(1), Jul 1973, pp. 143-150.
column19: Examined the influence of potential ingroup censure and race of target on aggressive and rewarding responses in 2 experiments with white male undergraduates (N = 72). In Exp. I, Ss were allowed to aggress against a black or white target under conditions varying the availability of their responses to an ingroup member. Prior to statistical analysis, 2 orthogonal variates were identified: direct aggression and indirect aggression. It was found that lower levels of direct aggression were delivered to black targets under potential censure conditions (responses available) than under noncensure conditions (responses not available). No differential responding was exhibited toward white targets as a function of the same situational conditions. In Exp. II, potential censure was found to facilitate both a direct form of reward and an indirect form of aggression toward black targets. Results are discussed in terms of problems associated with heightening aggressive inhibitions. An expanded conceptualization of the notion of indirect aggression is offered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Meta-subjectivity: A model for interracial understanding.
column12: Massey, Robert F.: City U. New York, Graduate Div.
column13: International Journal of Group Tensions. Vol.2(4), 1972, pp. 71-85.
column19: Defines meta-subjectivity in terms of a social system that allows for communication and interaction on the basis of individual uniqueness and the integrity of the groups within it. The isolated status of the Negro man in America and its effect on the Negro personality is considered. It is suggested that isolation has resulted in denial of individual uniqueness and relegation to an inferior position relative to other groups, as well as denigration of the African culture and denial of access to economic and political resources. (33 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Group training for community relations: The community workshop.
column12: Olmosk, Kurt E.: U. Leeds, Organization Development Unit, England
column13: Interpersonal Development. Vol.3(1-4), 1972, pp. 100-114.
column19: Describes the planning, organization, issues, staff, and participants involved in a weekend community workshop on the effects of multiracial sensitivity training. Participants were 13 parents and 14 school teachers from a white and West Indian community in northern England. The goals of the workshop were to (a) increase community awareness of racial problems, (b) learn about the other culture, (c) understand one's own attitudes and behavior in an interracial context, (d) increase communication between groups, and (e) plan solutions to some of the problems. The workshop was designed in 3 phases: a climate setting and "unfreezing" phase, problem identification, and action planning. Emotional factors, problems in participant recruitment, subgroup relations (teachers and parents), and the power and influence structure are also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Pilot study of racial interaction in a public place: Northern and Southern settings compared.
column12: Kaplan, Paul F.: U. Cincinnati
column13: International Journal of Group Tensions. Vol.2(3), 1972, pp. 63-79.
column19: Studied social manifestations of racial interaction in public settings in northern and southern regions of the U.S. The settings were supermarkets near universities in cities in Ohio and Kentucky. Patterns of avoidance of racial contact differed for the 2 regional caste systems. In the southern, paternalistic system, avoidance was minimal because of the wide status gap which allows for close but unequal contact. In the northern, competitive system, avoidance was greatest because of the ambiguity governing interracial contact. Avoidance was also greater for males than females regardless of race. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: LeRoi Jones' Dutchman: Inter-racial ritual of sexual violence.
column12: Weisgram, Dianne H.: Trinity Coll., Hartford, Conn
column13: American Imago. Vol.29(3), Fal 1972, pp. 215-232.
column19: Attributes the power of Jones' play to the fundamental psychological conflicts which enhance its political theme. The latter says that all white Americans, symbolized by Lulu, tease the black into demanding his rights and then murder him, using his demands as justification. But on the psychoanalytical level the underlying themes are oral loss, frustration, and consequent rage. When Clay breaks from his false white man's self, his black identity erupts in such intense rage that he dies in the next instant. The play's fundamental tension between true and false identity is an orally based schizoid one in which the personality is charged with hatred and disintegrates in a self-destructive defense. The 2 ways of expressing aggression, transformation and violent revenge, represented in the play, correspond to E. Erickson's 2 categories of oral defense, the expulsive and the intrusive. The symbolic role of the subway passengers is briefly analyzed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Reactions of high school students to school desegregation in a southern metropolitan area.
column13: Psychological Reports. Vol.30(2), Apr 1972, pp. 543-550.
column19: Conducted a preliminary study of attitudes and emotional reactions of 12 black high school students who desegregated formerly all-white schools in a southern city. It was determined that there were many forebodings, unpleasant experiences, and emotional upsets, but that on the whole no deep emotional disturbances resulted. In the main study, 32 black and 32 white Ss completed the Self-Analysis Questionnaire and 2 racial attitude scales. Ss then viewed slides of racial situations and their blood pressure and respiration were recorded. Results do not confirm hypotheses that length of desegregated experience results in lessened ethnic prejudice on either a cognitive or noncognitive level, that state anxiety is altered by vicarious "formal" or "informal" interracial situations, and that black girls react more intensely to such situations whan white ones. However, differential reactions did result from vicariously experiencing "formal" vs. "informal" situations. (25 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Interracial conflicts as resistance in group psychotherapy.
column12: Kibel, Howard D.: 344 E. Main St., Mount Kisco, N.Y
column13: American Journal of Psychotherapy. Vol.26(4), Oct 1972, pp. 555-562.
column15: Assn for the Advancement of Psychotherapy; US
column19: Presents a clinical illustration in which members of an interracial psychotherapy group were confronted with a disturbing experience, viz. they saw one of their members become acutely disturbed, requiring immediate hospitalization. This incident aggravated previous latent fears within group members. Afraid to discuss their feelings and faced with this common threat, they banded together and displaced the feelings onto a less threatening but significant issue-the racial feelings within the group. This discussion revealed, metaphorically, some of their reactions to the provoking incident, thus serving as resistance. The phenomenon of group resistance is explored, and it is concluded that such an intense resistance is particularly difficult for the therapist to handle. (17 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Discusses interracial marriage in terms of the oedipal struggle and narcissism. The choice of a mate as different as possible from the desired parent is an extreme attempt to escape the oedipal conflict. Narcissism is relevant as the stranger group is solicited in the search for personal identity. A detailed discussion of Shakespeare's Othello is included. column5: White worker-minority client.
column12: Mizio, Emelicia: New York U., Graduate School of Social Work
column13: Social Work. Vol.17(3), May 1972, pp. 82-86.
column19: Examines the implications of racism in the therapeutic relationship between a minority client and white worker. The contention is stressed that common background is less important than many claim and that special training can help compensate for differences between worker and client. Early in their training, social workers learn to subject themselves to critical self-examination with regard to their feelings toward clients. To overcome the blocks to interracial worker-client relationships, they must use this technique to examine how their racial attitudes affect their work with minority clients. Only then will they reach their professional goal of serving all clients effectively. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Attitude, voice, and behavior: A repressed affect model of interracial interaction. [References].
column12: Weitz, Shirley: New School for Social Research, Graduate Faculty, New York, N.Y
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.24(1), Oct 1972, pp. 14-21.
column19: Investigated the relationship between verbal attitudes, voice tone, and behavior toward blacks among a sample of 80 white college males in the North identified as "liberal" on the basis of Schuman and Harding's Irrational Pro and Anti Scales. A simulated interracial encounter in which Ss expected to interact with a black (or white) stimulus person was used. A general pattern of overt friendliness and covert rejection was found. Voice tone and behavior were positively related to each other, but negatively related to friendliness of attitude toward blacks. Results suggest a repressed affect model leading to conflicting cues in interracial interaction. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Conducted an attitude survey of 10 black and 22 white college teachers participating in an Afro-American studies program. Ss indicated their level of agreement or disagreement with a list of 15 statements. Significant consensus patterns were found on 4 items. When the 2 groups were considered separately, cognitive differences were found between the groups on 7 items dealing with the detention of the Japanese during World War II, black identity, ethnic assimilation, interracial marriage, social change, revolution, and race favoritism in employment. The response pattern is interpreted as suggesting that both groups tended to respond in an idealistic manner when the question was not directly relevant to their immediate worlds. The limitations of the questionnaire procedure for measuring attitudes are discussed. (25 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Cohen, Elizabeth G.: Stanford U., School of Education
column13: Human Relations. Vol.25(1), Feb 1972, pp. 9-24.
column19: 19 4-member groups were formed from boys in the 7th and 8th grade and observed as they played a game of strategy. Each group contained 2 black and 2 white boys matched for height and combined index of socioeconomic and school attitude. The groups were systematically observed by both black and white Os using an observation scheme derived from status characteristic theory. No systematic differences were found between black and white Os. Three hypotheses were confirmed: (a) Race was strongly associated with differences in rank order on the number of acts initiated, with whites more likely to have a higher rank than blacks. (b) On an independent measure of influence, a white S's suggestion became the group's decision more frequently than a black's, especially where decisions were contested. (c) The indices of influence and rate of initiation were strongly positively related. It is concluded that blacks are more inhibited and less willing to argue for their point of view in an integrated work situation, and therefore less influential than whites. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column19: Investigated interracial difficulties of blacks and whites working together, when blacks are in a supervisory position over whites. 45 groups of male undergraduates were supervised by blacks, and 45 were supervised by whites. In each group, 2 subordinates played a business game with either a black or a white supervisor and were observed by 2 white Os. Results indicate that (a) the performance ratings of black supervisors were significantly poorer than those of white supervisors; (b) subordinates supervised by blacks behaved differently than subordinates supervised by whites, and some of these behaviors appeared to hinder the effectiveness of the black supervisor; and (c) subordinates with negative racial bias gave poorer ratings to black supervisors than subordinates with liberal racial attitudes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Race and belief: A further analysis of the social determinants of behavioral intentions. [References].
column12: Goldstein, Marvin: Rider Coll
column13: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Vol.22(3), Jun 1972, pp. 346-355.
column19: Conducted a replication and extension of the H. Triandis and E. Davis (see record 1966-02762-001) study. 150 white undergraduates responded on behavioral differential scales to stimulus persons who varied in race and 2 beliefs. Ss also evaluated civil rights issues, along with the stimulus-person beliefs. Using multidimensional scaling and multimode factor analysis, 2 S factors were isolated. These 2 S types, called race rejectors and belief rejectors, differed systematically with respect to the importance attached to the race or belief characteristics of the stimulus persons. Furthermore, race was increasingly important for all S types as the response continuum became more intimate. A cube of data consisting of stimulus person characteristics, response continuum, and S type is presented in interpreting the race vs. belief controversy. Finally, the hypothesis that race rejectors would perceive their important others as more disapproving of interracial contacts than would belief rejectors is confirmed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
